article.article_title: Notable Photo Books of 2014, Part II
article.article_text_abstract: Photo books remain the preferred medium of photographers, and its stature has grown in recent years with no signs of slowing down. Here, the editors of PDN highlight some of the most notable photo books of 2014.
article.article_text:
Photo books remain the preferred medium of photographers, and its stature has grown in recent years with no signs of slowing down. Here, the editors of PDN highlight some of the most notable photo books of 2014.

Danny Clinch: Still Moving 
By Danny Clinch
Abrams
296 pages; 200 photographs
$50; abramsbooks.com

Danny Clinch: Still Moving is a journey through Clinch’s diverse portfolio from the last three decades. The book’s 200 color and black-and-white images, almost all of them at full bleed, encompass a wide variety of musicians, bands, genres and photographic styles. Let the record show that Danny Clinch is much more than just a “rock” photographer. He’s arguably one of the most accomplished and versatile photographers and film directors of his generation. He’s shot editorial assignments (Rolling Stone, Vanity Fair, GQ and The New York Times Magazine), advertising campaigns (American Express, Advil, Gap) and album artwork (Nas, Bruce Springsteen, Black Keys). He’s directed music videos (Pearl Jam, The Avett Brothers, Ben Harper, and Tom Waits) and even a few documentaries (Tim McGraw and the Bonnaroo music festival), concert DVDs (Foo Fighters and John Mayer) and many print ads and commercials for long-time music-lover and fashion designer John Varvatos. Clinch’s work has been presented in numerous galleries, and he’s published two previous books: Discovery Inn (1998) and When the Iron Bird Flies: Tibetan Freedom Concerts 1996-1999, both of which include a wide variety of work made in 1980s and 1990s.

This latest book is comprised of five chapters: Documentary, Friends & Family, Backstage, Live and Portraits. Each chapter draws you into the next. Clinch captures the subject’s personality in each image, whether posed or candid, on stage or backstage. A particularly interesting feature of the book is the image pairing and sequencing. Still Moving combines then-and-now images of various artists, both famous and less well-known or emerging artists. Among them are Eminem (2001), Eddie Vedder (2006), Foo Fighters (2005), Steven Tyler & Joe Perry of Aerosmith (1997), Jackson Browne (2010), Blind Melon (1993), James Brown (2003), Jeff Beck (1999) and Gary Clark Jr. (2011). In another example of deft image pairing, a wide shot of Jay Z (2010) performing on stage in front of thousands of fans precedes a tight shot of Bruce Springsteen (2003), bending over backwards holding the microphone, seemingly onstage by himself.

The book captures the spirit of a celebrated music photographer and musician. Still Moving is an essential addition to the collection for Clinch fans.
—Amy Wolff

Pikin Slee 
By Viviane Sassen
Prestel
120 pages, 93 images
$40

Viviane Sassen has become world-renowned for her dream-like fashion images, collected in books like Parasomnia and Flamboya. Her boldest compositions combine brilliantly colored objects with bodies— typically, black bodies—posed at surprising angles to create graphic, striking and sometimes surreal compositions. In her new book, Pikin Slee, she once again explores juxtapositions of forms and shapes, but here her probing eye elevates mundane objects.

Sassen, who was born in the Netherlands and raised in Kenya, traveled in 2012 to Suriname, and stayed in a remote village called Pikin Slee on the Upper Suriname River, where people live without electricity or running water. Judging from the photos in the book, Sassen was equally fascinated by the natural world surrounding the village—she has several photos of leaves in the trees and the pattern of shadows they cast—as she was by people and the objects they use. In a photo of a boy wearing one yellow kitchen glove and dark blue pants, the glove appears searingly bright. She photographs a still life as an array of color: pale green vegetables on a blue cloth and a bright yellow bag. In her color images, the brightest objects are often manmade. Many images in the book are in black-and-white. In the absence of color, form becomes more noticeable, highlighting how Sassen’s eye was drawn to the shapes of branches, the shadows cast by leaves on a corrugated tin roof, or a piece of wood set at an angle to the door of a house. Sassen has said she went to Suriname seeking a simpler form of photography. In her photos of Pikin Slee, she boils photography down to its essence: inspiring us to take a second look at the world around us by showing us how it is transformed within the borders of a photo.
—Holly Stuart Hughes

Liu Bolin 
By Liu Bolin
Abrams
224 pages, 200 color images
$60; abramsbooks.com

On November 16, 2005, China’s government started evicting the residents of the Suojia Village International Arts Camp, a Beijing suburb that was home to hundreds of artists. Soon, they would demolish the neighborhood—and artist Liu Bolin’s studio—to make way for the infrastructure that would house the 2008 Olympic games.

But from the ashes of the arts community grew a silent protest. In the first image from his series, “Hiding in the City,” Bolin made a self-portrait in the ruins of his studio, camouflaged amongst the bricks of the hollowed-out space. He soon made more, blending into landmarks throughout China, and then in Italy, Paris, and New York, aiming a more subtle middle finger at the instruments of power than Ai Wei Wei’s “Study in Perspective.” As he explains, “Instead of saying that I simply disappear into the background, it would be better to say that the environment has engulfed me and that, consequently, I cannot afford to choose to be either active or passive.” These are the images that make up the bulk of his first monograph, Liu Bolin.

Part performance art, part painting and part photography, Bolin’s series of “hidden” portraits may be his vision, but in practice it is very much a collaboration. His team of assistants includes painters and photographers, and as his own most frequent subject, he is forced to relinquish at least some control—when he is being painted (always in his army fatigues), he must remain perfectly motionless for hours.

In a literal sense, his work is even more of a study in perspective than Ai Wei Wei’s. Eschewing any postproduction, Bolin’s team must line him up perfectly with the camera when painting, which often tests his physical endurance. On a particularly detail-rich scene at a New York newsstand, it took five days to blend him into the racks of magazines.

Fittingly, the popularity of Bolin’s work gave the invisible man increased exposure, leading to some high-profile collaborations. In New York, he collaborated with the artist JR, who wheat-pasted a giant portrait of Bolin to a wall in Manhattan, which Bolin subsequently painted himself into. When Jon Bon Jovi asked him

to do the artwork for his band’s 2013 album What About Now, he reluctantly indulged his wife, a diehard fan. And in 2012, Harper’s Bazaar commissioned him to “hide” fashion designers Angela Missoni and Jean-Paul Gaultier, among others. Gaultier, at least, saw Bolin as a kindred spirit. “It’s very good for my work to be a chameleon,” Gaultier said. 
—Matthew Ismael Ruiz

The Return 
By Adrain Chesser in collaboration with ritualist Timothy White Eagle
Daylight
144 pages, 72 color images
$49.95; daylightbooks.org

The Return is a collection of quiet, beautiful photographs juxtaposed with preachy, strident text. Adrain Chesser’s images explore a subculture of young men and women who have dropped out of society to embrace the lifestyle of Native Americans—or at least their romantic notions of it. “Most come in one form or another from the disenfranchised margins of mainstream America. Most are poor, some are queer, some are transgender, some are hermits, and some are politically radical,” co-author Timothy White Eagle writes in the introduction, helpfully enough. Chesser’s images show his subjects hunting, gathering, and herding goats in the high deserts of the American West. “These willing pioneers are stepping off into uncertain terrain, searching for something lost generations ago. In their search, they struggle to be released from old ways of being. Cars, soda pop, cell phones and cigarettes follow them,” the introduction continues. Chesser shows the struggles and contradictions. His subjects head out in their SUVs, for instance. They stop at Burger King for a meal. And Chesser cuts through utopian illusions with images of unforgiving landscapes and occasional brutality. But he’s sympathetic to his subjects, and shows them on their own terms with an eye for gorgeous light, telling gesture, and detail. There are several images—“magpie,” “morning,” and “dressing a carcass” to name three—that are magnetic. But much of White Eagle’s text, which deifies Native American culture while vilifying modern industrial culture, is naive. For instance, he describes the book’s subjects as “uncommon heroes shedding layer by layer the learned domestication of the dominator culture.” Yeah? So we should all decamp to the wilderness with our bows and arrows? Savor Chesser’s images, dear readers, without mistaking them for a prescription for solving the world’s very complicated problems.
—David Walker

Angel Gitano: Men of Flamenco 
Ruven Afanador
Rizzoli
240 pages, 142 black-and-white images
$95; www.rizzoliusa.com

Ruven Afanador has a love affair with Andalusia. The southernmost autonomous community in Spain, it’s the birthplace of a culture that is internationally thought of as Spanish yet largely it’s own; particularly the bullfights and flamenco. Afanador has already paid homage to the bullfights (Torero, 2001), and the women of flamenco (Mil Besos, 2011), so with his latest tome, Angel Gitano: Men of Flamenco, the Colombian photographer focused on its men. The Gitanos are Spain’s Romani population, Gypsies who blended Andalusian song and dance with their own to create the famous flamenco.

Andalusia is almost as much of a character in the book as its subjects. Afanador describes it as“a universe inhabited by Gypsies, musicians, and...flamenco dancers,” which he plants in the wheat fields of Sevilla and the bleak landscapes of Jerez de la Frontera, dressed in dark but flamboyant outfits, or made up in his signature Italian Neo- realist theatrical makeup. “This is the region where the deepest roots of flamenco exist,” he said of Andalusia, speaking to the The New Yorker about Mil Besos in 2011.

But Angel Gitano stands in stark contrast to his portrait of flamenco’s women. It inhabits the same land, visual style and neo-classical esthetic, but unlike Mil Besos, Angel Gitano is overtly sexual. Afanador’s lustful gaze is felt throughout the book, with the often-nude dancers in almost feminine poses, albeit with muscular, masculine bodies seemingly carved from marble. While Mil Besos did not feature much nudity and felt, for the most part, asexual, Angel Gitano kicks you in the face with sex, right on the dramatic and perfectly executed cover.

For wardrobe, Afanador mixed his subjects’ own clothes—flamenco-style ruffled blouses and berets—with his more ostentatious tastes. Corsets, pants with high waists and wide bottoms, and long skirts are prevalent.

The 142 black-and-white images are bright and high-contrast, and mix paint and props to create his fantastical imagery. He counts Dali and Goya among his influences, as evidenced by a boy’s prosthetic horns, or another’s giant demon hands. But no matter his stylistic choices, it’s clear who are the stars of the show.

“I have always loved to photograph dancers,” he recently told Out magazine. “They work so hard on their bodies, and they are such great artists and collaborators.”
—Matthew Ismael Ruiz

article.article_title: Notable Photo Books of 2014: Part I
article.article_text_abstract: Photo books remain the preferred medium of photographers, and its stature has grown in recent years with no signs of slowing down. Here, the editors of PDN highlight some of the most notable photo books of 2014.
article.article_image_credit: © Matthew Brandt/Courtesy Yossi Milo Gallery, New York
article.article_image_caption: "Convict Lake," from Matthew Brandt's Lakes and Reservoirs.
article.article_text:
Photo books remain the preferred medium of photographers, and its stature has grown in recent years with no signs of slowing down. Here, the editors of PDN highlight some of the most notable photo books of 2014.

Lakes and Reservoirs
By Matthew Brandt
Damiani/Yossi Milo
176 pages; 125 color images 
$65; www.damianieditore.com

 

 

 

By soaking his C-prints in water from the lakes and reservoirs that his images depict, Matthew Brandt creates a stunning visual dialogue between photographer, image and subject. The unique prints that emerge from Brandt’s process occupy an area between abstraction and representation. Beyond appreciating the rich colors of his works, viewers are encouraged to consider the permanence of a photograph, and its ability to show us what we can’t otherwise see. The images also urge viewers to ponder the unique properties, history and potential of each individual body of water. Photographers, in particular, will wonder how much Brandt is able to control his technique.

Brandt began exhibiting his “Lakes and Reservoirs” prints a couple of years ago, and this book, co-published by Yossi Milo Gallery and Damiani, is the first large published collection of the work. Early in the book, he emphasizes the water’s role in his process by including images of the jugs he used to collect and store his water samples. The patterns and colors that emerge throughout the pages are surprisingly varied. The inky black and purple shapes in Brandt’s “Lake Isabella, CA 4” diptych recall graffiti lettering, while “Mary’s Lake, MT 5” looks like a pointillist painting.

Whether Brandt intended it or not, lakes and Reservoirs can also be read in the context of current discussions about water as a finite natural resource, and anxiety that water may be in short supply in years to come. One can’t help but look for the evidence of fresh water’s life-giving qualities when looking at Brandt’s images. As if this most important element of our world weren’t magical enough, water also happens to be capable of collaborating in the creation of compelling artworks.
—Conor Risch

Events Ashore 
By An-My Lê
Aperture
192 pages, 125 color images 
$89.95

 

 

 

 

It’s difficult to comprehend the meaning of the U.S. national defense budget—$526.6 billion for 2014, according to the Department of Defense. An-My Lê’s new book, Events Ashore, slightly clarifies the reality of our military industrial complex, the number of people it employs and the equipment it builds and maintains. To create the work, Lê, who was named a MacArthur Fellow in 2012, traveled around the globe photographing non-combat operations with a large-format camera and color negative film.

The speed, action and sense of peril common to news photographs of conflict are largely absent from her pictures. Instead, readers get the impression of a massive force lumbering deliberately across the globe, from Australia to Panama, Antarctica, Greenland and elsewhere.

In one image, divers stand on the ice-covered hull of the USS New Hampshire nuclear submarine, its sail jutting out of the pristine, otherwise empty white landscape of the Arctic Sea. We see joint training exercises with the Thai military; soldiers in repose in Haiti; military veterinarians tending to a goat in Panama; the commanding officer of a rescue and salvage ship exchanging flowers with Vietnamese military officers.

In Lê’s beautiful portraits, officers and other personnel appear placid, stoic, almost bored—another day at the office, keeping watch on a multi-billion-dollar aircraft carrier as it ambles through the Arabian Gulf.

That figure of $526.6 billion is staggering, but as a country we mostly accept it as the necessary status quo. Lê’s photographs reflect this sense of normalcy. But in doing so they also ask whether our place in the world should require a ubiquitous U.S. military, and they urge us to contemplate more deeply the amount of money and effort that go into making sure the “sharp end of the spear” hits home when we need it to. 
—Conor Risch

 

Does Yellow Run Forever? 
By Paul Graham
MACK
96 pages, 31 color photographs 
$50; mackbooks.co.uk

 

 

Photographs of rainbows, of one’s girlfriend sleeping, and of pawn shops that buy jewelry from those who either need to sell or no longer want their baubles—these are well-known (and some might say cliché), entries in the photographic lexicon. Certainly these images can be beautiful and magical; tender and erotic; and poignant symbols of financial struggle, respectively, but original? Not in most hands.

In his latest book, Does Yellow Run Forever?, Paul Graham employs these familiar photographic tropes to surprising effect, mixing them together into a sequence that leads readers to contemplate beauty and wonder, love, hope, doubt, lust, greed, photographic symbolism and other themes.

In the small yellow-covered book, which has shimmering endpapers and gold-edged pages, glossy photographs of rainbows made in the majestic green hills and valleys of Western Ireland alternate with peaceful images of a woman sleeping in different beds. We ask: Has Graham gone soft? Previous works like a shimmer of possibility, which earned him a solo exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art and the 2009 Deutsche Börse Prize, considered issues of class, race and economics both in the United States and England, where he is from. Yet when he introduces the New York City gold stores to this series, the places where onetime symbols of love and prosperity all too often end up, the book takes a new turn. Then the rainbows and the sleeping woman are reintroduced and the cycle is repeated.

It may be that we’re seeing some of Graham’s most personal work to date. Whether or not he’s wondering about the (im)permanence and artifice of love—or photographs—doesn’t preclude us from doing so ourselves. Nor does it matter as we appreciate Graham’s ability to make compelling sequences from beautiful but conceptually unremarkable images.
—Conor Risch

 

Afghanistan 
By Larry Towell 
Aperture
192 pages, 350 images 
$127.50; aperture.org/shop/books

 

 

Photojournalist Larry Towell traveled to Afghanistan in 2008 and 2011, and in the course of his tours was embedded with U.S. and British troops, visited a hospital for landmine victims, photographed ordinary citizens, and for a time traveled with the Taliban. His new book is a deeply personal reflection on his experiences in the country. The book is a reproduction of a maquette he made, with photos stuck onto the pages and handwritten notes around them, as well as collages of multiple images overlapping. A long essay by Towell appears in a smaller booklet that is pasted within the photo book; it tells the stories behind many of the series he includes in the book, and expresses his impression of what he calls “the shell-shocked people of this disfigured land,” their leaders and their occupiers.

Many of the pages are crowded with images that show subtle variations of a scene or subject. He includes typologies: a series of Russian army helmets, another on prosthetics made for landmine victims, another on weapons. These catalogues of objects are a reminder of Afghanistan’s recent history of conflict, dating back to the Soviet invasion of the 1980s. But one of the earliest photos in the book shows an ash- and debris-covered street in lower Manhattan on September 11, 2001, and the main concerns of the book and of his essay are the consequences of the invasion by the U.S. and Western allies. 

In his essay he writes with affection about soldiers he spent time with, but he describes the beginnings of the war on terror as opening a Pandora’s box that, in Afghanistan, he says, became a war on a society. “The critical question, to me, remains: how many private military contractors, drone navigators, CIA agents, and other intelligence operatives will be left behind to continue an endless war based out of Afghanistan? This was never one in which the U.S. could declare victory and walk away.” 

Towell, who also photographed the war waged by the U.S.-backed Contras in Nicaragua in the 1980s, takes a long view when it comes to the consequences of violence. He presents a multitude of photos of people and places wounded and battle scarred, and notes, “the Afghans will settle their scores.”
—Holly Stuart Hughes

 

Compendium 
By Michael von Hassel 
teNeues
208 pages, 125 color images 
$125; www.teneues.com

 

 

German photographer Michael von Hassel’s Compendium is an exuberant, colorful, and hyper-real romp across a wide swath of subjects: forests, malls, cityscapes, Oktoberfest tents, fashion show venues, Monument Valley. You can practically hear Von Hassel saying, “Look! This is so cool!” and there you are, high in the Alps under surreal skies, or on a cobble-stoned, neon-smeared street in Istanbul, or perhaps a parking garage aglow with mercury vapor lights. 

He’s drawn to brilliant color, repeating patterns and texture, and everything real becomes a little (or a lot) out of this world. Von Hassel sometimes achieves that with collage and double-exposure techniques, and more often with a lot of post-processing, which can be a dangerous thing. Photographers often rely on digital filters to run interference for bad pictures. Or they just don’t know when to say when, filtering to the point of crassness. Von Hassel skates along the edge of thin ice, but manages (usually) not to fall through. His colors are garish. He cranks the contrast way up. But it has the effect of heightening the experience, like a psychotropic drug. 

There are some clunkers, however. The opening series of collages built around words such as Peace, Power and Love, seems trite. And the book includes a few too many fawning essays by experts and non-experts alike who over-analyze and oversell the importance of the work. Compendium is about the surface of things. It’s not particularly challenging, but von Hassel’s style is distinctive, and his work is fun to look at.
—David Walker

article.article_title: Shooting On Spec To Land Advertising Assignments: Chris Stanford for Ashworth Golf Apparel
article.meta_description: Kevin Buth, a creative director at the ad agency Zambezi, suggested photographer Chris Stanford try shooting a test shoot to score ad work for an Adidas subsidiary; it worked, and also scored him jobs with other clients.
article.article_text_abstract: Kevin Buth, a creative director at the ad agency Zambezi, suggested photographer Chris Stanford try shooting a test shoot to score ad work for an Adidas subsidiary; it worked, and also scored him jobs with other clients.
article.article_image_caption: The actual campaign for Ashworth was a reprise of the test shoot, with top professional players instead of amateurs.
article.article_text:
Test shoots are a time-honored strategy for honing new skills and building portfolios. But photographers talk less about shooting on spec—i.e., shooting a test for a particular client for free, with the hope of landing an assignment. Many photographers frown upon it, fearing that if they shoot on spec, clients may start to expect it, forcing photographers to work even harder (and spend out of pocket) to land jobs.

But shooting on spec is a strategy that can work if it’s for a client you trust, and if you’re shooting for your portfolio, too. Photographers Aaron Greene, Alex Farnum and Chris Stanford all landed assignments from the spec work made for clients they were pursuing. In all three cases, the photographers had pre-existing relationships with the clients or their ad agencies. Those relationships gave them access to the people, information and brand strategies they needed to plan their spec shoots, and get their work in front of the critical decision makers.

Here is what they told us.

Chris Stanford for Ashworth Golf Apparel

It was creative director Kevin Buth of Zambezi in Los Angeles who suggested Chris Stanford do a test shoot for Ashworth, the golf apparel brand owned by Adidas. Stanford was reluctant. “I was worried they’d get me for an editorial price, and use the images for advertising,” he says. But he trusted Buth, and it paid off—with work not only for Ashworth, but other clients, too.

It all started with a fashion spread Stanford shot for Golf Digest in early 2012. Buth saw it and called Stanford, explaining that he wanted to pitch a campaign idea to Ashworth, inspired by the Golf Digest spread.

Buth’s idea was to shoot a print campaign featuring four golf pros traveling around California, playing different courses. He wanted the campaign to emphasize the friendship, camaraderie and adventure, not the mechanics of golf. “We wanted to go back to the spirit of the game,” he says. “A lot of times, to prove a vision or piece of creative you can’t just source inspiration or reference, you have to go make it,” Buth told PDN via email. He approached Ashworth with the idea, and showed them some of Stanford’s work. “[They] said ‘Let’s go make it happen.’”
The plan for the test was to take a one-day road trip to the Sandpiper Golf Club in Santa Barbara with four non-professional golfers, including Zambezi and Ashworth employees. Stanford, who has a background in photojournalism, documented the trip.

“I shoot a lot, and I shoot quickly,” he says. He shot the players on the course, having a meal and drinking beers on the beach. “It was a freewheeling shoot, doing whatever we wanted to do.”

Afterwards, Stanford submitted his take to Buth, who edited the work. “It helps he has years of golf experience so there are lots of gems. In the golf category you can’t fake that. Any faux moments or bad players are exposed by the smallest flaw,” Buth says.

Ashworth “loved” the test images, Stanford says, and signed off on a campaign. The brief was to re-shoot the test, but with six pro players at the Riviera Country Club in Pacific Palisades. The key players were veteran Fred Couples and rising star Justin Rose. “It was a little bit [about] passing the torch,” Stanford says of the shoot. Buth adds that the goal was to “capture people and the Ashworth brand in uncontrived, casual, natural moments.”

The shoot took place in November 2013. Stanford says the golfers hit the course and started sharing stories. His only instruction to them was “keep telling stories and just play.”

It was a lot more complicated than the test shoot, however. Stanford estimates there were 100 or more people on set, including the golfers’ entourages, stylists, groomers, producers, agency creatives, client representatives, and a video crew “shooting b-roll over my shoulder,” Stanford says. “Kevin said to me, ‘Just do Sandpiper again and I’ll keep everyone out of your way.’”

Ashworth ended up using the images in a print campaign and in a TV spot. Ammirati USA saw the spot on the Golf Channel, and hired Stanford to direct two TV ads for the PGA.

Meanwhile, Buth and Stanford did a second test shoot for Ashworth last April. It was similar in many ways to the first test, and once again, Ashworth bought the idea and signed off on another campaign. The shoot was scheduled to take place in October.

Stanford says his success with the Ashworth test shoots has made him less reluctant to shoot on spec, at least under certain conditions. “If it were a project that we could really fall in love with and make some interesting art, and it could possibly lead to a bigger campaign, well, then I’m totally in.”

Related: Shooting On Spec To Land Advertising Assignments: Alex Farnum for Reebok 
Shooting On Spec To Land Advertising Assignments: Aaron Greene for Confluence Outdoor

article.article_title: Mona Kuhn's book "Private" and series "Acido Dorado" Take on the Esthetic of the Desert
article.article_text_abstract: The colors and landscape of the deserts of California and the American Southwest inspired Mona Kuhn's new book of nude photographs, "Private," and her series "Acido Dorado."
article.article_image_caption: “Chanon,” 2013.
article.article_text:
Mona Kuhn likes to distinguish between the words “naked” and “nude,” emphasizing that nakedness implies being “vulnerable” or “caught off guard.” Known for her thought-provoking and sensual—but decidedly un- erotic—nude photographs, Kuhn uses friends and family as models, thereby creating a level of comfort and trust that she feels is intrinsic to her work.

The German-Brazilian photographer’s new monograph, Private, set in the harsh landscape of the American Southwest, was inspired by her curiosity about the vast deserts surrounding her adopted home of Los Angeles, where she is an independent scholar at The Getty Research Institute.

“I was guided by these sand colorations... and then the similarities that has to skin coloration,” Kuhn explains. Beginning in 2011 and over the course of the next two-and-a-half years, she took numerous trips into the Mojave desert, crossing into Arizona and even spending some time on a Navajo Indian reservation. Kuhn stayed with friends and subjects, but also camped in the desert, putting her film in a cooler to protect it from the heat.

Kuhn went into the wilderness with ideas about abstracting the human form, in all its vulnerability, against the implacable harshness of this land, and letting her senses guide her from there.

Dun colored slopes of sand dunes, barren save for an occasional patch of scrubgrass. The pale swell of a woman’s breasts, thumb hooked in her brassiere, a tattoo of a black widow spider adorning the same hand. The wrinkled white sheets of an unmade bed approximate an image, on the opposite page, of shifting desert sands that sit in the shadow of a promontory. The mirage of a naked woman seen through a window as she turns away, the reflection of a palm tree superimposed over her and sunlight refracted through it all. A “sand waterfall” spilling over the terraced edges of worn cliffs, a tan-colored veil plunging to the canyon floor. These are some of the images we see in Private.

Kuhn, fascinated by art at a young age, was initially drawn to photography by the medium’s immediacy. She guesses she has been shooting nudes since the early 1990s. Realizing that clothing dated her photographs, Kuhn “started simplifying things,” she says. “The nudes came as a way of going back to a more basic humanity and becoming a little more intemporal.”

Kuhn’s process is highly intuitive, focused on putting herself in a position to best react to what she encounters without overthinking things. For her, the mysterious intersection of chance and unconscious desire is where photography is most vital. “There is no formula [for what I do]. I think it’s what attracts you to something, together with your instincts, and that is something that nobody can teach you,” she elaborates. “You play, you look, you see, you adapt. It’s better to embrace the element of surprise than to try and control it too much.”

Kuhn made the photographs in Private entirely on film with a Hasselblad, in part because of the unavailability of electricity while she was traversing the desert alone or with her subjects. To edit the work she would mount “little prints on a huge wall” in her workspace and look them over daily, taking out anything that started to bore her, lacked a certain depth or simply didn’t fit the evolving narrative. Through this sort of attrition she whittled two years’ worth of photographs down to the most compelling and cohesive set of images. “It’s a slow process, six to eight months, but that [process] is when the work will tell the artist what it wants to be,” Kuhn says.

Kuhn’s projects are slow-moving, and she often is working on more than one at a time. Something new is always bound to snag her imagination, and her related series, “Acido Dorado,” is a perfect example. Kuhn began “Acido Dorado,” which was exhibited recently at Edwynn Houk Gallery in New York, in the fall of 2013, while she was working on finishing Private. Jacintha, a longtime friend and frequent model for Kuhn’s work was visiting the U.S., and the two women traveled to Acido Dorado, a house in the desert town of Joshua Tree. Handmade by renowned California architect Robert Stone, Acido Dorado is a home of gold and mirrors, a futuristic birdcage nestled high in the desert. Captivated by the structure’s exuberant combination of minimalism and decadence, rich with colors drawn straight from Kuhn’s palette, she reached out to the architect and secured access to the location.

For Kuhn, the ability to be inside or outside of the glass house and remain intimately connected with the surrounding landscape, through reflections on windows and metallic surfaces, was transformative. Jacintha is the only model, but the house and desert surroundings take on roles in the narrative, merging and diverging, in keeping with the mirage-like atmosphere. Kuhn works without assistants, but in many ways “Acido Dorado” became a quasi-collaboration. She and Jacintha would shoot in the mornings and evenings to take advantage of the quality of the light, then examine the results together (Kuhn made the images with a digital Hasselblad) and exchange ideas about what direction to take the next day. “It’s something I hadn’t done in my work before and don’t necessarily plan to do in the future,” Kuhn says. “It had to do with a specific moment in time with a specific person...my own maturity as an artist and the maturity of our relationship.”

Although Kuhn and Jacintha did a preliminary edit of “Acido Dorado” together while they were in Joshua Tree, that project ended up on Kuhn’s “wall” as well. It was then, when she could look at all the prints together, that Kuhn began to really see how the images interacted with one another, how her efforts to abstract the human form had, in the mirrors and glass of Stone’s trippy oasis, become something “illusory” and “disorienting.”

Private and “Acido Dorado” are clearly connected in their inspirations, but work on very different wavelengths. The hazy intimacy of “Acido Dorado” seems to almost stand in contrast to the stark vision of Private, where we move between the sunswept silence of the desert and the still coolness of the indoors, wedges of light streaming through the corners and gaps of heavy curtains and drawn blinds. Kuhn is currently working towards editing “Acido Dorado” into book form but demurs when asked for a likely publication date. “It’s always a process...that’s what’s fascinating, I never know when it will start or end, but thank goodness it does,” she laughs.

article.article_title: Career Launch: Jason Elias, Portrait Photographer
article.article_text_abstract: Jason Elias transitioned from a career as a gaffer in the film industry when a chance meeting with a Discovery TV executive turned into his first big assignment.
article.article_image_caption: A promotional photo for Steve Austin’s Broken Skull Challenge. The reality show, aired by CMT, pits contestants against one another in a variety of physical challenges—for a $10,000 prize.
article.article_text:
For Jason Elias, a week-long assignment to shoot promotions for “Moonshiners,” the Discovery Channel reality show, was the big break he’d been waiting for, and he was feeling rattled. Lara Richardson, senior VP of broadcast promotions, came on set for the last day of shooting, and just looked on in silence. “I would [shoot] stuff and say, Lara, are you good? And she would say, ‘If you think you’ve got it, move on.’”

Elias decided to trust his instincts and just keep moving. After the wrap, he asked Richardson why she’d been so quiet. “And she said, ‘I wanted to see how you reacted. I wanted to see how you ran the set.’” She wanted to see if he could draw out their personalities rather than simply direct them “to stand there with their arms crossed, looking mean,” he explains.

Elias aced the test, and went on to shoot numerous promotions for Moonshiners, Deadliest Catch, Amish Mafia, Fast N’ Loud, and other Discovery Channel shows. That led to assignments for Country Music Television, the History Channel, TLC and other clients. “I found this incredible niche that gets me a lot of work,” Elias says.

But he struggled to get his career off the ground. He endured a decade of false starts and bad luck before his film industry experience, some entrepreneurial talent, and a lot of soul searching paid off.

In fact, success came after he quit trying so hard. “I decided to stop striving for a while,’” he says. “One of the things that I have learned is, if I’m constantly assessing and strategizing...That’s when I start really doubting myself. If I trust myself, what’s the worst that can happen? I go back to being a gaffer, and I have a great career and a good life.”

Elias attended film school, and during the ‘90s worked his way up to head gaffer on commercial sets for Fortune 500 brands, such as GM. He also worked on feature films. One day, he bought a still camera from a unit photographer on a film set, and shortly afterwards took a vacation to Hong Kong.

“Back from the trip, the response to photos I took randomly was tremendous,” he says. “I discovered my passion: walking around with a still camera.”

Elias had no idea how to become a photographer, other than to find work as an assistant. But it would have meant a steep cut in pay that he didn’t think he could afford. And in the film business, he says, “There’s a sense of, ‘We’re doing the real work, and the stills guys mimic what we do.’”

Then a friend, who was head traffic manager at House of Blues, offered him a job shooting images for a menu. He went to Samy’s camera in Los Angeles and said he had no idea what film to use. A guy at the film counter spent an hour talking Elias through the job, and then asked, “How did you get this job?”

Elias ended up “shooting everything” for House of Blues for the next two years. “What I learned from the film business was, if you don’t know something, hire someone who does. So I had awesome lighting people, awesome grips, camera assistants, makeup and wardrobe people,” he says, noting that he at least learned as a head gaffer how to manage people and a budget. “I had the confidence to surround myself with people who knew more than me. I wasn’t afraid to do that, and that’s what saved me on this job.” 

He made good money, but it was his only client. And with no idea how to market himself, he wasn’t able to build his base. Eventually, his House of Blues contact moved on. The photo assignment work fizzled out. Elias went back to gaffing in 2009, but decided also to try his hand at making a documentary film.

“I interviewed old time crew members who had worked on the films of the golden age of Hollywood,” he says. The project took nearly three years to complete, and Elias was on the verge of signing a distribution deal. “It fell apart at the last minute,” he says. “At the same time, I went through a pretty bad divorce. Nothing seemed to be working.”

That was his turning point, he says. He took up Buddhism and started meditating. It was then he decided to stop striving, and just try to be the best gaffer he could be. Not long afterwards, he met Richardson while doing broadcast production work for Discovery. “We just became friends,” Elias says. “There was no sense of me ever wanting anything from her. In a certain sense, that helped me.”

Through their casual conversation, Richardson found out Elias was a travel photographer “but we never talked about me shooting for her.” That changed when a photographer Richardson had booked for a Moonshiners promotion bailed out at the last minute for a National Geographic assignment. Richardson called Elias, and offered him the job.

“Here was my opportunity,” he says. “I was completely terrified.” 

After passing Richardson’s test on that shoot, Elias was shooting assignments for her all the time. [Richardson was unavailable for comment before our deadline.] He also started researching how photographers self-promote, and realized he had to do two things: define his strength, and use it to target specific clients.

“I had a real passion for travel photography: flying to weird places, meeting local people who lived a lifestyle that I didn’t understand, and using my camera to understand and engage with it. That’s portrait work,” Elias says.

He started listing clients he thought would want him to engage with people “to explore what their product is: people working in their plants, scientists formulating stuff, or reality show stars who make moonshine or catch crabs,” he says. Elias started sending emails every six weeks announcing different campaigns he’d shot, followed by postcards to those who clicked through his e-mail links to his website.

He was strategic about what he sent, and to whom. With a promo featuring an image he’d shot for Deadliest Catch, for instance, he’d send emails to broadcasters, and clients in the adventure travel business. “I would have in my mind exactly what kind of client I would go after, and it really started to pay dividends. I started getting those [clients].” (He landed a job for Country Music Television that is likely to lead to more CMT work, he says).

Most of Elias’s work so far has been for broadcast networks. He’s now pushing to land corporate assignment work. He’s also doing cinematography for the Disney Channel and ABC. And he’s shot commercials for Google, BET, Nickelodeon, A&E and MTV.

Elias says the secret to his success was simply figuring out what he was passionate about, but it doesn’t require all the suffering he went through to figure it out, he adds. “You can think to yourself, what’s hot right now? How do I chase the market? [But] you’ll never be tapping into what it is that you actually want to express.

“I think the way you end up trusting yourself is pretty simple. If you shoot something that you think people would want to see, and then shoot something that you want to see, watch what the [difference in] reaction is...if you actually focus on what comes from within you, you will have clients that will work with you forever.”

article.article_title: Shooting On Spec To Land Advertising Assignments: Alex Farnum for Reebok
article.meta_description: Photographer Alex Farnum leaned on the strength of his relationships at an ad agency to score a coveted client—Reebok—with some spec work.
article.article_text_abstract: Photographer Alex Farnum leaned on the strength of his relationships at an ad agency to score a coveted client—Reebok—with some spec work.
article.article_image_caption: From a Reebok campaign. “Alex busted his ass to prove to us—and maybe himself—that he was the right choice” for the assignment, says Venables Bell & Partners design director Cris Logan.
article.article_text:
Test shoots are a time-honored strategy for honing new skills and building portfolios. But photographers talk less about shooting on spec—i.e., shooting a test for a particular client for free, with the hope of landing an assignment. Many photographers frown upon it, fearing that if they shoot on spec, clients may start to expect it, forcing photographers to work even harder (and spend out of pocket) to land jobs.

But shooting on spec is a strategy that can work if it’s for a client you trust, and if you’re shooting for your portfolio, too. Photographers Aaron Greene, Alex Farnum and Chris Stanford all landed assignments from the spec work made for clients they were pursuing. In all three cases, the photographers had pre-existing relationships with the clients or their ad agencies. Those relationships gave them access to the people, information and brand strategies they needed to plan their spec shoots, and get their work in front of the critical decision makers.

Here is what they told us.

Alex Farnum for Reebok

Advertising photographer Alex Farnum does test shoots to build his portfolio, but he had never shot on spec to land a particular client. That changed earlier this year when he shot on spec to land jobs from Reebok. It worked: Farnum shot his first Reebok assignment in August, and a second in October.

The key to that success, he says, was the strength of his relationships with everyone involved, from his rental house, to his crew, to Cris Logan, the design director at Venables Bell & Partners, Reebok’s ad agency.

Farnum makes a list every year of the 20 or so brands he’d like to shoot for. This year, Reebok was on his list, and he discovered the account had recently moved from DDB to Venables Bell & Partners.

“I had worked with them on Intel and eBay, and had a great relationship with them already,” Farnum says. “I called Cris and said, ‘You should give all the work to me!’” Logan said he thought Farnum’s style suited the brand, according to the photographer. “But he said, ‘I don’t see much sports on your website.’” 

Logan explained in an email that Farnum’s work at the time was “pretty people in pretty places, doing aspirational things. Alex probably felt he needed to show us he was capable of the rawness and grit we need Reebok photography to represent.”

Farnum asked Logan if he’d be interested in seeing a test shoot. “He said, ‘That would be awesome.’” So Farnum pulled together  his “go-to team”: the producer, hair stylist, makeup artist, and wardrobe and prop stylists that he frequently works with. All agreed to do the test for free. Farnum also got rental equipment at no cost from a rental house he works with regularly.

“I explained I had the opportunity to shoot this test, and if Venables liked it, I might win Reebok work,” Farnum says. The understanding was that if he won a job, he’d hire everyone who helped with the test. “We all [believe] you need to spend money to make money.”

The idea was to photograph athletes decked out in Reebok clothing and shoes, going through the paces at a CrossFit studio. Logan had shown him comps of a Reebok campaign that was already in the works. “I saw it was in-line with my style,” Furnam says. “For me, it was a challenge because I hadn’t shot a ton of sports.”

Farnum shot both stills and video of the model performing a variety of training exercises. (His producer scouted a studio, which the owner let Farnum use in exchange for images.)

“The images were spontaneous and beautiful. I liked what he did so much, I ended up using some of his test images in comps,” Logan says. He adds that he’d never seen a photographer go to such lengths to win work. “It really showed us his fire, his intensity and his commitment to expanding and improving his craft. Alex busted his ass to prove to us—and maybe himself—that he was the right choice.”

By August, Farnum had his first assignment to shoot a set of Reebok ads for retail display. The brief called for photographs of a woman in action in a dance studio, shot in a gritty, reportage style.

After he completed that assignment, Reebok booked him for another “much bigger” assignment. Like the first assignment, it called for shooting models engaged in sports-related activities.

Farnum says he approaches all of his test shoots with three questions in mind: Will it be a challenge? Is it a good creative outlet? Will someone be interested in the work?

“Obviously I think about what kind of work it will win me,” he says. “The best route is to go out, do the test, then use the work as a way to get through the door.”

Related: Shooting On Spec To Land Advertising Assignments: Aaron Greene for Confluence Outdoor

article.article_title: Photographer Erin Trieb Embeds With the ISIS-fighting Kurdish Women's Protection Unit
article.meta_description: Freelance conflict photographer Erin Trieb turned a chance meeting with a general into an exclusive look at the YPJ, an all-female Kurdish military unit battling ISIS in Syria.
article.article_text_abstract: Freelance conflict photographer Erin Trieb turned a chance meeting with a general into an exclusive look at the YPJ, an all-female Kurdish military unit battling ISIS in Syria.
article.article_image_caption: At a funeral procession in Roshava, Syria, Kurdish Women’s Protection Unit (YPJ) soldiers carry the casket of fellow female soldier, Evrim, who died in combat while fighting ISIS. Evrim was one of about 24 Kurdish soldiers buried in the cemetery during the month of August.
article.article_text:
Given the dangers facing journalists who try to travel in northern Iraq and Syria to cover the fight against ISIS (the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria), it’s a challenge to find stories that aren’t already being told. So when Erin Trieb—a veteran freelancer who has been embedded with U.S. forces in Afghanistan—was offered a chance to shoot a typically closed-off all-female unit of Kurdish volunteer soldiers in Syria, “I jumped at the chance,” she tells PDN via email. “When you are asked that question, as a photographer, you don’t say no.”

The Austin, Texas-based Trieb had been working in Kurdistan for two months, and was hoping to embed with the Kurdish Peshmerga fighters when she got the offer from a general to embed with the Kurdish Women’s Protection Unit (YPJ). 

While it wasn’t a difficult decision for Trieb, any sort of travel in northern Iraq can be perilous for westerners, and recent executions by ISIS have only heightened tensions. To get to the YPJ, Trieb had to secure rides for a 12-hour journey over the Kurdistan-Syria border, talking her way through checkpoints along the road.

“During one border crossing, I had to get in and out of four different vehicles, each one driving me closer to the border but not driving more than a mile,” Trieb recalls. “There is some contention between certain military and political factions, so a particular group wearing a particular uniform had to escort me.”

But the women she met—and the images she made—proved worth the trouble. Some 7,000 women make up the ranks of the YPJ, which grew out of the Kurdish resistance movement. The U.S. provides support to moderate rebel groups fighting ISIS and Bashar al-Assad’s regime, such as Harakat Hazm, but the U.S. won’t supply the YPJ, because it has been associated with Turkey’s Kurdistan Worker’s Party (PKK), which has been labeled a terrorist organization by the U.S. State Department.

Trieb hoped to provide a glimpse into the reality for many refugees in the area. She found the women and their families to be honest, kind and charitable. Most who fight are between 18 and 24 years old, but some as young as 12 help with cooking and other chores. The women receive supplies and food from the locals that they protect.

The unit trains constantly. New recruits begin their days at 4 a.m., drilling, taking lessons in classrooms and getting six hours of sleep per night. Many of them had never even played sports or engaged in any physical activity before joining the YPJ. Most are unmarried and have dedicated themselves to the struggle.

Trieb says that since the project came to her unexpectedly, she didn’t have time to do any research or map out a plan for the story. “But I did ask a ton of questions while shooting, did many interviews and gained a solid understanding of the story early on,” she says.

She spent six days with members of the unit, capturing the mundane details of daily life as well as the harsh realities of soldiering. She started her days early. “I especially loved making images in the early morning, when their environment was quiet and still and there was beautiful soft, glowing light,” she says. All of the women lived together at several military bases, not unlike dormitories. In one room, the soldiers would be watching TV, in the next room they would be cooking lunch, and in the next they would be repairing their weapons.

Trieb had no trouble gaining the women’s trust. Her main obstacle was the YPJ leadership, which repeatedly denied her requests to photograph the women fighting on the front lines. “They said ‘You are our American guest, we can never let anything happen to you, we don’t want that on our hands. What will Obama say if you get injured?’”

Trieb says she edited images “every few days or so,” and even sent some work to a close colleague, photographer Katie Orlinsky, who gave her feedback about what the story was missing and what she needed to look for. After returning to a military base in Erbil, Iraq (from which she’s covered Kurdistan in recent months), she pitched the story to NBC News.

“It immediately caught our attention,” says NBC News photography director James Collins. “It was a unique angle to this story. It was confidently shot—nice, intimate moments. It gave you a feel of the hard work that these women were doing to prepare themselves for battle, but also seeing the camaraderie. You can tell that these are women who were fighting for their own land.

“We know her as a visually creative person but also as a solid journalist,” Collins adds. “That’s a very important combination. [Sometimes] photographers can have a good esthetic sense about their images, but the journalism is not so solid, in terms of telling the story.”

Trieb says she hopes to return to do more work about the YPJ. She’d like to photograph more women at home with their parents, the few YPJ soldiers who are married, and the new Yazidi refugee recruits who are now enlisted. She would also like access to the frontlines to capture the women fighting in combat.

Having covered conflict for several years, Trieb says experiencing the excitement of something new and surprising like the YPJ helps remind her why she does what she does. “This project was a bit out of the blue,” she says. “I got that giddy buzz you get when you’re just starting out as a shooter, a thrill that makes your heart pound. I live for those moments.”

article.article_title: What's Your Niche: Stephen Crowley, Political Photojournalist
article.meta_description: Known for his distinctive behind-the-scenes political coverage for the New York Times, photographer Stephen Crowley explains how he works around the limits imposed on press photographers.
article.article_text_abstract: Known for his distinctive behind-the-scenes political coverage for The New York Times, photographer Stephen Crowley explains how he works around the limits imposed on press photographers.
article.article_image_caption: A tightly scripted campaign moment to announce John Edwards as John Kerry's running mate goes awry as Teresa Heinz Kerry reaches over to remove young Jack Edwards' thumb from his mouth.
article.article_text:
Photographer Stephen Crowley, known for his distinctive, insightful, behind-the-scenes political coverage for The New York Times, explains how he works around the limits imposed on press photographers and what drives him to make his images informative.

PDN: What fascinates you about covering politics?
Stephen Crowley: It’s the sport of kings. You have teams, you have strong players and weak players and trades, and schemes. It’s always a story. And it’s a vocation you can do that actually benefits people. You don’t get rich doing this, but you live an incredibly rich life.

PDN: You’re known for witty, quirky images. what’s your motivation?
SC: Part of my motivation is I lost Class Wittiest by two votes to my brother in high school. But most of what I do is [provide] information. [My work is] there for the historical record. I like to impart important information that’s presented like a well- turned phrase.

PDN: You use a lot of different cameras and formats. why do you change it up so much?
SC: I’m not emotionally attached to any piece of equipment. Sometimes music is better with a cello and other times it’s more effective if you play it on a banjo.

PDN: How do political photographers get along when they’re always shoulder-to-shoulder? And how do you get something different in such close quarters?
SC: Everyone gets along really well. It’s just not an issue. Yeah, we compete. But I work differently than others.

PDN: How so?
SC: I think if I have any kind of gift, it’s humor. If I can take it right up to the edge of opinion, that’s great. But objectivity in what we do is essential. I avoid relationships with politicians. If you want to set the stage, and present your issue, I’ll go. If you want to close off a campaign or the Oval Office to the press, I’ve built a career working around that. If I can do it with a little bit of humor to draw attention: Good.

On a campaign, you don’t need to be with the candidate. You need to watch who else is with the candidate. Who’s coming in the back door? Who’s slipping in the side of the hotel to meet them? Who’s the potential secretary of state walking in? That’s what you need to pay attention to: all the moving parts. They’re trying to get their message out, but I’m not their PR person. I’m just trying to grab little morsels of truth as I’m moving along through this story non-stop.

PDN: People are cynical about politics right now. Is that a problem, and is there anything photographers can do about it?
SC: People have always been cynical about politics. But with the collapse of news media, I think there are stories that aren’t being told. So it’s important to show people how their government works, and who they’re electing.

PDN: But the press corps is now so walled-off from candidates and politicians, isn’t it?
SC: I disagree with that. Am I inside the White House with [White House photographer] Pete Souza? Absolutely not. But you can get a sense of what’s going on. It’s a matter of journalists committing themselves to find out. Our job is to keep poking at it, to walk up and down the streets and see who’s having lunch with whom, and piece it all together.

PDN: You don’t feel your access is overly restricted? News organizations, including your employer, complained last spring about photographers’ lack of access to the president’s official meetings, and about being given white House handout photos instead. [See http://bit.ly/10mvdsu]
SC: I’m OK with the White House making their decisions. It’s not my place to tell them they’re wrong. The real problem is when networks, and magazines, and newspapers, and websites all started using those handouts. You’re putting seasoned pros out of work. You’re calling me because I’m one of the last ones standing. Where’s Callie Shell? Chris Morris? Chris Usher? They’re gone [not shooting Washington politics anymore]. The news organizations choose to use the handouts. That’s what’s wrong. [Note: Crowley says The New York Times rarely publishes handout photos.]

PDN: What can photographers do about it?
SC: [Make] bean counters aware that it doesn’t take much to derail an individual or organization’s credibility. It’s really that simple. There’s the value in supporting staff and professionalism.

PDN: When does the 2016 presidential campaign heat up?
SC: It has started. As soon as the mid-term [elections] are over, things will really kick in.

PDN: How old are you?
SC: I’m 61.

PDN: Campaigns require a lot of stamina. Is it getting more difficult for you?
SC: Of course. [But] the campaigns are not making as many stops as they used to. They’re using social media [so] they can do one event in a city instead of making a number of VFW calls. That’s bad for democracy. You just see a packaged news report on [local TV], and it’s less interaction with the people.

But the White House trips? They’re manageable. I don’t go out drinking at night. I have a disciplined approach I learned from Larry Downing at Reuters. As long as you discipline yourself—when I was younger, on some of these campaigns, it was party all the time.

PDN: Who were your mentors?
SC: I didn’t really have mentors, but there were people I admired. Wally McNamee. David Burnett for his humor. Chris Usher for his work ethic. Larry Downing has a discipline. Scott Applewhite. Grey Villet from LIFE magazine. You learn a little something from everybody.

PDN: With your “smoke-Filled Rooms” project, you were delving into the politics of various issues. What projects are you working on now?
SC: We have this new project called “First Draft.” It’s eating up pictures like crazy. Lens [The New York Times photo blog] was great with the “Smoke-Filled Rooms” project. They gave me an opportunity to package [stories] in a creative way, and the approach made my coverage better than it had been. The other thing is, in the end I wanted to have a book. I never said I was going to be Henri Cartier-Bresson. But if I can find an interesting way to present [my images], then OK. If I do a quad- or triptych—take those things apart and they’re not great pictures, but put them together in a creative way and suddenly it means something. And if every once in a while I do make the decisive moment, that’s great, too.

article.article_title: PDN December 2014: The Advertising Photography Issue
article.article_text_abstract: The table of contents for the December 2014 issue of PDN, which focusses on Advertising Photography.
article.article_text:
View the Digital Edition

Subscribe to PDN

THE ADVERTISING PHOTOGRAPHY ISSUE

Shooting on Spec to Land Advertising Assignments
Photographers Aaron Greene, Alex Farnum and Chris Stanford explain how they planned and executed spec shoots for specific clients, and won jobs as a result. BY DAVID WALKER

How Photographers Can Brand Themselves for Social Media Work 
Clients are seeking photographers with strong creative voices to create content for Instagram, Tumblr and Vine. As a result, photographers and reps are altering their marketing strategies to take advantage of this growing market. BY CONOR RISCH 

The Big Ask
With a growing demand for photographers to shoot image libraries, art buyers explain the specific skills they’re looking for. BY MINDY CHARSKI
