article.article_title: 10 Modern Mirrorless Systems and the Lenses That Help Them Shine
article.article_text_abstract: These lenses will help you get the maximum performance from your mirrorless camera.
article.article_text:
Bob Dylan famously observed that you don’t need a weatherman to know which way the wind blows. And there’s an unmistakable wind at the back of mirrorless camera systems. Models like Panasonic’s Lumix GH4 and Sony’s A7/A7R have piqued the interest of both professional still photographers and videographers (and those who do both).

Whether you’ve taken the plunge or still have your finger to the wind, we’ve collected some of the key glass across a spectrum of lens mounts to show you what mirrorless systems have to offer.

LEICA T-MOUNT
Leica recently announced two T-mount lenses along with its new Leica T mirrorless interchangeable-lens camera: the Summicron-T 23mm f/2 ASPH and the Vario-Elmar-T 18–56mm f/3.5–5.6 ASPH lens. Of the two, we think the 23mm model is better suited to pro photographers, thanks to its 35mm full-frame-equivalent focal length and f/2–16 aperture range.

Designed with nine elements in six groups, the 23mm lens features two aspherical surfaces that help it deliver lovely bokeh. Autofocus is available but the lens also offers manual override in AF mode for fine-tuning your focus. The Summicron-T 23mm accepts 52mm filters. At 5.4 ounces and 2.5x1.5 inches, this little lens won’t take up much space in your camera bag. Judging from the price point, it will free up some space in your bank account, too.

PRICE: $1,950 
INFO: us.leica-camera.com


FUJIFILM X-MOUNT
It was difficult to choose a favorite among Fuji’s XF/XC series lenses, but we think the Fujinon XF 56mm f/1.2R is ideal, with its 85mm-equivalent focal length and an f/1.2 low-light-conquering aperture. The lens features a metal aperture ring that clicks into place for accuracy, along with a focusing ring for photographers who prefer to forego autofocus (AF).

Created for both esthetics and practicality, the lens’ seven- blade aperture delivers pleasingly round bokeh. Thanks to a new optical design, which features 11 elements in eight groups (including two extra-low dispersion elements, one double-sided aspherical element and four concave elements), this 56mm lens promises a reduction in chromatic aberration.

Faster AF is possible too, given an internal focusing system that moves only the smaller mid- and rear-elements. If you’re not shooting at a distance, set the lens to macro (with a focusing distance of 2.3–9.8 feet) for even speedier AF. The lens is compact at 2.88x2.74 inches, accepting 62mm filters. It weighs about 14.3 ounces.

PRICE: $999 
INFO: www.fujifilmusa.com

SAMSUNG NX
Announced at the same time as Samsung’s NX30 mirrorless camera, the 16–50mm f/2-2.8 S ED OIS is the first lens in the company’s new Premium S-series. With a full-frame- equivalent focal length of 24.6–77mm, it can capture an image from a wide angle, then quickly zoom into portrait mode. With a maximum aperture of f/2 at 16mm and f/2.8 at 50mm, this lens is fast, but can be stopped down to f/22 for shooting under bright sunlight.

The lens is splash- and dust-proof, too, so you can use it with confidence in rough weather. This optically stabilized lens features an updated Ultra-Precise Stepping Motor that Samsung claims focuses three times more precisely than the earlier model. Designed to minimize spherical and chromatic aberration, the lens is constructed of 18 elements in 12 groups with three aspherical lens, two extra low dispersion lenses and two extreme high refractive (XHR) elements. The lens accommodates 72mm filters.

PRICE: $1,099 
INFO: www.samsung.com

TAMRON SONY E-MOUNT
The 18–200mm f/3.5–6.3 Di III VC has a focal range equivalent of 27–300mm, versatility that earns Tamron’s “all-in-one” lens designation.

From group and environmental portraits to distant shots, this lens functions as an all-purpose accessory for Sony E-mount cameras. At f/3.5–6.3, the lens is slower than others mentioned here but is more than acceptable given a decent amount of natural or artificial light. Plus it’s stabilized, so the camera/lens combo can be easily handheld at slower shutter speeds.

A stepping motor promises improved AF  and, thanks to a moving magnet system and smaller coils, vibration compensation is more effective while keeping the lens’ size and weight to a minimum. The lens is relatively lightweight and compact, weighing in at 16.2 ounces and measuring 2.7x4 inches. Available in all black or black and silver, the 18–200mm lens has a 62mm filter thread.

PRICE: $739  
INFO: www.tamron-usa.com

SONY FE/E-MOUNT
With the launch of Sony’s groundbreaking full-frame mirrorless cameras–the A7, A7R, and A7S–the company also introduced its new FE lens mount. New FE lenses will work on Sony’s APS-C E-mount mirrorless cameras, but older lenses built for APS-C cameras do not cover the full-frame image circle. You'll need to set the camera to either crop the image (on or auto) or you'll end up with a vignette on the full-frame A7/R/S. While the FE line is growing, one of the first FE models available is particularly notable: the Sonnar T* FE 35mm f/2.8 ZA. The 35mm focal length—when used on a full-frame camera—works well for any number of shooting situations, while its 50mm full- frame equivalent on E-mount cameras is also extremely useful.

In addition to being fast at the wide end (f/2.8), the aperture range extends to f/22. A seven-bladed circular aperture brings the bokeh while a dust- and moisture-resistant housing protects the lens’ seven elements (including three aspheric) from nature’s wrath. At just more than two inches long and less than 1.5 inches wide, this tiny prime lens is convenient enough to carry on location. It weighs 10.8 ounces with a filter diameter of 49mm.

PRICE: $798 
INFO: www.sony.net/digitalimaging

PANASONIC MICRO FOUR THIRDS
Mirrorless systems not only feature smaller cameras but smaller lenses as well, and that’s a huge benefit when shooting telephoto. Panasonic’s Lumix G X Vario 35–100mm f/2.8 ASPH lens (with an equivalent 70–200mm focal length) packs a popular zoom range into a fast but compact package. Measuring 2.7x3.9 inches and weighing a mere 12.7 ounces, it’s downright diminutive next to the equivalent lenses on DLSRs.

Though small, this lens doesn’t lack for the features that pros want, such as powerful optical image stabilization. It’s constructed with 18 elements in 13 groups with two ED lenses and one UED lens, has Nano surface coating, and a seven-bladed circular aperture.

The f/2.8–22 aperture range is excellent for varying your depth-of-field, and you can focus on objects as close as 2.8 feet. It also features an almost silent power zoom and accepts optional 58mm filters.

PRICE: $1,498 
INFO: panasonic.net/avc/lumix

SIGMA MICRO FOUR THIRDS AND SONY E-MOUNT
Sigma now offers a trio of f/2.8 prime lenses for both MFT and Sony E-mount cameras: 19mm, 30mm and 60mm. Available in either silver or black, this lens is part of Sigma’s Art lens lineup. Mounted on an MFT camera, the lens delivers a 120mm focal length; with Sony E-mount models, the focal length shortens to 90mm. Both versions have a minimum focusing distance of just under 20 inches. Built with eight elements in six groups, this lens features a new linear AF motor—eliminating the need for gears or other mechanical parts when focusing—which means you’ll enjoy quiet AF operation. Chromatic aberration is minimized thanks to the lens’ low dispersion glass. The lens measures a compact 2.4x2.2 inches and weighs about 6 ounces.

PRICE: $350 
INFO: www.sigmaphoto.com

ZEISS LOXIA E-MOUNT
With its Loxia 35mm f/2 (2/35) and 50mm f/2 (2/50), Zeiss is christening a new lineup of manual-focus lenses for full-frame E-mount cameras (FE). The two lenses offer mechanical aperture settings with a maximum aperture of f/2 and the ability to deactivate the click-stop so you’ll be able to change the aperture silently during video recording. Both lenses offer a 180-degree angle of rotation on the focus ring, allowing for ultra- precise focusing. The 2/50 has a minimum focusing distance of 1.2 feet while the 2/35 can focus on objects as close as 11.8 inches away. The all-metal lens barrels have weather sealing at the mounts to protect camera and lens from inclement weather. While both lenses debuted at Photokina, only the 2/50 is shipping now. Zeiss promises the 35mm will be on store shelves by the end of the year.

PRICE: 2/50, $949; 2/35 $1,299 
INFO: www.zeiss.com

OLYMPUS MICRO FOUR THIRDS
The first in Olympus’ new Pro line of lenses, this 12–40mm zoom (24–80mm full-frame equivalent) offers the same splash-proof, dust-proof and freeze-proof construction as its E-M1, E-M5 and E-M10 cameras. Given its wide-to-mid telephoto focal range, along with its manual-focus clutch (to switch easily between AF and MF), this lens offers the flexibility that pros will appreciate.

While it may not be the fastest Micro Four Thirds (MFT) lens in terms of maximum aperture, the Pro 12–40mm offers a constant f/2.8 throughout the zoom range. Other benefits include its video- and still-compatible drive system for fast and quiet AF, along with its seven-blade circular aperture. 

It features 14 elements in nine groups, a minimum f-stop of f/22 and accepts 62mm filters. It measures 2.75x3.30 inches and weighs 13.47 ounces.

There will also be a new member to the Pro lens family in stores this month. Announced at Photokina, the M.Zuiko 40–150mm f/2.8 Pro lens is positioned as a handheld telephoto lens, weighing just 30.6 ounces with the removable tripod plate attached. The lens offers 11 weather seals to protect against the elements and optical image stabilization that’s CIPA rated at 3.5 stops.

PRICE: 12–40mm, $999; 40–150mm, $1,499 
INFO: www.olympusamerica.com

VOIGTLÄNDER MICRO FOUR THIRDS
A rather exotic lens to be sure, the Voigtländer Nokton 42.5mm (85mm equivalent) f/0.95 is compatible with MFT-mount cameras. It combines an ideal portrait focal length with a super bright and exceedingly fast maximum aperture that you’re not going to find in standard lenses. Beyond the low-light capability, the Voigtländer 42.5mm’s Selective Aperture Control System offers a stepless (de-clicked) aperture ring for pinpoint aperture control as well as silent operation during video capture.

There will be no AF-searching sound on your videos, since this is a manual focus lens; just be sure to hone your manual focusing skills. In addition to a ten-blade diaphragm, the lens features 11 elements in eight groups, including one super high refractive element and one aspherical element. It focuses as close as 9.06 inches and has a minimum aperture setting of f/16. Although the Voigtländer Nokton weighs a relatively hefty 1.26 pounds thanks to an all-metal barrel construction, it’s nicely compact at 2.53x2.94 inches.

PRICE: $999  
INFO: www.voigtlaender.de

Correction: An earlier version of this article stated in the description of the Sony FE/E-Mount lenses that older lenses built for APS-C cameras will not work on the full-frame A7/R/S. Older lenses do fit, but do not cover the full-frame image circle.
- See more at: http://www.pdnonline.com/features/10-Modern-Mirrorless-12118.shtml#sthash.sEO2ccCd.dpuf

article.article_title: McNair Evans: Confessions For a Son
article.meta_description: After his father's death revealed a family business in ruins, McNair Evans created a project that helped him and his family cope with the tragedy.
article.article_text_abstract: After his father's death revealed a family business in ruins, McNair Evans created a project that helped him and his family cope with the tragedy.
article.article_image_caption: McNair Evans was making photographs in San Francisco that addressed the country's historic economic crisis when he realized that it was the crisis in his family that he needed to address.
article.article_text:
Confessions For a Son is a new monograph by photographer McNair Evans that grapples with the past and present of a storied Southern family. The work is an engrossing interrogation of the relationship between parent and child, guilt and regret, love and loss. It’s a settling of accounts—that thankless work which the dead bequeath to the living. 

The roots of this remarkable book lie in the sudden passing of Evans’ 70-year-old father, McNair Evans Sr, in 2000. That loss was soon followed by the realization that the family business was insolvent and the family’s finances were in ruins, a fact that the patriarch had been hiding from his family. Evans, a college anthropology student at the time, was a full semester away from his first foray into photography. During the subsequent years, he seldom spent time in his hometown of Laurinburg, North Carolina, which made it easier to avoid facing the complex emotions surrounding his relationship to his deceased father. 

Having moved to San Francisco after college, his first extended trip home was in 2008. The town of Laurinberg was in a deep depression: empty storefronts downtown and failed franchises on the periphery. Given the size and prominence of the family businesses in Laurinberg, Evans knew that the causes and ramifications of the town’s economic collapse were intertwined with his family’s declining fortunes.

“My great-great-grandfather John F. McNair was a Civil War soldier who, like many at that time, returned home and busied himself with farming and business,” Evans explains. “By the time my father finished college this had grown into a family enterprise with farmland throughout the Southeastern United States, as well as oil refineries, railroading, banking, insurance, fertilizer production and much more.”

Back in San Francisco, Evans began shooting abandoned commercial and office spaces in the city’s downtown amidst the country’s historic economic downturn. The more he worked on the project, the more he recognized that photographs he had intended primarily as a critique of the American economy had become something much more intimate. His camera lingered on the human element: forgotten personal items, stains on carpets, notes on whiteboards.

“By listening to my photographs, I realized there was something else being communicated than what I set out to do,” Evans remembers. He realized the images of loss and isolation he was making were motivated not by a frustration with the system, but “with my family, with my dad. I was like those people who moved out of those office spaces. They were a metaphor for me.”

Evans decided he had to confront those emotions artistically, at their source. In November of 2009, he returned to Laurinburg for two weeks and took, in his own estimation, the best photographs of his life. The next month he moved home, relying on his mother’s hospitality and using the project as a means to uncover who his father truly was as a husband, a co-worker and a son himself.

The result is Confessions for a Son, a book that captures the Evans family, its history and the land upon which it had subsisted for generations, with a Faulknerian compass. A once-proud house sags amidst thorns and brambles—whether its former grandeur weighs upon its shoulders or props it up, one cannot say. Images show rutted dirt roads, huddled black turkeys, felled trees and ransacked offices, strewn with scraps of paper. Old photographs— with their sun-bleached hues and practical framing—show children at play, neat yards and squealing newborns. Worn hands seek ancient runes in the bark of trees they have known all their lives, and grandfather’s rifle, wrapped tidily in newspaper, is thrown in a river.

Evans knew that his narrative approach would be both autobiographical and a biographical look at his father. He shot the project entirely on film, with a 4x5 Shen Hao field camera and a 6x7 Mamiya rangefinder. He worked steadily for a year, using the seasons to frame his father’s story, ending on the tenth anniversary of his passing. Given the economic situation in Laurinburg, empty spaces were plentiful, and Evans found a former art store he was able to use as a studio. He edited while shooting, tacking up 4x5 contact proofs on walls of the cavernous building.

As the project took shape, Evans made a discovery that would expand the book’s scope. Family lore had it that all the photographs from his childhood had been lost in a 1983 house fire, but in December 2012, Evans unearthed a trove of his father’s photographs, 8mm film reels and processed negatives from the back of a closet. Evans would eventually incorporate some of those images into the book, creating a cross-generational visual dialogue stretching 50 years into the past. 

After winning a residency at San Francisco’s RayKo Photo Center and gallery, Evans exhibited “Confessions for a Son” in November 2013. The show allowed him to re-envision his work. “From the beginning I had always seen this as a book project, but my dummies kept feeling flat. [The exhibition] changed everything for me,” he says, “because the two processes are so different. Creating an exhibition was a completely new way to look at the pictures, and it helped me understand the work beyond the previous book sequences I had made.”

Repurposing the work for gallery walls forced him to break with his previous layouts and sequencing choices, to look at everything with fresh eyes. The spatial demands of the show also helped him find ways to incorporate disparate paraphernalia—written text, his father’s photography, business records, personal correspondence— into his book’s final drafts on a scale that informed his images, rather than overwhelming them. Evans credits the residency for giving him the resources to experiment with his archival discoveries, pushing boundaries that he might not have otherwise. 

Evans’s work treads ground—the death of a patriarch, financial ruin, family secrets—that remains sensitive for those close to him. He acknowledges that it was very difficult for some in his family to accept that he would not “let sleeping dogs lie.” He pressed on with the project, undeterred, in part because he felt that no one in the family was communicating about what had happened or addressing their own feelings in the wake of the tragedies, both personal and financial. The work became a means for him and his family to confront things that had never truly been aired, he says. His faith in the transformative properties of photography was buoyed as the project picked up momentum and critical acclaim, and became an affirmation of the family’s fight to pick up the pieces.

“What we went through, that was really something serious,” Evans says. “And it was okay to be sad about that, to be pissed off and angry. And that has been really helpful for me and my immediate family.”

article.article_title: Making Videos Clients Will Love With Budgets You Don't
article.meta_description: Photographers-turned-directors explain their strategies for spending production money wisely to make the best videos they can on tight budgets.
article.article_text_abstract: Photographers-turned-directors explain their strategies for spending production money wisely to make the best videos they can on tight budgets.
article.article_image_caption: A still from a recent assignment for Mini Boden shot by photographer Stephanie Rausser; her DP shot video. Because her lifestyle work demands time putting her models at ease, Rausser says her video work is better when she has the resources to devote time and a DP to the video side of her assignments.
article.article_text:
One of the challenges of shooting motion is squaring clients’ high expectations for production value with their tight budgets. Many clients still see motion as an add-on to a still shoot, with little understanding of what motion production requires. “We hear over and over that motion is secondary,” says photographer Jim Hughes. “Clients tell us, ‘Just shoot me a bunch of [video] and we’ll figure something out.’”

Photographers with motion experience know better than to fall into that trap. So what strategies do they use to manage clients’ expectations, and get them to invest more in all the elements required for a video production? How do photographer/ directors work around low budgets, without sacrificing the quality of the final product? And what are some budget line items that experienced photographer/directors won’t sacrifice, no matter what?

Hughes emphasizes that because budgets are almost always tight, his job is to help clients understand what is possible--and what isn’t—within their budget. He starts by explaining the cost of a production that delivers everything they ask for, the way they ask for it.

“I tell them, If you want A-level production, here’s what you’re going to need. I hold the integrity of pricing,” he says. From there, clients inevitably ask: What can we get done for five grand rather than 25 grand?

“My rep says, ‘They come to you for a solution.’” Hughes explains, adding that the more creative freedom a client is willing to give—i.e., the less specific the client is about details of the final production—the more Hughes can do with a bare-bones budget.

“There are so many places you can cut a production budget. It all depends upon what the shoot is about. So I ask questions to the point where it’s like beating a dead horse.”

The questions help him figure out what the most important on-camera elements are.
“If it’s all about the talent, and the location doesn’t matter so much,” a plain, simple room might do, Hughes explains. “Is the talent in the background? Fine. Maybe you don’t need a stylist; maybe you need a groomer instead.”

Hughes first looks at ways to cut the biggest expense: the crew. Often that means he has to wear multiple hats: director, director of photography and grip. “I’m cutting out luxuries,” he says. “Can we live without craft services and deal with sandwiches from across the street? Do we need a PA [production assistant], or can the producer take care of PA tasks first thing in the morning? For hair and makeup, can we get someone junior?”

But Hughes has his line in the sand, beyond which he won’t accept a job because the budget would only sabotage the shoot. He recounts a big job he recently walked away from—”They were surprised,” Hughes says, and he struggled with his decision—but the client kept insisting on a long list of shots in multiple locations with complicated props. Hughes didn’t think he could possibly do it for what the client was willing to spend, and feared that he’d have a black mark on his reputation if he tried.

Jesse Scolaro, who produces still and video shoots at Bend Creative for photographers and directors, says his spending priority is usually the production details that appear on camera. He recently produced a shoot for a juice company that started as still photography only. The day before the shoot, the agency told the client, “We have this crew. What if we include a motion component?” The client went for it, Scolaro says. Suddenly the budget doubled.

“It freed up funds to increase the scope of what we were capturing,” he says. In addition to hiring a camera crew for the motion component of the shoot, Scolaro spent more on art direction. “Our production designer was able to add a crew person, and we had the budget for better props,” he says.

Though photographers pride themselves on figuring out how to make a production work on a bare-bones budget, they often have budget line items they’re reluctant—or outright unwilling—to sacrifice. For Scolaro, it’s a digital tech, who is on set to manage media, back up and secure image files, and make sure camera cards are not corrupted.

Scolaro has insisted on hiring a digital tech for every production since having a near miss on a job a few years ago. “We were just going to have a camera person copy cards at the end of the day” to save the cost of hiring a digital tech, he says. But they ended up hiring the digital tech, who discovered during the shoot that some camera cards that looked fine when played back in-camera were actually corrupted. The crew was able to re-shoot important scenes on the spot that would have been lost otherwise.

At press time, Scolaro was trying to convince a footwear client to send a digital tech along with a director, director of photography (DP), and producer on a multi-city tour in Asia to shoot videos featuring celebrities. “We’re going to be in cities where there aren’t a lot of reliable production resources,” Scolaro says. “It’s penny-wise and pound-foolish to travel without a digital tech. God forbid there’s a problem. You’ve sacrificed your entire budget if you don’t have that crew person there.”

Lifestyle photographer Stephanie Rausser says her make-or-break budget requirement is money for a DP. “For a long time I was my own DP. I’ve learned from doing it one too many times that to be a good art director and be in communication with people on my crew, I can’t be behind the camera,” she says.

Rausser says that getting models comfortable with one another and directing action on set requires a lot of her time and attention. “I’m a very vocal director. I found that when I was behind the camera, I couldn’t also speak,” she says, explaining that she was too preoccupied by framing the images, anticipating the next shot and worrying about changes in the light. “It was very stressful.”

For Rausser, a DP (or a day dedicated to shooting video) is fundamentally about enabling herself to achieve the look and feel that defines her visual style. It’s also what motivates other photographers to protect certain production budget line items. Hughes says the last thing he’ll cut is lighting and equipment, such as the expensive prime lenses he uses. “I don’t like to cut on our tools—those are making the nice beautiful pictures that clients hire us for,” he says.

Photographer Jonathan Chapman says the look of his videos is dependent upon having multiple cameras at work.

“To have one camera trying to get [everything], that’s just not my approach to visuals,” he says. “My business model is based on really exploring from subtle details to the broad overview. That’s what clients have grown to love in the way I work,” he says. Getting those details, he says, requires a second, third or even a fourth set of eyes. (For a recent Target C-9 shoot, he worked with four camera crews.)

Chapman hires DPs who understand his workflow and visual style. “You’re tag-teaming to get two shots in one,” he says. “I almost always direct the scene and run the A camera while the secondary camera is there, positioned to capture an alternate angle that complements my shot.” While Chapman is reviewing shots or discussing ideas with the client, a second camera crew can look for details that aren’t necessarily scripted, and that clients wouldn’t want Chapman to spend time shooting, but “really are the backbone of the edits.”

On a creative call for a Samsung assignment, the creative director mentioned a b-roll cut on one of Chapman’s videos for McDonald’s that showed the talent’s hands on a counter. It was “a little element, a little nuance” that the CD loved, he says. “That’s not a shot I might have had time on my own to grab on a production for McDonald’s, but having a second camera on set allows us to capture a broader library of those subtle but impactful moments.”

And therein lies the challenge for photographer and their producers: convincing clients to spend money on production extras—and even essentials—that they don’t understand the value of, simply because they can’t pre-visualize the results. The production sacrifices you end up making can depend heavily the sales skills you bring to the bidding process and creative calls, long before you get on set for the shoot.

article.article_title: The Growing Market for Fine-Art Videos
article.meta_description: Photographers like Gregory Scott, whose art practice includes video, have found new audiences for their work among galleries, collectors and curators.
article.article_text_abstract: Photographers who've expanded their art practice to include video have found new audiences for their work among galleries, collectors and curators.
article.article_image_credit: © GREGORY SCOTT/COURTESY OF CATHERINE EDELMAN GALLERY, CHICAGO
article.article_image_caption: An image of "Half Dome," a work by Gregory Scott that combines photography, painting and video. Catherine Edelman, who represents Scott, says the pieces she showed in 2008 sold out in a couple of days.
article.article_text:
The increased accessibility of filmmaking technology in the past five years has invited legions of still photographers to consider the possibilities of the moving image. While commercial and editorial photographers have led the charge into video, fine artists are also increasingly producing motion work, seeking new opportunities to realize concepts, and finding new audiences for their work among collectors and institutions. It’s now common to see video pieces included in photography exhibitions like MoMA’s annual New Photography show, and to see motion work on the walls of the booths of photography dealers at AIPAD and other art fairs.

Technological development is also helping collectors get comfortable with the idea of purchasing video-based art. Buying video works no longer means committing to the installation of a bulky television or finding the space for a projector—they can now be displayed seamlessly on slim monitors hung cleanly on a wall. “Media work is more consumable and is more widely available than it once was, and so by extension it becomes more collectible,” says Catharine Clark, a San Francisco-based gallerist who has represented video artists for more than two decades.

When artists initially began working with video decades ago, they weren’t thinking they could sell the work, Clark says. “I think they were just really interested in the form, and it’s happened that a market has developed from that.” As video technology has become more accessible, making video work has become more financially viable for artists, which in turn has made video work more financially accessible to collectors. “[Artists] can make things that are easier for collectors to consume without breaking the bank,” Clark adds.

Catherine Edelman, a Chicago gallerist and AIPAD member, says she has “tiptoed” into the video-art market in the past decade after years of showing only photography, but is “severely looking” for artists who work with video to represent. She currently shows Gregory Scott’s work, which combines elements of photography, painting and video into wall-based pieces that offer “a dialogue about art history” to which audiences and collectors have responded positively.

Scott, who opened a solo exhibition at Edelman’s gallery this past September, first worked with Edelman when he was making still photographs. She offered his photographs non-exclusively as part of her online print sales platform called The Chicago Project. After Scott began incorporating video into his work during his MFA studies, Edelman started representing him. She first showed Scott’s work at Art Miami in 2008. Both she and Scott were new to the video market, and they priced the work, which is displayed in a custom-built, self-contained piece that collectors just have to hang and plug in, at $16,000 to $22,000 for editions of five. The works sold out in a couple of days. “We were delightfully taken aback,” Edelman recalls. Now his prices start at $28,000 and sell out at $34,000, and they offer them in editions of eight “to meet demand for his work through other venues and dealers” that want to show and sell the work.

Working with Scott has “completely expanded our market,” Edelman says. Few collectors of traditional photography buy Scott’s work, she says. “Most of the people who are buying it collect contemporary art in that broader sense of the word.”

Dutch artist Charlotte Dumas, known for her photographs of horses and other animals depicted in the tradition of Dutch portraiture, ventured into video art while working on a series of works commissioned by the Corcoran Gallery of Art in Washington, D.C. While Dumas was photographing the horses used in ceremonial burials at Arlington National Cemetery, she captured video of the animals as they fell asleep. She didn’t intend to make a work from the footage, but the experience of seeing the horses nod off was enthralling. “I just felt like it would be stupid not to videotape them to have the footage.”

Creating video work was, she says, “something that crossed my mind before, like many photographers who’ve watched their subject” move and have wanted to translate what they see for an audience. When she reviewed what she’d shot, she felt the material was too valuable to ignore. Dumas decided to rough out a “sketch” of a video piece that combined footage of a few of the horses. She showed the sketch during an exhibition of her stills at a vintage photo archive in Holland.

Representatives of a large corporate collection happened to be at the archive during Dumas’ exhibition. They saw the video and wanted to buy it, Dumas says. She took encouragement from their interest and worked with an editor to finish and color grade the piece, which has been shown in her solo exhibitions, group shows and in film festivals, broadening the audience for her work. She has also sold her video to both collectors and institutions.

Dumas went on to make a second film about Nevada’s wild horses, and she is currently working on a third film about horses that work with loggers. “I was lucky enough that the first one was sort of a hit, and that gives you the confidence to make a second one.” Dumas plans to show all three films at a major exhibition she is planning for next year at Museum De Ponte in the Netherlands. Curators she is working with are very enthusiastic about showing the video work, she says, and “people who would not have otherwise seen my work” are now interested.

Last year, Richard Mosse, who has worked with both photography and motion pictures, debuted an ambitious multi-channel video and audio work at the Venice Biennale. Called “The Enclave,” the 40-minute piece was created with the help of a cinematographer, production assistant and an electronic musician, who worked with Mosse in eastern Congo creating a piece that seeks to present the humanitarian disaster there “in an entirely new light, to refresh people’s attention and raise visibility,” Mosse says. The piece has “completely” expanded the audience for Mosse’s work. “It is a highly immersive multimedia environment which brings together photography, music and sculpture. Audiences of all kinds, not just the art cognoscenti or untouchable curators, respond to that. Museums generally like and actually need works of art that can speak to a broad spectrum of people.”

Mosse says that though the cost of installing the piece does limit its potential audience, “Exhibitions of ‘The Enclave’ have been scheduled in 21 different cities, and the work has drawn large audiences.” Mosse adds, “The most amazing thing has been walking into installations of ‘The Enclave’ and sometimes finding crowds of people sitting within the space trying to dissect the piece, moving around the space.”

Julie Saul Gallery, which represents Dumas in the United States, also represents Adam Magyar, another artist who began creating videos after working with photography, and who has seen the market for his work expand as a result. According to the gallery’s director, Edna Cardinale, Magyar began making video work after Anne Wilkes Tucker, the longtime photography curator at the Museum of Fine Arts Houston, saw a video Magyar made to show the creative process behind his “Stainless” series of photographs, which depict travelers on subway trains in cities around the world. She encouraged Magyar to sell the video as a fine-art work in and of itself, and eventually bought it for the MFAH collection. Magyar has gone on to create several videos.

Following media coverage of his work, the views on a pair of excerpts that he posted on Vimeo spiked. As of this writing, two of the excerpts had more than 800,000 views. The interest led to a mass of inquiries about his work, Cardinale says. “People who weren’t necessarily collectors were contacting us and purchasing work.”

Magyar is very technically savvy, Cardinale says, and is willing to tailor the format of the work to the needs of collectors, which she says is helpful, especially with collectors who haven’t previously bought video work. Long-time video collectors are comfortable with how they are going to present work and often have their display equipment sorted out. “Then you have collectors who might like a video, but then they say, ‘What am I going to do with it?’”

Clark sees fewer and fewer technical questions about the display and longevity of video art from collectors and institutions. Just as photography was at one time thought of as a lesser medium in contemporary art circles, video was once marginalized. Now, “video is more integrated into people’s practices,” Clark says. “It’s not a shocking phenomenon. It seems part and parcel of what artists do: They have tools at their disposal and because video is so readily available, that’s just one of the many tools.”

Edelman has also noticed that more young artists coming out of MFA programs are “mixing the media in which they’re immersed,” and extending into video work.

During his MFA work in the ICP-Bard Program in Advanced Photographic Studies, Michael Itkoff continued an interest in video-based work that began when he was an undergrad at Sarah Lawrence. Recently Itkoff produced a series of looped video works that appropriate imagery from 20th century instruction manuals for activities like yoga and karate. New York gallery Haus Projects showed the “How To” videos, as he calls them, at Photo LA. Paul Kopeikin saw the videos there and has been showing them since.

Itkoff sees his video work as part of his evolution as an artist and his “exploration of various ways to tell stories, and partly it is in response to the frustration of the limitations of typical photo-based projects.” He hopes that existing collectors and patrons “will come with me on this journey,” and that “more people will have a chance to see this work that might not be involved in the traditional photo world.”

Clark notes that while there are distinct video collectors, “There are a good number of people who buy videos and photographs.” With artists like Nina Katchadourian, whose practice results in both photo- and video-based work, collectors who have a video work often want a photograph, and vice versa.

There are “clearly more people who just buy photographs,” Clark admits, noting that video editions are smaller and there are fewer video works available in general. She also believes that a lot of beginning collectors are inclined towards traditional media because “we think about art [as] something that resides on the wall.”

But she also thinks it’s easier to sell video art than sculpture now. With her younger collectors, she sees “less bias about new media.” And she predicts that young people who become collectors in the years to come will have “zero of these questions” about how to value and display video art.

"There is something about video that is so accessible today," adds Edelman. "We're all looking for that person who gets our heart going, and [video] is the one avenue that I'm definitely seeking."

article.article_title: How I Got That Shot: Fashion Photographer Gustavo Marx Turns to the Classic
article.meta_description: A designer's look-book assignment inspired Gustavo Marx to return to his photographic roots.
article.article_text_abstract: A designer's look-book assignment inspired Gustavo Marx to return to his photographic roots.
article.article_image_caption: Marx wanted to follow the model as she moved, so he used continuous lights and shot handheld with an old Contax camera as he looked for angles he liked.
article.article_text:
A recent assignment for the Apartamento 03 clothing line inspired fashion photographer Gustavo Marx to look to his past and shoot in a way he hadn’t shot in years. The Brazil-born Marx—now based in New York City—has worked many times with Luiz Cláudio, designer and founder of Apartamento 03. In designing his Autumn/Winter 2014 line, Cláudio had taken inspiration from his memories of his grandmother’s sister, a woman who always presented herself to her family in elegant, glamorous clothes though she had little money and lived quietly on her own. To help Marx understand the woman he had in mind, Cláudio showed the photographer images by Lillian Bassman, a master fashion photographer who shot for Harper’s Bazaar in the ’50s and ’60s. Known for her elegant compositions and grainy, high- contrast black-and-white imagery, Bassman had photographed urbane, sophisticated women who reminded Cláudio of his great aunt. Says Marx, “I could immediately relate his memories to Bassman’s work because of the dreamy black-and-white, the silhouettes, the dresses.”

Marx, who is known for executing sleek, polished and richly colorful imagery in his advertising assignments, was eager to try to emulate the artistic spirit he saw in Bassman’s imagery. “She was working and shooting in what seems to be a very free environment,” he says of Bassman, a protégé of the legendary art director Alexey Brodovich. On the Apartamento 03 shoot, he decided to shoot a handheld camera on a simple, spare set and use a minimal lighting setup that would allow him the freedom to follow the model, photographing any gestures or movements that appealed to him.

“I wanted to go back to my roots, and not be overthinking everything,” he says.

LOGISTICS
In January of this year, Marx and his crew—which included his long time stylist, Mariana Sucupira—arrived in Belo Horizonte, Brazil, where Apartemento 03 is based. They had only five days to prepare.

Marx cast the model himself, after meeting her in person. “I like to have a conversation with models three or four days before a shoot. I’ll send references to the bookers or show them the things I love in their work.” These words of guidance and encouragement, he says, make directing the model easier once the shoot begins.

Marx rented a local photographer’s studio that had a white cyclorama. The day before the shoot, he managed to find a smoke machine. This added more to the shoot than atmosphere alone, he says. “I thought: I don’t want this model to see me all the time. I told her that I wanted to be invisible to her.” He described the woman who had inspired Cláudio, but gave the model no script. Instead, he encouraged her to interpret the character as she wished. He sent most of the crew out of the studio, leaving only himself, Cláudio, the graphic designer and the stylist, to eliminate any distractions for the model. “I wanted her to feel she was in her own world,” he explains.

LIGHTING
Marx typically uses strobes, but for the Apartamento 03 shoot, he wanted the model to move all the time, so he chose to use continuous lights. “I didn’t want to lose any single shot because of recycling time.”

He had his assistants set up three 1200-watt HMIs about 15 feet apart in a simple triangle shape. One, placed at the back, was on a stand about 10 feet high; the two in the front were six to seven feet high. The model was in the middle, turning, walking, dancing, stretching or adjusting her clothes, while Marx moved around her, shooting handheld from just outside the triangle of lights. “I was walking around her trying to find the best things to shoot,” he recalls.

After he photographed the first outfit, he began trying subtle variations in the lighting, adjusting the angle of one of the shorter lights with his left hand while continuing to operate his camera with his right. With each adjustment he would watch how the shadows changed, or how the light looked when it hit the hazy wall of smoke.

In some of the shots he took, a light stand or the silhouette of the stylist was visible within the frame. “I thought, I don’t mind, because I’m not losing this beautiful angle I see here.” He let the designer preview these shots, he says, “and the client was saying: ‘Go for it.’”

CAMERA
The precision and resolution of modern digital cameras seemed poorly suited to a shoot inspired by the romanticism and contrast of the images that Bassman had shot on black-and-white film, so Marx turned to an older technology. “I used an old Contax 645 camera and an old digital back. The combination of those with old, soft Contax lenses was right for the final look,” he says.

Wanting to be able to move freely around the studio, Marx chose not to shoot tethered. Instead, as he tried different shots, he would occasionally check the results on the small screen of the digital back, Leaf Aptus II 5, and show them to the graphic designer and Cláudio.

To make sure there was visible grain in the images, he shot at ISO 200, he says. “I shot half of the job at f/2.8 and the other at f/3.5.”

The shoot took about five hours, he says. “This shoot was a statement from me: I need to do more with less.” On more recent shoots, Marx has tried to rely less on well-planned formulas, and to allow for spontaneity, as he did while shooting the Apartamento 03 assignment. “I think it was a return to the best of my work years ago,” he says.

POST PRODUCTION
Once Marx had finished shooting one look and the model was changing clothes, Marx’s assistant downloaded images to a computer, then printed four or five of the favorites as 4x5s using an Epson inkjet printer. To make their final selection, the designer and Marx reviewed all the proofs tacked to a blank wall, and chose nine images for the brochure and campaign. Says Marx, “That was truly, truly amazing. I don’t usually make a selection on the day of the shoot. I think it’s because I’m usually really tired. But this day was magical.” He had not hired a retoucher for the job; his only post-production work was to enhance the vignetting and grain himself using Alien Skin Exposure 6 software.

The images were printed in a brochure and on the designer’s website. During the image selection process, the client also photographed the wall of prints, and posted his images to his Instagram account to provide customers and press a sneak peek at his next collection. Marx’s images were also made into 18x24-inch prints and sent as a portfolio to members of the fashion press.

Related: How I Got That Shot: Mimicking Sunlight for an Interior Shot 
How I Got That Shot: Tom Corbett's High-Energy Fashion

article.article_title: Create Spotlight: Rebecca Simpson Steele of Reader's Digest
article.meta_description: Photo director Rebecca Simpson Steele talks about the redesign of the publication and how she assigns photographers to shoot for all of the brand's platforms.
article.article_text_abstract: Photo director Rebecca Simpson Steele talks about the redesign of the publication and how she assigns photographers to shoot for all of the brand's platforms.
article.article_image_caption: Photographer Jamie Chung worked with a special-effects makeup artist and a willing model to create images illustrating a story about doctors inducing hypothermia to save lives, published in the "Genius" issue.
article.article_text:
With its January 2014 issue, the venerable Reader’s Digest brand unveiled a redesign that transformed the print magazine, its website and its tablet edition. Emerging from chapter 11 bankruptcy in 2013, it has since introduced new columns and larger, bolder imagery. PDN talked to photo director Rebecca Simpson Steele about planning the redesign and how she assigns photographers to shoot for all the brand’s platforms. A graduate of the Rochester Institute of Technology, Steele has worked in the photo departments at several magazines, including Prevention and Kiplinger’s Personal Finance, as well as on the photography teams at the White House and the Maryland State House. Her photo direction has received awards from American Photography, Photo District News, the Society of Publication Designers and the Folio Ozzies. She co-created a photo consultation business, 2 Editors, where she helped photographers edit their work.

PDN: What is the editorial mission of Reader’s Digest, and who are its readers?
Rebecca Simpson Steele: We’re trying to create an engaging reading experience through a curated collection of uplifting, entertaining and useful stories that enrich readers’ lives. We are an uplifting oasis amid a lot of snark and negativity.

Reader’s Digest is among the magazines with the highest paid circulation in the world. It’s been passed down through generations. It’s something people know well and when you make changes to the brand, they notice.

PDN: What were the goals for the redesign? 
RSS: There was a lot of emphasis on going back to look at what Reader’s Digest, a 92-year-old brand, had done through the years—what had worked, what it had done right. The redesign is clean, streamlined, and it’s classic in style. The emphasis is first on the reading. I think it’s valuable to know that people come to the magazine first to read great stories. As in many magazines, the pages had gotten busier, and our design director wanted to take it back to an easier reading experience where there aren’t a ton of elements and images screaming from the page.

PDN: Is the primacy of the text a challenge for you as a photo editor?
RSS: The photos really stand out now, [so] we’re able to make smarter, more thoughtful choices when running a photo.

PDN: How much of the photography is assigned, and how much is pick-up?
RSS: It depends on the issue, but I’d say the mix from the front of the book to the back is about 70-30, assigned versus existing photography. About 50 to 70 percent of the stories in the issue are curated from other sources. If we’re commissioning work, it has to be as strong as if we’d researched everything out there. If the existing art we see with the text is amazing, we’ll contact the photographer and rerun that if it fits the re-edit.

PDN: Are there genres of photography you need often?
RSS: We do a lot of conceptual photography to illustrate many of our stories. We often approach the photography in an illustrative way, asking how it’s adding to the piece and what it’s bringing to the reader. That can mean still lifes, studio work or concepts using models. For our “Genius” issue, we had Jamie Chung photograph a beauty model “freezing.” It was for a health story titled “Frozen Back to Life,” about how modern medicine is using lower temperatures to save lives. We had a great special-effects makeup artist adding crystals and dust and things to the face of a very willing model. We also froze medical tools and a human heart.

We have art meetings to concept ideas that we pitch to the editor-in-chief. We tell her who we think the best photographers are for that job. The photographers have to build on the ideas once we decide to work with them, but it’s really about matching the best photographer to the concept in those cases.

PDN: Are you relying on a stable of contributors or looking for new photographers?
RSS: We have some established photographers for certain sections of the magazine, and other than that we’re open to new contributors. For example we started a new column with the redesign called “Faces of America.” [Photographer] Glenn Glasser is going around the country and meeting a lot of people, doing short interviews with them, taking their portraits, getting to know one person at a time. That’s been a really fun project. 

In the front of the book we have the “Words of Lasting Interest” column. It’s a page of thoughtful, insightful text that our editors have found. Dan Winters photographs that every month. He reads the text and pitches a few ideas of what he got out of it. It’s helpful in building consistency to have certain pages that have familiar looks.

PDN: How do you find photographers?
RSS: I talk a lot to photo editors, photo producers and other people who are hiring and working with photographers. I’ve gotten a lot of recommendations that way. I look through promos I get through the mail. I love printed mailers. Emails always come in when you’re on a set or in a meeting. It’s harder to grab someone’s attention that way; we get so many emails every day. It’s nice to be able to choose when you want to go through your mail. That’s when you have time to take a break.

I definitely look through other magazines, too. Being a general- interest magazine, we never know what’s around the corner so it’s good to know all genres of photography. I think right now TIME and New York magazine are very strong for general interest stories. I look at men’s magazines, fashion magazines, city and regional magazines, quite a range.

PDN: Is there a photographer you hired recently who was new to Reader’s Digest?
RSS: I just recently hired Ramona Rosales on the recommendation of [photo editor] Moira Haney at The Hollywood Reporter. It’s always nice to know who people have loved working with. Ramona had shot a lot of celebrity portraits on location for them that were great. I sent her to photograph Jetsonorama, a street artist in Arizona who has been making amazing murals on the Navajo nation. She did a video while she was out there. They were driving around the Navaho nation, so there were wide, open roads, beautiful skies, and he was actually installing murals while she was there. I asked her if she could get some footage of this because it would be cool to see his process. We married the footage with the interview that the editor had originally done with him.

PDN: Are you looking for photographers everywhere or do you have a budget for travel?
RSS: We do have a small travel budget but I love to know where everyone is from, and where they like to go. If a photographer’s in a smaller market, that’s great to know.

PDN: What’s the division of labor in your department?
RSS: There’s myself and my photo editor, Deb Wenof. We divide up the magazine pretty evenly. She’s working on the front of the book and features and I’m working on the cover and features. We have two great assistants for the art and photo department who split their time to help with photo research and office administration.

PDN: How do you recommend photographers promote their work to you?
RSS: I think that a lot of times people send out a promo that’s not reflective of their whole portfolio. I often like a mailing campaign where you’re getting a card every few weeks that is in a similar format or a card that has multiple images so you can summarize your work better. I think that often people have a great shoot, they think: This image is great, I want to share it with the world. But if it doesn’t tell me about your overall portfolio, it’s hard to pitch.

article.article_title: Letting Go of The Camera: Frank Ockenfels 3 and DP Welles Hackett Bring Stills to Life
article.meta_description: When AMC, FX or other TV networks assigns Frank Ockenfels 3 to shoot short motion clips that mimic his still images, he calls on director of photography Welles Hackett.
article.article_text_abstract: When AMC, FX or other TV networks assigns Frank Ockenfels 3 to shoot short motion clips that mimic his still images, he calls on director of photography Welles Hackett.
article.article_image_caption: Promotional image of January Jones as Mad Men character in a promotional image for the show.
article.article_text:
In the past two years, photographer Frank Ockenfels 3 has frequently brought director of photography Welles Hackett onto shoots for AMC, FX and other TV networks requiring short motion clips that imitate the still images Ockenfels shoots.

Their first combined still/video job was on the set of Black Sails, a series created by STARZ. Ockenfels was hired to photograph cast members on location in South Africa, but the marketing team also asked for motion clips they could use online. Ockenfels recalls, “They said, ‘We would like to marry these images together. We could have motion that’s identical to the still photography.’” Ockenfels brought in Hackett, his long-time friend; they first met 17 years ago when Ockenfels was directing music videos and commercials. For the Black Sails assignment, he and Hackett sometimes shot side by side in natural light, “or every time I’d step back, Welles would step in and shoot exactly what I’d been shooting.” In Hackett’s clips, he says, “It’s like my camera came alive.”

Ockenfels proposed a similar idea to AMC when he was hired to shoot an image library for the show Mad Men. The network agreed. Since then he has worked with Hackett to deliver stills and videos for Mad Men, The Walking Dead, The Killing, an as-yet-to-be-released show for Netflix, and other shows.

Networks have sometimes gotten motion clips by hiring photographers to shoot video on DSLRs, “but the quality was not satisfactory to some people,” Ockenfels claims. Hackett shoots on an ALEXA, sometimes in slow-motion, and has his crew of gaffers and grips recreate Ockenfels’ lighting style with continuous lights suited to the motion camera. With network marketers demanding more and more online content that they can deliver to fans, a partnership with an experienced DP is “a relationship that’s become a necessity for work in the TV industry,” Ockenfels says.

On each assignment, their division of labor is similar. Ockenfels positions the actors, shoots stills, and then gives the actors a few simple directions about an action they’ll perform for the motion camera. Then, Hackett shoots their action for a matter of seconds. By the time Hackett steps in, Ockenfels has typically moved on to his next task. “When we do Mad Men, we’re doing 54 setups in a day,” he explains. In Hackett, he has a trusted collaborator “who knows my vision so I can say: You’ve seen what I’ve done, now continue on with that thought and make it come to life.”

Ockenfels adds that Hackett’s “creative, collaborative” approach extends to his crews. Many film veterans, Hackett concedes, are used to “rigid protocols” about who handles which gear. Hackett relies on a team of gaffers and grips who can be flexible and “have been very willing to learn the strobes that Frank likes, what they look like and what can be good substitutes for those lights,” he says. “My gaffer will talk to his main assistant and say, ‘Can we put this light here, will that be cool?’” Once he’s gotten the stills he needs, Ockenfels says, “My guys will work with his guys to move everything around so he can get motion.”

Ockenfels says collaborating with a DP is no different from collaborating with ad agency creatives, art directors, talent and crew members. “To have an ego to say, ‘This is my picture and I don’t want to recreate it in any way but the way I see it through my lens,’ you’re missing the point of what your job is in this industry,” he says. As a photographer or as a director, he says, you’re part of a team “collaborating to achieve something interesting.”

Hackett notes that he and his crew enjoy the hectic pace of the image library shoots, as well as working alongside Ockenfels and his assistants. “A large part of what I do on commercials is sitting around watching people obsess over a bowl of yogurt for hours,” he says. Shoots with Ockenfels are about getting great visuals. “The heart of the process is photographic,” he explains, “Which means I get to have the conversations I love to have: How do we make the photography better?”

The key to getting the most out of a good cinematographer, Hackett advises, is to respect their work. “Use them the way you would any other creative tool because the cinematographer is there to make your work better,” he says. “You just have to be open to that collaboration.”

Related: Letting Go of the Camera: We Are The Rhoads and their go-to Director of Photography Tom Banks
