article.article_title: Has a Textbook Publisher Trampled Your Copyrights? There's a Solution For That
article.meta_description: Numerous photographers have filed copyright infringement suits against textbook publishers who routinely overran photo licenses. A copyright attorney offers tips on how to file a claim.
article.article_text_abstract: Numerous photographers have filed copyright infringement suits against textbook publishers who routinely overran photo licenses. A copyright attorney offers tips on how to file a claim.
article.article_image_caption: A photo of a mysterious circle—possibly a WWII military outpost—in Africa. The image was one of several by George Steinmetz that Houghton Mifflin Harcourt allegedly reproduced beyond the usage license limits.
article.article_text:
Photographers and stock photo agencies have filed dozens of lawsuits against textbook publishers in recent years, alleging reproductions of photos that far exceed the limits of usage licenses. Courts have ruled in favor of photographers in many of the cases. Robert Frerck, for instance, won a summary judgment this month on his copyright claims against Pearson Education, and won a settlement from McGraw-Hill last May on another claim.

After reading reports that the publishers had overrun the image usage limits granted by other photographers, Frerck began buying textbooks for which he’d licensed images.

“There were numerous uses of my images that were not mentioned on the purchase orders and consequently never invoiced or licensed,” he told PDN in an email. “I had met many of their picture editors personally and we had developed a relationship based on trust and I considered many of them to be personal friends. So I felt betrayed when I learned that these companies were knowingly cheating me as a standard business practice.”

Despite—or perhaps because of— settlements paid to Frerck and others, new claims continue to surface.

Photographer George Steinmetz, a National Geographic contributor, sued Houghton Mifflin Harcourt in April for three dozen instances of infringement. He began checking the publisher’s uses of his images against his invoices after reading a previous report in PDN about infringement by textbook publishers. Steinmetz says he was reluctant to sue a client, “but at the same time, I thought it was outrageous. If someone buys a bottle of whisky and steals a six-pack of beer at the same time, it’s not right. You don’t let it go because they’re a customer.”

Filing the lawsuit, he continues, “has been a major headache. I have fairly complete records, but to go back and dig all that stuff up is a chore. It’s a lot of trouble.” His advice to others: “It’s critical to make sure [you register] your copyright, hopefully before it’s infringed upon,” because that makes a huge difference in how much money you’re eligible to recover for damages.

Meanwhile, photographer Jon Feingersh filed suit against McGraw-Hill this summer, and Joel Gordon has filed separate lawsuits at various times this year against McGraw-Hill, Pearson Eduction, and Houghton Mifflin Harcourt. Feingersh declined a request for an interview. Gordon didn’t respond.

But the claims of both photographers follow the usual pattern. Court papers show that, according to his latest claim, Gordon granted Houghton Mifflin Harcourt (HMH) photo usage licenses between 1990 and 2008 that “were expressly limited by number of copies, distribution area, language, duration, and/or media.”

HMH ultimately violated those limitations, according to Gordon’s claim. He does not specify the extent of the alleged infringement, explaining only that HMH has that information. But he cites a previous claim against HMH by photographer Ted Wood, who had limited use of his photographs to 40,000 copies, only to discover that HMH had published more than 1 million copies. Wood won his case on summary judgment.

Gordon goes on to cite another 25 claims of copyright infringement against HMH, and he accuses the publisher of having a business model “built on a foundation of pervasive and willful copyright infringement [that] deprived Gordon and hundreds of other photographers and visual art licensors of their rightful compensation and unjustly enriched HMH.” He is seeking unspecified monetary damages, and an injunction to bar the publisher from further use of his photographs.

Attorney Maurice Harmon of Harmon & Seidman LLC, the lawfirm that represents Gordon, Frerck, Steinmetz, Feingersh and many other photographers for claims against textbook publishers, explained via email why these types of claims persist, and how photographers who believe their copyrights have been violated by textbook publishers can protect themselves.

PDN: Why do these claims by photographers against textbook publishers continue to trickle out?

Maurice Harmon: Photographers have only gradually come to realize their photographs have been infringed. Once they know of the individual infringements, the photographers have three years to file a case.

PDN: Do any publishers make good-faith efforts to settle the claims before photographers sue, or before claims go to trial?

MH: That varies greatly—but we always try to negotiate a fair settlement at every stage and 98 percent settle before trial.

PDN: What must a photographer be prepared to endure, in terms of an investment of time and money, and/or mental anguish—to take on a textbook publisher with one of these claims?

MH: That also varies greatly. Some cases are resolved quickly without anything more than sending us the invoices. Other cases require more documents and a deposition. We advance all expenses, so there is no out- of-pocket cost to the photographer.

PDN: What is required for a photographer to make a strong claim?

MH: Invoices/licenses with terms that identify the specific licensed photographs that limit the uses a publisher can make of those images. Each photograph must also have been registered or can be registered with the Copyright Office.

PDN: What can photographers expect to recover if they win in court?

MH: That depends on the extent of the unauthorized uses, the license terms and conditions, the registration status of the photographs, etc., but it has proven to be well worth our —and the photographers’—time.

PDN: If a photographer never registered his or her image copyright, or registered after a textbook publisher misused them, does that make an infringement claim more difficult than it’s worth? [Editor’s note: Filing registration before a proven infringement makes copyright holders eligible for statutory damages, which are often much higher than actual damages.]

MH: Sometimes, but not always—it depends on the number of infringements after registration and the license terms and conditions.

PDN: Aren’t these claims subject to a statute of limitations? When is it too late to make a claim?

MH: The photographer has three years from the date he or she knew, or reasonably should have known, about the specifics of the infringement to file a case.

PDN: What percentage of these claims are successful? What are the most common reasons they fail—ie, they’re dismissed by a court, or a photographer recovers little or nothing in the end?

MH: The cases we bring have all been successful unless the plaintiff is determined by the Court to lack standing; that is, to lack ownership of the photographs. 

PDN: How have textbook publishers changed their license agreements to avoid these claims in the future?

MH: The textbook publishers are now demanding rights so broad it is almost impossible to overrun the license.

PDN: What’s your parting advice to photographers who license images to textbooks?

MH: Act immediately to find out and protect your rights.

article.article_title: Reimagine the Client Gift With Custom Self-promo Magazines
article.meta_description: Photography self-promotion ideas, custom photography magazines and books, Blurb
article.meta_keywords: Photography self-promotion, custom photography magazines, custom photo books, Blurb
article.article_text_abstract: Sponsored post: Fashion and beauty photographer Benjamin Kaufmann discusses his experience creating a custom magazine through Blurb for his clients this holiday season.
article.article_image_caption: The first edition of Benjamin Kaufmann's self-promotional magazine.
article.article_text:
With the shift to digitize nearly every kind of imagery—from portfolios to photo albums to Christmas cards—it’s easy to forget how impactful a printed product can be. London-based fashion photographer Benjamin Kaufmann discovered as much when he decided to try printing his first self-promotional magazine to send to clients through the end of the year.

“In a more and more digitalized world, a printed product makes an impression and people tend to keep it in their shelves,” says Kaufmann.

With the holidays approaching, many photographers are opting to send small printed pieces as a gift to their contacts. Kaufmann knew he needed to think big to make his promotion stand out from the pack. It didn’t take long for him to settle on a printed magazine, which commands more attention and has an inherently longer shelf life. Kaufmann, whose clients include Elle and Marie Claire, is no stranger to beautiful, high-end glossy magazines. And because most of his clients are used to producing editorial features and advertisements in magazines, they’d appreciate the format.


Above: Kaufmann opted for full-bleed images and no text to show off the high quality of his photography.

With that in mind, he began looking for a partner that would help him produce the type of high-end glossy that would match the quality of his clients’ productions, both in design and printing—a subpar printed product would fall flat. When a colleague recommended Blurb, Kaufmann was more than a little intrigued. As he discovered, Kaufmann says, the self-publishing company offered a straightforward approach, a simple process, and a wide variety of custom options, from design tools to paper choice to printing quantity.

The ease of use was certainly a selling point for Kaufmann, but it was the customizability of Blurb that sealed the deal. Prior to working as a fashion and beauty photographer, Kaufmann spent many years in graphic design. With Blurb, thanks to their plug-ins for professional design applications like Adobe InDesign and Adobe Photoshop Lightroom, Kaufmann could create a completely original magazine design that took advantage of his graphic design skills and avoided the cookie-cutter layouts that plague many self-publishing efforts.

Blurb also has its own proprietary program, BookWright, which makes it incredibly easy to create customized layouts for those that aren’t experts at InDesign. BookWright uses a “what-you-see-is-what-you-get” approach to layout design that makes it simple to move images and text around and test their professionally designed layouts or unique, personalized ones.

Blurb allows orders of one copy all the way up to 500, allowing the ability to print for specific events, client types or contacts. With this level of personalization, photographers have more creative control to easily tailor their books to the interests of different contact groups, or even single contacts.

“The more one communicates on a personal level with clients and the more effort one puts into self-marketing, the greater the feedback will be,” says Kaufmann. “The idea of creating a book or magazine with pictures specifically for one person is very intriguing.”


Above: A two-page spread in Kaufmann's magazine.

Kaufmann is wary, however, of using printed books and magazines as a first point of contact. He believes printing hundreds of copies of a book and sending it to random prospective clients would hardly produce a good return on investment. Printing a limited run for established contacts is more effective route, and, additionally, on-demand printing allows him to quickly follow up with a new client to solidify a relationship.

“That's the beauty of digital printing,” Kaufmann says. “You can react quickly and get printed only what you need at any given moment.”

Kaufmann recently completed a first run of his customized Blurb magazine, which contains a selection of his fashion, beauty, and landscape photographs. To create the glossy look, he chose the magazine format with a softcover and the Velvet Premium 80# paper.




Above: A selection of Kaufmann's featured fashion and landscape work.

“The Premium paper ensures it has the highest possible quality. That’s important when I’m trying to make an impression,” he explains.

To ensure that the printed product matches what is designed, Kaufmann recommended calibrating your monitor before and during design. In addition, Kaufmann had a single magazine printed first as a proof so that he could check colors, layouts and the binding for errors.

Kaufmann’s first full print run was an order of 60 magazines, and so far, they’ve been a hit. Kaufmann has used the magazines as a gift to existing clients and as a give-away during industry events. He’s even begun leaving it with clients after face-to-face appointments, which has kept him at the front of their minds when they look to their next project. The feedback, according to Kaufmann, has been amazing. He’s only had one problem: “Almost too many people want a copy.”

Get started on your printed book or magazine today at www.blurb.com.

article.article_title: How Luxury Real Estate Clients Hire Photographers
article.meta_description: New luxury residential developments need photographers working in many genres to help draw high-end buyers and brokers to sumptuous spaces.
article.article_text_abstract: New luxury residential developments need photographers working in many genres to help draw high-end buyers and brokers to sumptuous spaces.
article.article_image_credit: © SOUTH LOOP LUXURY/PHOTO BY SCOTT FRANCES
article.article_image_caption: For Chicago's South Loop Luxury, the branding and design firm Otherwise Inc. hired photographers to create aspirational lifestyle shots and showcase the development's architecture.
article.article_text:
The effects of the housing market’s collapse in 2007 and 2008 are still being felt. But in many cities the clamor of construction heralds growth in the real estate market—in particular, of luxury residential developments. Developers of condominium and rental properties and the design firms and advertising agencies that represent them are assigning photographers to help market these spaces in a variety of media to both wealthy consumers and real estate brokers.

“It now requires far more sophisticated experience-building and brand-building to attract renters and buyers because there’s a lot of competition in each one of these markets,” says Nancy Lerner, the co-founder of Otherwise Inc., a Chicago-based branding and strategic design firm that works with real estate clients around the U.S. “For developers with very high-end and high-profile projects to compete, they have to think of them as luxury brands.” Photographers are being assigned to shoot images that can stir the aspirations of potential buyers with a taste for luxurious amenities, and are often required to shoot more than just interiors. Describing the photography her clients need, Lerner says, “Some of it is about the beauty of the product itself, but some is about being able to convey lifestyle, and in some cases [it’s about] doing both in the same visual experience.”

To market a trio of newly constructed condominiums in Chicago that the developer Related Midwest had acquired and upgraded, Otherwise branded the three properties as South Loop Luxury by Related. The initial 2013 campaign featured photography of the interiors. Then in February, Otherwise launched an email marketing and digital advertising campaign featuring lifestyle photography. “The buildings are really beautiful and we wanted to show people enjoying the life they could lead if they purchased at South Loop Luxury,” says Courtney McKeen, a marketing manager at Related Midwest.

One ad shot by Chicago-based Bob Coscarelli shows a smiling boy holding a cello and bow near a window overlooking a lit-up Chicago skyline. In another, a dad plays with his pajama-clad kids in a bright room with a lakefront view. A third ad, shot by New York-based Scott Frances, shows a man who appears to be relishing both the elegant pool he’s standing in and the glance of a smiling woman walking by.

Lerner says Otherwise chose Coscarelli and Frances because of their experience shooting not only interiors, but also talent in those spaces. “The combination of the two was critically important to us,” she says.

Coscarelli, who was also hired by Otherwise to shoot a campaign for The Ritz-Carlton Residences in Chicago, notes that developers need photographers to sell a lifestyle, while at the same time capturing “the magic of the space or the grandeur or the sexiness—why that space is a $1.5 million two-bedroom condo.”

Frances says that showing people in architectural advertising can help developers define and reach their target demographic, as well as illustrate a space’s size and functions.

“With architecture, it’s very hard to tell scale because it’s just lines,” says Frances, who has been a contributing photographer to Architectural Digest for 25 years. “The only things that give us reference of scale are things we’re familiar with—a dinner plate, a fork, a chair, or humans—so that’s an important part of using talent in architecture [photography].” 

The combination can be challenging to shoot well. “I often think about, ‘How do we frame this moment we’re going to capture with talent in such a way that we can provide context and honor the space?’” Coscarelli says. “I think it’s two different disciplines, because often the best lifestyle shooters shoot with a very impromptu approach, so in the heat of capturing a magic moment, the lighting in the space can become secondary. So then the challenge is: How do we capture the moment embellished by the light?”

Lerner recommends that photographers who want to work on luxury real estate projects approach developers directly. Many are commissioning photos directly from photographers that never appear in advertising. They may include the photos they assign in a portfolio shared with lenders, for instance, or give them as gifts to new buyers, she says.

Developers and the agencies they work with don’t only need photographers who can show the beauty of a space. When a building has yet to be completed, for example, the assignments can be more offbeat.

When the design firm Pentagram began working on branding for The Printing House—a property in Manhattan’s West Village that was being converted from rentals into luxury condos—they hired New York-based photographer David Leventi to take photos for a teaser that would be sent to brokers. His images showcased spaces that were not just empty, but completely stripped down to concrete, plaster and nails. Luke Hayman, a New York-based partner at the design consultancy Pentagram, explains, “We had to communicate, ‘No, this isn’t just a new lick of paint – this has been blown apart.”’

Hayman believes that showing people in real estate advertising isn’t always a wise strategy. “There’s a theory that you shouldn’t put anyone in there because the idea is for you to project yourself in that space,” says Hayman. “If you see someone else in [that] life, you think, ‘Well, this is kind of someone else’s apartment. I kind of like it but I’m not sure.’”

A different way to show what life could be like for prospective residents is to spotlight the neighborhood around the development. For The Printing House, Pentagram assigned Leventi to make images of life in the West Village that would run in a brochure and on the building’s website and app. The imagery would run alongside interior photography from New York-based Pieter Estersohn that was also featured in print ads. Pentagram had hired Leventi in 2008 to make similar photos of street life around the site of a proposed building in TriBeCa. Hayman says that before Pentagram hired Leventi, the designers had first looked for stock photos of the neighborhood. “We couldn’t find many of the shots we wanted, and combining images from different photographers and different time periods would have created a bit of a visual mess.”

Leventi says his images for The Printing House “romanticize the idea of living in the West Village.” He adds, “It was important to show a lot of green and brownstones, and to create the feeling of community.”

Pentagram gave Leventi a list of sites to photograph that had been determined with the client, Corcoran Sunshine Marketing Group, the real estate advertising company that works for the building’s developers.

In the mix were schools, boutiques, restaurants and “everything that makes a neighborhood appealing,” Hayman says. Leventi photographed runners near the Hudson River, and people walking on a sidewalk with a line of pedicabs on one side and restaurants on the other.

“I try to take a beautiful, unique, emblematic shot of each place. It’s often easier said than done,” Leventi says. “Unfortunately, New York City is a dirty place and the majority of cars are not very photogenic and become compositional eyesores.”

He’s found some creative solutions. He may capture a moving yellow taxi in a blur not only because it’s a symbol for the pace and energy of New York, he says, but also because it “serves as a blanket for a maybe not-so- appealing street level.”

While Leventi is an architectural and fine-art shooter, Hayman says that travel photographers shooting editorial assignments have the relevant skills to capture the kind of aspirational images needed for these campaigns. The goal for every real estate marketing campaign is the same, he says: “Selling a vision and a dream for an apartment and a neighborhood that you could be living in.”

article.article_title: PDN November 2014: The Moving Image Issue
article.meta_description: How and when to hire a director of photography, video art sales, video production tips for tight budgets.
article.meta_keywords: video, art, photography
article.article_text_abstract: Making the most of director/director of photography collaborations; the growing market for fine-art video work; tips and tricks for creating videos clients love on budgets director's don't.
article.article_image_caption: ON OUR COVER: A still image of “Don’t Fade Away, 2013,” a work by Gregory Scott created using photography, painting and HD video. Scott’s work is discussed in “The Growing Market For Fine-Art Videos.” Image courtesy the artist and Catherine Edelman Gallery, Chicago.

Subscribe to PDN

THE MOVING IMAGE ISSUE

Letting Go of the Camera
Photographers-turned-directors explain how working with a trusted DP has expanded their technical expertise, and helped them produce motion work they couldn’t have made on their own. Their DPs talk about what it takes to create a successful director-cinematographer collaboration. BY PDN STAFF

The Growing Market for Fine-Art Videos
Photographers who’ve expanded their art practice to include video have found new audiences for their work among galleries, collectors and curators. BY CONOR RISCH

Making Videos Clients Will Love with Budgets You Don’t
Photographers-turned-directors explain how they spend production money in strategic ways to make the best videos they can on tight budgets. BY DAVID WALKER

PDNEWS

Picture Story: Love Radio Rwanda
An ambitious multimedia project combines fictional drama with documentary storytelling to reveal Rwanda’s lingering tensions two decades after its shocking episode of genocide. BY DAVID WALKER

How I Got That Grant: VSCO’s Artist Initiative Program
Photographers explain how they completed projects with support from Visual Supply Company, which recently established a $1 million fund to discover, fund, advise and promote photographers and other artists. BY DAVID WALKER

Copyright Watch: Has a Textbook Publisher Trampled Your Copyrights? There’s a Solution for That.
For years, it was business-as-usual for textbook publishers to overrun the limits of photo-usage licenses, and photographers continue to file infringement claims as a result. A copyright attorney explains what is required to file a claim. BY DAVID WALKER

CREATE

Building Demand
Developers of luxury residential properties need photographers working in many genres to attract high-end buyers and brokers to sumptuous spaces. BY MINDY CHARKSI

Spotlight: Reading Reader’s Digest
Photo director Rebecca Simpson Steele on the types of photography the 92-year-old publication has commissioned since its redesign. INTERVIEW BY HOLLY STUART HUGHES

GEAR

How I Got That Shot: Gustavo Marx Turns to the Classic
An assignment from a designer takes the fashion photographer to the roots of his technique. BY HOLLY STUART HUGHES

Product Reviews
Metz Mecablitz 64 AF-1, G-Technology G-RAID Studio, Macphun Tonality Pro. BY GREG SCOBLETE

Frames Per Second: Using Sound to Tell a Story
Photojournalist Damir Sagolj fell in love with recording audio and used it to poetic effect in a multimedia piece about refugees from the Fukushima nuclear disaster. BY HOLLY STUART HUGHES

10 Mirrorless Marvels
Mount these lenses to your mirrorless camera for maximum performance. BY THEANO NIKITAS

EXPOSURES

A Father’s Son
After his father’s death revealed a family business in ruins, McNair Evans created a project that helped him and his family cope with the tragedy. BY DZANA TSOMONDO

New Construction
In a new book, Michael Ashkin uses a unique visual language to trace the seizure and destruction of Long Branch, New Jersey, which displaced longtime residents to enrich real-estate developers and the local government. BY CONOR RISCH

article.article_title: Letting Go of the Camera: Zen Sekizawa and Ernesto Lomelli's Technical Finesse
article.meta_description: Photographer/director Zen Sekizawa says director of photography Ernesto Lomelli's technical knowledge and fraternal familiarity helps her make better videos.
article.article_text_abstract: Photographer/director Zen Sekizawa says director of photography Ernesto Lomelli's technical knowledge and fraternal familiarity helps her make better videos.
article.article_image_caption: A still from "Agon," a recent project for shoemaker LD Tuttle's Autumn/Winter 2014 line.
article.article_text:
It takes a lot of trust for a photographer to relinquish control of their camera on set. So whether photographer Zen Sekizawa is occupying the director’s chair on a motion shoot or working on a hybrid video/stills production, when she has a choice, her director of photography is always Ernesto Lomeli.

The pair first met on set as co-DPs on a Nike Fuel Band commercial, working for the production company Motion Theory. Sekizawa had shot print campaigns piggybacked on their productions, but with a little prodding from MTh, she soon found herself booked on gigs as a cinematographer. While confident in her lighting and stylistic choices, the sets were larger than she was used to, and she had a whole new set of tech and lingo to learn. Lomeli, a self-professed gadget nerd also working with MTh, has worked on motion sets for his entire career. Paired with Sekizawa as co-DPs, he was the perfect adviser to ease her into shooting video.

“He was very patient,” she says. “He still is. It feels like a complete collaboration. It doesn’t feel like here’s my role and here’s your role, we’re definitely working with each other.” Theirs is a collaboration built on trust, which Lomeli says “comes from a mutual respect of each other’s talent and creativity.”

Since the first job for Nike, the two have become close friends, forming a formidable photographer/DP team with credits for brands such as Sony and shoe designers Jimmy Choo and LD Tuttle. Like any good collaboration, theirs starts with communication—the messages and conversations that happen before a shoot are crucial. 

“I think the most important thing for me, working with a DP,” Sekizawa explains, “is the understanding of what it’s going to look like…if we’re coming at it with the same sort of compositional ideas.”

The two exchange references—photos, books, films or anything else—to get on the same page. While most of the directors Lomeli works with are concerned with their 40-foot tracking shots and movement within the frame, Sekizawa typically references the tone and direction of the light.

But sometimes Sezikawa will show Lomeli a film to dissect, peppering him with technical questions. How did they get the shot? What kind of camera movement was used? The answers help her understand the machinations required to execute her vision.

“I think it’s important to understand technically what’s happening,” she says. “It can be really frustrating not knowing why it’s not looking the way you want it to look.” But Sekizawa’s gains from Lomeli’s technical expertise are complemented by her openness to creative experimentation with the gadgets he loves. 

Lomeli, who owns the rental house Ace Image, has access to almost any piece of gear imaginable, a luxury not all directors have. When he gets a new piece of gear, he’ll often coax Sekizawa to come up with a creative way for them to use it. One example, a slow-motion fashion video for LD Tuttle, began as an opportunity to test the PhantomFlex 4K, a high-speed camera that can capture HD footage at up to 1000 frames per second. 

They often work together on hybrid shoots, in which the client expects high-quality still and moving images from the same shoot. While such assignments can often involve separate crews and become logistical nightmares, their familiarity and fluent communication often solves many of the typical problems.

“We’re so familiar with each other that I can be in his space,” Sekizawa says. “We could be cheek-to-cheek [shooting] and it’s fine. I know when he’s about to flip a lens, and that’s when I go in and do a stills pass.”

Rather than devise two sets and lighting setups, Lomeli likes to “light the room and not the set.” It can take a little longer and cost a little bit more. “Instead of putting a lot of little lights, you’re putting big giant lights through the windows,” Lomeli explains. “But once you’re set, you can point the camera in almost any direction and, barring minor tweaks, you get a real consistent look, with both cameras, motion and still.” Lomeli says clients are often surprised by how effectively and efficiently they work on complicated jobs.

But when it comes to moving from shooting stills to directing videos, Lomeli doesn’t see that much difference between the roles of directors and photographers. 

“On higher-end photo sets, the photographer is pretty much a director,” he explains. “They rarely even touch the camera. They’re talking about location, the esthetic. They don’t care what lens is on, they just know what they want it to look like. They tell somebody and it gets done. To me, that makes sense. A director is somebody with a vision of what it is we’re trying to get. How to accomplish that? That’s why you have a team of people.”
