article.article_title: How Photographers Reinvent Their Careers
article.meta_description: Photographers explain how they re-charge batteries, renew their creative energy and spark, and move their careers in new directions.
article.meta_keywords: professional photographer, creative renewal, career makeover, personal work
article.article_text_abstract: Photographers explain how they re-charge their creative energy and move their careers in new directions in this collection of articles.
article.article_text:
For most photographers, careers wax, wane, and evolve. Sometimes the phone stops ringing, forcing a photographer to adapt to external changes such as market shifts, or clients' changing tastes. But photographers' interests can also change over time, compelling them to re-evaluate their work and creative direction. Either way, the transition can feel lonely, and stressful. The good news is, plenty of photographers have been through the process, and figured out ways to re-charge themselves and move their careers in new directions.

The October 2014 issue of PDN features profiles of several photographers who have used their personal work to re-brand themselves. One is James Wojcik, who says, "To feel good about yourself as a photographer, you have to make work you care about." In addition to those stories, here are several others from past issues of PDN that describe various ways photographers have reinvented themselves.

Career Makeover: Trading a Staff Job at Disney for a Freelance Advertising Career (for PDN subscribers)

Diana Zalucky relied on her resourcefulness and tireless work ethic to make a portfolio from scratch, build her name recognition and land big advertising assignments. 

Craig Cutler Just Keeps Shooting (for PDN subscribers)

The commercial photographer talks to PDN about an ambitious project that grew out of his sense of creative restlessness.

Veteran Food Photographer Jeff Kauck Changes With the Times (for PDN subscribers)

Chicago food photographer Jeff Kauck explains how he manages to keep busy in a highly competitive niche after 33 years in the business.

Personal Work that Lands Assignments: Shaniqwa Jarvis

Shaniqwa Jarvis began photographing guys in their apartments to work through a painful breakup, and to hone her photographic skills. It turned into a signature project called “This Charming Man” that jump-started her career.

School of Hard Knocks (for PDN subscribers)

Three photographers--Zack Arias, Chip Litherland, and Mark Katzman--tell us their stories about recovering from hardship, and the lessons it taught them.

James Worrell: Sketching Concepts for Editorial Clients to Gain the Attention of Ad Agencies (for PDN subscribers)

Every few years or so New York City-based photographer James Worrell reinvents himself in order to stay relevant in the market. In this story he explains how he did it most recently.

How to Introduce a New Specialty to Clients (for PDN subscribers)

Reps explain how photographers can prove expertise in new categories—without looking like a jack-of-all-trades and master of none.

Rebranding Through Personal Work

Four photographers explain how shooting and sharing the work they love to make helped them get work and communicate their identity as artists. 

David Yellen: From Corporate Offices to the Outdoors

Ryan Schude's Car Owner Portraits Open Up New Opportunities

Sasha Gulish: From a Little of Everything to Lifestyle Advertising

James Wojcik on Making Work You Care About

article.article_title: Picture Story: Love Radio Rwanda
article.meta_description: An ambitious multimedia project combines drama and documentary storytelling to explore Rwanda's lingering ethnic tensions and expose fault lines in post-genocide reconciliation.
article.article_text_abstract: An ambitious multimedia project combines drama and documentary storytelling to explore Rwanda's lingering ethnic tensions and expose fault lines in post-genocide reconciliation.
article.article_image_caption: Radio listeners from Rulindo, North tune in to hear an episode of Musekeweya, the long-running radio soap.
article.article_text:
Over a 100-day period starting in April 1994, a media hate campaign instigated by Rwandan Hutus fomented genocide against Rwandan Tutsis. More than 800,000 people died, and the brutality shocked the world. Twenty years later, Rwanda projects a narrative of reconciliation and forgiveness. But tensions persist below the surface, and two Dutch journalists—writer Eefje Blankevoort and photographer Anoek Steketee—have explored them through an ambitious Web-based multimedia project that mixes fictional drama with documentary images.

Called Love Radio, the project was inspired by a popular Rwandan radio soap opera called Musekeweya. The soap tells the story of conflict and reconciliation between two rival villages. Love Radio, the derivative (but independently produced) Web project, includes an “On Air” channel that recreates an abridged version of Musekeweya. For a second “Off Air” channel, Love Radio’s creators explore contemporary life in Rwanda to assess the country’s actual progress toward reconciliation. The Love Radio project also includes essays by journalists and academics to provide additional context.

Working in collaboration with an interactive design team and with grants from a variety of arts organization and the Dutch government, Blankevoort and Steketee created the Web project, plus a pared-down version for smartphone users. They’ve also turned the project into an interactive exhibition, which was displayed at the Foam museum in Amsterdam. As one of five winners of the 2014 POPCAP competition for contemporary African photography, Love Radio will also be part of an international traveling exhibition over the next year.

The roots of the project go back to 2008, when Steketee and Blankevoort were working on a project about amusement parks around the world. On their way to Rwanda for that story, they met with George Weiss, founder of La Benevolencija, a Dutch NGO working to empower groups that are targets of hate speech. La Benevolencija launched the Musekeweya radio soap in 2004 as entertainment. But its scriptwriters draw from academic theories about the origins of genocide to help prevent future violence and foster Rwanda’s process of reconciliation.

The two journalists ended up reporting a magazine story about the soap opera and its dedicated fans in 2008. “When we talked to people on the street, almost everybody knew about [Musekeweya], and started to shine when they talked about it,” Steketee says. “We were intrigued by the connection between the radio soap and daily life in Rwanda.”

They were also interested in the universal themes of Rwanda’s recent history: ideas of guilt and innocence, good and evil, the power of media, mob violence, individual and collective resistance, and trauma. “One of our goals was to bring this story to a western audience. It can function as a mirror for people. At the same time, it’s a story about Rwanda, and a complex process of reconciliation there. It’s not that everybody is reconciled now, and it was of interest [to us] to tell that.”

Beginning around 2010, Blankevoort and Steketee started thinking about producing a more in-depth story using audio “because it’s about a radio show. Then we thought, if we’re going to do audio, we should do video, too. It became bigger and bigger, and we decided to do a Web documentary,” Steketee says.

The plan percolated over several years, a few visits to Rwanda, and meetings with Musekeweya’s creators and actors. The inspiration for the “Off Air” component of the project came from a Musekeweya fan who called the radio station to say life was imitating art in his own village. “They were friends with a neighboring village, then everything went wrong, and his village attacked the other village,” Steketee explains.

The man’s village eventually became one of the settings of the “Off Air” channel of the Love Radio project. “We went many times” to interview people and film scenes of daily life in the villages, Stekeete says. “To provide context for the [On Air] story about the radio soap, you have to show a little of the daily reality—a very personal story of this [radio caller] and his neighbors.”

Realizing a Web-based multimedia project would require interactive design expertise, they teamed up with Sara Kolster, a designer and producer specializing in digital storytelling, and with Kummer & Herrman, an interactive design agency. Together, they began applying to foundations and agencies for production grants. “We wrote an extended application with technical details about the interface that was a book of its own—about 60 pages,” Steketee says.

Most of the filming for the project was done over a period of three weeks last year. “We worked with storyboards because we didn’t have much time. I was in my last trimester of pregnancy,” says the photographer. “We knew what we wanted to shoot, and who we wanted to interview.”

For the “Off Air” segments, she and Blakenvoort made a list of shots of daily life that they wanted to film. Those included landscapes, street scenes, domestic scenes and people gathered around their radios, plus behind-the-scenes shots of the Musekeweya actors re-creating an abridged version of the story for the Love Radio project. Steketee and Blankevoort used that footage as b-roll over interviews with village residents, and with some of the Musekeweya actors.

The challenge of the “On Air” channel was re-creating a 20-minute summary of a soap opera that had been airing for ten years. “There have been 30 different characters, all with complicated names, and many things have happened. We needed to bring the whole story back, and make it interesting to a western audience,” Steketee explains.

The narrative about two villages in conflict is interwoven with a story about two characters torn by their love for each other and their loyalty to their respective villages. “We picked out key scenes and key lines, and asked the actors to [dramatize] the lines again,” Steketee says. (They paid the actors their usual rates for the performances.)
Post-production took several months. Blankevoort and Steketee transcribed all the interviews and logged all the video files, then sorted the material by topics, such as freedom of speech, radio culture, reconciliation, scapegoating and other themes.

Producer/designer Sara Kolster suggested organizing the fictional “On Air” layer as episodes to reflect the episodic structure of Musekeweya, and pair them with “Off Air” segments. “We had to bring in a cliffhanger in every episode, which is difficult because we’re not dramatists,” Steketee says. For help, they consulted a scriptwriter, who also advised them to use an English- speaking narrator to help move the story along and keep the attention of Western audiences.

Steketee and Blankevoort took pains to highlight universal themes to appeal to an international audience. They also worked to keep the project accessible. “It should be intelligent and layered, but not too arty-farty or complicated,” Steketee says. “You can lose the impact if you put [in] too much information.” Deciding what to include and exclude was a topic of constant discussion, she adds.

The Love Radio project debuted on April 7, 2014—the 20th anniversary of the outbreak of the Rwandan genocide. On a bi-weekly schedule over a period of 100 days, Love Radio creators posted the entire project in seven installments.

Since then, the challenge has been to build the audience, Steketee says. “Traffic to the website is OK, but it could have been more,” she says. She’s hoping exhibitions of the project will help drive more traffic. Besides the POPCAP exhibitions and the Foam exhibition (mounted after Blankevoort and Steketee showed the completed project to curators at Foam), Steketee says “We’re working on extending the list” of exhibition venues.

article.article_title: How I Got That Grant: VSCO's Artist Initiative Program
article.meta_description: Visual Supply Company established a $1 million fund to fund and promote photographers. Three photographers explain how VSCO's support helped them complete their projects.
article.article_text_abstract: Visual Supply Company established a $1 million fund to fund and promote photographers. Three photographers explain how VSCO's support helped them complete their projects.
article.article_image_caption: Josh Wool won a VSCO grant to document Hudson Valley artisan communities using tintype processes.
article.article_text:
Since launching its Artist Initiative program last March, Visual Supply Co (VSCO) has awarded grants to support a variety of new projects by at least 14 artists, including nine photographers. The process is decidedly less-formal than that of most other photography grants. And so far, VSCO has awarded most of the grants to emerging photographers whose work straddles the boundary between documentary and fine-art photography.

Josh Wool, who left a career as a chef about two years ago to pursue photography full- time, recently won a VSCO Artist Initiative grant to use tintype methods to document artisan communities in New York’s Hudson Valley. VSCO also provided a grant to brothers Christopher and Jonathan Schoonover for a project about the glitz and ritual of semi- professional wrestling.

Established in 2011, VSCO offers digital- imaging tools and services. To build a customer base, the company has a free app for shooting and editing images called VSCO Cam. VSCO Cam users can share their images on the VSCO Grid, a curated social media site similar to Instagram, but with less clutter and noise.

The Artist Initiative program is backed by a $1 million scholarship fund meant “to honor art and artists by discovering, funding, advising and promoting creatives from all corners of the globe.” It is also intended to drive business by encouraging use of the VSCO Cam and VSCO Grid: Only those artists with VSCO accounts who actively use the VSCO Grid are eligible for the grants. And while grant recipients retain copyrights to their work, they are required to use the VSCO grid to document progress on their projects, and allow VSCO to publish their images in books, exhibitions and VSCO’s blog, called VSCO Journal. Proceeds from any book or print sales are split with the photographers.

Because VSCO is a private company managing its Artist Initiative program internally, the grant process isn’t transparent. Most of the AI program funding comes from Accel Partners, a venture capital firm that invested $40 million in VSCO last spring for product development and marketing. An Accel executive declined on the company’s behalf to answer PDN’s questions about the grant program, pending “small updates” to the program.

But VSCO’s website indicates that applications for the AI grants are judged by a team of VSCO employees on the basis of four criteria: a project’s potential for positive social and artistic impact; how unique and interesting the proposed project is; the proposed budget; and “evidence of passion, initiative and creativity” in the application.
There are no deadlines. Applications, which must be submitted online, are accepted and judged on a rolling basis. And they may be approved and funded in a matter of weeks, rather than months.

Brothers Chris and Jon Schoonover approached VSCO for support for their project about semi-pro wrestling last winter, shortly before VSCO announced the Artist Initiative fund. “My brother and I were talking about how awesome the pageantry of wrestling was,” says Chris Schoonover. “Wrestling is just the flashiest thing I could think of. It’s so gaudy, it’s beautiful. There’s a lot of glitter, showmanship and pageantry that goes into it. It’s amazing to see.” They needed money to produce the project, and assistance promoting it.

Chris Schoonover was a Web designer before he switched to photography about a year ago, and he met some VSCO staffers at the 100-50-1 charity exhibition of iPhone portraiture at the NWBLK gallery in San Francisco last November. Schoonover’s work was in the show; VSCO was one of the sponsors. So last January, Schoonover sent an email to his VSCO contacts describing the proposed project as a photojournalistic study. He explained that he and his brother would attend wrestling events and practices, create a large body of work and eventually turn it into a book and gallery show.

“I told them: We feel the project is going to be a hit, and we’d love to have VSCO be a part of it,” Schoonover says, adding that he asked for help editing and promoting the project, plus any other help that VSCO might be willing to offer as partners in a collaboration.

VSCO contacted the Schoonovers in April, Schoonover recounts. After a series of phone meetings the company asked them to come up with a budget, itemizing what they needed. Within a month, they had the funds in hand.
Schoonover declined to say how much money they got, but says, “We really didn’t ask for much. We take pride in running a bare- bones operation. It makes you work harder.” They had planned to travel to wrestling venues all over the country, but decided there were enough venues close to home in southern New Jersey. So they asked for gas money, travel money to bring some of the wrestlers to a studio in New York for portrait sessions, plus money for equipment, including a camera and several Canon 600EX-RT Speedlites.

Meanwhile, photographer Josh Wool says he pitched projects on three different topics via VSCO’s online application: Hudson Valley artisan communities, commercial fishing in the Carolinas, and musicians trying to eke out a living on concert tours around the country. He wrote four or five paragraphs about each idea, explaining the story, what made it timely and compelling, and what he would photograph if given a grant.

For the farmer/artisan idea, he explained how he’d become friends with a couple who raised sheep and rabbits on a small farm in the Catskills. In addition to supplying restaurants in New York City (they’d been one of Wool’s suppliers in his previous career as a chef ), they raised their own food and made their own clothing, ran a recording studio on the side, and were part of a like-minded community of farmers and artists.

“The more I looked into it, the more I found little communities like that popping up around the Hudson Valley,” Wool told PDN in a phone interview.

A week or two after he submitted his application, VSCO called him. “They really liked the farmers and artisans idea,” he says. It felt unique, and it was manageable for a first project because of Wool’s proximity to the Hudson Valley. “They asked me to present a budget.”

Wool’s proposed budget included line items for materials, including tintype plates. It also included travel costs: car rental, plus food and lodging for a month. In addition, Wool budgeted for two months’ worth of rent and living expenses in Brooklyn. “I took care of myself [in the proposed budget] for about a three-month period: a month to get ready, a month upstate, and a month for post-processing,” he says.

He submitted the budget on a Friday. By the following Tuesday, it was approved, and the grant money was in his account less than a week later. Wool finished shooting this summer, and is now working with VSCO to turn the project into a book, as well as an exhibition. “They’re going to pick up the production costs,” he says. Wool hopes to release the book in early December, in time for the holidays, and mount the exhibition by early 2015, provided he can find an exhibition space.

“I’m beyond grateful for having this [grant],” Wool says. “It was a great opportunity for me as an artist to really gain confidence, and to have somebody behind me who knows how to support [my project].”

article.article_title: Letting Go of the Camera: We Are The Rhoads and their go-to director of photography Tom Banks
article.meta_description: The husband-and-wife photography team We Are The Rhoads collaborates with the technically-saavy DP Tom Banks and his crew for video assignments.
article.article_text_abstract: The husband-and-wife photography team We Are The Rhoads collaborates with the technically-saavy DP Tom Banks and his crew for video assignments.
article.article_image_caption: An image from “California Dreaming” for Kinfolk, shot by We Are The Rhoads. When the duo is making videos for editorial clients, they prefer to work with DPs who have backgrounds in documentary film.
article.article_text:
Husband-and-wife team We Are The Rhoads began working with directors of photography when bigger brands with bigger budgets began calling on them for motion work. They wanted to take their directorial work, which they’ve done for clients such as Sony, Bose, Subaru, Dockers and Kinfolk, to “the next level,” Sarah Rhoads says, and operating the camera “limits how much you can throw yourself into the act of developing the story, directing talent, thinking through camera moves, scenes and overall art direction.” Working with a DP freed them up.

Collaborating with DPs has also helped them learn about both technical and creative aspects of filmmaking. For Chris Rhoads, “learning how to communicate more effectively” has been key, something they’ve learned through working with different DPs. Photographers typically aren’t asked to convey their ideas so that someone else can execute them, he points out.

“The practice of describing what you want results in a better, more identified and understood concept/idea in the end,” he explains. “Sometimes I wish I went to school for creative writing, because I feel like the use of adjectives” is important in expressing nuance and mood.

Once they’ve communicated an idea or concept to a DP, the pair also has found it educational to see how a DP approaches a shot technically. “There are a million ways to light a scene to achieve the desired goal,” Sarah Rhoads explains. “Working with a DP and his team of gaffers and grips, you always see interesting and new ways to light a scene to achieve the desired look and feel.”

They admit it was initially challenging for them to give the camera to someone else. “There was an element of relinquishing a certain amount of control,” Sarah Rhoads notes. But because they are used to working with each other and have seen projects elevated creatively through their collaboration, they understand that working with others “can result in even better final products,” Chris Rhoads says.

Sarah Rhoads advises that choosing the right DP for a job is important to getting the most of the director/DP partnership. “DP’s come in all different shapes and sizes; they have all different specialties and working styles.” When the duo is working on video projects for editorial clients, they tend to work with DPs who come from documentary film backgrounds because they are more comfortable with a looser, more naturally lit production. For broadcast work, “that requires extensive storyboarding and preplanning, and working in a lot of different environments with unique lighting situations,” so the Rhoads like to work with DPs from the feature film and commercial worlds.

DPs bring more than “a visual signature” to projects, Chris Rhoads adds. “Vibe and personality” are also important elements. They do best working with DPs who are “adaptable and flexible” when they want to try something that may veer from the storyboards on a project, and they also appreciate when a DP has his or her own opinions and ideas to contribute to the process, Chris Rhoads says.

The Rhoads met Tom Banks, a DP they’ve collaborated with on several motion assignments— including a recent campaign for Bose electronics— when they were working alongside a film director on a commercial set a couple of years ago. Banks is “technically very savvy, has a youthful energy and effervescence to him, and is a great collaborator,” says Sarah Rhoads. They also like the crew of gaffers and grips Banks works with.

Banks believes that a good director/DP partnership depends on the director’s ability to “balance knowing what they want with being open-minded and collaborative.

“I always find it valuable when a director can present specific references and annunciate details about what they are going for visually,” Banks says. With the Rhoads, he also values the fact that their collaboration has turned into a friendship. “Being able to work with talented people you can call your friends is really the holy grail of our jobs, so I’m really grateful to have the relationship.” 

Related: Letting Go of the Camera: Zen Sekizawa and Ernesto Lomelli's Technical Finesse 
Letting Go of The Camera: Frank Ockenfels 3 and DP Welles Hackett Bring Stills to Life

article.article_title: Step Ahead: Preserving Memories With Mylio
article.meta_description: The launch of Mylio, a new photo storage management system with image security.
article.meta_keywords: Mylio, photo storage, image security, photo organization.
article.article_text_abstract: Sponsored post: Mylio, an elegant new tool for photo storage, management and security, is launching at PhotoPlus Expo. We spoke with Joe McNally about the software's importance to both his professional and personal collection of imagery.
article.article_image_credit: Image of baby © Joe McNally/All other images courtesy of Mylio
article.article_text:
Mylio is a powerful new software tool that lets your photos do the talking. Simply stated, Mylio aims to solve the central dilemma facing photographers of all skill levels: how to find, organize and safeguard an ever-growing library of digital memories across all of our multiplying devices. From the professional photographer with a library of RAW files, to the casual snap-shooter hunting for an iPhone shot of the kids, Mylio’s software is intuitive and streamlined, allowing image-makers to focus on what truly matters: the photographs.

Joe McNally knows the value of photographic memories. In addition to his work as an acclaimed professional photographer, he’s a prolific speaker and educator within the photographic community. And like everyone else, he has personal memories to preserve alongside his professional output. For McNally, Mylio can help with both. When asked to select the most important image he’s taken in his storied career, he says, “I’ve photographed famous, beautiful people. Not to mention heads of state, movers and shakers and heroes of the athletic field. But none are as important to me as this one: my kid, trying to walk.”


Photo © Joe McNally

McNally’s daughter is now 28, and he says, “I’m very lucky to still have the negative. It is a piece of my memory that could have easily been lost.”

Today, millions of photographers have—through no fault of their own—put their own digital negatives at risk; photos are sprinkled among external hard drives, laptops and mobile devices. Mylio offers a home with easy organization and an elegant interface. From a unified view of your entire image collection, you can tag, arrange and make edits that will instantly propagate across all of your devices. Mylio can also judge which photos are unprotected according to its 3:2 principle (an image is protected when there are three copies made in two separate locations). Armed with this knowledge, you can quickly identify which photos need a little extra security.



For professional photographers, who require numerous backup copies, McNally says Mylio’s seamless approach across all registered devices is very appealing. For the rest of us, Mylio’s drive for elegance and simplicity will resonate.

See Mylio for yourself at mylio.com/getmylio, and if you're attending PhotoPlus Expo this week, stop by booth 273,

article.article_title: Cole Barash's "Talk Story" Explores Oahu's Famed North Shore
article.meta_description: Through the life of 21-year-old surfing phenom John John Florence, Cole Barash offers a counterpoint to the action imagery typical of Hawaii's notoriously insular surf community.
article.article_text_abstract: Through the life of 21-year-old surfing phenom John John Florence, Cole Barash offers a counterpoint to the action imagery typical of Hawaii's notoriously insular surf community
article.article_image_caption: Cole Barash centered his book on the North Shore of Oahu, Hawaii, around the family and daily life of one of its most famous citizens, phenom surfer John John Florence.
article.article_text:
Notorious. Fabled. Legendary. Fearsome. Read any story about surfing the North Shore of Oahu, Hawaii, and chances are one—or all—of those adjectives will make an appearance. Seven miles of white sand, world-class waves and generations of surfing mythology make it the sport’s undisputed Mecca.

Twenty-one-year-old surfer John John Florence was born on Oahu and grew up on the North Shore, with the world’s most coveted swells breaking in his backyard. It was as if LeBron James had grown up across the street from Rucker Park, or the Williams sisters spent their childhoods on the grounds of Wimbledon. At the age of three he was riding his own board; by 13 he was competing professionally and being profiled in The New York Times; and at 19 he became the youngest surfer ever to win the Triple Crown, the sport’s most prestigious competition.

Brooklyn-based photographer Cole Barash grew up surfing New England’s rocky coastline from the age of nine, a world away from that Pacific Elysium. Nevertheless, by the time he was a teenager, the significance of Hawaii’s North Shore had “been pounded into [his] head.” So when Barash saw an opportunity to make his first trip to the North Shore and work with Florence, he seized it.

“I wanted to shoot a project on the subculture of the North Shore, but I wanted to shoot it like it hadn’t been shot before,” explains the 27-year-old photographer. “So much high-level [surfing] action is shot there every year, and I wanted to turn 180 degrees from that and focus on what really makes North Shore what it is: the places and the people.” Barash self-published his book, Talk Story, and exhibited the work at Picture Farm Gallery in Brooklyn in July.

For Barash, the soft-spoken Florence would be the anchor of the work, an emotional center around which he could explore the insular beach community in all its roughly hewn beauty. Barash came up as a snowboarding photographer whose esthetic was partially defined by his documentation of the quieter moments during athletes’ travel and downtime. Shooting something more intimate than the typical surf porn that comes streaming out of Oahu would not be easy, though, as North Shore locals have a reputation for fiercely defending their turf from outsiders. Barash had never been there before and, as he puts it, it is “not a place that you can just show up and make demands.”

But connections are everything, and Barash knew someone who was in the process of making a film about Florence. Through his friend, he floated some of his ideas for the book by the young Hawaiian and crossed his fingers. Florence’s response was an enthusiastic yes. “He is also into photography,” Barash says, noting that the young surfer’s appreciation for the art form was one reason he agreed to participate. “He has a darkroom. He’s been shooting for three or four years and actually has an eye.”

Once on Oahu, Barash split his time between shadowing the Florence family—Florence has two brothers and was raised by a single mother—and going out on his own, looking for the things that the hordes of photographers on the island miss. He wanted to get photos of the locals others were either too ignorant to know about or too intimidated to approach, and to find a way to capture the more subtle beauty of a paradise that has been shot time and time again. He achieved the former by being “light on his feet,” respectful and unobtrusive. For the latter, he relied on instinct to bolster a stubborn determination not to settle for the obvious. While the hyper-masculine environment sometimes wore on him, Barash also came to understand the crucial role played by the community’s unwritten rules. “If not for the localism and Hawaiian pride, the North Shore would be filled with suburban development, with SUVs and mansions everywhere,” he says.

Talk Story was shot entirely on film, Barash’s medium of choice for his personal projects. “I mostly shoot on the [Mamiya 7 and Mamiya RZ 67], along with a couple point-and- shoots, because it’s a look I really like, and the depth of that Japanese glass is amazing. It’s the closest thing to a 4x5 without shooting 4x5,” he explains. “When I started shooting that camera four or five years ago, it really changed [my work]. The glass in the Mamiya is unlike any other medium format [camera].” Working exclusively with film also meant that Barash wasn’t able to see what he’d shot while he was on site, but he views that as a positive—being unable to preview his work helped him stay in the moment. In his mind, it’s all about “trusting your gut.” If he got home and felt he didn’t have the right images, he would have to go back.

When photographing Florence, Barash focused on everyday surroundings, domestic routines and family interaction. The result is a series of complex and compelling images of a manchild at play and at rest, contemplative portraits rich with texture and emotional resonance. These images simultaneously blend and clash with Barash’s vision of the environment itself: a shotgun marriage of rusting metal and marauding overgrowth, wide vistas and dirt roads. There is a rhythm to the work, the pulse of lives lived slowly, yet without reserve. A backyard littered with surfboards. Modest houses with their doors standing open. Pickup-truck beds, living- room couches and treehouses brimming with sun-soaked teenagers. 

From the beginning, Barash knew that he wanted to self-publish Talk Story. He didn’t want to compromise his vision of a highly personal work that would be meticulously designed. For assistance, he turned to graphic designer Tucker Phillips, whom he knew through a mutual interest in ’zines. Barash describes Phillips’ role as equal parts facilitator and devil’s advocate, saying their collaboration took the work to “another level.” Phillips admits that the project was a bit overwhelming at first, due to the sheer volume of quality images Barash had produced. While Barash edited and sequenced the photos, Phillips explored printing techniques and mocked up layouts. Eventually “we landed on a minimal design, mixed with unique printing techniques that would bring attention to the photos without overshadowing them,” Phillips recalls.

Although he is a successful commercial photographer, Barash makes it clear that his personal projects are paramount. Shooting something for himself (not an art director or client), the hunger to create something better than his last work, and his desire to leave his “stamp on the map” are what really drive him as an artist. Given that he calls surfing “my one outlet in life, something I have done since I was a grom and will do until I can’t breathe,” it is easy to understand why he wasn’t willing to put this project into a publisher’s hands. His love and passion for both his subject and medium is suffused into every part of this sublime book.

article.article_title: 7 iPad Portfolio Apps for Showcasing Your Images and Videos
article.meta_description: These useful portfolio apps range from the simple but effective to the feature-rich and highly customizable, and can help you share slideshows and videos on your iPad.
article.article_text_abstract: These useful portfolio apps range from the simple but effective to the feature-rich and highly customizable, and can help you share slideshows and videos on your iPad.
article.article_text:
As the iPad has matured as a tool for photographers showing their images and videos in portfolio meetings, so have the portfolio apps. Where once there were hastily coded offerings short on features, we now have a thriving marketplace. For less than the price of a single pro-lab 8x10 for your print portfolio, you can have a powerful program at your fingertips that will allow you to present your work in any way that you wish.

Here’s a round-up of some of the best portfolio apps available, ranging in price from $3 to $17. Most offer support for common image and video file formats. Each app highlighted here will present your images beautifully. Where they differ is in how files are loaded and synced to the iPad, which file types they support, how extensively they can be customized around your personal style and the amount of support offered by the developer.

Portfolio Pro for iPad
Slightly less-expensive than most of the other options here, Portfolio Pro for iPad is nonetheless a full-featured portfolio app.

Importing can be done from your iPad’s photo albums, Flickr or Dropbox. Portfolio Pro can also import directly from your Flickr Photostream and Flickr Sets and will even preserve your photos’ titles and descriptions. Using Dropbox, you can export and clone to multiple iPads. But unlike with some of the other apps, there is no automatic sync capability for Dropbox, so any changes to the master must be manually exported and imported to the other iPads. Portfolio Pro offers enough branding and design customization options to match your portfolio to your style, but not so many that it becomes complicated and confusing. Inserting your logo, choosing a start screen image, and changing color schemes are all quick and easy. One particularly useful feature is the app’s ability to easily hide galleries from view. You can have multiple portfolios for multiple purposes, and quickly choose which you want to show or hide. The developer has an active Twitter account, a Facebook page and a specific support-ticket area on their website.

PRICE: $9.99
INFO: nickkuh.com/portfoliopro

Portfolio for iPad
Portfolio for iPad has been a strong contender in the arena of photo-portfolio apps for several years, and the app’s developers have regularly released updates.

Aimed at working photographers, Portfolio allows for a significant amount of customization, as far as presentation and branding is concerned. You can upload images from your iPad’s photo albums, iTunes, Dropbox, Box, a URL or via the Mac Loader app. Portfolio can handle any image, video, or PDF file that the iPad supports. The iPad app is divided into three main sections: the manager (for gallery creation and content importing/organizing), the appearance customizer (where the interface colors, themes and behaviors are edited), and the viewer (where all content playback and browsing is done). A backup feature allows you to create different configurations for your portfolio or clone the same configuration to multiple iPads. The developer has an extensive user guide on its website and a support email address.

PRICE: $12.99 
INFO: ipadportfolioapp.com

Xtrafolio
The priciest of the apps listed here, Xtrafolio offers an extensive feature set. Importing is done via iTunes, Dropbox or the iPad’s photo library. All iPad-supported image, video and PDF files can be displayed. As part of the integration with Dropbox, you have the ability to make one iPad the “master” and then create multiple “slave” iPads that are clones. Any changes to the master portfolio will automatically populate on the slave iPads—a useful feature for bridal shows or busy portrait studios. Conveniently, Xtrafolio lets you create an unlimited number of folders and add unlimited images to each folder. It also supports nesting for folders within folders, giving you a significant number of organizational options and making it more practical to have a large portfolio.

Xtrafolio has a modern, stylish design that should serve any working pro well. Fonts, colors, layouts and backgrounds can all be adjusted. The customizable splash screen, logo, and text options help with branding. One particularly nice feature is the ability to have a watermark automatically added to your image if anyone wishes to email it from the app. The in-app help feature is not as thorough as it should be (and requires an Internet connection), but the developer has a more extensive user guide online, as well as Facebook, Twitter and email contact options.

PRICE: $16.99
INFO: xtrafolio.com

Foliobook
While creating Foliobook, the app’s creators worked with professional commercial photographers to great effect—it’s easily one of the most popular portfolio apps. But perhaps more importantly, they seem to have done a good job of listening to their customers; since Foliobook’s initial release, they have pushed regular updates and added features.

Foliobook offers extensive customization and styling options; when an app lets you change the color of the control buttons, you know it’s serious about customization. Branding options also abound; you can use a still image or video as the splash screen and overlay your logo on top of it. In fact, setting up Foliobook is a bit like building a Web page. You can even link videos from menu items rather than just placing them in a gallery, a nice touch for wedding studios that offer both photo and video packages. But keep in mind that using video on Foliobook requires a plugin ($1.99 in-app purchase). Foliobook can access your photo library or import via Dropbox. It can also import via your PhotoShelter account, a unique feature among its peers.

It may have a steeper learning curve than many of the other apps, but Foliobook also has extensive support options. With a large user guide, a community discussion forum, a help-desk ticket system, Twitter, Facebook and email, you won’t be at a loss for assistance.

PRICE: $12.99 
INFO: rocketgardenlabs.com

Minimal Folio
Many of the apps in this list are quite fancy, with as many integrations and customizations as one could need. But sometimes photographers just need a simple app to show off their work. Minimal Folio is that app.

When you first open the app, a quick tutorial guides you through the setup process and images are organized on a grid. You use columns to group related images, then move through that group with an up/ down swipe. Left/right swipes move you between columns and thus through your different groupings. You can copy from your camera albums, import from iTunes or sync to a Dropbox account. Minimal Folio can display iPad-supported images, videos and PDFs, and reordering images is as simple as a drag-and-drop. While there is no splash-screen branding, the app loads quickly and always takes you to the first image of your project, so it can pull double-duty as a title or branding slide. The in-app help feature is useful, and the developer has Facebook and email contact info available on their website.

PRICE: $2.99
INFO: www.simonheys.com/minimalfolio

Padfolios 
Creator Juan Pablo Mazuera, a Colombian photographer, showcases his knack for design and app development in his portfolio app Padfolios. An avowed Apple fan, he was one of the first people in Colombia to get his hands on an iPad back in 2010. But as a photographer and designer, he was disappointed in the tools he had available to use his iPad as a digital portfolio, so he set about creating Padfolios.

Importing is done exclusively through the iPad’s photo library. Padfolio’s layout is not extensively customizable, but looks clean and professional without being excessively minimal. Backgrounds and text allow for branding and personalizing, and text and line colors are infinitely adjustable through the use of RGB sliders—a nice touch. It’s convenient that Padfolios saves your changes automatically, as it can be frustrating to be forced to click “save” after every adjustment. Padfolios is designed to showcase images only, which can be a drawback if you have videos to display. On the flipside, Padfolios is a universal app that will run on both the iPad and the iPhone/iPod Touch. The app’s help file is simple but covers all of the basics, and Mazuera has Twitter, Facebook and email contact options on his website for additional help.

PRICE: $14.99
INFO: padfolios.me/home.html

Mediapad Pro
Mediapad Pro’s strengths include its simplicity and the ability to handle multimedia files. Images, video, audio, HTML and more are supported, and the app may just have the simplest adjustment tools for a slideshow function. Photos are imported through iTunes or from your iPad’s photo library. A custom homepage banner, portfolio banners and custom backgrounds are also supported. Aside from that, only minor color and font theme changes are customizable. The app’s developers have a handy introduction video that quickly runs through the basics of using Mediapad Pro, but it’s hosted on YouTube and thus unavailable offline from within the app. Mediapad Pro is still a very handy budget option for those who want a basic portfolio app for different types of media, but caveat emptor—there doesn’t appear to be an active support site, or any contact info for the developers.

PRICE: $6.99 
INFO: www.medlmobile.com/apps/ipad/mediapad-pro

article.article_title: Client Meeting: The Chronicle of Higher Education
article.meta_description: The Chronicle of Higher Education is a publication aimed at university professionals and relies on photographers all over the country to breath life into stories about the Ivory Tower.
article.article_text_abstract: The Chronicle of Higher Education is a publication aimed at university professionals and relies on photographers all over the country to breath life into stories about the Ivory Tower.
article.article_image_caption: A Mark Abramson image of an Occupy Wall Street demonstration at Baruch College, for a news story about students protesting tuition increases.
article.article_text:
Whether shooting editorial portraiture, chronicling a critical social issue, or reporting a news story, one of the biggest challenges a photographer can face is to make a compelling photograph of a subject that is not inherently visually interesting. Finding creative ways to do just that is key for the freelance photographers working for The Chronicle of Higher Education, a Washington, DC-based publication that prints news, job opportunities and opinion pieces for people working in academia. A physicist winning an award or a group of students in a university classroom are not necessarily the sexiest subjects, but the photographers who work for The Chronicle have to make compelling images each week by thinking creatively and being quick on their feet. 

Photo editor Rose Engelland and assistant photo editor Erica Lusk hire more than 20 photographers each month from their evolving database of over 1,000 international freelancers. “We look for photographers who take something that would be ordinary and run with it,” explains Lusk. “We assign a lot of what would seem like uninteresting shots on the surface, but can be taken up a notch by the right photographer.” 

The topics The Chronicle covers range widely, from student protests, to regulations that allow the National Collegiate Athletic Association (NCAA) to enforce concussion prevention guidelines in college sports, to interviews with the likes of Bill Gates, who discussed his views on education. Because The Chronicle doesn’t have a budget for travel expenses, they hire photographers based in whatever location they’re covering—whether that be Toronto or Dubai. 

As a result, Engelland and Lusk are able to work with a wide variety of photographers and can handpick talent according to what they are envisioning for any given story. They haven’t always met the photographers they work with and have to rely on what they see on websites and in portfolios to decide if a photographer is a good fit for a job. “I’m very sensitive to the way a website is organized,” says Engelland. While she enjoys looking at fine-art projects, what she is really looking for is a shooter’s commissioned work—editorials and documentary photographs, for example. “They might have a very funky approach to shooting a dozen eggs, but I need to know that if they meet a scientist, they can bring his research alive in an image,” she explains. 

The Chronicle updates daily online and receives more than 1.9 million unique visits per month. The print publication goes out to more than 64,000 subscribers every week. Although the publication covers international stories like the influx of Chinese students into American universities, or the psychology of violence in regions such as Bosnia, most of its readership is based in the United States or Canada. 

Lusk and Engelland both tackle different sections. Engelland, who has been at The Chronicle for more than 30 years, takes care of the international assignments—for these stories, she usually hires one photographer a week—as well as all of the images in The Chronicle Review, a weekly magazine insert that includes opinion pieces and stories about art, culture and literature. “Some of the opinion pieces can get really heady,” Engelland says. Her job is to humanize the stories, no matter how intellectual they are, by providing images that the reader can connect to. She typically commissions a cover story and the occasional portfolio inside the magazine. Roughly 60 percent of the images she uses are stock photographs, with the other 40 percent assigned to photographers or photo illustrators.

Lusk, who came to The Chronicle six years ago from The Washington Post, hires at a much more robust pace for the newspaper and for the website. Generally, she commissions stories from five to seven shooters per week during the school year. Those jobs vary from portraits to photo essays to documentary images. Engelland says The Chronicle pays a competitive day rate and covers local transportation and expenses.

When Lusk is talking with photographers with whom she hasn’t previously worked, she usually asks see an un-edited shoot, in addition to their standard portfolio, to get a sense of how they’re seeing on an assignment. “It’s not always well-received,” she laughs.

In the past 18 months, Lusk and Engelland have ventured into commissioning video stories around topics such as untenured adjunct professors; a college president who was recently tasked with the burden of selling his institution; and how the 9/11 attacks influenced higher education. The 9/11 video profiled professionals and students involved in the aftermath of the attacks. It included Alexis Glenn, now a photographer at George Mason University, who was in her second day of photojournalism classes when she photographed the burning Pentagon, and Chaplain Sanaa Nadim, a counselor of the Muslim community at the State University of New York, Stony Brook. The assignment went to Mark Abramson, a New York-based multimedia journalist and photographer originally from Russia who produces, on average, two stories a month for The Chronicle. 

Abramson says that The Chronicle is his favorite client to work with and that Lusk is always open to creative ideas. “She doesn’t hire freelancers because they know how to shoot a photograph—she hires them for their eyes,” he explains. “She loves seeing an edit with quirky compositions.” 

Initiative is also important. Both Abramson and Matt Roth, a Baltimore-based photographer who has contributed to The New York Times, The Wall Street Journal, AARP and USA Today, travelled to The Chronicle’s D.C. offices to meet with Engelland and Lusk. “I’m sort of old-school in the sense that it helps a lot if a photographer meets us in person,” confesses Engelland. “I like to get a sense of how nimble they are, and how they think.” Neither editor is partial to any particular medium for viewing a portfolio—they’ve seen them on iPads, laptops and multimedia presentations, as well as in print. 

Both editors were impressed with Roth, because they could immediately tell he was not a rote thinker. They have since hired him to shoot a number of essays for them, including a moving piece on Ron Shriver, a retired marine staff sergeant who is the first in his family to attend college, thanks to the new G.I. Bill. “With The Chronicle, I feel like I have a lot of freedom to be creative,” explains Roth, who ended up capturing Shriver not only as a student and former soldier, but also as an attentive and loving father. 

The Chronicle encourages photographers to run with their assignments. For example, Abramson was assigned by Lusk to photograph Occupy Wall Street protests at Baruch College, but found himself in the middle of a skirmish when campus police beat up a group of students. “I was in contact with Erica the whole time, getting feedback,” he says. “She gave me the bread and butter, and then she allowed me to go play.” Lusk ended up running a full spread of his images in Section A. “[Lusk and Engelland] are just open to ideas,” Abramson elaborates. “They want me to shoot a scene how I see it—not how it’s supposed to be.”

article.article_title: Ryan Schude's Car Owner Portraits Open Up New Opportunities
article.meta_description: Photographer Ryan Schude's series "Them and Theirs," a look at people and their vintage cars, has helped him tap into the car photography market.
article.article_text_abstract: Photographer Ryan Schude's series "Them and Theirs," a look at people and their vintage cars, has helped him tap into the car photography market.
article.article_image_caption: Ryan Schude photographed Zack Stratis and his 1976 Mercedes 300D in Glendale, California, as part of his personal series “Them and Theirs”.
article.article_text:
Ryan Schude started making portraits of people with their vintage cars as a way to take a break from his signature high production value work. As a result, he’s been able to tap into the car photography market, bidding on and landing commercial jobs, and he’s also received a ton of press for the series, titled “Them and Theirs.”

The Los Angeles-based photographer is best known for his elaborately lit cinematic tableaux, which frequently involve large groups of models. “Them and Theirs” gave him a chance to work on a simpler documentary-style project that also incorporates some of his production know-how. Many of the portraits are straightforward, but if his subjects are willing, he’ll work with them on more stylized “wacky concepts.” “I’m not good in the streets at approaching strangers, so it gave me access into a more documentary world. But I could take my time with it and still work with the subjects to really plan an elaborate shot,” Schude explains.

A recent image shot from above shows an owner lying on top of her powder blue 1963 Ford Falcon. In another shot of production designer Adi Goodrich with her 1988 Chevy Cavalier wagon, Goodrich stands on the hood and roof of the car, while huge ribbons of red fabric flow through the scene.

Schude began the series after he moved to LA, which is famous for its car culture. He photographed friends with their cars, and eventually the series grew to the point that he was getting referrals and requests from people who wanted to participate. He also leaves postcards with an image from the series on the windshields of cars he’d like to photograph, with a note to the owner about the project and his contact info. Schude says he has a lengthy list of people to shoot. “I’ve been doing at least one or two a month when I have time away from work,” he says.

While he didn’t start the series thinking it could land him ad assignments involving cars, it didn’t take long for him to realize there was a commercial application for the work. First Wieden + Kennedy in New York called, asking to see his car photographs, and then he published one of the images in Angeleno magazine. He bid on Toyota jobs through Saatchi & Saatchi, and then Slate published an article about his series, leading to a number of online and print publications picking it up. The images, which he’s promoted primarily through social media and email, have also won recognition from PX3 and the World Photography Awards.

“It’s now so obvious [to me] that there’s an application [for] it commercially,” Schude says, noting that the car industry is using more and more lifestyle work.

One of the biggest commercial jobs to result from the work wasn’t for a car company, but it did require that he photograph a car. For an ad for Samsonite, commissioned by Saatchi & Saatchi in Belgium, Schude photographed a couple on the road in a vintage Porsche with a suitcase that has broken away from the luggage rack, smashing into the foreground.

Schude has also shot smaller social-media jobs for Volkswagen and Honda through Edelman in New York, and has offered to shoot portraits in the vein of the series on spec for agencies with car clients. “Creatives want to do something like this because it’s relatable” and different from standard car work, Schude posits. He’s even had one creative director ask to be photographed with his own car for the series.

As he continues the work, Schude wants to include owners of modern cars in the series, “and find a way to still make it look cool and fun,” he says. One of his favorite shots was of a friend and his Prius, which Schude made on spec when he was bidding on a job for Toyota.

“Everyone knows someone who has a [cool] car, or they have one and they want to be shot,” Schude says of the interest in the series. “It’s funny how they get excited about it. It makes sense, if they are going to spend this amount of time and effort [maintaining] a classic car, they probably want to be shot with it.”

Related: David Yellen: From Corporate Offices to the Outdoors
James Wojcik: On Making "Work You Care About"

article.article_title: Sasha Gulish: From a Little of Everything to Lifestyle Advertising
article.meta_description: A year ago Sasha Gulish was shooting food, travel and portraits; then she hired a consultant to help redefine her brand through her personal work.
article.article_text_abstract: A year ago Sasha Gulish was shooting food, travel and portraits; then she hired a consultant to help redefine her brand through her personal work.
article.article_image_caption: A test shot by Sasha Gulish recreating a moment in her own life she captured and posted on Instagram.
article.article_text:
A year and a half ago, Sasha Gulish was shooting a few different things: travel, food and portraits. Relying on repeat business and word of mouth, the San Francisco-based photographer was busy with editorial assignments and pharmaceutical advertising, but she felt her work was unfocused. Friends would tell her she should be trying to land ad assignments with higher profiles, but she didn’t know how. When she decided to treat herself to a photo workshop taught by Norman Jean Roy at the Santa Fe Workshops, she had an epiphany. Before the workshop, Roy asked participants to fill out a detailed questionnaire that included a question about their goals for the future. Gulish recalls thinking, “I don’t want to have any regrets.” If she wanted to change her career, she decided, “I don’t want to look back and say I didn’t try.”

So the photographer asked her friends for help. Nick Onken and Sarah Rhoads of the photography duo We Are The Rhoads recommended consultants Amanda Sosa Stone and Suzanne Sease. Stone and Sease agreed to work with her, and Gulish sent them “thousands of images” that she considered to be her best work, including personal and assignment work of every type. The consultants selected a few that stood out, images that Gulish had shot in her spare time. They showed her son—not yet two years old when she first began working with Stone and Sease—and family and friends in unguarded candid moments. The selections formed the seed of a portfolio she could pitch to advertising clients looking for authentic lifestyle imagery.

“It was cohesive as a body of work,” Gulish says, but she had overlooked it among all the images she was shooting at the time. “I feel like sometimes we obsess and get stuck editing our own images. It was nice to let go and have someone with fresh eyes tell me what they see in my work.” Gulish, who studied photography at Art Center College of Design in Pasadena, CA, realized in hindsight that for too long she thought that when making work for herself, she should shoot images that seemed serious or artful. “I realized I enjoyed photographing the joyful, happy moments because they’re beautiful. There’s nothing not arty about that.”

Gulish and the consultants agreed there were holes in her portfolio that she needed to fill. To get more photos of older kids, teens and a wider mix of families, she set up test shots with friends, cousins and models she found through modeling agencies or Craiglist. Once she had demonstrated a knack for putting first-time models and kids at ease, agencies were happy to work with her to produce images for the models’ books and her own. When she shoots personal work, Gulish often takes inspiration from her own family life. One image she calls “Stinky Baby” shows a friend—childless in real life—posing with a diapered baby held at arm’s length, recoiling from the scent of the diaper. She made the image into a postcard she uses as a leave-behind when she meets with creatives.

She completed the overhaul of her website in 2012 and signed with rep Kim Knight that September. By December she was getting requests to bid on lifestyle ad assignments, and by February 2013 she had shot ads for Coors Light, Similac and PediaSure while she was pregnant with her second child.

Shooting images she loves has made self-promotion a pleasure rather than a chore. She faithfully emails new work to clients every six to eight weeks; after she photographed her baby and four-year-old destroying her home office, for example, she turned the image into an email promo she sent to clients at tax time. “I’m not doing it because I think, ‘uh-oh, I need to send out a postcard,’ I’m thinking, ‘oh, this is hilarious.’” The images she shares on her Instagram and Tumblr are now focused on moments from her life.

When bidding on a job, she pulls images from her archive or shoots new tests to show the style and approach she would take. She sends these to clients in PDFs, adding a letter explaining what she likes about the campaign and how she plans to bring it to life. She also tries to set up meetings with creatives whenever possible. “I think it’s important to meet creative and art buyers in person. People like to work with people they are comfortable with.”

On creative calls, she regularly hears, “We love the realness of your photos.” Her constant testing has taught her to get believable moments fast, even within the artifice of commercial shoots. When Barilla recently hired her to shoot ads for their protein pasta, she had only a short time to photograph a restless kid for one shot. In another she had to capture a relaxed family dinner— with a group of models who had never met before. “In order to capture real moments, I have models get to know each other on set so the real moments can happen while I’m shooting,” she says. “Otherwise, it would feel staged and inauthentic.” On the Barilla shoot, she got the models laughing and talking.

Though the commercial assignments have been coming in at a steady clip, she always makes time to shoot personal work. “I was working nonstop for about six weeks. I told my rep I need to be home for about a week, because that inspires me,” she says. “Going to the grocery store, potty training, being sleep-deprived. No matter how busy I am, I always need to be photographing those times.”

Related: Ryan Schude's Car Owner Portraits Open Up New Opportunities
