article.article_title: David Yellen: From Corporate Offices to the Outdoors
article.meta_description: Corporate portrait photographer David Yellen used personal work to rebrand himself as an outdoor shooter.
article.article_text_abstract: Corporate portrait photographer David Yellen used personal work to rebrand himself as an outdoor shooter.
article.article_image_caption: David Yellen landed an assignment shooting portraits of Maine lobster fisherman for Downeast after he made time to shoot the kind of minimally lit, outdoorsy images he had wanted to shoot.
article.article_text:
Last spring, corporate portrait photographer David Yellen was so eager to change direction, he says, “that I wished I could have changed my name, because when people think of ‘David Yellen,’ they think of old white guys on gray seamless, and I was like, ‘Oh, God. I’m 41. I’m too young to be that guy.”

He didn’t change his name, but he’s on the road to re-making his career. He is using personal work to show clients the kinds of portrait assignments he wants to shoot, and to show off his new minimalist lighting style. It’s beginning to pay off. Recent assignments include photographing a shark-fishing tournament for Field & Stream; portraits of lobster fishermen (and women) for Downeast magazine; and portraits of a stunt woman for Ink magazine.

“I want my photography to be an adventure,” says Yellen. “I want to experience something, I want to meet people I wouldn’t have met.” Rather than photograph executives in offices, he says, “I’d much rather be on a wharf with an old crusty guy telling me about how he used to make boats, or in the woods hunting something.”

Yellen’s enviable success as a corporate photographer has made re-branding himself difficult. His career “went from 0 to 100” when he quit assisting in 2001. He was soon shooting for SPIN, ESPN, New York and others. Photo editors took him from one publication to the next as they changed jobs; he eventually found himself shooting for Forbes and Fortune.

By 2011, though, the excitement was gone, and he was no longer enjoying it as much. But with a family to support, “I had to keep going,” he says.

Looking back, Yellen says his problem with corporate work was that he’d simply fallen into it. “I wasn’t specific about what I wanted to shoot,” he says. “But eventually I wanted to shoot stuff that I was more interested in.”
About three years ago, his wife got a job, which “gave me room to breathe,” he says. He started taking risks on assignments, shooting subjects the way he wanted to, in addition to shooting them the way clients wanted. His lighting style, he explains, “got too complicated over the years,” giving his pictures a surreal look. He continued to shoot assignments that way, but also made shots of his subjects using just one strobe and available light.

To Yellen’s surprise, 90 percent of the time his clients chose the simpler images, and he started getting even more work.

Around that time, while shooting corporate portraits for Discovery Channel, he showed the client pictures from a tuna fishing trip he’d been on. “Within two weeks they called me to a shoot a poster for a fishing show. That put me on the road to: This is what I want to do.”

Yellen knew he’d have to start shooting personal work to show clients the kinds of subjects he was interested in shooting. But he hadn’t shot any personal projects in years, and the voices of self- doubt—“Maybe your vision is not good, maybe it’s going to suck”— paralyzed him for two years.

Last year, he decided to take a leap. He had kept a notebook of project ideas; one was to photograph a demolition derby. “I said, ‘OK, I’m going to do this. And I loved the way the pictures turned out,” he recounts, explaining that he shot portraits of drivers with their cars in addition to documentary images.

Then he moved on to other projects on his list. Last summer, he and his wife rented a farm in Sweden for a few weeks, inviting friends to tag along. He would shoot portraits after dinner every night at sunset with a single studio light, he says, posting the pictures on Instagram. Before he’d returned from Sweden, he was getting calls for assignments. “I thought, OK, I’m onto something here.”

Yellen then set about rebuilding his online portfolio. Jennifer Kilberg, a photography consultant and a friend of Yellen’s, helped him edit his personal work. He ditched his old website, which was too slow and difficult to update, and put his new portfolio on Photoshelter in January. He’s also posted new personal work on his Tumblr, and continues to update his portfolio with new images.

To get word out to clients, Yellen is mailing postcards and sending bi-monthly email promos through Agency Access. “For the first one I went really wide to see who was interested and who opted out, then I refined it.”

Clients are calling now, but Yellen was initially discouraged when the first promo landed “like a thud.” But he also tries to get meetings with every client who clicks through the email promo to his website. After each meeting, he leaves behind a 30-page Blurb book of his images.

Yellen continues to shoot corporate portrait assignments, and says he’ll never shut the door on that work. He just hopes to reduce them to about 15 percent of his business, “and make the rest interesting environmental portraits.”
Reflecting on how difficult it was to get the courage to change direction, Yellen says, “Changing your style is like going to rehab. You have to be ready for it. You have to wear the other [old style] out hard.”

article.article_title: Tips From Editors on Making Better Video
article.meta_description: Experienced editors discuss the mistakes inexperienced filmmakers sometimes make, and what they wish directors understood about what can and can't be fixed in the edit.
article.article_text_abstract: Experienced editors discuss the mistakes inexperienced filmmakers sometimes make, and what they wish directors understood about what can and can't be fixed in the edit.
article.article_image_caption: Still from the band Paramore’s “Ain’t It Fun” video; color-correction, visual effects and finishing by Stephen Venezia and Dan Giraldo’s Nimblefox Productions.
article.article_text:
You’ve wrapped principal photography on your video. Now it all comes down to the edit; assembling all the pieces to make a compelling, cinematic narrative.

Many photographers who have moved into motion work say that they learned the most about how to shoot video while trying to edit their own work, or by working closely with video editors. Their feedback on technical mistakes, the types of footage they were missing and how to best to organize their clips can be crucial to understanding how to approach a video project.

We asked some experienced editors to provide insights into their work and some advice for new directors.

PROVIDE ENOUGH COVERAGE, AND A VARIETY OF IT.
For photographers used to capturing decisive moments, the biggest adjustment when shooting video is learning what to shoot; the goal is to provide the editor with the footage they need to weave together multiple clips with smooth transitions. Photographers used to looking only for the best compositions need to learn how to shoot the same scene in many ways while keeping the look consistent.

“I like working with photographer/directors,” says Raphael Rice, who edited Seeds of Hope, a documentary for the non-profit World Vision directed by photographer-turned-director Josh Victor Rothstein. “They have a good eye, and as an editor it makes my job easier to work with good shooters because the footage is more likely to be usable. But it’s not automatic.”

Some photographers may not be used to finding and making use of multiple angles. Rice says, “A good shooter can make it seem like there were two cameras in the room by shooting from two different angles. In order to do that, they have to understand how angles work narratively, how close or how far they have to be, so as to feel like it is still the same scene even though the two shots are from different moments.”

As an example, Rice notes, “After the main conversation is captured, if I get some coverage of a conversation from an angle where I don’t see the subject’s lips moving, that will be very useful as a cutaway.” A cutaway—footage inserted into the flow of continuous action—can be used to avoid abrupt jumps by the subject. Seeds of Hope, for example, features an interview with actor and World Vision spokesperson Hugh Jackman, shot with the camera placed close to the subject and then further away, on a different angle. Rice pieced together footage from each angle seamlessly, intercutting footage of Jackman on his way to testify at the United Nations.

He adds, “The director has to have a sense that they have gotten enough... synced conversation, and while that conversation is still going on, at risk of not capturing the subject’s face when something important is said, they will move to a new angle and get some good cutaways. The shooter has to be thinking on many levels to pull that off.”

GET THE BEST AUDIO YOU CAN.
“Focus on getting clean sound, because that will make a bad film seem better,” Rice says. Checking sound quality and audio levels while also shooting and directing is difficult, so many editors recommended working with a good crew that includes an audio engineer.

To get high-quality sound, directors and their crew typically choose to use an external recording device rather than record sound directly to the camera. That creates an additional problem: syncing audio with visuals. “I’ve actually been handed a lot of footage that is not slated. Getting raw footage and un-slated audio files is my worst nightmare,” says Stephen Venezia, a director and editor at Nimblefox Productions. Venezia, who has worked on music videos for Paramore (directed by Sophia Peer) and Girl Talk (directed by Allen Cordell), says, “Sometimes I’ll have to sit down with five hours of talking heads and have no idea which audio files belong to which video files.”

When recording interviews, Venezia recommends noting the take and subject, and always using a clapboard. If you’re not using an electronic clapboard or slating app, write down the timecode on your digital recording device, or call out the take and subject at the start of the recording. If you’re paying an editor by the hour, syncing the audio saves money.

DIRECT FOR ACTION, NOT COMPOSITION.
“Sometimes when I get footage from a photographer moving into video, I tend to notice that the model—or whoever they’re shooting—might be a little more rigid,” says Venezia. It’s a problem an editor can’t fix. Learning to direct subjects with an eye for body language and emotion takes practice; good video casting also helps. Before attempting to work with actors, he says, “I think people need to understand how to direct for video as opposed to just for photos.”

DON’T LOSE SIGHT OF THE STORY YOU’RE TELLING.
There’s a lot to remember when shooting multiple takes from multiple angles. The goal, however, is not so different than when shooting stills: to communicate a story. Stephen Mlinarek, who edited a video for 2b bebe (directed by fashion photographer Brooke Nipar), says photographers already know how to capture mood, tell a story, and communicate a client’s message. “Making the leap from one medium to the other, it’s easy to forget that your goals are the same when caught up in how simultaneously exciting and difficult the prospects of film production are,” he says. His advice: “Remember what you’re trying to say.”

Venezia observes, “I think that people who might be unfamiliar with video tend to shoot a lot of content and then just hand it to an editor and say, ‘Assemble this.’” Directors need to pre-visualize all the material they want. Storyboards can guide the shoot; they’re also useful when it’s time to explain the story to the editor. Venezia recommends designating a note-taker during shoots, marking which takes worked and which ones had technical problems or audio flubs.

UNDERSTAND WHAT IT WILL TAKE TO DO THE JOB.
“There’s an expectation some newbies have about what can be achieved that isn’t realistic within their content, budget or timeline,” says Mlinarczik. He advises directors, “It’s far more beneficial to ask me what’s possible instead of telling me what you think I should be able to do within a given period of time.”

Depending on the video format you choose and the editor’s software, the editor may need to convert or transcode the video files. In planning a budget and schedule for a job, Rice says, “I like to build in a tech day” devoted simply to organizing and prepping all the files.

The most time-consuming part of an editor’s job is reviewing all the footage. “More footage is more time. It doesn’t matter if you want a 30-second piece; if you hand me ten hours of footage, it’s going to be a long edit,” Rice says.
He adds, “The more you can do to be organized—narratively, technically—the happier I am.”

Related: Frames Per Second: How Storyboarding Can Make Your Video More Cinematic
Frames Per Second: Create Smooth Video and Tracking Shots on the Fly (And On a Budget)

article.article_title: James Wojcik: On Making "Work You Care About"
article.meta_description: 30-plus-year veteran James Wojick pours himself into his personalized promotions, and his clients are paying attention.
article.article_text_abstract: The boxed set of 50 postcards, which include the URL of the website he created just for his oyster project.
article.article_text:
James Wojcik has almost as much acclaim for the promotional mailers he’s created during his 30-plus-year career as he has for the still lifes he shoots for Vogue Brazil, Target, Nike, H. Stern, Bacardi, Town & Country, Departures and other editorial and commercial clients. He’s crafted posters, booklets and decks of cards, but each has shared a different project that he’s thrown himself into with enthusiasm. Says Wojcik: “To feel good about yourself as a photographer, you have to make work you care about.”

He doesn’t plan the promotions as a way to land specific types of work, he says. Photographers need different promotions at different times of their careers. If you “want to make a splash,” he says, send an email blast or mail a poster. For Wojcik however, crafting printed promotions is a means of “creating something with my hands” and showing work that reflects his passions. “I want to create a series of photographs that...I can look at 5, 10, 15 years later in my life,” he says. It’s not a marketing strategy he recommends to every photographer, “but for me, it’s a natural path,” he says. “I’m trying to get attention, but I also want to represent who I am as a photographer.”

The impact his personal series have on potential clients is hard to quantify, he says, but he knows that they’re memorable. Three years ago, a creative director Wojcik was working with complimented him on his deck of cards that showed images of alphabet shapes he had sculpted out of cardboard and simple objects. Wojcik had mailed the promotion in 1990. Clients still talk about the booklet he made four years ago from his Wo-Brands series: garishly lit images showing packaging of well known American brands (Hawaiian Punch, Lucky Strike, Budweiser) with logos he had remade, inserting the first syllable of his last name. The promos he likes have “a little reality, a fantasy or alternative world, [or] humor,” he says. “To me, it’s everlasting if you can touch on many emotions.”

His newest promotional effort “represents all that I’ve been trying to do with promos.” It centers on Wojcik’s latest obsession: the oysters he’s raised near his vacation home on Shelter Island, New York. Some of the hundreds of images he’s shot of oysters—shucked, unshucked, cooked and plated or fashioned into sculptures with plastic eyes on them—are hosted on a website he made for the fictional Dinah Rock Oysters Company. He’s also turned 50 of the images into a boxed set of postcards.

Wojcik began raising oysters four years ago after completing a course at the Suffolk County Project in Aquaculture Training in Southold, New York. “I wasn’t going to photograph them. I grew them because they’re fun,” he says. But his fascination inspired him to look at them photographically. “Then I realized these things are kind of ugly,” Wojcik says. He liked the challenge of making compelling images from something that “looks like a rock.”

After harvesting some oysters, he would spread them out on a sheet on the dock, or bring them into his studios on Shelter Island and in Manhattan to photograph them in a variety of ways, against different backdrops. “I think you want to keep going back to shooting things over and over again so you can find subtle differences or layers,” he says.

(Wojcik ate his subjects. “After an hour of shooting, I’d have maybe 40 oysters on ice and then usually fry them up.”)

After two years, Wojcik had shot hundreds of images and decided to create a separate website linked to JamesWojcik.com. He created a fictional company— the aforementioned Dinah Rock Oysters, named after a rocky ledge in the bay near his home—and registered the website domain last year. Wojcik and his digital tech selected images and roughed out Web pages for categories such as “Right Valve,” “Left Valve,” “Culling and Sorting” and “Recipes.” The behind-the-scenes images of Wojcik and his crew sorting and photographing the oysters were placed on a page he titled “Dr. O and Co. at Work.” He asked Steve Motzenbecker—a designer for New York magazine who has worked on many of Wojcik’s marketing efforts—to polish the logo, typeface and site architecture.

Wojcik believes that these days, a website is more valuable than a portfolio, but he was concerned people might only look at the site once. His wife suggested he make postcards with the website URL. “Postcards are timeless,” he says, “and create something three-dimensional that you can hand to people and lasts forever.
Wojcik believes that these days, a website is more valuable than a portfolio, but he was concerned people might only look at the site once. His wife suggested he make postcards with the website URL. “Postcards are timeless,” he says, “and create something three-dimensional that you can hand to people and lasts forever.”

He chose 50 images to go into a box set; Studley Press in Dalton, Massachussets, printed the postcards and made the cardboard boxes emblazoned with the Dinah Rock logo. Wojcik estimates that printing and manufacturing costs were about $4 a box. Since the website went live in April, he’s emailed links to the site, and mailed about 1,000 boxes of postcards to editorial and advertising clients and designers. He also handed them out as gifts to maître d’s, a fishmonger and friends, and donated 6,000 to the Suffolk County Project in Aquaculture Training to use in fundraising.

The feedback has been positive. “People can’t believe the devotion to making images of such an unattractive object.”

Whether or not the series leads directly to assignment work, Wojcik says the project has already delivered less-tangible rewards. “For me it’s about being devoted to a subject and constantly exploring something,” he says. “Ultimately, keeping your name out there as a contemporary photographer and staying inspired by finding new ways to express yourself will keep people looking for your work.”

article.article_title: How I Got That Shot: David Prince's Colorful Collages
article.meta_description: Photographer David Prince takes an intuitive approach to assembling and lighting still lifes.
article.article_text_abstract: Photographer David Prince takes an intuitive approach to assembling and lighting still lifes.
article.article_image_caption: A personal image Prince shot in his studio using window light. It was made as part of a series he assigned himself to explore different colors using simple props he bought or pulled from his own collection.
article.article_text:
Client: Town & Country

Still-life photographer David Prince experiments constantly. He often adapts the compositions and techniques that he explores in his test images to his assignment work for editorial and commercial images. In one self-assigned series that he assembled and shot in the morning before beginning work on assignments in his studio, Prince created images based around a different color.

“I never had an idea of what I was going to do, I’d just say ‘Today it’s gold, or it’s purple, or it’s gray.’” He would shop at an art supply store near his New York studio, buying thread, lengths of string, elastic bands—anything he could find in a single color. He then gave himself an hour to assemble and shoot a single still life using the items he had just bought and any objects he had on hand that fit the day’s color palette. The objects he used ranged from the mundane—a packet of artificial sweetener, a tape measure—to works of art he had collected.

By limiting the amount of time he gave himself to arrange and shoot each image, he ensured that he couldn’t overthink his compositions: “It’s about combining the unexpected without thinking, and reacting to shapes and forms.” Over the course of ten days in his studio, he created ten still lifes. “It’s a good thing to do because it forces you into problem-solving and quickly putting things together,” he explains. “That’s what being a commercial photographer is: You’re often photographing things that aren’t your choice, and you have a short amount of time to make something compelling.”

On an assignment for Town & Country to photograph expensive, gold-embellished handbags, he created a similar assemblage of items, incorporating the luxury items the client had supplied with a variety of objects from his studio and home that would complement the gold tones in the handbags. He shot the assignment with the same camera and lens he used for his test shots, and chose a light source that mimicked the window light in his studio that had illuminated his color-palette experiments.

LOGISTICS
The Town & Country assignment called for Prince to shoot luxurious handbags adorned with gold hardware and metallic elements. In discussing ideas for the shot with the client, he recalls, “The most important thing was to show the sheen and a sense of luxury.” He suggested creating a collage of elements around the bags. Working with stylist Hilary Robertson, he composed an arrangement of props. Prince decided to incorporate a Pablo Picasso bowl from his own ceramics collection into the shot. Like many of his favorite items, the bowl has appeared in several of his photos. “I said that it would be great to put that in, because it’s another reference to France and to fashion and to the world,” the photographer recalls.

As in the compositions he creates for his test shots, “I tend to put things down intuitively,” he says. “Within a couple of captures, we’ll have something, and then I just tweak it.”

LIGHTING
When it comes to choosing lights, Prince says he tends to go on streaks, using only strobes or only softboxes for days at a time. To capture the sheen of the metallic elements, Prince chose to use a single small HMI light, an ARRI 575w fresnel light kit. “I tend to simplify as much as possible. There are times when I’ll use 16 lights,” but in this case, he says, “The HMI light made the most sense because it’s the most controllable directional light source.” He placed it on a stand about four feet from the tabletop arrangement, so it raked the light across the top. He chose to use two fill cards to bounce light into the darkest areas of shadow, though he notes that he likes the realism shadows can lend to an image.

In regards to working with the HMI, “I felt it would give me the most pop and the most saturation and the most richness,” he says, adding, “It imitates natural light.” During the color palette tests that inspired the Town & Country composition, Prince had been using only the light from an east-facing window in his studio. In those pictures, the only control he had over the light was to draw the window shade or reposition the table. “If it was overcast, I’d move the table to the window. If it was bright and sunny, I’d move the table away.”

CAMERA
Prince shot both the handbags and his color compositions with a tethered Phase One 645DF and an 80mm lens. Prince, his client and his digital tech, Levi Miller, huddle around the monitor to preview shots on set.

POST-PRODUCTION
After choosing two to three favorite images, Prince and his digital tech will tweak contrast and color values. Prince likes to edit on set, he says, “so the client is walking out with whatever they need.” When he and Miller are working on an editorial shoot like the Town & Country assignment, Prince says he likes to make sure the final, retouched image captures the spontaneity of his personal work. In guiding his digital tech, he says, “I have comments about what’s right or wrong.” The advice Prince often gives his digital tech is advice he follows himself: “Don’t overthink it.”

David Prince will teach a seminar titled “Visual Vocabulary: The Making of a Still Life Photographer” on October 31 at the PhotoPlus Expo and Conference. Details at photoplusexpo.com.

article.article_title: Create Spotlight: Lara Richardson of the Discovery Channel
article.meta_description: As senior VP for marketing at Discovery Channel, Lara Richardson is responsible for all of the network's on-air and print campaigns, social networking, domestic distribution of content and the annual upfront sales presentations
article.article_text_abstract: As senior VP for marketing at Discovery Channel, Lara Richardson is responsible for all of the network's on-air and print campaigns, social networking, domestic distribution of content and the annual upfront sales presentations. She talks to PDN about the challenges of TV marketing and her work with photographers to create campaigns on a variety of platforms.
article.article_image_caption: Image from Fast N’ Loud, which features Richard Rawlings and Aaron Kaufman from the Dallas, Texas-based Gas Monkey Garage.
article.article_text:
As senior vice president for marketing at Discovery Channel, Lara Richardson is responsible for all of the network’s on-air and print campaigns, social networking, domestic distribution of content and the annual upfront sales presentations. Before joining Discovery she was the vice president of creative for TLC; she has previously served as creative director at the History Channel and History International. She shot, directed and produced the film Katrina: A Volunteer Story for Discovery Production Group; she has also worked as a producer. She talked to PDN about the challenge of television marketing and her work with photographers to create campaigns for a variety of platforms.

PDN: Your job as senior vice president of marketing is described as “creating and executing the vision of the Discovery Channel brand.” What do you think the vision and brand of the network is?

Lara Richardson: The Discovery Channel has a “brand halo,” unlike a lot of other networks. You say “Discovery Channel,” and people definitely have a distinct impression of it. That’s both a blessing and a curse, in a way. We’re storytellers, and fueling curiosity in people has always been at our core. We’re about exploration and we’re exploring compelling characters. We’ve put the focus more on people. It used to be about penguins and sharks, now it’s also about gold miners, fishermen, survivalists.

My main areas of concern involve how our brand is presented in on-air and off-air promotion, print, out-of-home and outdoor advertising, and in our strong social media presence that continues to grow daily.

PDN: To present character-driven shows, you must commission a lot of portraiture. What skills are you looking for in a portrait photographer?

LR: We are about authenticity, and that can be difficult to capture. When the subjects of one of our shows are out on a boat on the Bering Sea, I may not always have a photographer there to capture the action. When you bring these subjects into a studio and try to recreate that, how do you do it in a way that is true to the brand? Most of these guys have never set foot in a studio before, and that can take a special photographer.

We used [photographer] Jason Elias on the last in-studio shoot. I’d first worked with Jason when he was a gaffer. He’s a very personable guy. I knew I’d need someone who would make the talent feel comfortable. I’ve come across a lot of talented photographers, but they’re used to dealing with models. Jason is that guy who can be friends with everybody and, combined with his photography skills, he was a good fit.

We had two stages going at once: We did video on one and stills on another, and shot all our major talent in 40 setups over a two-day period. It was a lot.

Earlier this year the Discovery Channel delved into scripted programming with a miniseries called Klondike. The challenge was: How do you convey that we’re the number one nonfiction network, but say we’re going to do this series on a scripted basis? Kevin Lynch, who is based in Los Angeles, had done some celebrity portraits, and I was drawn to his portraiture. He did a great job shooting a gallery for us and maintaining a sense of authenticity. He captured it very quickly, and that’s a huge deal. We didn’t have a lot of time, but he made it look like he had hours.

We’re going up to the Yukon in a couple of weeks with Jason Elias to photograph for Gold Rush. Sometimes you have to embed a photographer [with subjects of a show]. When the subjects are searching for gold, you have to have a photographer there to capture exactly the right moments.

PDN: How much photography are you assigning, and how much is pick-up from shows?

LR: We’ll do two to three off-air campaigns a quarter and we’ll typically shoot something original for those. Though we are not buying as much print [advertising] as we used to, I always need stills: on the Web, on social media. There are autograph cards and DVD covers. For the iTunes store, you need key art for that. A lot of people lift frames from video of a show, but I think that shooting proper stills to represent a show is still important.

PDN: You’ve worked in and around network television for a while. How do you feel the marketing of television programs has changed?

LR: The major change is that the marketplace has gotten so crowded. It’s now harder to break through—just getting the consumer’s attention is more difficult. That’s exciting from a creative standpoint, because things that in the past were just good, or good enough, don’t cut it anymore. It’s now a balancing act between not being so out there that we alienate people who identify with the brand and have strong feelings about it, but at the same time pushing the creative so it gets someone’s attention.

PDN: Does the fact that you’re showing photos on so many platforms change the criteria you use to evaluate photos?

LR: We still tend to think in terms of key art. I think if you have a clear, singular image that sums up the show, it should work at any size. That’s what I’m going for in a lot of these pictures: simple images that capture what the show is about.

PDN: Is there particular experience or skills a photographer has to have to work for the Discovery Channel?

LR: It’s not so much about experience, though when I hire people, this is not their first time at the rodeo. Part of what our brand stands for is covering everything from the epic to the everyday, from the landscape of Alaska to the life of a moonshiner. So I look for photographers who can see the epic in the everyday. For example, for a show called Moonshiners, I need a photographer who can take moonshiners and make them look epic, or can look at the landscape of Alaska and draw people into the everydayness. It may be about finding a fresh way to look at Alaska, getting in there and showing snow on a branch.

PDN: Are you looking for new photographers or relying on a stable of people you’ve worked with before?

LR: I’m always looking for new talent. Sometimes I see something on the Web, sometimes I’ll see an ad in a magazine and find out who shot it. We have an internal creative agency and they have a ton of photographers in their library. They’ll show me books.

PDN: You mean printed portfolios?

LR: Yes, I still look at printed portfolios.

PDN: You’ve worked as a documentary filmmaker. Do you think that experience influences the way you work with photographers or directors?

LR: I think I feel comfortable talking about the creative process. I’m a hands-on person. I might have just enough technical knowledge to make me a pain in the ass, but I also appreciate the talent required to make good work.

PDN: What do you wish the photographers you work with understood better about the work of a marketing director?

LR: It’s not about an understanding of what a marketing director does, but an understanding of the many objectives we have to fulfill. When I first got into this, I thought I was an artist. It’s not really an art: There are ratings goals to meet, for example. There may be an amazing picture that would look great in a gallery, but if it doesn’t sell my show [then]...it’s just for fun.
