article.article_title: When Instagram Success Leads To Advertising Assignments: Lauren Lemon
article.meta_description: As brands try to maximize the potential of social networks like Instagram, photographers like Lauren Randolph are using social networks to help build their careers and land assignments.
article.article_text_abstract: As brands try to maximize the potential of social networks like Instagram, photographers like Lauren Randolph are using social networks to help build their careers and land assignments.
article.article_image_caption: A photograph shot for the Nordstrom BP brand of juniors clothing.
article.article_text:
The industry isn’t quite sure yet what to call them: iPhotographers, iPhonographers, social photographers, mobile photographers, or most directly, influencers. As brands try to capitalize on the rise and reach of social media networks such as Instagram—now more than 200 million international users strong— they’re turning to the platform’s native talent like Lauren Randolph for their eye, their experience, and not least, their followers.

“This is all new, so a lot of agencies are learning while I’m learning," says Randolph, who is best known by her Instagram handle Lauren Lemon. Approaches to leveraging the platform have varied. Some brands, like Fruttare and Jamba Juice, have given her the creative control and budget to set up and art-direct her own mini shoots to accompany larger campaigns. For Fruttare, she traveled to Coachella and the iHeartRadio Music Festival to create lifestyle imagery and cheerful product shots. For Jamba Juice, she staged charming still lifes for their “Live Fruitfully” campaign: strawberries sitting poolside in red bikinis and shades, plump raspberries and blueberries lining the coast on a map of California. “It was about getting out there and being bold and living life to its fullest, and being healthy and active, which goes along with what I do [on Instagram] anyway,” Randolph says.

Just five years removed from college, Randolph has attracted more than 230,000 Instagram followers—more than twice as many as some of the brands that have approached her with work—with her vibrant, cheerful portraits, lifestyle images and quirky still lifes. Her avatar typically shows her wearing her signature yellow on bright yellow backgrounds. Even her least popular posts easily clear 1,000 likes, and it’s not uncommon for her to rack up double, triple or quadruple that number for especially compelling images.

For Randolph, Instagram has proven much more effective in attracting clients than any of the moves photographers traditionally make when starting out. “I moved to LA to pursue commercial photography and started assisting and taking all the steps you’re supposed to do to get jobs, and I had gotten a few decent commercial jobs,” Randolph says. “But once I joined Instagram, I started getting this large following. Having my work and my lifestyle out there every single day—all this colorful, carefree imagery that I put on there—that’s kind of the stuff that brands have been reaching out for me to do for their projects and campaigns.”

Counterintuitively, Randolph feels that the images she broadcasts to her vast network of followers feel more personal to the creative and art directors who follow her than even one-on-one communication might.

“I’ve hustled to get meetings at some great agencies,” she says, “but it’s honestly the creative directors and the people who are following me on Instagram that I’ve gotten work from. They’re seeing me post every day, they’re commenting on the photos, I’m seeing them like the work. I know that I’m staying on their radar, and it’s not just a follow-up email after a meeting that’s fed into all their other emails: it’s what they’re looking at when they’re leaving work and going home.”

Which is, of course, the same reason brands want to get in on Instagram. As Randolph says, “People are flipping through it in their in-between moments, when they’re on the go, in bed.” So what is it that makes a successful Instagram post? “It should feel personal, like someone’s looking at something that you want to share with them,” she explains. “I think the most successful Instagram photos are the ones people feel like they can take themselves.”

That sounds simple, but the ways in which brands can best create successful, authentic-feeling campaigns and images for a social network predicated on being instantaneous—and how experienced Instagrammers like Randolph can help—are still in flux.

One model that brands including Toyota and Nordstrom have tried is to hire social media photographers to shoot alongside commercial photographers on traditional shoots. On a Toyota shoot for a 2014 Prius campaign, for example, “the person shooting with the DSLR was shooting the big, wide shots with all the cars,” Randolph says, “but they wanted me to go in and shoot the little details that were approachable and felt personal— what a family would shoot if they were on a road trip with their car.”

From Randolph’s perspective, this arrangement worked better than expected. She was included in creative calls leading up to the shoot and welcomed on set. “As a fellow photographer I just didn’t want to feel like I was in the way or stepping on anyone’s toes,” she says. “It wasn’t like that at all. If anything, we kind of fed off of each other.” If the lead photographer was shooting wide, she’d stay out of the way. If he was shooting tighter, Lemon would grab one of the models and pursue her own ideas elsewhere.

Ultimately, Toyota decided not to pursue such an arrangement. “I don’t think it necessarily worked out the way we initially intended it to,” says Tony Donna, the associate creative director for Saatchi & Saatchi LA who works with Toyota. Initially, Donna says, Toyota pursued iPhotographers for their influence. But the brand later got skittish about having the photographers posting for Toyota on their own channels, where Toyota couldn’t control the other content the photographers posted. The brand ended up with bloated budgets and “double the material,” without the reach and influence that they had counted on leveraging.

Randolph agrees that the arrangement wasn’t the most efficient. “They’re hiring two photographers, but technically one photographer could be doing that. I could shoot the car, and [shoot the social media images] with my iPhone.”
For now, Toyota is experimenting with hiring Instagrammers not just for their vision, but for their reach; notably, the brand has grown more comfortable with having photographers post on their behalf. “It’s evolved,” says Angee Murray, a senior art producer with Saatchi & Saatchi LA. “We still work with our legal team and do background checks if we have time, but it’s become a lot more mainstream, especially with corporate America and the automotive industry doing all kinds of creative stuff.”

For photographers, this means working more independently. “It’s not just having a second shooter on set to shoot for Instagram anymore; it’s actually doing projects specifically with influencers,” Murray says. “This year we’ve been giving them their own assignments and using them for their influence. We’re having them post on their own channels as well as creating additional content for Toyota’s Instagram and Facebook accounts.”

Meanwhile, operations are springing up to connect brands and Instagrammers. Tyson Wheatley, a successful journalist who worked for Instagram and is an influencer in his own right (500,000 followers and counting) is launching Down Right, a “boutique digital agency that helps connect brands with the right kinds of influencers to do a really awesome campaign.” Wheatley, who befriended Randolph via Instagram, says he isn’t repping photographers in an official capacity, but will “pitch the creative with certain photographers in mind, negotiate rates and manage the projects on a case-by-case basis.”

“It’s still the Wild Wild West,” he says, with brands not necessarily understanding how to find the best creatives for their social media projects, or even what those projects should be. Neither side has quite settled on exactly how the arrangements should be made, or what the proper rates are.

“Right now, good or bad, the amount of followers you have can dictate higher rates, but a large following is not necessarily indicative of quality image-taking,” says Wheatley, who points out that some Instagrammers’ numbers may have been helped by being featured by the network—as both he and Randolph were—and that some certainly dabble in the “dark arts” of buying followers. “What I want to do with Down Right is tap into the people who do have big, influential followings, but who are also really talented photographers.”

What the rates for this sort of work should be is one of the biggest questions for brands and creatives.

“Two years ago when we were trying this it was more like this was people’s hobby; now emerging photographers or assistants have found a way to make a career out of this,” says Murray. “Photo reps are picking them up. There are whole collectives of these iPhotographers, as we call them. And because they’ve gotten reps, they’re trying to command [higher] day rates. There are guys out there who have a day rate as a commercial photographer, but we are not using those guys. We can’t justify that yet.” 

That’s been Randolph’s experience as well. “Definitely not all brands are onboard with the costs, but I’m trying to approach it the same way I do all my work,” she says, by putting together bids as she would for any commercial job, with budgets for models, props, and wardrobe, licensing fees and a reasonable day rate. “If it’s with my iPhone, it may be cheaper [than a commercial shoot] because I don’t need a digital tech or a bunch of gear, but at the same time, my creative day rates should still be the same, and I should still be approached as a photographer who’s creating content and using ideas that I’m coming up with.” On some assignments, she’s serving as a consultant to help the brands figure out how best to use not just Instagram, but Twitter, Tumblr and Facebook as well.

Often, the sorts of jobs for which brands approach prominent Instagrammers are inherently lower-budget productions. “They’re usually not full-blown,” says Murray. “Truthfully, it’s like we’re going to get an influencer a car for three days and let them go around town and get shots and play with the car on location or send them to an event. It’s zero production value there.”

Last year Sony hired Randolph and several other influencers to test out their new Sony QX lens-style cameras that clip onto smartphones, sharing images on their own networks as well as Sony’s—a project with essentially zero production costs for the brand. Whatever the project, Wheatley advises photographers, “The most important thing is to hold onto your creative control. It’s really important that you don’t sacrifice the integrity or the authenticity of what it is that feels native to your Instagram account.”

With Randolph, he says, “there’s something about her esthetic that remains true. It’s typically very colorful and bright, and there’s definitely a happy vibe. She loves to use this hashtag #neverbummed, which is great,” he says. He advises photographers, “Don’t try to be something that you’re not. That’s really important.”

While Randolph feels that her work has largely stayed true to her brand, she hopes eventually she’ll get assignments using not just her social media skills, but her more technical skills as well. For now, her work is split about 70 percent social and 30 percent other commercial and editorial jobs, though her income is about 50/50, “as the regular commercial income is still far greater than anything for Instagram.”

“I’m pursuing the whole scope of it,” she says. “I would love to get more campaigns where they’re hiring me to shoot with an iPhone as well as a regular camera.”

Tony Donna of Saatchi & Saatchi LA and Toyota doesn’t see any reason why she couldn’t. “She was a joy to work with,” he says, “and I follow her still.”

article.article_title: Karen Morgan's Dog and Cat Photos Go Beyond Cliches, Land Ad Jobs
article.meta_description: Chicago-based Karen Morgan has been shooting dogs and cats, and despite competition, landing ad assignments from clients like Pfizer.
article.article_text_abstract: Chicago-based Karen Morgan has been shooting dogs and cats, and despite competition, landing ad assignments from clients like Pfizer.
article.article_image_caption: Morgan’s day-sleeping pit bull, Lenny. Originally shot as personal work, the image has been licensed for greeting cards and appeared in I’m a Good Dog by Ken Foster.
article.article_text:
Karen Morgan, a Chicago-based photographer (and pit bull enthusiast), has specialized in photographing dogs and cats in her studio and on location since 2004. Amidst plenty of competition for photographing cute pets, she has landed assignments from a variety of advertising and editorial clients, in addition to shooting commissioned portraits.

PDN: How did you specialize in pet photography?

KAREN MORGAN: I have had a lot of animal training experience and a huge passion for animals my entire life. An art director who knew that hired me in 2004 to shoot branding images for a pet-collar line. After seeing the work, my rep at the time said I should focus on pets and animals. It was obvious. I’m that crazy kind of dog lady; when I’m walking down the street and I see you walking your dog, I’ll greet your dog first.

PDN: Who are some of your clients and how do they use your images??

KM: Pet nutrition brands Hill’s and Blue Buffalo, Hartz pet products, Partners for Healthy Pets, Greenies, which makes pet treats and dog chews, and Pfizer, which makes medicines for pets. Clients use my images in print ads and collateral, in books, on the web, in vet offices, on pet meds, etc.

PDN: There is so much pet photography now—pictures and videos of cute cats and dogs go viral all the time. Does that put pressure on you to up your game?

KM: Yes, it does. The content is everywhere. A great image can happen with anyone who doesn’t specialize in it, but the value of being able to produce 25 or 30 shots in several days is what makes the difference. I go over that in every conference call and client meeting. It’s definitely hard because it’s a booming niche, and you have to fight more—a lot more.

PDN: How do you distinguish your images from so many other pet images out there? 

KM: I like to get super sharp and crispy lighting that really enhances the texture of the fur, but if a pet is on the shy side, I might have to modify the light and go more for a shorter depth of field that is more about feeling rather that the visual texture.

PDN: How is photographing a portrait of an animal technically different from shooting portraits of people?

KM: They are very different, depending on the effect you want. Light wraps around fur very differently from human skin and hair.

PDN: Tell me a little more. How do you handle that?

KM: It’s where I put the lights and the direction. I don’t like to light animals from the front, because it flattens them. I try to light from the sides and behind and wrap the light around so you can feel the body of the animal. It’s beautiful for the pet, but if you stuck a person in there, they would not look good. So it’s a different lighting approach for a person and an animal together.

PDN: What special equipment does pet photography require??

KM: Sometimes the sound of the flash can scare certain animals, so years ago I had custom lights built that do not have a popping sound when the strobes fire. Profoto and Broncolor strobes are much quieter than they used to be, but I still pull out my custom strobes when I have a dog or cat that gets nervous.

PDN: Are there other challenges that are particular to pet photography?

KM: Casting is critical. Some clients want a very specific breed, [but] getting a specific breed that can also be great on set is sometimes difficult with a [tight] production schedule. I reach out to all my animal resources and connections, and I hold open casting calls if needed. I like to meet the pets myself during the casting process.

PDN: What in particular are you looking for besides cuteness?

KM: The [animal’s] ability to make eye contact and not shy away from the lens pointing directly at them, and the ability to understand commands and demonstrate the certain position needed for the ad. I also assess the animal’s comfort level when their owner is out of the room, and how well they listen to me when I clear the room. I want relaxed personalities on set—no heavy breathing, shakes, etc. I instantly know when an animal will be too nervous.

PDN: Are there particular dos and don’ts for photographing dogs and cats?

KM: Let the animals walk freely on set before it’s time to shoot. Do not adjust the lighting or diffusion elements quickly on set while they are present. No loud or sudden noises, and try to minimize the amount of people on set looking at the pet.

PDN: How do you get a dog or cat (especially a cat) to do what you want it to do on set?

KM: Every pet is different. I have numerous sounds, voices, toys and music [to coax the animals]. For cats, I have a special cat wrangler and trainer I like to work with on set. And most of all, you must have a calm voice and patience!

PDN: Can you describe a typical assignment? And what assignments have you shot recently?

KM: A typical assignment is to shoot a library of lifestyle images and portraits, in the studio and on location, of the pet alone and with a person.

I’m currently photographing famous Chicagoans and their pets. This is for a commissioned book with The Puppy Mill Project, and proceeds from sales will go to help stop puppy mills and provide veterinary care to dogs rescued from those horrible places. In 2012, 28 of my images of pit bulls were used in the book I’m A Good Dog by Ken Foster.

PDN: What are your rates for assignments??

KM: Commercial rates can range between $4,000 and $10,000 per day, depending upon usage. Editorial rates also vary dramatically between $350 and $3,000 per image or assignment.

PDN: What’s your advice for photographers trying to get into this niche?

KM: I’m not happy that more people are jumping on the wagon, but if I need to put my angel hat on, I’d say that you have to know a lot about animal behavior and training. And you have to shoot whatever your passion is. If you love horses, shoot horses, not every animal under the sun.

article.article_title: Photo Blogs Are Proliferating: How Photographers Can Make the Most of Them
article.meta_description: Competition among photo blogs to find and publish original photography projects continues to grow. Here's what photographers need to know to capitalize on the demand.
article.article_text_abstract: Competition among photo blogs to find and publish original photography projects continues to grow. Here's what photographers need to know to capitalize on the demand.
article.article_image_caption: An image from Frédéric Legrange’s Wakhan Corridor (Afghanistan) project, which was published in June on the CNN Photos blog.
article.article_text:
The digital revolution has stimulated a robust general interest and demand for photography, and photo blogs are proliferating to satisfy the demand. Several photo blogs with mass audiences are updating photo galleries several times per week, creating a feeding frenzy for original photo projects. But are photographers taking full advantage of their opportunities and choices?

The list of blogs that showcase photography—and pay photographers for the privilege—keeps growing. The Wall Street Journal recently announced plans to publish “more and more original content” on its Photo Journal blog. Director of Photography Jack Van Antwerp says the newspaper is “pushing forward digitally...[and] visuals are key to making that successful. Photography generates traffic.” The blog will publish up to several stories per week, and pay around $400 for each one, Van Antwerp says. The New York Times Lens blog, one of the most prestigious photo blogs, was among the first to publish slideshows of projects, and interview and write about photographers. It pays $350 per slideshow. Other sites with cache among photographers include The New Yorker Photo Booth (which pays $250), CNN Photos ($600), and TIME Lightbox ($750).

Others are joining the fray. Matter, an online magazine launched in May by the story-sharing site Medium, is also hunting for compelling photo projects, with a goal of publishing one per week. So far, it has published photo series by Rocky McCorkle, Matt Eich and another story about Adam Magyar, and it is paying “very competitive rates comparable...to Lens, Lightbox, etc.,” art director Erich Nagler explained in an e-mail.

“It has definitely become more competitive over the last couple of years,” says Paul Moakley, a photo editor at TIME. “There are lots of great places for photographers to think about putting their work.”

There are also a lot of photographers vying for publication. Moakley says he gets 10 to 20 e-mail pitches per day. James Estrin, who is co-editor of Lens blog with David Gonzalez, says 100 or so pitches arrive each week in Lens blog’s mailbox. Estrin gets another 100 pitches per week in his personal e-mail, from photographers, curators, editors and PR professionals representing book publishers, galleries and museums.

Blog editors also hunt for projects at portfolio reviews, and by trawling other photo blogs and magazines (print and online) that don’t have big audiences outside the photo industry. Lens Culture, Lenscratch, F-Stop magazine and Fraction magazine are among those that are heavily mined.

CNN Photos, for instance, often picks up stories from other blogs and publications. Frédéric Legrange’s project on Afghanistan’s Wakhan corridor appeared as a 28-page portfolio in UK-based PORT magazine before CNN ran it on June 23, says Legrange. Liz Calvi’s “Lost Boys” project, about young adult men forced to drop out of college for financial reasons, ran in Fraction before CNN published it on July 6.

Photo blog editors take particular pleasure in being first to discover new talent. And they put a premium on projects that haven’t been published by other blogs and websites, especially those with big general audiences. “If I see work published by a competitor, we’re likely not to cover it,” Moakley says.

Van Antwerp, Estrin and Simon Barnett, photo editor for CNN Photos, also say they’re generally not interested in stories their big competitors have run, but they will sometimes make exceptions. Photographers still have to choose carefully where they first publish a project, because they may not get a second chance. And yet a number of photographers interviewed for this story reported that they consented to publication by the first photo blog that asked.

“You have to look at this in a really sophisticated way, because some sites just throw up photos,” Estrin warns. “They don’t write about you, they don’t write about the work, they don’t give a crap about it. They’re looking for hits and nothing but hits, and you don’t get handled sensitively.”

Different blogs provide access to different audiences. Some are photojournalistic and current events-driven. Others emphasize art photography. Some appeal to industry professionals more than to general audiences, and vice-versa. Photographers have to recognize and weigh those differences against their own particular goals when choosing which blogs to publish on.

Money is also a consideration—not only how much a blog pays, but whether it pays at all. Among popular photo blogs that don’t typically pay photographers publication fees are Slate’s Behold, Wired Raw File, Feature Shoot, Huffington Post and Buzzfeed. All are competing for photography content with sites that pay, and promise exposure rather than money. (PDN’s Photo of the Day blog does not pay a fee.)

But blogs that pay can provide as just much—if not more—exposure to a desired audience. And Estrin says, “There are different expectations [about paying to publish photo projects] for different sites. If a photo blog is a labor of love, even if it’s popular, their not paying [photographers] is very different from Huffington Post and Buzzfeed not paying.”

Given the current level of competition for content, photographers may have more bargaining power than they realize. That’s what photographer Anastasia Pottinger recently discovered with her series of portraits of centenarians.

When she successfully pitched her project to Lenscratch three years ago, Pottinger was little-known outside of Columbia, Missouri, where she earns her living shooting portraits. A writer for Feature Shoot re-discovered her project this past May while looking through the Lenscratch archives, says Pottinger.

“It was posted on Feature Shoot, and four hours later, CNN called me.”

By then, other blogs had picked it up, and she told CNN that the story was about to appear on other blogs. “They said, ‘Don’t worry about it. We just don’t want you to sell it to TIME or ABC,” she recounts. (ABC’s photo blog, called Picture This, is updated only sporadically.)

After the story appeared on CNN, Pottinger says, it went viral. Dozens of blogs and web sites “just took it. Most of them re- tooled it to sound like they spoke to me.”

Huffington Post, which sought permission to publish her project after CNN published it, asked her to contribute her images for free, she says. She declined. “I may have said $100 per image—something pretty high.” She ended up negotiating a $375 fee to publish 10 images. Of a half- dozen photographers interviewed for this story, only Pottinger reported pushing publishers for money.

Her experience begs the question: Should other photographers be asking for more? Blog editors—like many magazine editors—say their budgets are limited, so a photographer’s fees are fixed and unlikely to improve anytime soon. But photographers are also compensated by the exposure a popular or influential photo blog can give them.
Pottinger is ambivalent about that argument, particularly from blogs that don’t pay fees. “Millions of people saw [Centenarians] who wouldn’t have seen it otherwise. That’s good for selling a book to publishers,” she says. “It’s hard because they’re dangling this fruit of exposure, but you know in the end, someone is making a living off it, and it’s not you.”

Other photographers are less conflicted about giving away their work, especially if they’re trying to launch their careers. When she started pitching her “Lost Boys” project, Calvi says, “I wanted to get my name and my work out there. I didn’t even know that some [blogs] paid” for publication rights. After it was published by Fraction, CNN Photos picked it up.

Eric Cousineau got his project about independent roadside motels published on the Wired Raw File blog. F-Stop magazine also published the project, and neither publication paid a fee. “Eventually, I’ll care about getting paid, but right now, I want to get my name out there,” he says.

Diana Markosian, whose various projects have appeared on Lens, Lightbox, The New Yorker’s Photo Booth, Boston Globe’s Big Picture, Slate, NPR and Feature Shoot, says, “It sets a terrible precedent when you have outlets... not paying for work and photographers accepting it in exchange for ‘exposure’.” (Her work has also appeared in the 2014 PDN’s 30 gallery, and in a PDN “Picture Story” column.)

Markosian adds, “I think many of us also feel pressure to constantly produce work and have it seen. If you don’t publish, you perish. And while many of these blogs don’t pay decent rates, some photographers (including myself ) would rather see their images featured than sitting on their desktop. My approach is to sell to a magazine first and then a blog.”

Of course, Markosian is in a better position than most photographers to get her work published in print. But given the robust competition among photo blogs, a lot of photographers may have more options and negotiating power than they realize.

article.article_title: Picture Story: Teen Brothers at Home, In Jail, and in the System
article.meta_description: Isadora Kosofsky embeds herself in the emotional world of two teenage brothers, one in the juvenile justice system and the other in and out of adult jails.
article.article_text_abstract: Isadora Kosofsky embeds herself in the emotional world of two teenage brothers, one in the juvenile justice system and the other in and out of adult jails.
article.article_image_caption: Brothers Vinny and David against the sky of an approaching summer storm.
article.article_text:
Shortly after she turned 18 in 2011, Isadora Kosofsky began photographing a New Mexico boy named Vinny. He had just been sent to juvenile prison for stabbing a man who had been assaulting Vinny’s mother. Kosofsky ended up immersing herself in the project, and what has emerged is a story about a close-knit family torn by loss and a sense of powerlessness, but still holding on to love and hope.

The project, called “Vinny and David,” after the two brothers at the center of the story, was published by TIME Lightbox this past May with the headline “The Intersection of Love and Loss: Confronting Youth Incarceration.” The project grew out of Kosofsky’s curiosity about the juvenile justice system, which started when she was just 14 years old. She wanted to photograph teen boys who were incarcerated “because I felt like I related to them,” she says, explaining that in her early teens she had friends who were caught up in the system.

At the age of 15, she began submitting requests for access. Her pitch to prison officials around the country was to do a project that looked beyond the “hegemonic masculinity” of prison culture by exploring the vulnerability and sensitivity of young offenders. She pointed out that as a young person herself, she was in a unique position to tell the story.

“Reading over my letters to prison officials now, I don’t think they were that convincing,” she says.
Every request she sent was either rejected or ignored, but her age was the main reason, she says. She continued making requests, and immediately after she turned 18, administrators of several youth prisons granted access. Kosofsky quit college to pursue the project, fearing the access might be rescinded if she waited.

“My goal was to go on a personal journey through these institutions and document the lives of these young people,” she explains. But she quickly realized after spending time in two prisons that “photographing solely in these institutions made it almost impossible to convey the extent of [the subjects’] individual identities. Their confinement rendered their story very limited. I knew I wanted to go beyond those walls, and show their humanity in context of broader society.”

Upon her arrival at a youth prison in New Mexico, she met Vinny, who had just been detained. He opened up to her almost immediately. “I don’t know why some people become subjects of long-term documentary projects. There was just something I saw in him and his story that needed to be told,” she says.

Her project about youth incarceration suddenly narrowed to a project about Vinny, and her first images of him show a vulnerable, traumatized kid tasting his first prison meal, and sleeping on a cement slab.

Kosofsky sought out Vinny’s mother Eve at his next court hearing. “I told her, ‘I would like to get to know you,’” Kosofsky recounts. Eve was open from the start. On the economic and social margins, she was used to being invisible. Kosofsky surmises that someone trying to tell their story made her feel empowered.

Soon afterwards, when she knocked on Eve’s door for the first time, Eve’s oldest son (and Vinny’s oldest brother) David answered, told Kosofsky she wasn’t welcome, and shut the door in her face. Eve let her in, but it took the photographer a year to win David’s trust.

Kosofky eventually realized that David’s fear was of abandonment—that Kosofsky would be another person in his life who would take something and then disappear. “He made a comment one night, about six months in, that even if I leave I always come back,” she says. “When he said that I realized the [importance of ] being present, not even talking, just bearing witness and sitting and observing and being patient.”

David had his own troubles. He’d joined a gang, had been cycling in and out of adult jail, and lived in fear of being yanked away from the family. Kosofsky ended up becoming close to David through an exchange of letters and phone calls, including when he was in jail. While saying goodbye after one of her visits, “[David] said it was great seeing me, and I should keep in touch. That was a moment I felt was a turning point in our relationship,” Kosofsky recounts.

Kosofsky says she became so integrated into the brother’s lives, she started to feel like a sister. Then she began to worry about how immersed she had become. Kosofsky says she was living a divided life—her own, and theirs—that was blurring into one, and it was difficult to separate emotionally from the family and their story.

“It’s definitely a conflict in all [my] projects to find the balance between being compassionate, empathetic and emotionally present, and at the same time, conserving that photographic distance,” she says. But she also says she doesn’t “really believe that the objective stance even exists, and I think that some of the most powerful photography is from that subjective view, where the photographer has become part of that community.”

Kosofky says the family didn’t even notice her taking pictures after a while. Nothing was off limits or hidden, and Kosofsky’s images focus intently on the relationships, interactions and emotions of her subjects. Frustration, anger, fear, resignation, compassion, joy, love and hope are all on display, and Kosofsky shows the full range, dignifying her subjects as real, multi-dimensional people, not archetypes of poverty or prison culture. “This is much more a story about family than about incarceration. Incarceration is a facet of it, [and] I think it’s very important that is at the forefront. But they’re not defined by their incarceration. And I very much wanted to show the confinement that they live in outside of the context of the actual penal system,” she says. Kosofsky believes that their confinement is emotional, stemming from traumatic experience and the feeling of social invisibility and powerlessness.

She began editing her images last summer after nearly two years working on the project. She kept a journal to help edit the work, and six months ago, she showed the work to TIME’s Nicholas McClelland. He had championed “Senior Love Triangle”—another project Kosofsky had started as a teenager, about the unusual relationship of three seniors fighting the fear and loneliness of aging together. Lightbox published that story in May 2012.

“The theme of love and loss is something that is in all of my work,” she says.

Kosofsky is now returning to college, where she’s focusing on gender studies. She says she’ll continue to work on the “Vinny and David” project indefinitely. “There's no time constraint, no end date.” She adds that she hopes to engage as many people with the story as as possible. “I’m thinking of ways to expand it for publication [as a book] and exhibition.”

article.article_title: Christian Weber's New Book Explosions Paints With Energy
article.meta_description: In Explosions, Christian Weber captures the depth and beauty of controlled explosions that would otherwise be invisible to the naked eye.
article.article_text_abstract: In Explosions, Christian Weber captures the depth and beauty of controlled explosions that would otherwise be invisible to the naked eye.
article.article_image_caption: Christian Weber had the idea to create a series of photographs of explosions after using pyrotechnics on a fashion shoot.
article.article_text:
Some appear as wraiths, twisting phosphorescent and half-formed out of a looming void. Others are roiling clouds of fire and pitch, echoes of primordial conflagrations. Christian Weber, who reveals that he always wanted to be a painter, cheekily describes the process that produced his new book, Explosions, as “painting with energy” and indeed, there is a depth and abstraction to his images of pyrotechnics.
   
The inspiration for Explosions came from a commissioned fashion shoot in 2009 for which Weber decided to utilize pyrotechnics. He had been doing some “light reading on physics,” and was also intrigued by the dramatic transformation of energy that he saw from the explosions on his shoot. Though the idea of creating a series of photographs of explosions was enticing, Weber mulled the concept for more than a year before deciding to move forward with it. “If I see something and am drawn to it, I tend not to act as quickly as some people might,” he says. “The true test for me is if it stays with me for a time and I still feel compelled to do it, then I know it’s right for me.”
   
Drawing upon contacts he had made doing commissioned work, Weber established a relationship with a pyrotechnician he felt could help make the project a reality. The first order of business was to locate an appropriate outdoor space that would be available for an extended period of time. Once they found their “studio” in a Connecticut rock quarry and secured the necessary permits, the pair got down to business. “We started experimenting, first by combining explosive compounds to produce different colors and levels of intensity, and [then] by creating a way to control the trajectory of an explosion,” Weber explains.
   
It was slow work—they rarely set off more than five or six explosions in a day, and Weber points out that all of the images in the book were shot in daylight. The darkness of the backgrounds is the result of the extreme intensity of the heat and light generated by the blasts blotting out the sun.
   
In an effort to keep things simple, Weber used just two cameras, one focused wide and the other tight, both fired by a single remote. This allowed him to capture both the “sculptural aspect of this energy display” and a shot of the interior of the explosion for its “textural detail.” Having started taking photographs a quarter-century ago, Weber comes from a background steeped in traditional photography techniques, so his initial instinct was to shoot the project on 4x5, using chrome, while utilizing a Canon 5D Mark III as the second camera. However, after blowing up test prints from both cameras, he found that the difference in resolution was negligible, and that the digital media was outperforming film in this context. Given the brevity of the explosions, the responsiveness and efficiency of the DSLR was hard to ignore. In the end, more than 70 percent of the images in the book were shot digitally.
   
Rather than using laser or sound triggers to fire the cameras, Weber triggered the cameras manually. He refers to the process as “the draw.”  “I wanted to rely on instinct, skill and good old-fashioned countdowns,” Weber elaborates. His remote fired each camera simultaneously, and each took a single picture. He admits there were more than a few misses in the early going, but feels the process was an integral part of the final result. The tension of the countdown, the brute force of the blast, and the raw anticipation all kept him wired into the moment, lost in the act of creating. This organic approach also meant that, as the project progressed, Weber began to operate more instinctively, experimenting with the timing whereby, instead of aiming for the exact point of detonation, he might trigger the camera fractions of seconds later. Precision was less important than immersing himself in the action.
   
From the beginning Weber envisioned the project as a book and was “plotting it as I worked,” he says. As the book began to take shape, he realized that he wanted to include some text: He was drawn to the idea of including a poem as well as a piece that could elaborate on the science behind the images he was creating. Familiar with John Yau’s Jackson Pollack-inspired poetry, Weber reached out to Yau. The poet and critic responded enthusiastically, contributing a poem. Forensic scientist Peter Diaczuk covered the scientific angle, contributing an essay full of insightful digressions on the history and nature of man-made combustion.

Beyond the literal flash-bang spectacle and the power and beauty of this crude manipulation of physics, Weber believes these images are about time and the human experience. “The explosions represent life. Each one is completely unique, unable to be duplicated or to recur as the same event, “ he says. “The explosions are momentary phenomena, imperceptible to the human eye. When you see one of the detonations, it is impossible to process the details. You can feel the force and hear the energy, but the visual details are lost. The photographs allow me to process the event and see what had actually happened right before my eyes.”

article.article_title: A Guide To Green Photography
article.meta_description: The electronic gear photographers require is typically loaded with materials that can be toxic to the earth; here are some ways to cut down on electronic waste and limit energy use.
article.article_text_abstract: The electronic gear photographers require is typically loaded with materials that can be toxic to the earth; here are some ways to cut down on electronic waste and limit energy use.
article.article_text:
Photography can be a dirty business. The electronic gear photographers require is typically loaded with materials that can be toxic to the earth. Here are some of the ways you can cut down on electronic waste and limit your energy use. 

RECYCLING YOUR GEAR
A few organizations that will take your old electronic gear and keep it out of landfills.

The Biodiversity Group
This international organization, whose mission is to maintain environmental landscapes for future generations, runs a program in Tucson, Arizona, called Cameras for Conservation that puts your old cameras to good use. Cameras for Conservation accepts gear like camera bodies and lenses that biologists and photographers in the Biodiversity Group use to document diversity all over the world. Cameras for Conservation will provide a receipt for the donation and the price of shipping your camera to them so you can get a tax-deduction. 
   
INFO: www.biodiversitygroup.org/donate
   
Recycling for Charities (RFC)
This organization gives individuals the opportunity to donate or recycle old cameras, cellphones, iPods, iPads and more. If your camera or electronic gear is in good enough condition, RFC will refurbish it and donate it in turn to the charity you choose so it can be used again. For each donation, RFC also contributes a minimum of $.25 to the selected charity. When electronics are beyond repair, RFC strives to recycle them as responsibly as possible. 
   
INFO: www.recyclingforcharities.com/index.php 
   
Free Geek
This Portland, Oregon-based nonprofit provides free computers and education in exchange for community service. It recycles technology in two ways. The first is by refurbishing old technology and then donating it where it’s needed—schools, free tech classes and other volunteer programs—or offering it for sale in the Free Geeks thrift store. The second method is by simply recycling equipment that can no longer be refurbished in a responsible manner. Free Geek has a suggested two-dollar recycling fee for cameras, which helps fund its volunteer programs, such as free classes for the community. 
   
INFO: www.freegeek.org/donate/ 
   
Staples and Best Buy
Both of these massive office and electronic supply stores offer recycling opportunities. You can bring your old camera to any Staples or Best Buy location and they will recycle it for you. They work with recyclers to adhere to recycling guidelines and standards. 
   
INFO: www.staples.com
www.bestbuy.com

Canon
Canon has developed the Canon Consumer Products Recycling Program to assist their U.S. customers in recycling their products. Canon works with its customers to ensure appropriate recycling of products including cameras, lenses, flashes and more. All you need to do is purchase a shipping label online to send in the products that you want Canon to recycle. A shipping label for most DSLR cameras costs six dollars. 
   
INFO: http://www.usa.canon.com/cusa/about_canon/community_environment/
   
Samsung
This camera and electronics maker has partnered directly with take-back and recycling companies to recycle old Samsung products. Samsung has fixed drop-off locations across the U.S. where you can leave your old products for recycling. Simply go online and find the store closest to you. They have also started a program called S.T.A.R., a free service that lets business and consumer printer customers recycle empty toner cartridges by sending them to Samsung. 
   
INFO: www.samsung.com/us/aboutsamsung/citizenship/usactivities/environmentalinitiatives/recyclingdirect/
   
The Disabled Photographer’s Society
This U.K. charity promotes photography for people with disabilities and for groups that are involved in helping the disabled. Their many programs include technical support for disabled photographers. The Society accepts donations of most photography equipment including cameras, lenses, tripods, cases and more. You can send your equipment to their offices in Kent. 
   
INFO: www.disabledphotographers.co.uk/donations.php

GREEN PRODUCTS
Innovative products made with clean, renewable resources.  
   
Flash Drives from Renewable Materials
Plastic tossed in a landfill may take up to 1,000 years to decompose and can potentially leak pollutants into the ground. While plastics are made of fossil fuels, wood—especially bamboo, which grows rapidly—is a renewable resource. Photo Flash Drive is one of many companies that now offer wooden and bamboo flash drives that function just like normal flash drives, but are made of renewable resources. Both the wooden and bamboo options offer a variety of capacities, starting at 2 GB of memory and going all the way to 64 GB. They are offered in a variety of colors and some can be engraved. 
   
PRICE: Starts at $14.67 for 2GB and ranges to $64.17 for 64GB
SIZE: 2.4 x 1.1 inches
INFO: www.photoflashdrive.com

Solar Camera Bags
Solar energy is one of the cleanest sources of energy, and solar camera bags allow you to use that power to charge your rechargeable batteries and other electronic devices. Eclipse Solar Gear offers a variety of solar-enabled camera bags. All you need is a standard 12V car adapter: Just as the car adapter transfers the energy from the engine of a car into an electronic device, this adapter can transfer energy collected from the bag’s solar cell to your device. The Eclipse bags offer plenty of storage, with compartments for all your photography equipment, and they come in different styles, including backpacks and side-strap camera bags. The “Nova” bag, for example, can hold a DSLR camera along with three lenses and adjustable foam dividers for specific gear, with room for still more accessories. It has an adjustable padded shoulder strap and exterior pockets, as well. The approximate charging time for a camera is four to six hours, depending on how strong the sunlight is. Although not waterproof, all bags are made of durable materials and can be left outside. 
   
PRICE: Nova $79.95
SIZE: 15 x 9 x 10 inches
INFO: www.eclipsesolargear.com

article.article_title: The International League of Conservation Photographers and the Wilderness Society Protect Idaho's Clearwater Basin
article.meta_description: Kista Schlyer and Amy Gulick, two photographers from the International League of Conservation Photographers, work with the Wilderness Society to photograph the landscape, wildlife, and people of Idaho's Clearwater basin.
article.article_text_abstract: Krista Schlyer and Amy Gulick, two photographers from the International League of Conservation Photographers, work with the Wilderness Society to photograph the landscape, wildlife, and people of Idaho's Clearwater basin.
article.article_image_caption: Kokanee salmon swimming up the Selway River to their spawning grounds, Idaho.
article.article_text:
Last year, the International League of Conservation Photographers (iLCP) joined with The Wilderness Society to create a series of photographs of Idaho’s Clearwater Basin, an area of more than 9,000 square miles that includes beautiful forests, pristine rivers and some of the only remaining roadless wilderness in the lower 48 states. The photos have become an important part of The Wilderness Society’s efforts to protect and preserve the Clearwater Basin from threats including logging and road construction. 
   
Krista Schlyer and Amy Gulick, two photographers from the iLCP, a non-profit organization whose members create images and other content that help advocate for environmental causes all over the world, worked with The Wilderness Society for several days to photograph the landscape, wildlife, and the local people who live, work and recreate in and around the basin.
   
A Wilderness Society donor initially connected the group with the iLCP, which evaluates projects based on several criteria, including the credibility of the organization, whether funding is in place or needs to be raised, and whether “the campaign is critical and timely so the images are going to have an immediate use,” explains iLCP Executive Director Alexandra Garcia.
   
Once iLCP signs on for a project, it puts a call out to its member photographers, who apply to work on a project. “We specifically said that we wanted two kinds of photographers: one that was going to do the fauna and landscape and one that was going to do the people piece,” Garcia recalls.
   
The work appealed to Gulick for a number of reasons. A Seattle-area-based photographer, Gulick considers the Clearwater Basin an extension of the Pacific Northwest. “Anything in my backyard, I feel I have a responsibility to let the world know how incredible it is and do whatever I can to preserve and maintain it in a responsible way going forward,” she says. She also appreciated the history of the place as part of the traditional home for the Nez Percé people, and the beauty of the wilderness. 
   
Working with Jeff Halligan, a Wilderness Society representative, Gulick made photographs of people who live in and interact with the Clearwater landscape in various ways. “People are a crucial part of the Clearwater story,” Gulick says. “The people that live there are so tied to the land. It is their way of life.” Environmental and conservation photography often depicts the landscape, but misses “half the story” when it doesn’t also focus on people in the landscape, she notes.  
   
For Schlyer, the Clearwater Basin project lined up with her previous work on public lands and wilderness, and clean water issues. “I’m just really interested in wilderness designations and protections as well,” she says. Schlyer worked with Halligan for nine days to “get into as much wilderness as possible to try to convey both the intrinsic and indirect values of wilderness, but also some of the more tangible values like clean water, intact forests and things like that.” She also made two flights with LightHawk, a non-profit organization and frequent iLCP partner that provides free flights to people working on conservation photography and research. 
   
The Wilderness Society has worked for the past six years as part of the Clearwater Basin Collaborative (CBC), a 23-member group that includes political blocs, conservation organizations, the timber industry, off-road vehicle groups, sportsmen and -women and others: in short, a “bunch of different people who use the land in very different ways,” says Brad Brooks, The Wilderness Society’s Idaho Deputy Regional Director. 
   
“The task when we came together was trying to figure out whether or not we could support one another so everyone is getting something that they want,” Brooks says. “It’s been going quite well. For us the ultimate prize is permanent protection through legislation of special places as wilderness and other designations.” 
   
A year ago, the CBC came to a signed written agreement to create a half-million acres of permanent protections and roughly 200 miles of river protections, Brooks says. That agreement formed the basis for legislation that the CBC is currently working to introduce in partnership with Idaho Senator Mike Crapo. (At press time Brooks did not have a timetable for the legislation, and he noted that national politics in the lead-up to the primaries was “affecting our timing in an unfortunate way.”)
   
The CBC agreement, however, “doesn’t mean that all of the local communities know what we’re doing or agree with it,” Brooks says. The Wilderness Society realized it needed to invest in building grassroots support, and the images that Schlyer and Gulick produced are an important part of that effort, which has included print brochures that explain the work of The Wilderness Society and CBC, and hundreds of local presentations throughout the Clearwater area. 
   
The photographs help the Wilderness Society tell the story of the basin to people inside the basin, nearby in Idaho, and in Washington, DC. “We can talk about places and designations and acres of wilderness in abstract terms, but when you put a picture in front of somebody and you say, ‘This river or this mountain needs to be designated as wilderness,’ there’s a visceral reaction that’s so much different than talking about it in the abstract.”
   
In a conservative state like Idaho, where citizens are wary of any government intervention, photographs also help change the conversation, Brooks says. “In the abstract it’s very easy for people to just say ‘No.’ But when you’re showing photos and saying, ‘Wouldn’t you agree that this place should stay the way it is today,’ most people would say, ‘Yeah, I can remember when I was a kid, hunting with my dad, and it’s just amazing. I hope it doesn’t change.’”

article.article_title: From Assistant to Pro: Andrew Burkle, Food Photographer
article.meta_description: Andrew Burkle's hustle as a photo assistant in Chicago fast-tracks his dreams of opening his own studio.
article.article_text_abstract: Andrew Burkle's hustle as a photo assistant in Chicago fast-tracks his dreams of opening his own studio.
article.article_image_caption: A plate of Vietnamese pho. Food styling by Josephine Orba.
article.article_text:
Two years ago, Andrew Burkle was a photo assistant in Chicago with a ten-year plan for establishing a career as a photographer. This spring, he found himself far ahead of schedule when he opened a 6,000-square-foot food photography studio in Cleveland with business partner David Hagen. They’ve already shot for national food brands including Jif, Crisco and Martha White; and for Vitamix, the Cleveland-based maker of food blenders.
   
Burkle was taking all the usual steps to prepare for his transition: building a nest egg, test-shooting regularly, and showing his portfolio to prospective clients. But he says the key to transitioning faster than he expected was the impression he made as an assistant. He worked hard, put his best foot forward on set, and learned how to communicate with crew and clients alike. People noticed, and wanted to work with him. 
   
Burkle, who is 28 years old, graduated from Ohio University in 2009 with an interest in portrait photography. He moved to Chicago and worked first as a freelance assistant doing portrait and fashion work. After about nine months, he answered a help-wanted ad on Craigslist for an assisting job at Stephen Hamilton Photographic (SHP), a big Chicago food photography studio. 
   
He loved the atmosphere. “Everyone was super nice, and they collaborated. I wasn’t a big fan of all the make-up artists, the models, and the ego in portrait and fashion work,” he says. Soon he joined SHP as a full-time assistant, with a new goal of becoming a food photographer. “I had to throw my [portrait and fashion] portfolio in the garbage and start over,” he says.
   
At SHP, he learned as much as he could about the business. “It was just being vigilant, and being a sponge. You don’t want to ask too many questions, though, because that makes it look like you’re prying.”
   
With Hamilton’s encouragement, Burkle used the studio every Saturday to do his own test shoots. He’d pack his gear in his car to and from the studio to simulate the feel and the routine of paying assignments, he says. At first he didn’t have money for big productions. “I’d go to the farmer’s market, pick out some vegetables, and do tight beauty shots,” he says. 
   
Eventually he started approaching food and prop stylists he’d met on jobs, asking for help with his test shoots. Many were assistant stylists willing to work in exchange for images for their own portfolios. But one was a top Chicago food stylist who rarely helped anyone with test shoots, he says. She and others who didn’t need portfolio prints were willing to help him because they saw it as an investment in someone who might hire them later, he explains, adding, “When you’re working as an assistant, it pays to have good relationships with the crew, not only because it makes the shoot go better, but because they’re willing to help you.”
   
Meanwhile, Steve Hamilton’s studio was so busy that Burkle and other assistants effectively worked as photographers. They interacted with clients and set up shots. That was invaluable experience, Burkle says, explaining that many assistants get so used to working in the background that they have trouble thinking and acting like a photographer when they try to go out on their own. “As a photographer, you have to have confidence and know how to lead a shoot,” he says.
   
While working for SHP, Burkle was saving money. He lived in a small apartment to pay less rent than he otherwise would have. He deposited his paychecks in a savings account at one bank, and maintained his checking and credit card accounts at another. That arrangement forced him to spend more consciously, he says, and it kept him from spending on things he didn’t really need, like a new TV or car.
   
His plan for striking out on his own was to move into a space that could double as a studio and living space. He’d then earn some more money, move into a bigger space, and repeat the cycle until he had enough business—and savings—to open a food photography studio separate from his house. “It was a tiered plan,” he says.
   
Meanwhile, Hagen was in Cleveland, ready to go out on his own after working for years for Kalman & Pabst Photo Group (KP Photo). Because KP Photo had recruited interns from Ohio University, Hagen knew Burkle, and had kept an eye on his portfolio. When he was in Chicago visiting KP Photo clients, he’d arranged to meet with Burkle at SHP. But when Hagen arrived there, Burkle was too busy trying to wrap up a major shoot for an SHP client. He ended up giving Hagen a quick tour and rushing him out of the studio.
   
“It was 9 o’clock at night. Six or seven people were still working, and Andrew was the one orchestrating everything,” Hagen recalls. “He’s producing, retouching and shooting for big clients. And on top of that, he’s a nice guy. I’m like, OK, that’s a guy I can work with.”
   
Hagen followed up with Burkle by e-mail, proposing a business partnership, and outlining a rough business plan for opening a studio together in Cleveland.
   
At first, Burkle had no interest in leaving Chicago for Cleveland. “It didn’t sound appealing, but the more I thought about it, the more it made sense,” he says. A number of national food brands are based in northeast Ohio, including Nestlé, J. M. Smucker and Vitamix. The city has a vibrant restaurant industry, and real estate and other overhead costs are dramatically lower than Chicago’s.
   
Burkle and Hagen met for dinner a few times to get better acquainted, and decided the partnership would work. “We’re both laid back but hard working,” Burkle says. They found an industrial studio space for $1,200 per month—less than what Burkle was paying for his apartment in Chicago. With business loans and their savings, they built out the space with two full kitchens. The studio opened for business in May. Their roster includes both local and national clients, and when they’re not shooting, they’re busy promoting themselves. 

Burkle says he and Hagen are committed to running BurkleHagen as a teaching studio. “Assistants will have to shoot their own work or we’ll ask them to leave,” Burkle says, explaining that he believes assistants who shoot their own work are more engaged on the job. It was, after all, one of the keys to his own quick rise in the business.

article.article_title: What's Your Niche: Bill Ingalls, NASA Senior Photographer
article.meta_description: Bill Ingalls, a NASA photographer since 1989, discusses assignments and what he looks for in a NASA shooter.
article.article_text_abstract: Bill Ingalls, a NASA photographer since 1989, discusses assignments and what he looks for in a NASA shooter.
article.article_image_caption: Launch of space shuttle Atlantis in July 2011 at Kennedy Space Center.
article.article_text:
Bill Ingalls, who has been a NASA photographer since 1989, describes the variety of assignments he covers, and explains what he looks for when hiring other photographers for the U.S. space agency.

PDN: How did you become a NASA photographer?
Bill Ingalls: I was in college at Waynesburg University outside of Pittsburgh. An alumnus who worked for NASA offered a [media] internship. I was fortunate enough to win that, because other students I was competing against got afraid and gave up. That was a lesson in life: Don’t give up.

PDN: How did the internship turn into a career?
BI: I finished my degree and taught television production at Robert Morris College [now called Robert Morris University] in Pittsburgh. But I’d had such a great summer at NASA that I continued to call repeatedly [about openings]. I joke that they got so sick of me calling that they said, “Get him an office in the corner and we’ll hear less from him.”
PDN: What was your assignment, and how has it evolved since you started?
BI: When I first started, my job was to cover press conferences at NASA headquarters, and shoot a lot of grip-and-grins—VIP handshakes, awards ceremonies. We still do all of those things, but we now cover bigger assignments outside of Washington, DC, too.

PDN: Like what?
BI: We make a lot of trips to Florida to cover Space Shuttle launches and landings. And we have our hands full covering our relationship with the Russians. My first trip to Russia was for meetings with our counterparts in 1991, [and] my first [Soyuz] launch in Kazakhstan was in 1995. 
   
NASA recognizes the power of the photograph. If you ask people about the most important photos we’ve seen in our lifetime, most people are going to mention the first time we saw earth from space. That has not gone unnoticed within NASA.
   
PDN: What are you looking for when you’re covering a Soyuz launch?
BI: I try to capture some of the people doing that work, and hopefully a little bit of emotion. That’s sometimes the toughest thing when you’re talking about photographing hardware: trying to bring in the human element. Seeing a rocket is exciting, but I’ve seen it a lot of times, so I look around at peoples’ faces. 

PDN: What’s the most appealing part of this job for you?
BI: I like a challenge. We’ve shot a million press conferences here at NASA headquarters, and every time I ask myself: What can I do to tell the story in a creative way? You need to be on your toes. For any assignment I’m given, I do my homework. I make sure I understand what the mission is, and often I prepare caption templates and keywords. I think about who will be there, and I pre-visualize the assignment and ask: What kinds of images might I get out of this? So when I’m on assignment, I’m not thinking about these things for the first time.

PDN: Aren’t you straddling the line between documentary and public relations photography?
BI: Yeah. I’m a NASA contractor, but I do think that one of the reasons my office has been fairly successful is because we don’t just put out smiley images. NASA is known—in government circles, at least—for being on the forefront of social media, and for engaging the public. They take that same kind of thinking to photography and TV. We do a good job at keeping it real.

PDN: What gear do you typically carry in your bag? 
BI: The basic bag for all the photographers in the office is two Nikon D4 camera bodies, with 14-24mm, 24-70mm and 70-200mm lenses, a couple flashes and maybe a couple of 1.4x teleconverters. Then there’s a shelf of shared equipment, with lots of prime lenses.

PDN: Is there any specialty gear that NASA photographers use? 
BI: The biggest thing, which is not unique to NASA, is remote triggering devices. You can’t stand 100 yards from the rocket and take pictures, even though I’ve done that.

PDN: You have?
BI: At the first Soyuz launch we [photographed] in 1995, we had set up a tree of remote cameras and said, “Let’s get out of here.” Our guide said, “This is where you’ll stand for the launch.” It wasn’t a smart thing to do. It’s extremely loud, and there’s a lot of debris that flies around the pad. Anything loose on the ground becomes a projectile. It’s not unusual for us to go retrieve our remote cameras and have the front end smashed out of the glass.

PDN: What type of experience do NASA photographers bring to the job?
BI: It’s very mixed, from sports photography to travel to fine art, even. And I should point out that we wear multiple hats. We’re not just photographers. My job is senior photographer and project manager. Another contractor is a photographer and photo editor. The other position is photo archivist and photographer, which requires experience with digital asset management.

PDN: How do you select photographers? What do you look for?
BI: It’s extremely tough. A lot of good, very talented photographers want to work here. Obviously you’ve got to have the chops to make good pictures, but that’s not hard to find these days. We’re looking for personality, too: folks who can remain calm and handle the stress and frustration that can come with this job. There’s bureaucracy to deal with. I tell folks: Taking pictures is the easy part of your job. 

PDN: So how do you find the right people?
BI: With a lot of interviewing, a lot of references, and knowing people. 

PDN: What advice would you give to photographers who aspire to shoot for NASA?
BI: My advice is that it has to be something you love in order to get good pictures from it. But you have to show a range, too. The sexy stuff is only 10 percent of it. A lot of people walk in the door and can’t wait to go to a launch, but I have to tell them, “You’re going to shoot some passport photos, you’re going to do some grip-and-grins, you’re going to do awards ceremonies,” and I still do those things to this day. That’s what pays the bills, and we’re lucky we get to shoot this other stuff that keeps us jazzed.
