When [national reporter] Trymaine Lee went to Florida for the George Zimmerman verdict, I assigned Wayne Lawrence to photograph Goldsboro, [an historic African-American community, not far from where Trayvon Martin was killed], to examine the social and economic state of the area before and after his death.

PDN: Are you working mainly with photographers you’ve worked with in the past or are you open to finding new photographers?
AP: We’ve published some great bodies of photography blogs—any venue showing serious reportage really. The photo department meets every other week to go over pitches and to discuss future photo essays and assignments.

PDN: What qualities, skills or expertise make a photographer right for one of your assignments?
AP: We are looking not only for great photographers, those who can compose an engaging and interesting photograph, but they should also be solid journalists who can report a story with depth and intelligence. That includes complete, accurate captions, [and] multiple aspects and perspectives on a story.

I have a particular love of photo essays, which are so much more than just a series of photos in a slide show.

PDN: What do you think distinguishes a good photo essay from a good slide show?
AP: I think there’s an art to editing both but the distinction for me is that a slide show is a collection of interesting photos, and a photo essay is an in-depth, reported story that goes beyond any one picture. It’s the storytelling aspect that is crucial and that takes reporting, research, and, over time, intimacy and depth. Apart from the photographs, which work with one another to inform and play off each other almost in conversation, there is also the importance of informative and meaningful captions. We also always have a written introduction work from photographers who were new to us, like Oksana Yushko [who photographed “Unwanted people: A portrait of Crimea”] and Greg Kahn [on the effect of rising sea levels on communities along the Maryland shore].

PDN: Where are you looking for new work?
AP: We spend a lot of time researching and watching what people are doing. We look at agencies, of course, photographer’s websites, Instagram and other social platforms, award and grant winners, or essay to go with photo essays. We rarely publish a picture story without adding to it.

We publish three to five photo essays a week and choose them based on different factors. Sometimes it’s because of current events, as with Victor Blue on assignment in Afghanistan to cover the election. Other times it’s a good subject for our audience, like Charles Ommanney’s gun control story, which he had shot previously but never published.

PDN: What’s the purpose of the MSNBC.com Instagram feed (@msnbcphoto)?
AP: I see it as an extension of our site, another editorial tool to showcase the work we do. It’s the fastest growing major mobile platform with an audience whose sole purpose is to look at photography, so it seems like a natural fit. We kicked it off in March with Mark Peterson covering CPAC [Conservative Political Action Conference] for us, and Wayne Lawrence, Balazs Gardi and Jared Moossy at the South by Southwest Music Conference and Festival (SXSW). Everything that’s on our Instagram feed is either from an assignment, the Week in Pictures or from a photo essay that we have featured on the site. With the IG feed, the hope is that we are generating interest in the subjects we cover and maybe even furthering a public discourse around these issues and at the same time, building a new audience for MSNBC. There are a lot of very young people on IG but they seem to be into it. They’re commenting and engaging, even though some of the pictures we’re showing are of some pretty tough subjects. I think that’s encouraging.

PDN: It seems like MSNBC.com runs more overseas stories than the network does. Why?
AP: I personally want to show the international stories. I think it’s important to round out our coverage and show stories to our audience that they perhaps haven’t seen otherwise or from a different perspective. I feel we have a social responsibility to show a broad range of important work.

PDN: How is your work at MSNBC.com different from your previous work on print publications?
AP: Very different. It’s a very fluid process: There is very little that is fixed like a print publication; you don’t put it to bed at the end of a week like at a weekly magazine. We have room to run long essays with 30 pictures if we want, or to write a 1,000-word introduction if that’s what works best.

Because we are building this from the ground up and working very hard at it, there is a really positive sense of possibility and community here. Each of us is very vested in it and we want to do good work. That’s inspiring and very exciting.

article.article_title: Why Editorial Works: Flora Hanitijo for Port
article.meta_description: The photographer discusses a memorable portraiture subject, and explains why meeting interesting people makes editorial work worthwhile.
article.article_text_abstract: The photographer discusses a memorable portraiture subject, and explains why meeting interesting people makes editorial work worthwhile.
article.article_image_caption: Image of jazz pianist Ahmad Jamal by Flora Hanitijo for Port magazine.
article.article_text:
It's no secret that budgets for editorial photography are often slim, deadlines are frequently tight and subjects can be less than accommodating. Yet the creative freedom, challenges, experiences and opportunities to make great pictures offer photographers something they can't get from any other type of work. In this series of articles about editorial photography, which originally appeared in the June Photo Annual issue of PDN, photographers talk about what made their favorite editorial jobs great, and about what editorial work means to them. Use the below links to read other articles in this series:
Why Editorial Works: Kareem Black for VIBE
Why Editorial Works: Jamie Chung for Document Journal
Why Editorial Works: Ackerman + Gruber for The Wall Street Journal
Why Editorial Works: Brian Finke for National Geographic

When Flora Hanitijo received the call from UK-based magazine Port to go and photograph legendary jazz pianist Ahmad Jamal, she didn’t know what to expect, and she certainly didn’t anticipate an experience that she says gave her “the jitters for days” after the shoot. “I just thought it was another portrait job, and I had to do a video,” she recalls.

Hanitijo, who estimates that 60 percent of her work is editorial and the rest commercial, photographed and shot video of Jamal at his home outside of New York City. “I was in his living room with two baby grand Steinway [pianos], recording him playing for me all day long.” The next day, she says, he played Carnegie Hall. The shoot appeared in the Winter 2013 issue of Port, the quarterly men’s general interest magazine, and Port used Hanitijo’s 2-minute video to promote the issue.

Port was “really cool about a lot of creative freedom,” she says, something that characterizes her favorite editorial jobs. But Jamal himself made this particular assignment memorable. Hanitijo says he was an “awesome” presence, who was humble and “respectful of my work,” spending most of a day with her and her audio tech, “which was so kind of him.”

Hanitijo says she chooses which editorial work to take based on whether the job makes sense for her creatively, and then evaluates the budget. “If it doesn’t add to my portfolio and [take me] where I want to go, I step back and look at it and see if it’s worth it or not.” At times she’ll come away from an editorial shoot with good images for her portfolio, but the experience isn’t great due to factors like “weather, personalities, production, budget.”

This was an instance where the experience made the shoot. “Meeting a really graceful, talented person—that was what was so great,” she says. “A lot of the time you meet such amazing people doing portrait work,” she adds.

article.article_title: Why Editorial Works: Brian Finke for National Geographic
article.meta_description: How the photographer's Instagram photos of barbecue helped land him a dream assignment for National Geographic.
article.article_text_abstract: How the photographer's Instagram photos of barbecue helped land him a dream assignment.
article.article_image_caption: A BBQ image by Texas native Brian Finke that helped land him an assignment from National Geographic.
article.article_text:
It's no secret that budgets for editorial photography are often slim, deadlines are frequently tight and subjects can be less than accommodating. Yet the creative freedom, challenges, experiences and opportunities to make great pictures offer photographers something they can't get from any other type of work. In this eries of articles about editorial photography, which originally appeared in the June Photo Annual issue of PDN, photographers talk about what made their favorite editorial jobs great, and about what editorial work means to them. Use the below links to read other articles in this series:
Why Editorial Works: Kareem Black for VIBE
Why Editorial Works: Jamie Chung for Document Journal
Why Editorial Works: Ackerman + Gruber for The Wall Street Journal

While he shoots occasional advertising jobs, Brian Finke’s work is primarily editorial and he likes it that way. “I love to be busy working, so I always try to fit jobs in,” he says. Finke doesn’t promote himself to editorial clients heavily. However, he has made personal projects that he has published in books, exhibited in galleries such as ClampArt in New York City and Galerie Wouter van Leeuwen in Amsterdam, and shared online.

As a result, he says, he gets calls from editors when the subject matter suits his personal style. “I get called to go and make my pictures,” he explains.

Finke evaluates which editorial assignments to take based on the subject matter and the editor who calls. When National Geographic asked him to spend six weeks in Texas creating a photo essay about “America’s love of meat,” it wasn’t a tough decision. The editors at National Geographic tapped Finke, who had never worked for the magazine, in part because he often posts images of his own barbecue and grilling exploits on his Instagram feed.

So far he’s photographed cowboys and slaughterhouses and butchers and family dinners and other subjects for the assignment, which is scheduled to appear in National Geographic this fall. A Texas native, Finke, who is based New York City, has wanted to do a project in his home state for years, he says. The National Geographic assignment “feels like one giant personal project.” Because of the amount of time National Geographic allows, “if something’s not working, you can go back the next day.”

“I come from working on assignments where you show up and work through it and produce, basically, regardless of the circumstances,” he adds. This job is “definitely spoiling me.”

article.article_title: Why Editorial Works: Ackerman + Gruber for The Wall Street Journal
article.meta_description: The photography team Ackerman + Gruber recall a challenging photo and video assignment about a lobotomized World War II veteran, and explain why editorial work appeals to them.
article.article_text_abstract: The duo recall a challenging photo/video assignment about a lobotomized World War II vet, and explain why editorial work appeals to them.
article.article_image_caption: Roman Tritz, photographed by Tim Gruber and Jenn Ackerman for The Wall Street Journal, heads toward the King Street Kitchen, which he’s visited everyday for more than 30 years
article.article_text:
It's no secret that budgets for editorial photography are often slim, deadlines are frequently tight and subjects can be less than accommodating. Yet the creative freedom, challenges, experiences and opportunities to make great pictures offer photographers something they can't get from any other type of work. In this series of articles about editorial photography, which originally appeared in the June Photo Annual issue of PDN, photographers talk about what made their favorite editorial jobs great, and about what editorial work means to them. Use the below links to read other articles in this series:
Why Editorial Works: Jamie Chung for Document Journal
Why Editorial Works: Kareem Black for VIBE
Why Editorial Works: Brian Finke for National Geographic
Why Editorial Works: Flora Hanitijo for Port

One of the most exciting things was just this idea of the unknown,” says Tim Gruber of a recent assignment for The Wall Street Journal. He and his wife and partner, Jenn Ackerman, were commissioned to capture photographs and video of Roman Tritz, a 90-year-old World War II veteran who is one of 2,000 soldiers given lobotomies by the U.S. government in an attempt to cure their post-war mental illnesses.

Tritz lives alone in La Crosse, Wisconsin, and doesn’t have a telephone, so Ackerman, Gruber and writer Michael M. Phillips went to his house without knowing how he’d react to them being there. (Phillips had sent him an overnight letter in advance, but otherwise there was no communication, Gruber recalls.) “One of the more exciting things about editorial work is it allows you to be curious,” Gruber says. “There are all these possibilities before the shoot and you’re not quite sure what you’re walking into.”

The photographs, which were featured in the print edition of The Wall Street Journal and in a multimedia digital presentation, depict Tritz in quiet moments at home; eating alone at a restaurant he’s gone to everyday for more than 30 years; and visiting a VA hospital. The video footage of Tritz became part of a short documentary film for the story’s digital package, in which he talks about his lobotomy and experiences since.

Their editor for the assignment, Matthew Craig, told them he wanted photos and video that were “full of emotion and mood” that conveyed some sense of the life Tritz lives, alone and still very paranoid. Otherwise he gave them free rein.

With “commercial or ad work it comes with a higher price tag, but most likely you’re giving up a great deal of creative freedom,” Gruber says. “We love editorial work because we get all of this creative freedom to go out and almost treat every assignment as if it was a shoot just for us.” Often editorial work will end up in their quarterly promo newsletters, or they will print a postcard about the assignment and send it out, Gruber says.

He also notes that there is “a lot less hassle in editorial work,” including back and forth with clients. “We love just being out and creating. We spend too much time behind our computers as it is.”

article.article_title: Why Editorial Works: Jamie Chung for Document Journal
article.meta_description: Jamie Chung describes how editorial work enables his creative growth.
article.article_text_abstract: Jamie Chung on a fascinating recent shoot, and how editorial work enables his creative growth.
article.article_image_caption: An image of a sculpture by Pierre-Jean David D’Angers by still-life photographer Jamie Chung, shot at The Frick Collection for Document Journal.
article.article_text:
It's no secret that budgets for editorial photography are often slim, deadlines are frequently tight and subjects can be less than accommodating. Yet the creative freedom, challenges, experiences and opportunities to make great pictures offer photographers something they can't get from any other type of work. In this series of articles about editorial photography, which originally appeared in the June Photo Annual issue of PDN, photographers talk about what made their favorite editorial jobs great, and about what editorial work means to them. Use the below links to read other articles in this series:
Why Editorial Works: Kareem Black for VIBE

One of the main reasons still-life photographer Jamie Chung shoots editorial work is because it allows him to make a lot of pictures and grow as a photographer. “Shooting and experimenting [are] the only ways I can really see getting better,” he says. And while he could try and improve on his own, working with magazine art directors and photo editors leads to “a collaborative growth where I’m pushed stylistically or conceptually,” he says, which has been “a big part of the improvement” in his work. “It makes my eye sharper and makes me faster and able to shoot different types of things.”

Chung also publishes the editorial work he’s happiest with on his blog, and enters it in contests, which he says are “a really good platform to get your name out there.”

Editorial work also offers a variety of different assignments that are “life-enriching,” Chung says. “I’ve been able to have all of these experiences where I’m traveling to shoot [in interesting places] ... I want to work with interesting people and shoot interesting things, that’s why I got into this, so I feel a lot of fulfillment there.”

One of Chung’s favorite assignments from last year came from Document Journal, a print and digital publication devoted to esthetics. The Frick Collection, a New York City museum, was getting ready to open the first American exhibition of the work of nineteenth century French sculptor Pierre-Jean David d’Angers. Chung went to the museum and set up a makeshift studio in the vault, working with art handlers to photograph the sculptures included in the show.

The brief from Document Journal specified that Chung do something different than one might see in a museum catalogue. “That was perfect for me,” Chung says. His images, which he shot on black seamless, are lit to bring out the beautiful texture of the works.

article.article_title: Why Editorial Works: Kareem Black for VIBE
article.article_text_abstract: The photographer discusses the value of doing editorial work for magazines, and a favorite recent shoot with comedian Kevin Hart.
article.article_image_caption: Comedian Kevin Hart photographed by Kareem Black for VIBE magazine's 2014 "Race Issue."
article.article_text:
It's no secret that budgets for editorial photography are often slim, deadlines are frequently tight and subjects can be less than accommodating. Yet the creative freedom, challenges, experiences and opportunities to make great pictures offer photographers something they can't get from any other type of work. In this first in a series of articles about editorial photography, which originally appeared in the June Photo Annual issue of PDN, Kareem Black talks about a great editorial jobs he recently shot for VIBE, and about what editorial work means to him.

I want to do more editorial work,” exclaims Kareem Black. “I hate going to Barnes & Noble and seeing all the magazines that I’m not in.” Black works mostly on advertising jobs, and is happy to do so, but he’s making a concerted effort, including creating new promos targeted at editors, to get more editorial assignments into the mix of his business.

“I’m not as worried about numbers as my agent is,” Black says. “That’s what they’re paid for. I want to take some fucking pictures.” While commercial assignments are more lucrative, editorial work is about “the adventures and the pictures,” Black says. And it’s also valuable promotion, he believes. “Your successes in editorial are very public. Money is rarely the driving force in editorial photography. Editorial can be great promotion.”

VIBE magazine is among the editorial clients Black does have, and he’s admired the magazine since he was an undergraduate. “VIBE was on the level of Rolling Stone for me [as a young photographer],” he says. “I always have a special place in my heart for VIBE.”

Black has photographed three covers for the magazine, including a recent shoot with the comedian Kevin Hart for VIBE’s Race Issue, which was released in December of last year. That shoot presented an interesting challenge, Black says. The topic of race is “by nature potentially incendiary,” so the question was, “How do we navigate the race issue ... in a smart way?” Black explains, “When the call came in I was definitely interested in that aspect of the challenge.”

The cover depicts Hart sitting against white seamless beneath the legs of a white model, which form an inverted-V over his head. One of the interior photographs shows the woman stepping on Hart with her stiletto.

article.article_title: Picture Editor Mike Davis On Clarity of Voice in Today's Media Landscape
article.meta_description: One of the industry's most revered picture editors explains why it's pivotal for photographers working in today's media market to establish a personal vision.
article.article_text_abstract: One of the industry's most revered picture editors on why establishing a personal vision is essential for photographers now.
article.article_image_caption: Picture editor Mike Davis is also the Alexia Tsairis Chair for Documentary Photography at Syracuse University
article.article_text:
This article is part of a series, "The Next Big Ideas: Thoughts on recent trends and innovations likely to influence photography in the year ahead," which appeared in the June Photo Annual issue of PDN. Use the following links to read other articles in this series: 
Why Social Media Marketing Demands Great Photography
Why CMOS Sensors Are Changing Medium-Format Photography 
Ivan Sigal on Bringing New Ideas and Underrepresented Voices to Storytelling
Hackathons: Asim Rafiqui On The Value of Multidisciplinary Experiments 
The Market for Better-Looking Stock

It’s an interesting commentary on the state of the photo industry that one of today’s more revered picture editors doesn’t work at a traditional media company. Though Mike Davis was twice named Newspaper Picture Editor of the Year (POYi and BOP), and spent time at National Geographic and The Oregonian, for the past four years he’s primarily been a consultant, working directly with photographers on everything from editing  finished bodies of work to advising them while a series is in progress in order to fill holes in their narratives. Last fall, he also became an adjunct professor and the Alexia Tsairis Chair for Documentary Photography at Syracuse University.

Being in the unique position of collaborating with a variety of photographers, who have recently included Diana Markosian, Lynn Johnson, Zun Lee, Sol Neelman, Ivan Kashinsky and Karla Gachet, gives Davis a keen insight on the direction the industry is headed.

Considering the current media landscape, in which viewers are inundated with imagery, Davis believes strongly that photography with a “voice” has a better chance of breaking through the clutter. “It’s always been true, I guess, that the uniqueness of a photogra- pher and the photographer’s voice ... is what got people hired, it’s just more true now,” he explains. Davis finds the old idea that a photographer should be an impartial observer of events no longer applies. Instead, he believes the photographers whose work is sought after today “are powerful in what they say [and] in how they take a photograph.”

Finding your own photographic voice can be difficult, he notes, though he likens it to a light switch being turned on: “Whether a light comes on is dependent on the person. Some people don’t have a lot of ‘self’ to explore or to express, so even though they may try, it’s not going to happen. But obviously unless you never know that is a goal, then you’ll never go there.” For Davis, this is the difference between “molding” your work to a client’s needs versus having a client hire you for the “unique way in which you perceive the world through your photographs.”

Davis advises both his students at Syracuse University as well as emerging and professional photographers to create powerful and varied bodies of work that are “like the work you want to do.” Now more than ever, he notes, you will be hired based on the work you are currently shooting. “It’s a somewhat simplistic notion, but that’s what distinguishes [a photographer] ... compared to the old days of producing a general portfolio of work.”

He encourages the photographers he works with to explore their subject matter in a way that is “dynamic and dimensional.” Davis explains, “The assumption is [that] the more complex the ‘why’ is, the more interesting the ‘how’ can be and the more directed [the images] will be.”

Additionally, a body of work should explore a subject from all angles. He cites the cliché of a photographer following around one homeless person and creating a single body of work from the images. Davis suggests instead focusing on poverty and the many ways it’s manifested in society. While homelessness can still be a part of the project, he explains, the project may cover other aspects, like the food eaten at a homeless shelter, the places where the homeless sleep, the cardboard signs panhandlers hold.

Equally important is presenting the work in the most emotionally powerful way possible, and also taking into account the platform on which it will be displayed. “I think increasingly you have to think about how you edit a body of work [for] the different places where it will live, and photography can live in so many more different places.” Essentially, every platform requires a different edit: a website, a print portfolio, a photo book, a gallery exhibition, an app. “Each one of [these places] does require a different way of thinking—in that the space where photographs live does have a pretty significant context: how you treat them, how you sequence them, how it feels when one sits next to another.”

For many photographers, Davis creates selections of 12, 20, 40 and 60 images, depending on where the series will be presented. He adds, “a lot of the core relationships between the photographs stay the same but with some variability.”

Having twice edited portfolios that won POYi’s Magazine Photographer of the Year honors, and having three times edited portfolios that earned POYi’s Newspaper Photographer of the Year honors, Davis firmly believes that the sequencing of images can impact how viewers (and contest judges) see them. Many elements are taken into account when Davis sequences images, including color, light, composition and where the subject is in the frame, but he rarely goes into those details with a photographer until a goal of what the work should communicate is set.

Davis strongly agrees with many in the industry who believe that, thanks to the increase in imagery that surrounds us now, the “visual literacy of the world is growing.” That change isn’t necessarily a bad thing, he notes. But it does mean that the quality of work and the way in which it is presented is even more important as a photographer builds his or her career. And it means that getting advice on honing and shaping a project is more valuable than ever.

“I think now there is a greater need for picture editors and people who can craft visual narratives [to] help photographers develop [their work],” Davis says, “at a time when there are fewer of us than there have [historically] been.”

article.article_title: The Market for Better-Looking Stock
article.article_text_abstract: Why stock agencies are gambling on the market for existing images with high production values.
article.article_author: By Mindy Charski and Holly Stuart Hughes
article.article_image_caption: Offset, a new divison of Shutterstock, is geared toward clients looking for higher end stock photos. The company licenses assignment outtakes and personal work by professional photographers, including this image by Bob Croslin.
article.article_text:
This article is part of a series, "The Next Big Ideas: Thoughts on recent trends and innovations likely to influence photography in the year ahead," which appeared in the June Photo Annual issue of PDN. Use the following links to read other articles in this series: 
Why Social Media Marketing Demands Great Photography
Why CMOS Sensors Are Changing Medium-Format Photography 
Ivan Sigal on Bringing New Ideas and Underrepresented Voices to Storytelling
Hackathons: Asim Rafiqui On The Value of Multidisciplinary Experiments
Picture Editor Mike Davis On Clarity of Voice in Today's Media Landscape

For years, news about the stock industry concerned the downward pressure on prices and bargain discounts, or the ridicule of clichéd and corny stock imagery on the Internet. But in the past year, two agencies have made gambles on the market for existing images of better and higher production values. Though the two agencies take very different approaches to the business of licensing images, both are trying to appeal to busy art buyers and researchers who need images and don’t want to spend the time to wade through giant archives to find them.

In February, Trunk Archive, the rights-managed licensing agency that handles the archives of 350 fashion, advertising and celebrity photographers, acquired rep group Bernstein & Andriulli (B&A) and its subsidiary Gallery Stock, the stock agency known for its roster of fine-art photographers like Stephen Shore and Larry Fink, as well as many commercial shooters. Gallery Stock began in 2005 when its founder, Bill Charles of Bill Charles Represents, formed a joint venture with Howard Bernstein, co-founder of B&A. While B&A and Gallery Stock will retain their brand identities under Trunk Archive’s ownership and continue to operate under Bernstein’s direction, the acquisition brings under one company the right to license images by many well-known photographers.

“They have made imagery available that typically wasn’t available because you had A-list photographers who didn’t want to go with one of the [traditional] stock agencies and now they’ve found a place that will be respectful of their work and much more in control and protective of it,” says Juliette Wolf-Robin, the national executive director of the trade association American Photographic Artists.

Many of the images that Trunk Archive and Gallery Stock offer were shot on assignments for clients who have the budgets for great preproduction and styling. “They’re better crafted images,” notes Toby Kaufmann, photo director at fitness, which regularly sources beauty and lifestyle images, as well as whole stories, from Trunk Archive. She runs the images prominently, she says. “It’s not stock as we used to think of it. It’s not running a 1/16 of a page: It’s opening a story.” While the magazine’s photo researcher will regularly search through large image archives like Getty Images, Alamy and Corbis Images to find quality work, Kaufmann says, “It’s exhausting.”

Yvonne Stender, photography director at Sunset, says Trunk Archive and Gallery Stock are her “go-to sources,” particularly when she wants an image that’s “evocative rather than literal.” She says, “I know I’ll never see the images I see on Gallery Stock or Trunk anywhere else.” Stender believes readers no longer respond to clichéd stock shots, and are “starting to have a better visual acumen.” When she can find it in her budget, she’s willing to pay more for what Trunk Archive and Gallery Stock offer. “They’re better esthetic quality, frankly, and their prices reflect that.” Kaufmann estimates that an image from Trunk Archive used as a full page typically costs around $1,000, which is more than she would pay at most large stock agencies.

The royalty-free stock agency Shutterstock is now bringing the idea of high-quality, well-curated imagery to the lower priced, royalty-free market. In September 2013, Shutterstock launched a new division called Offset, featuring assignment outtakes and personal images by successful commercial photographers including Gentl and Hyers, Maura McEvoy, David Prince and Stephen Frink as well as images submitted by other stock libraries and archives. “We realized there was a true need for higher end imagery, and we developed Offset to answer that need that our clients have,” says Keren Sachs, director of content development at Shutterstock.

“People can often have a notion of what a stock image looks like and with Offset, we’re trying to change people’s minds and open them up to what other things can be considered stock,” Sachs says.

Offset has its own logo, website and branding distinct from Shutterstock. Offset is significantly smaller than its parent company: It currently has 75,000 images by more than 150 artists, compared with the 35 million images by more than 55,000 artists Shutterstock offers. Its team of curators chooses images that have contemporary art direction and style, look authentic and tell a story.

Prices for individual images on Offset are higher than for Shutterstock, but direct comparisons can be difficult to make since they have different pricing plans. With Offset, users pay $250 for a small image of about 3 MB and $500 for a large image of around 50 MB—though enterprise clients can receive custom pricing. Shutterstock sells various levels of subscriptions, but users can also choose multi-image packs. One enhanced license plan offers two images for $199, for example, and another 25 images for $1,699.

This is still less than the high-end licensing agencies charge, and photography advocates like Wolf-Robin believe royalty-free agencies devalue imagery.

One agency that contributes to the Offset image collection is trying both the rights-managed and royalty-free models. The Licensing Project (TLP), which offers rights-managed licensing of images by dozens of fashion, editorial and commercial photographers, has submitted roughly 2,000 images shot by some of its photographers to Offset, according to TLP Managing Director Josef Siegle. The images he sends to Offset are quick release—not requiring model or individual artist approval—but have the polished esthetic of other TLP images, Siegle says. (Some photographers on TLP’s roster have declined to participate—typically because they want approval for how their images are used.) He thinks royalty-free can be a good deal for photographers of still-life and other images not requiring releases, making up in volume what is lost in large fees. “It is also opening up completely different markets to our brand,” he says. As he recruits new photographers to TLP, he’s letting them know that marketing through Offset is an option. Siegle adds, “The Offset website traffic should also increase our online presence when clients see our credit line on Offset.”

Busy photo editors and art buyers say they care more about the quality of the image—and how quickly they can find it—than how much they pay for it.

Michael Wichita, director of photography at AARP Media, says he wouldn’t ignore a good stock photograph no matter what the pricing structure or how many other clients can license it. “We’re very lucky that it still comes down to finding the right image for the right story and being able to give it the play it deserves.” Joe Rodriguez, associate photo editor of men’s Health magazine, says he welcomes new entrants in the licensing market. “It gives buyers more places to look,” he says, “and everyone wants more options, don’t they?”

article.article_title: How I Got That Shot: Photographing A Shiny New Ferrari
article.article_text_abstract: Veteran car photographer Tim Damon explains how he executed a challenging rig shot of a black sports car.
article.article_image_caption: Working with a camera mounted on a car rig during a long exposure, Damon had to adjust the light to accommodate the car's movement.
article.article_text:
In his 25 years as an automotive photographer, Tim Damon has made almost every kind of image that car clients demand: performance shots on race tracks, cars and trucks in dramatic landscapes, and lots of studio shots, sometimes done on his 18,000-square-foot stage in Los Angeles. But whatever the assignment, his goal is to bring out the unique contours of each car. “When designers sculpt a car, they want all those lines and shapes to be celebrated,” he explains. “What normally happens is that a client gives me a preferred angle: ‘This will be a three-quarter, passenger-side rear view.’ Once we set the angle, my job is to use lighting to make it look its best.”

Recently Damon got to employ all his skills for what he calls “a dream job” for Ferrari. The car manufacturer gave him a new car for two days, and asked him to take some “cool pictures” any way he liked. The four shots he came up with included outdoor shots and a shot he created in his studio, which he turned into a dark parking garage. Using multiple lights and a camera rig, he shot a long exposure, capturing the moving car in crisp detail, while the dark walls around the car blurred.

The studio easily accommodated the rig, which lifted the camera about 20 feet above the car, and scaffolding on which Damon stood to look down on the scene. The studio also provides storage for all the lights, cameras, gear, and camera trucks that Damon and his production company, Square Planet Media, own and use.

The studio also serves another purpose. Damon says he always prefers to get the shot he wants in camera. “It is sometimes easier just to fix it in the computer, but I would rather work harder and get it in camera.” However, if a location shoot isn’t working the way he wants, he may bring the car to his studio to get an additional shot for a composite. “That’s why it’s important for me to have my own stage: I don’t want my hands to be tied.” On a recent shoot for Lincoln, for example, he photographed the car in early morning light on a hill overlooking Los Angeles. The silver car’s reflective surface wasn’t showing all the colors of the city lights, however, and to Damon’s eye, looked detached. Back in his studio, he says, “I could use colored gels and different types of lighting sources to give the vehicle more shape and depth,” then he had his retoucher composite the two shots (see final image below).

Damon believes that his clients come to him knowing that he prefers not to rely on compositing, and he finds the challenge more fun. “I’d rather do the extra work,” he says, than have a retoucher do a job Damon enjoys. “I believe that if I get a Christmas card from a retoucher, I’m not doing my job.”

Logistics

For his studio shot of the Ferrari, Damon’s crew set up black cloths and flats to block off an area of the white studio and make it look like the inside of a parking structure. Damon mounted the camera to one of the rigs he designed himself for car photography. It was attached to the rear of the car, extended about 25 feet and lifted the camera about 20 feet high. Damon wanted the driver to maneuver the car out of the studio’s cyclorama. During a long exposure, the background would blur while the rig-mounted camera, moving along with the car, would keep the vehicle in focus.

The lighting had to be adjusted to accommodate the movement of the car. “When you’re doing a rig shot you don’t put a light here and there. It’s not like playing sheet music, it’s like playing jazz,” says the photographer. “The only way you’re going to get it is to start doing your exposure and then moving your lights. It sounds tedious but it’s fun.”

Damon oversaw the scene from scaffolding about 20 feet above the floor. To preview his work, he usually uses a second, smaller camera on the rig to deliver a live video feed, but on this shoot, it wouldn’t show him the blurred effect of the long exposure. To see that, he also tethered his main camera to a monitor so he and the digital tech could preview the actual shots and test the lights.

Lighting

“I say this all the time: Black cars separate the men from the boys,” Damon notes, because bringing out the contours in the dark metal is challenging and unforgiving.

He begins by lighting the car—“It’s the most important thing,” he says—but because the car is reflective, he has to consider how he’s lighting the background at the same time.

One Kino Flo created a streak of light on the window on driver’s side. Another light made the streak along the roofline. A line of Kinos was also positioned on the floor, with another slightly higher to create the line of light along the back of the car.

He placed one of the softboxes that he had made above the car; measuring 40 x 15 feet, the light is visible at the top of the frame as a streak of light. He says he positioned it to bring out the crease just above the driver’s door handle.

He also used a 10K ARRI tungsten light with a Fresnel just outside the left side of the frame, down stage. This light illuminated the floor and, in the long exposure, made it glow.

“Funny, I like big, big, big lights. I use old ones with big Fresnels on them,” he says. He prefers the quality of light from a tungsten rather than HMI, which Damon says feels “clinical.” When using a big light source like this, he positions it far from his subject. “If I flag off an area, it’s a softer transition than if you put a barn door on a 1K: That’s a harsh transition.” Using a large light source, he adds, “gives me the ability to come in with hot lights and kiss an area with hot lights. It won’t feel forced.” For example, he used an ARRI 1K tungsten light just to illuminate the area near the taillight on the driver’s side. Without illuminating that small area, he says, “There’s no shape there. I added the light so it’s more convex.”

Camera

A Hasselblad H4D camera with a 50-110mm f/3.5-4.5 HC AF lens was used for the Ferrari shoot. Damon estimates it was an eight- to 12-second exposure.

Post-Production

The studio shot of the Ferrari, one of four he delivered to the client, needed only slight retouching to remove the arm of the rig, a job Damon’s digital tech, Anthony Dias, performed. On jobs requiring compositing, Damon has the retoucher on set throughout the shoot, then produces a tight comp to show the client how the finished shot will look. “It is absolutely the best way to work,” he says. “Everyone is there: the retoucher, the client, the agency. We can make decisions and get everything expedited really fast.”

Related: Frames Per Second: Create Smooth Video and Tracking Shots on the Fly (And On a Budget)

article.article_title: Ivan Sigal on Bringing New Ideas and Underrepresented Voices to Storytelling
article.article_text_abstract: Media producer and Harvard Fellow Ivan Sigal discusses current storytelling strategies.
article.article_image_caption: Photographer Ivan Sigal is the executive director of the nonprofit media initiative Global Voices.
article.article_text:
This article is part of a series, "The Next Big Ideas: Thoughts on recent trends and innovations likely to influence photography in the year ahead," which appeared in the June Photo Annual issue of PDN. Use the following links to read other articles in this series: 
Why Social Media Marketing Demands Great Photography
Why CMOS Sensors Are Changing Medium-Format Photography 
Hackathons: Asim Rafiqui On The Value of Multidisciplinary Experiments
The Market for Better-Looking Stock
Picture Editor Mike Davis On Clarity of Voice in Today's Media Landscape

Ivan Sigal is a media producer who works on long-term photography, multimedia and writing projects and is the author of White Road (Steidl, 2012), based on eight years of photography and writing about Central Asia and Russia. He is the executive director of Global Voices, a nonprofit online global citizen media initiative. He is a fellow at the Berkman Center for Internet & Society at Harvard university, where he studies digital storytelling and online communities.

PDN: In 2012, you taught a course, “New Directions in Visual Storytelling,” in the master’s photojournalism program at Corcoran College of Art & Design. Who were your students, and what were you hoping to teach?
Ivan Sigal: My students were aspiring professional photographers, videographers and content creators who hope to be working in journalism. My intent was to help them understand that the mass-media market is no longer a given and that to have careers they need to have critical thinking around the stories they make and how they were making them, and to ask certain questions:

What’s the goal of my project? Which technology best serves my project? What is my audience and what is the best platform to reach them? For instance, if my audience is a poor community that primarily gets most of its news from the radio and they don’t have a lot of Internet access, does it make sense to do a rich HTML5 presentation?

Given that we now create work in networked environments, in which subjects are often telling their own stories, to what extent do I engage them in the creation of the content? What are the intended effects of the work: informational, educational, transformative?

Answering these questions may change the way you work.

When we submitted work to mass-media publications, these questions were taken care of for us by the publication. If you’re building a story without the support of a media institution, it becomes more important to understand who might consume or participate in your project and what kind of relationship you want to build with them. These choices will affect the way you tell the story.

Is the goal to make something that is beautiful? Is it informational or educational or dialogical? Is the goal to persuade? Perhaps a photo essay isn’t the most effective form; maybe there’s another way to make sure that the people affected [by the issue you’re covering] are heard.

I think it’s helpful to make work with an understanding of where that work will live. Work made with this understanding has a force and value that could transcend a two-minute engagement.

There have been a lot of projects involving creative use of technology that have failed. I think there’s nothing wrong with failure when you’re testing new technologies and tools. It can be challenging to create a workflow so the story is not overwhelmed by the technology. But I think you have to be comfortable with a certain amount of risk.

PDN: Risk of what, failure? Or loss of control over the use
of your image?
IS: That’s one kind of risk in this market. Some people are vigilant about policing the sharing of their work and I don’t criticize them. Others are more comfortable sharing.

We know that in a networked media environment, what’s abundant is content. What’s scarce is attention. You’re competing against everything for attention: talk, stories, Hollywood, social media, games—all occurring on the same screens. That’s the radical shift we’ve experienced. We also have immediate feedback on what people will or won’t pay attention to. In that context, sharing material is one way to draw attention.

PDN: Is interactivity important? It seems like it’s sometimes incorporated into online stories as a way for media producers to attract attention, but it doesn’t always inspire engagement.
IS: Personally, I think that bringing audience and producer closer together is a good thing for a couple of reasons. The first is transparency: It asks us when we make something to be aware that the person you’re representing will see your work. That makes our work better and more honest.

It also changes the idea that we have a producer and we have audience, and they are separate. We have a lot of language we use, such as “immersive,” “interactive” or “participatory,” to describe this change.

I think it’s important to ask ourselves why we’re trying to make the work. We tend to get fascinated with technology. Sometimes as a result the story serves the technology, rather than the other way around.

There’s no sense in making an HTML5 presentation out of every 800-word news item, but there are stories where just a touch of interactivity can enhance it. The medium changes the story. If you’re making a photo book, it’s linear, but a Web platform doesn’t require you to be linear. Much of the media we see online are using older forms transplanted onto the screens in front of us. We want to be conscious of that.

PDN: It sounds like your course was somewhat vocational: To survive as a photojournalist you need to know how to produce more than seven- to 12-image photo essays.
IS: There are other ways of conceptualizing, preparing and sharing work now. What’s the value of restricting yourself to that form? At least ask the question.

For instance, if your goal is to advocate for change on an issue or policy, showing an issue from a single author’s point of view might no longer be the most effective strategy. We now have the technology to have dialogue with people we’re documenting. Why isn’t that what we’re doing? It is at least worth exploring the affordances
of our technologies that allow us to communicate with the people we’re documenting.

There are numerous recent examples of this. Sandy Storyline created a platform that combines the documentation of professionals and subjects affected by Hurricane Sandy, adding layers of advocacy and conversation to the journalism. Homicide Watch D.C. works closely with communities to document every killing in the city, shifting the structure of homicide stories away from the relative importance of the victim or the sensational nature of a given murder, and emphasizing that many homicides that hadn’t been reported in the news still deeply affect the communities in which they occur.

PDN: One school of thought says that to survive in photojournalism, you have to be entrepreneurial, and act as your own publisher, agent, fundraiser. Another school says that to survive you need to be part of a team producing a larger, richer experience of storytelling. What do you think of those arguments?
IS: I think you have to be entrepreneurial within a team.

Let’s take a step back. What’s really important is to find the collaborators you need to make your project successful. I’m not sure the [photo] agency model serves that need. Perhaps it’s more of a Hollywood model, whereby people with specialized skills gather to work on a project. Some magazines, newspapers and agencies will be large enough to have those teams in-house, but a lot of media outlets won’t. If you’re a freelancer, you may need to come together with other freelancers in a collaborative project outside of institutions.

Some of these collaborations are occurring because people meet in story hackathons, or reviews. Others find collaborators through informal networks or university settings. There is no single way to find the collaborators you might need. An interactive Web documentary might need a photographer, a video editor, someone with database skills, someone who knows Java, someone else who is a front-end designer. Sandy Storyline is a good example of a project like this—collaborative, not based in an institution, with a lot of volunteer effort. And sometimes creative use of off-the-shelf plug-ins and applications can make great projects. Not everything needs to have a massive budget.

PDN: What did your students think of the course, and the examples of different kinds of visual storytelling you shared?
IS: For the most part, they were excited because one of the goals was to help them incorporate the ideas and the tools into their work. It was a chance to experiment. Some are now thinking about co-creating work with the communities they care about. Some interesting projects came from that.

PDN: What about the students who didn’t like the course? Why didn’t they?
IS: There weren’t many who disliked it. I think some were less interested in the social and economic questions; they just want to produce the work that makes sense to them. For some, that will be a great strategy. There’s definitely an argument that one should make work without too much regard for the context in which it will appear; a lot of brilliant and difficult material is produced with this attitude, and for many projects I also work this way. My primary point is: Ask yourself why you make the choice.

PDN: In your work on Global Voices, what have you learned from the citizen journalists you’ve worked with and what do you wish journalists in big media centers like New York City or London understood about them?
IS: I’ve learned a tremendous amount. Global Voices is a community of volunteer writers, editors and translators. We try to find stories that are interesting and important to local communities that are not well-represented in global media, and we explain and amplify their work. The inclinations and news frames of mass media become evident: We see who’s quoted, who’s not quoted, who’s given space. One reason that people participate in Global Voices is they want the chance to change the way people talk about the place they’re from.

PDN: A lot of professional journalists see “citizen journalists” as competition, as lowballers undermining the value of their reporting or images.
IS: To my mind professional and citizen are not opposing concepts. The question that interests me is why people choose to make and share images or to report on stories when it’s not a job. Many of the Global Voices reporters are professionals but they’re not writing for Global Voices for professional reasons; they’re doing it for civic reasons. If you think that civic engagement is important, and you believe that sharing information and stories improves engagement, then to me it makes sense to support [civilian journalism]. It doesn’t make sense to me to disparage people’s ability to create and share their work. As a society, I think we are enriched by it. 

One of the characteristics of a networked media ecology is that the center doesn’t hold. Yes, there are concentrations of capital and talent, like New York City and London, but the idea of “foreign” is becoming obsolete to me. What is interesting about network structures is that work by talented people can be [found] anywhere. If there are whole worlds and stories that are outside your focus, it’s easier than ever [to find them]. Rather than send a photographer to Tunisia, it’s good to also contact someone in Tunisia to tell the stories of the people there. It’s not necessarily worse.

article.article_title: Photographer Amanda Marsalis’s First Feature Film Debuts at LA Film Fest
article.meta_description: Photographer Amanda Marsalis reveals what she learned during the making of her first feature film, Echo Park.
article.article_text_abstract: The commercial and editorial photographer talks about learning to direct actors rather than models, and other lessons from her first effort as a movie director.
article.article_image_credit: Courtesy of Echo Park Films LLC
article.article_image_caption: A still from Echo Park, photographer Amanda Marsalis's directorial debut.
article.article_text:
Photographer Amanda Marsalis makes her directorial debut this month with the premiere of the feature film Echo Park at the 20th Los Angeles Film Festival. The film stars Mamie Gummer as Sophie, a successful Beverly Hills handbag designer who, needing a change of scenery, trades one Los Angeles neighborhood for another, Echo Park. The film follows Sophie as she develops a friendship with a longtime resident, Alex, played by Anthony Okungbowa, and comes to know this previously unfamiliar neighborhood and its culture.

Marsalis, who has lived in Echo Park for a number of years, shot the film over the course of three weeks with a crew that included a number of “old-school Hollywood guys” who were happy to help out a young director, she tells PDN. Marsalis met the film’s producers through a writer she photographed a few years ago, with whom she remained friends.

PDN spoke with Marsalis in April to find out what she learned about filmmaking while working on her first movie.

PDN: How was it learning how to direct actors?

Amanda Marsalis: It was a learning curve. Because at first—it wasn’t as if I was thinking about them as if they were models, but I was directing them more physically instead of emotionally. I was like, “I need you to do this and I need you to do that.” And I quickly learned that you do not get anything from telling actors that. You have to connect with them on an emotional level and talk about their character, and where they’re coming from and where they’re going, and where you need to get to and all of those kinds of things. I learned on set. I did not know that. There was no prep for that.

PDN: What are the biggest things you learned?

AM: Making a film is so much different than taking photos. And certainly they’re not related whatsoever. It takes so many people to make a film and there’s so much work that goes into it. And my photos are so reportage-y, I’m never one to set up a photograph or necessarily even think about it too much ahead of time, I just always show up and I can find the best photo in that given situation; making the film there’s months of pre-visualization, and talks about what rooms are going to look like and how things are going to change throughout the movie and what sort of visual language [we’re going to use].

I think it’s also changed me as a photographer because now I have a better ability to basically direct whomever I’m photographing and not just be like, “Hey, can you look to the left? Chin up!”

PDN: How do you think making a film will influence you as a photographer?

AM: It influenced me as a person, so that changes me as a photographer. But also I wrapped the movie and then went on a road trip with a camera and my boyfriend and just took tons of photos. I did the opposite of what I was just doing. My photo career is just like that, you know, giant production on a Norwegian cruise ship versus myself and one assistant in Merida, Mexico, for a week just discovering things. And then on the cruise ship it is all set up, we know exactly what time we’re going to be [shooting], we know exactly what our talent is going to be doing. We know what they’re going to be wearing, we know what we need, we’ve got the shot. I never like to do too much of one of them. I need the other one. Once I’ve done a few big jobs I’m like, “Please let me just go someplace by myself and take pictures for a while.”

PDN: Who was the most important person on the crew?

AM: I would say Maime [Gummer], our lead actress. And she’s amazing. She’s a really great actress and really good at what she does, and really beautiful and comes from an amazing family [Gummer is Meryl Streep’s daughter]. She fills those shoes.

PDN: How was your director-actor relationship with her?

AM: It was interesting. There is a learning curve and I was incredibly nervous and totally intimidated. As a director you have to be in charge. You have to be leading the ship and so you basically have to be like, “I totally know what I’m doing. Do this. This is what I think, this is what’s important.” And then I would go home every night and be like, “Oh my God. I hope I know what I’m doing.”

PDN: So how did you get over the nervousness?

AM: There was no option but to do it. There was no space for failure or for having a total breakdown or something. I was like, “I’ll just do it after the movie is over.” But then as soon as the movie is over you go into the editing room.

PDN: How has that whole process been?

AM: It’s been really good. We’ve been editing since August [2013] and we wrapped the picture [in March 2014]. I probably learned more about directing from editing than I did from being on set, because now I see like, “Ah, I could have used that [shot].”

You’re also like, “I should have shot a wide master for that scene that I could have cut out to”; all the ways you could save yourself in editing. It’s basically like shooting plates and being able to Photoshop things. And I think very experienced directors with very experienced talent don’t need to do that, as much as maybe younger, less experienced directors.

PDN: Are you going to do a superhero movie next? Something with a lot of CGI?

AM: I’d like to. I’d like to do Point Break. [Director] Katherine Bigelow is my favorite, I love her so much. Who knows? I’ve gotten a lot of support, which has been really wonderful and I’m very grateful for, and I’m just very hopeful that basically somebody will let me make another movie.

This interview was edited and condensed.

article.article_title: Hackathons: Asim Rafiqui On The Value of Multidisciplinary Experiments
article.article_text_abstract: The Pakistan-based photojournalist explains how hackathons could help push photojournalism forward.
article.article_image_caption: Pakistan-based photojournalist Asim Rafiqui.
article.article_text:
This article is part of a series, "The Next Big Ideas: Thoughts on recent trends and innovations likely to influence photography in the year ahead," which appeared in the June Photo Annual issue of PDN. Use the following links to read other articles in this series:
Why Social Media Marketing Demands Great Photography
Why CMOS Sensors Are Changing Medium-Format Photography
Ivan Sigal on Bringing New Ideas and Underrepresented Voices to Storytelling
The Market for Better-Looking Stock
Picture Editor Mike Davis On Clarity of Voice in Today's Media Landscape

Hackathons, originally events for computer programmers to collaborate on software projects, now also serve as laboratories for journalists and photographers who want to experiment. Asim Rafiqui, a Pakistan-based photojournalist who has contributed to TIME, Stern, The Wall Street Journal and other publications, recounts his own hackathon experience, and explains how hackathons could help push photojournalism forward.

Most photographers are trapped in outdated and outmoded forms of project production and conception. They are still mostly thinking of project structure in terms of linear stories, single or sequenced images, and a very basic story framework: The subject does this, then he does that, here you see her doing this and here she is doing that. Frankly, it’s all very boring and it largely comes from photographers and editors being trapped in the esthetics of the frame, and from rarely placing the image in a broader political and institutional context, from being afraid to try new stories and ideas, from a need to be published, etc. There are strong financial reasons for photojournalism conservatism— digital images and a simple online photo essay are the easiest, least expensive means to show work and require the least resources possible. Innovation and innovative storytelling approaches are inevitably more complex, and require more human labor and time.

Hackathon collaborations are critical for shaking photographers out of these comfort zones, and for forcing them to see new horizons with regard to online digital presentation, navigation and sharing. Hackathons push the photographer to work outside her small camera viewfinder and allow others to understand and contribute to what she is doing. That was my own experience [working] with [game developer] Kati London at the Bit by Bit hackathon, produced collaboratively between the Columbia University Journalism School and The Brown Institute for Media Innovation in February 2014.

Kati forced me to think about how digital audiences work online, share information, post thoughts and customize what they see. After all, the value of digital information comes from the fact that it can be shared easily and quickly. I had been experimenting with the idea of using images as core navigation tools for content but while working with Kati, we pushed this concept further and came up with the idea of images as containers that can be customized with information and shared over the Internet. Experimenting with an old project about American evangelicals that I shot for French National Geographic, we developed the idea of a “primary author” and a “secondary author.” The primary authorship is retained, but secondary authors (i.e., viewers) are able to “enhance” the image with their own thoughts, ideas, links and even images.

I believe that a deeper engagement with the issues we are trying to document can reveal previously unconsidered situations, events, locations and subjects central to a story we are trying to produce. For example, in a story about Somali piracy, an awareness of the connections between international trading agreements, industrial fishing fleets and the devastation of existing economic arrangements would completely transform how such a story is produced by a photojournalist. A similar set of complex forces explains so much of what is taking place on the U.S.-Mexico border, where dozens of stories have been produced about immigrants trying to cross over, but few connect this to trade agreements like NAFTA and the creation of zones of sweatshops, and the disinvestment in agriculture from surrounding areas. There are already photographers out there working in these complex forms. Matt Black, to name one; his broad, intelligent, and humane engagement with the conditions and lived realities of people opens up all sorts of possibilities for how projects are presented and produced. Others like Rob Hornstra or Carl De Keyzer are producing complex and broad projects. Their works are intellectually complex, and that is what makes them exciting for me.

Which brings me to a key point: There has been a singular focus on how technological innovations or tools will redefine photojournalism, and I think this singular hanging of hopes on technical solutions has distracted us from the storytelling possibilities the same technologies opened up. Despite all that, today we are still really only producing what are no more than traditional documentary films, though we call them “multimedia,” and assuming that this is enough. Or that various interesting website designs are all that is needed. What have not been explored are new story structures, narrative frameworks, image-to-text relationships, greater use of content and images working together, and so much else. That is, what has not really been looked at is how the entire modus operandi of a photojournalist can be redeveloped, and the ways in which entire issues can be covered.

Using hackathons to reimagine photojournalism isn’t merely to boost traffic, shares and “likes.” The point is to engage audiences with important issues in deep ways, thereby moving them to action. Online readers engage the digital world in many different ways, and turn to different sources of information and entertainment at different moments. 

Conventionally, “action” presumes intervention based on a sense of superiority, a moral right, a social responsibility: A [Western photographer] travels out, reveals “injustice” and “saves” people. This model of “action” has been the source of much misunderstanding because it requires “victims” and “saviors,” and an erasure of complexity and our involvement. This has to change. We need a broader idea of what taking action can mean. For me, “action” as an outcome of a work can be to move people towards understanding, awareness, recognition, protest, disruption, curiosity, humility, questioning, doubt, trust, respect.

In short, a move toward understanding and acknowledgement constitutes an important action; one need not do anything more. By creating works that reveal the forces—political, economic and social—that create the pathologies in the first place, we create space for a reader/viewer to choose her mode of action. Today, as a citizen of a nation responsible for violent interventions across the globe, I question whether we have a need “to act,” or whether it has become more important to question, criticize and dissent.

Technological and intellectual experimentation is required, not only to engage and motivate our audiences, but to update the intellectual underpinnings of photojournalism. As I’ve argued previously on my blog:

... photojournalism (photographers and photo editors) has been oddly immune to transformations that have affected other fields. An entire literature has broken through from worlds previously silent. Counter narratives to debilitating colonial histories are being offered. In America alone the voices of women, African-Americans, South Asians, the indigenous, and so many others can no longer be ignored and have enhanced and illuminated our understanding of ourselves and the experiences of history ...

Yet mainstream photojournalism still remains largely about silencing the other, and reconstructing their worlds and lives as defined by pathos, victimhood and hopelessness. Photographers still [produce] stories right out the works of Joseph Conrad, revealing the “darkest” Africa, the direst of Asiatic “despotisms” or Islamic “madness,” for example. And unlike [in] other fields, there seem to be few counter voices that make it onto the pages of our finest magazines or the podium of our finest awards.

Hackathons have the potential to address [these] issues. Ideally, they would bring together not just photographer/storytellers and technologists, but also sociologists, anthropologists, ethnographers, geographers, historians, and so on to enhance the content and context of the stories we are trying to tell. There isn’t just one story, as [the writer] Chimamanda Adichie once argued, and we have to start to break the intellectual and informational structures we have become very comfortable with.

For the same reason, I would love to see more editors invited to hackathons. They are the financial and editorial gatekeepers, and as employees of inherently conservative institutions, they curtail a lot of the creative energies of photographers. Few photo editors engage photographers as equals or invite them to help conceive, design, arrange or present projects. Perhaps there is no room for this in the hectic work cycle of a magazine, but certainly hackathons can begin to break this structure, by creating a space where photographers and photo editors can experiment together, and see what emerges.

It’s very exciting that so many institutions are experimenting. What would be useful is if there is a way to catalogue and share all the experiments being done so others can build upon them. At the moment, I fear that many good ideas arising from hackathons simply disappear. I would love to know more about what arises from Photography, Expanded [an initiative of the Magnum Foundation and Open Society] brainstorming [sessions], or about how the NPR teams have thought about the issues, for instance. Some hackathons are better at disseminating ideas than others, but I would like to see a public website where anyone can explore the projects, ideas and outcomes, and use them as inspiration for their own work.

These are the best of times and also the worst of times for photojournalism. Its relevance is in question, and the resources scarce as editorial publications have largely abandoned it and reduced it to simply illustrations and slide shows. It is in hackathons that photojournalists may yet again discover what had compelled them go out into the world in the first place—a need to tell an amazing story, to reveal hidden realities, to inform us of that which we had previously not known, and to do so in so compelling a fashion that we can’t help but look.

article.article_title: Why CMOS Sensors Are Changing Medium-Format Photography
article.article_text_abstract: The digital medium-format photography landscape changed dramatically this year and it was all because of a single chip.
article.article_image_caption: The Phase One IQ250 digital back was released in January 2014, making it the first imaging product to sport Sony’s 50-megapixel 44 x 33mm CMOS sensor.
article.article_text:
This article is part of a series, "The Next Big Ideas: Thoughts on recent trends and innovations likely to influence photography in the year ahead," which appeared in the June Photo Annual issue of PDN. Use the following links to read other articles in this series: 
Why Social Media Marketing Demands Great Photography
Hackathons: Asim Rafiqui On The Value of Multidisciplinary Experiments
Ivan Sigal on Bringing New Ideas and Underrepresented Voices to Storytelling
The Market for Better-Looking Stock
Picture Editor Mike Davis On Clarity of Voice in Today's Media Landscape

The digital medium-format photography landscape changed dramatically this year and it was all because of a single chip. Manufactured by Sony, the 50-megapixel, 44 x 33mm CMOS image sensor quickly established itself as a “game changer” in the medium- format world when it first appeared in Phase One’s IQ250 digital back last January. We got our hands on an early IQ250 production unit and put the back and its much-touted chip, which is the world’s first medium-format-sized CMOS sensor, through its paces during a field test. In a nutshell, we were pleased with the photographic results. Extremely pleased, you could say.

Medium-format cameras are great for capturing gorgeous, detail- rich images with massive amounts of resolution and exceptional dynamic range, but they’ve never fared particularly well when shooting at high ISOs in low light. (In fact, many digital camera backs can’t even shoot past ISO 800.) Older digital backs and their CCD sensors have traditionally produced extremely noisy images at higher ISOs that are damn near impossible to clean up in image-editing software. But just as digital SLRs successfully transitioned from CCD sensors to less noisy CMOS chips nearly a decade and a half ago, the new CMOS-powered IQ250 produced remarkably clean images for us all the way up to ISO 6400. Only a few months prior, this would have been unimaginable. But this new medium-format CMOS sensor was not limited to the Phase One back alone. In March, Hasselblad started shipping its new H5D-50c medium-format camera system, which uses the same Sony-made 50-megapixel, CMOS sensor as the IQ250. The chip will also be used in the new Pentax 645Z medium-format model.

Another benefit of using a CMOS sensor instead of a CCD in a medium-format camera is that it allows these camera systems to shoot faster. In the case of the IQ250, it can shoot at 2 frames per second (fps), while the H5D-50c has a 1.5 fps capture speed. No, that’s not close to the speed of a pro DSLR, but with a medium- format sensor that has 68 percent more capture area than 35mm full-frame, that’s exceptional. And as these CMOS chips start turning up in more and more medium-format models, the best could still be yet to come. In the case of the Pentax 645Z, it may already be here. Thanks, in part, to its CMOS chip, the 645Z is the first medium-format camera that can shoot HD video.

article.article_title: Frames Per Second: Documentary Film Traces the Roots of Play
article.article_text_abstract: David McLain and Jerome Thelia explain how they are funding and making their film about different sports around the world that are played with balls.
article.article_image_caption: A still from the film showing a rubber ulama ball in Sinaloa, Mexico.
article.article_text:
The team behind Bounce: How the Ball Taught the World to Play may not have taken the most conventional approach to making a documentary film but it seems to have paid off. David McLain, director of photography for Bounce, and Jerome Thelia, the film’s director, say that rather than sit around and wait for funding for the movie, they decided to shoot first and ask the bigger financial questions later. While that got the ball rolling on Bounce, it also meant a significant investment on their part.

“We put up $200,000 of our own money up front before we knew for sure we had a movie,” Thelia says. “While people advised us not to, it ended up being something we did absolutely right.”

McLain and Thelia, who co-founded the production company Merge in 2003, may not have been sure they had a feature-length movie when they started, but they knew they had a good story. Based on a book by Harvard anthropologist John Fox titled The Ball: Discovering the Object of the Game, the movie traces the roots of play through ball- based sports. Like Fox’s book, Bounce hops around the world, from Brazilian favelas to Congolese villages, with McLain’s RED Epic camera quite literally following a bouncing ball from game to game.

First Bounce

As in Fox’s book, the movie begins on the remote Orkney Islands off Scotland’s northern coast, where the ancient game of ba’ is still played. A sort of medieval precursor to modern-day soccer, ba’ is best described as (largely) non-violent “mob football,” where parts of a town fight to bring a ball to their respective sides. After shooting and editing footage of a ba’ game in the town of Kirkwall in Orkney, McLain and Thelia showed their dramatic video to a potential investor who not only loved the clip, but was impressed the pair had put up so much of their own money on the project.

“We showed him that we were in it for the long haul,” Thelia says. “The fact that we were willing to put up our own collateral turned out to be a really good move.”

With the long-term funding from the investor in place, the next step was picking locations, setting a shooting schedule and working on the extensive preproduction required. For McLain, who comes from a still-photography background but has worked in video for many years, the biggest challenge was to stop thinking like a one- man band and start envisioning the bigger picture. “What it’s taught me is that film is so insanely complicated and time consuming. When you watch a movie and there’s 500 people in the credits, it’s for a reason,” he says. “With still photography, it’s just you alone with a camera. With filmmaking, the authorship is shared in a way that’s difficult to get used to. It’s humbling.”

Also joining the project was Thelia’s wife, Anne Carkeet, who is a producer on Bounce and oversees audio recording. One of the first decisions the three made was to hire a skilled video editor, because they knew that bringing the different segments from different locations together would be an important challenge. Also key was culling over 60 hours of footage (and counting) down to a 90-minute film. The man for the task, they decided, was Greg Wright, who had edited several documentaries previously. 

“The single biggest line item in our budget was for the editor because the film is only as good as the editor,” McLain says. “And Greg’s been amazing. He has the perfect disposition for an editor: non- emotional, in a good way. He’s like a judge.”

Geared Up

Another big but unexpected investment was on storage space. With everything shot at 5K on the RED Epic, McLain has captured over 90 TB of data. They had budgeted $9,000 for hard drive space but spent over $20,000. Otherwise, however, gear costs have not been huge for the film. The Merge production company owns the RED Epic camera along with the Zeiss and Canon lenses McLain is using to shoot Bounce. His other main piece of gear is a Steadicam Zephyr camera stabilizer, which has replaced all the jibs and cranes he’s used in the past.

“It’s a super stripped-down kit,” he says. “When cinematographers see it, they say: ‘I’ve never seen an Epic that looks that small.’ We’ve never had more than three checked bags [on the airplane] and that’s usually just personal stuff. We could lose all our luggage and still be able to shoot.”

The relatively small gear load and barebones crew has allowed the Bounce team to cover a lot of ground while shooting. In addition to Orkney, Brazil and the Congo, they have traveled to Sinaloa, Mexico, where the 3,000-year-old sport of ulama helped first introduce the world to rubber via a nine-pound ball that’s hip-checked back and forth on a dusty court. They’ve shot video of dolphins playing with balls in Florida and captured footage of modern English soccer pitches. Oftentimes, a planned shoot will snowball into something else, such as when they filmed bonobo apes spinning soccer balls with their feet at a preserve in the Congo.

“We didn’t know what to expect.
