article.article_title: So You've Just Graduated with a Photography Degree. Now What?
article.meta_description: A compilation of recent PDN stories that provide tips and advice about starting a career as a photographer in fine arts, photojournalism, and other specialties, with information about working as a photo assistant and networking.
article.meta_keywords: PDN's 30, career advice,
article.article_text_abstract: To help recent graduates make the transition from college to work less daunting, we've compiled a list of recent stories that provide invaluable tips and advice about starting a career as a photographer.
article.article_text:
Photography programs at colleges all over the country are holding graduation ceremonies this month, which means there are probably more than a few soon-to-be graduates asking themselves: Now what? How do I find work in the industry? How do I start a career?

To help make the transition from college to work a little less daunting, we've compiled a list of recent stories that provide invaluable tips and advice about starting a career as a photographer. The advice comes from industry veterans, as well as PDN's 30 photographers, many of whom were photo students themselves not long ago. Together, these stories provide both inspiration and information--about resources, financial management, lessons they didn't learn in school (but wish the had), financial management, assisting, marketing and other topics that aspiring photographers need in order to start successful careers.

PDN’s 30 Photographers Provide Career Tips to Aspiring Photographers

2014 PDN’s 30 photographers Bobby Doherty (still life), Billy Kidd (fashion), and Bryan Derballa (editorial/lifestyle), discuss how they found their visual styles, how they use social media to get noticed, build networks and land jobs, and the importance of learning and practicing good business skills.

What I Didn’t Learn In Art School: Life Lessons From Photographers 

10 photographers who've recently earned graduate and post-graduate degrees answer the question, “What lessons didn’t you learn in art school that have been important to your career?” (for PDN subscribers)

PDN's 30: Best Lessons Learned

Emerging photographers featured in our 2011 PDN's 30 issue share the most important lessons they’ve learned about marketing, business and setting themselves apart.

5 Financial Steps to Launching a Photo Career--And Avoiding Pitfalls

Photographers featured in recent PDN’s 30 issues share the best and worst decisions they made when they began shooting full time.  

How to Land Photography Assisting Jobs

Professional photographers share how they hire assistants, and what makes an assistant get rehired. 

9 Tips for Getting Hired (and Re-Hired) as a Photographer's Assistant

Jesse Dittmar, Therese Gietler and Ari Michelson offer tips to aspiring photographers about how to get hired by the best photographers as as a freelance assistant, and how to comport yourself on set so you get re-hired.

PDN's All-Star Assistants

PDN's profiles of top assistants, with galleries of their portfolios, plus links to stories about photographers who recently made the move from assisting to launching their own careers.

PDN Video: Lens Blog’s James Estrin’s Career Tips for Photojournalists

James Estrin, founder and co-editor of Lens, the popular New York Times photography blog, talks about how to launch a successful career as a photojournalist. His tips and insight cover how to choose meaningful projects, the importance of photojournalistic process, and practical advice about portfolios, mentors, and relationship-building with editors and peers.

PDN Video: Miller Mobley: How to Build Relationships with Clients

Miller Mobley built a successful business as an editorial and commercial photographer in his native Alabama, then gave it up to start all over again in New York City. He discusses how he landed jobs in both places, and the importance of showing new work to potential clients every time he approaches them.

article.article_title: Why Photography Is Key For News and Culture Website OZY
article.article_text_abstract: OZY photo director Leslie dela Vega discusses how the digital publication finds and commissions photography.
article.article_image_caption: A recent example of Ozy.com's Good Sh*t section, which is dedicated to "the next must-have, must-do thing."
article.article_text:
Co-founded in September 2013 by Carlos Watson, an entrepreneur and former broadcast journalist, and Samir Rao, OZY is a news and culture website. The site offers eight stories a day about “the new and the next,” presenting them with large, bold photos. Photo Director Leslie dela Vega talked to PDN about how she sources the many photos the site serves up each week. A veteran of print magazines, her role at OZY is her first job at an online-only publication. A graduate of San Francisco State University, where she earned her BA in photography, dela Vega got her first magazine job at Vibe as an intern. She worked at SELF, Premiere and Teen People before returning to Vibe as its director of photography. She has also been a photo editor at Fortune, TIME, Essence and Fast Company. Last fall she returned to San Francisco, her birthplace, to work on the launch of OZY.

PDN: What is OZY’s editorial mission, and where does photography fit?
Leslie dela Vega: It’s a news and culture magazine that brings information on “the new and the next” to readers in a different way. It’s about science, technology, business, the arts—really anything that will interest people—and not just what’s trending now, but what will be trending soon. To fully appreciate it, you have to go through the articles and the variety of writing styles and photography. We also have The Presidential Daily Brief: a few sentences by the senior editor, Sean Braswell, about things you need to know that are happening today, with links to sources and stories not on OZY.

One of the reasons I came here is that, as one of the founders said, OZY doesn’t have a part-time love affair with photography. Photography is his love and he wanted the homepage to be covered with photography. The story pages also have big images at the top.

PDN: So what’s your process for finding all these images?
LDV: We try to work at least a week in advance. We have a content calendar and I’ll look at that and try to reach out to the writer or assigning editor to find out: Are there particular moments or people I need to find?

PDN: Are you primarily researching existing images, or assigning?
LDV: It’s mostly research. I go to all the photo agencies you can imagine and, if there’s something hard to find, I’ll also go to local newspapers or other sources. I love research. I find it challenging and exciting. You have to find creative ways to find the photos you need.

When I needed a photo of Gina Raimondo, the treasurer of Rhode Island [for a story called “OZY On: Women Who Shape the World”], I couldn’t find anything great on her that would work. Then someone gave me the name of photographer Mae Gammino and her images [of Raimondo] worked out great.

PDN: What are some of the places you look for existing images?
LDV: We have subscriptions with Getty and Corbis, but often I’m looking for very specific or conceptual images and my primary source for those is Gallery Stock or a specific photographer. For a story on the epizootic of 1875, I found a beautiful fine-art image by Andrew McGibbon for our homepage. Or more recently we did a piece on the artist BONOM and I found beautiful black-and-white images of him by Ivan Put. I use a lot of Gallery Stock images per month because they’ve got great quality and great photographers. For a story on bikes in Bogotá, Columbia, I found images on Gallery Stock. If I have a news peg in a story then it’s usually the obvious agencies, like Redux, Panos, Magnum and VII.

Among the more oddball sources I’ve used is Flickr. We did a story about a Tokyo neighborhood, Shinjuku, known for its bars: They can’t fit more than three to five people. They haven’t been photographed a lot. I looked on Flickr, and found both the pictures by photographer Will Robb and Flickr user AJPSCS. I’ll e-mail the photographers [of images I find] and let them know I’d like to use their images for a fee, and most of the time they’ve been great about it and it’s worked.

PDN: When do you assign photographs?
LDV: I’ll go through the content calendar and figure out what has to be assigned because there’s nothing good out there. We’ve worked with some great photographers. When we needed a portrait of film director Ava DuVernay [the first African-American woman to win the U.S. Directing Award: Dramatic at the Sundance Film Festival] I reached out to a few photographers to see who could shoot it. Emily Berl was totally available and did a great job. We did a portrait shoot with [writer] Zack O’Malley Greenburg in New York City; he has a new book out on hip-hop. I asked Rayon Richards to shoot the portrait, because I like his lighting and sense of space. He had about ten minutes [with Greenburg] and did a great job.

These portraits were all assigned for our “Rising Stars” feature. The Rising Stars are featured on the upper right hand corner of the homepage and it’s important that we have original art; I’m not interested in seeing a hand-out we’ve seen before.

Because we are just starting out, our fees are humbling but the photographer has artistic freedom and can shoot however they want without any real limits. We just ask for one setup and a couple of angles.

PDN: You’ve also run some photo essays.
LDV: I’ve reached out to some photographers I know to run unpublished photo essays. Like Melissa Golden: For a Thanksgiving feature, we ran images from her project on Homeboy Industries in Los Angeles. We have published photo essays by Benjamin Lowy on Sudanese fashion and Michael Lewis on his celebrity selfies. My goal is to put in at least one photo essay a week. Another is to assign more photography. Right now it’s on an as needed basis, but I’d like it to be on an “as wanted” basis.

PDN: Do you have any exclusivity requirements for the photos you’ve commissioned or licensed?
LDV: No. To have that, I’d want to pay photographers a lot more, and I’m not able to do that. And, really, OZY doesn’t need [exclusivity].

PDN: Japan, Colombia, the Sudan—it seems you have a lot of international stories.
LDV: [OZY co-founder] Carlos Watson wants a lot of diversity in our stories and in our photos. We have one or two international stories a day. We have great writers around the world and we want to reach people not only in the United States.

PDN: How has working at an online-only publication differed from working at print publications?
LDV: What’s really different is that readers only have a day [to] look at the homepage and absorb it. And, if you’re working at a monthly, there’s time to prepare and think about the image you’re going to use. With a daily, it’s like the snap of a finger: I have to feel in my gut that this is the right photo, then I move on. I’ve worked at weeklies, but this is something completely different. My adrenaline is going every day. I think this is the way the world is going, and I love the feeling.

article.article_title: The Pros and Cons of Continuous Lights
article.article_text_abstract: Photographer discuss why they turn to continuous lighting over strobes for some assignments.
article.article_image_caption: A Dior handbag photographed by Nigel Cox for Bergdorf Goodman’s Spring 2013 catalogue.
article.article_text:
The debate among professional photographers about whether to use continuous lighting or strobes has raged for years, but recent technological advances are starting to change all that, with both lighting options now used by many pros.

The hard and fast rule used to be that, if you needed to stop motion in your images, you always went with strobes. The brief flash of a high-intensity bulb at several thousandths of a second was the perfect tool to stop even the fastest movement in its tracks.

On the other hand, if you had a stationary object or a subject that could sit still for a few seconds, the warm glow of a continuous light source was often preferred. But if you had children in the scene, you could forget about continuous lights as they rightly earned the moniker “hot lights” by getting hot enough to burn anyone within a foot of their bulbs.

But times have changed for studio lighting. Gone are the days of lights so hot that it felt like you were standing directly beneath the sun. Kino Flos, tungsten lights, HMIs and fluorescent continuous lights are not only now much more color-temperature-friendly, but a lot cooler to use.

As for motion, strobes are still the very best way to freeze action, but digital cameras are so advanced that a quick ISO and shutter speed bump can also help in that department.

With all these advances, the playing field for continuous lighting versus strobes is a bit more level. To get a glimpse of why some pros choose one light source or the other or, in some cases, use a mixture of both, we talked to several photographers to find out what they like about continuous lighting.

The Simplicity of Tungsten
Australian-born still-life photographer Nigel Cox has worked for everyone from Bergdorf Goodman and Martha Stewart Living to GQ, Esquire and Bon Appétit. Since moving to New York City in 1999, he’s seen just about every assignment a professional photographer can come across, and he’s approached each one as a blank slate.

“I try to keep a really open mind with any project,” Cox tells PDN. “I try not to get too fixated on the first image that pops into my mind when I hear an idea or get a brief.”

It’s an approach that has made his lighting technique change from job to job and even come full circle in the course of his career.

“I have been using a lot of tungsten lately,” he says about his most recent work. “I’d used it long ago and then I ended up doing a whole period of strobe for a long time. Maybe for ten years, I didn’t use a lot of tungsten. Just sporadically. But now I’m shooting it a lot more.”

For Cox, the decision to transition back to primarily tungsten lighting is about quality and fit for the jobs at hand.

“I like something with really direct light and crisp shadows,” he says. “That is the main driving thing with the tungsten; getting a really crisp, beautiful shadow next to an object. Then it just happens to be that most things look great under tungsten light, like they do under sunlight.”

And it’s also a matter of simplicity. Cox will often load a strobe-heavy shot with multiple lights, but the added power and consistency of tungsten has given him a chance to get back to the simplicity of one strong light.

“I use a lot more lights when it comes to strobe,” says Cox. “I might have eight lights on set, and a forest of C-stands. It becomes far more complex when I’m using strobe. That’s part of why I like how simple the tungsten is, in a way. It speeds up the process because you’ve got one light source to deal with.”

That doesn’t mean, however, that Cox is beholden to the tungsten bulb. While nearly all of the photographer’s client-based work is still life, his personal work includes the juxtaposition of animals and still-life objects in a series called “Lucky Dog.” He’s not afraid to break out the strobes when needed to capture the spirit of the pups.

“Obviously, I’m not going to use hot lights if I’m shooting animals. I need strobes to stop the motion.”

High on HMI
For Richmond, Virginia, stock photographer and videographer Ariel Skelley, the use of strobes seems like a distant memory now that her business focuses so heavily on video capture with her HD-DSLR. After using strobes for over two decades, the transition into stock videography made Skelley swap out nearly all her lighting gear for continuous HMI lighting, which has created a brand new workflow.

“I was an assignment shooter out of New York City for 20 years,” she tells PDN. “In order to be a stay-at-home mom, I took a demotion to shoot stock. Shooting stock resurrected my interest in photography altogether, but it has necessitated switching out equipment. In one fell swoop, I got rid of all the Profoto strobes and bought Joker Bugs [continuous HMI lights], and started letting the action go for ten seconds instead of 1/250 of a second. Frankly, it’s a lot easier to tell the story in ten seconds. If it’s a kid opening a Christmas present, you get to see what’s inside the present.”

In order for her stock buyers to see those presents, however, Skelley needs powerful continuous lights, and not just for her video capture.

“The requirements for stock are really tough,” she says, “and there’s not much leeway. They’re real sticklers for, particularly, focus.”

In the past, strobes would have been Skelley’s go-to light source for making tack-sharp stock images, but the addition of video would have meant carrying around two completely separate lighting kits.

“I’ve got four Joker Bug 5600 lights,” says Skelley. “They’re beefy lights. I bring all four of those with me on location and sometimes I’ll bring a few Kino Flo lights with me, too. The negative side was the price ticket, but the positive side was not only that you get to work with this new media [video] but you also get to double your income.”

It’s not, however, just the efficiency or simplicity of continuous lighting that Skelley prefers. She recognizes that there’s a qualitative difference in her work with continuous lights as well.

“My favorite is constant lighting, but I consider the sun to be a constant light,” she says. “All any of us are doing—particularly in lifestyle imagery—is attempting to replicate what the sun is doing. The continuous lights also bathe the models in a nice glow. When people hear the pop, pop, pop of strobes, that’s become the audio signal to pretend you’re [posing for] a Vogue cover, which is so not what I need.”

And the advances in technology that have come along during her lengthy career aren’t lost on Skelley either. “I started in photography shooting Polaroids to test the light. Having continuous lights is nice to be able to see what you get.”

Mixing it Up
Perhaps the most interesting use of continuous lights comes from Jeff Brown. With clients that include The New York Times Magazine, Fast Company, Bloomberg Businessweek, WIRED and New York, the Brooklyn, New York-based photographer, recently chosen for PDN’s 30, has begun to make a name for himself with unique and striking portraits that feature stark contrast and bold lighting and are often just slightly askew from reality.

“There are a lot of really clean, incredibly efficient styles in photography,” Brown tells PDN, “but I just want things to be unique.”

Citing influences from such varied photographers as Yousuf Karsh, Richard Burbridge and Nadav Kander, Brown is far from simplistic when setting up his lights. Not only does he use multiple types of lights, often mixing strobe with his continuous light sources, but he also packs his studio full of numerous lights to get the effects he needs for each particular shot.

“The minimum is usually five lights and … all the way to seven,” he says. “I like to mix strobes with tungsten as well. I use a mixture for almost everything. I prefer hot lights, but I kind of like working with both. There’s a level of excitement and I feel like I’m a better craftsman.”

If you push Brown to make a choice between continuous lighting and strobes, he’ll come down on the side of hot lights, but don’t, for a second, think he’ll give up his strobes.

“The money jobs want everything super sharp so I might need strobes there to stop any motion,” he says. “I like to use long lenses as well so I’ll drop focus and stuff without strobes, but I prefer the hot lights. They wrap around the skin, whereas strobes kind of punch through it. In this way, it’s like the difference between a really sharp digital picture and a really sharp film picture. [The hot light] gives you the softer sharpness. There’s a thing about strobe where you can just tell the difference.”

Shooting with Canon EOS 5D Mark II and Mark III camera bodies, Brown will mix up his lighting kit to include both and, in certain cases, even bring in bigger and stronger continuous lights.

“If you want people moving around or if you want a full-length shot, then you need to get into larger lights,” he says.

And it helps that Brown rarely ever puts any diffusion between his lights and his subjects. One notable exception is his recent portrait of Texas Senator Wendy Davis for the cover of The New York Times Magazine. “Typically, I use straight lights, even for strobes,” he says. “No diffusion.”

It’s an interesting concept and a far cry from the lighting techniques employed by professional photographers just a decade ago. The technology has come so far that almost regardless of what types of lights photographers use, the results will often end up sharp, detailed and usable.

Lighting kits have become one of the most important ways that photographers can embrace their creativity and set themselves apart from others in the field. Rather than worrying about which light they have to use, they can now focus on which lights they want to use.

“I remember once, to stop movement when I was shooting catalogue, we wired up an elevator sensor remote control that opened and closed the doors, so that when the models stepped over that hairline trigger, they would be in focus and the camera would shoot,” Skelley says with a laugh. “That’s how we stopped movement at that time.”

Whether it’s continuous or strobe, it’s pretty clear that technology has gone a long way in helping photographers everywhere see the light.

article.article_title: Photography Blues: Portraits of Legendary Blues Musicians
article.article_text_abstract: A personal project documenting blues musicians helped commercial photographer Lou Bopp land exhibitions and rediscover the passions that brought him to photography.
article.article_image_caption: A portrait of "Mr. Johnnie" Billington, from Lou Bopp's series "Blues Musicians."
article.article_text:
The man smiles broadly, revealing several missing teeth, as he holds his callused and bandaged hands up to the camera, palms out. They are the tools of a blues musician and, even without a guitar, they tell one hell of a story. “Portraits of the Blues” by Lou Bopp is a fascinating visual compendium depicting—through portraits, landscapes and details—a fading culture and the musicians who helped build it, with their hands and guitars.

Bopp is a commercial photographer whose client list is packed with heavyweights like Time Warner, Sports Illustrated and American Express. He has worked all over the world, once shooting on three continents in a single day, but it wasn’t an assignment that brought him to rural Mississippi, the birthplace of blues, it was his own love of the music. For Bopp, this project is first an act of documentation. He is keenly aware that the sun is setting on these aging musicians and with them, a golden era in American culture and music. “There are not a lot of young bluesmen in the pipeline unfortunately,” Bopp notes. “I have photographed 70 to 80 musicians and about half have already passed.”

Bopp credits his own curiosity for much of his success as a photographer; it’s also what inspired “Portraits of the Blues,” which is currently showing at August House Studio in Chicago. Bopp grew up a fan of artists like Led Zeppelin, The Rolling Stones and Jimi Hendrix. As he explored their influences, he found they invariably led back to the blues. Bopp became a fan of the music and years later that same investigative urge spurred him to ride his motorcycle down Route 61 from his home in Missouri to Clarksdale, Mississippi, a historic blues hotbed. What was intended to be a daytrip stretched into three or four days of roaming the Delta, searching for the music. That first spur-of-the-moment trip yielded photographs of legends Big George Brock and Robert “Wolfman” Belfour, along with an invaluable resource in Roger Stolle, a writer, artist and owner of Cat Head Delta Blues & Folk Art, a store in Clarksdale.

Connections proved invaluable to Bopp, as actually finding the musicians was and is the most difficult part of the project. Using an ever-expanding network of like minds and employing the occasional local fixer, Bopp found his way to the music, even if it meant being a long way from paved road. He makes it clear that a willingness to compensate his subjects went a long way; after all, some of the artists had made a good living playing the blues, but most hadn’t, regardless of their place in the canon. “I paid honorariums to everyone I shot,” he says. “Their time is valuable, my time is valuable. I respect people’s time.”

No matter his commercial workload, Bopp always makes time for personal projects. He credits his years spent working on the blues project in Mississippi with allowing him to “get back to the roots” of his love for photography. A penchant for travel and culture are what brought him to the art form, and that is what drove him back to Clarksdale, time and time again.

Bopp decided early on that he wanted to shoot the artists in their element, but not onstage. “I wanted to shoot them behind the scenes, at their homes,” Bopp explains. “One guy, Pat Thomas, I shot him at his father’s graveside. I wanted to get a little deeper and peel away the layer of their public persona.” His aim was to pull back the curtain, as it were, and capture something more intimate.

His photographs of Wesley “Junebug” Jefferson are a particularly poignant example. Roger Stolle put Bopp in touch with the obscure-but-legendary Delta bluesman, and though he was ailing, Jefferson invited the photographer to his home. The bedridden musician insisted on being photographed with his guitar and, unnerved but profoundly honored, Bopp obliged. Jefferson passed away only days later.

Unlike his commercial assignments with their attendant crews, production meetings and top-down creative direction, “Portraits of the Blues” has been a lean operation. Bopp works alone, traveling light and following his own compass. That challenge—and freedom—is part of why he finds the entire experience of pursuing his own projects so rewarding. He relies heavily on natural light, which he finds in abundance in the South. “The patina is beautiful, its got tons of character,” Bopp says. “Some guys got dressed up for me and some didn’t, I tried not to dictate things.”

Balancing the demands of his commercial work and “Portraits of the Blues” was a bit of a “juggling act,” but Bopp is proud to have never canceled any appointments—not with his ad clients and not in Mississippi. Structurally, his approach to shooting the images remained the same: get the “meat and potatoes” first. In one world that meant shooting the creative brief before trying to do it his way. In Mississippi it meant “think fast,” and make sure you get a shot you can use, all the while leaving “space for serendipitous moments,” he says.

Bopp’s income from his commercial work also allowed him to self-fund “Portraits of the Blues.” Surprisingly, chasing his passion in Mississippi would open the door for more commercial work when his images caught the attention of an agency in Jackson, Mississippi, which contacted him directly. What initially was going to be a simple licensing arrangement ended with Bopp directing four TV spots for the Mississippi Tourism Association.

article.article_title: 5 Lighting Design Tips for Video Productions
article.article_text_abstract: Photographer, filmmaker and educator Eduardo Angel shares his tips for lighting your videos.
article.article_image_caption: The author at work.
article.article_text:
Photographer, filmmaker and educator Eduardo Angel shares his tips for lighting your videos. He'll be teaching "Filmmaking Fundamentals" at the PhotoPlus Expo conference on Saturday October 24.

1. Use continuous light instead of natural light
Video often requires shooting over extended periods of time where you have to tear down and reproduce scenes days or weeks apart. Using continuous light—and a light meter—allows you to replicate the same lighting for each shoot. Try to minimize the impact of uncontrollable natural light by blocking the light (e.g., covering windows). In short, try to minimize the unknowns—those things you cannot control.

2. Find the color balance
Knowing the color temperature of a scene is key for video so always have a colorimeter handy. Like matching the exposure, color temperature is critical for replicating shooting conditions. Additionally, without color temperature continuity, post-production is more time-consuming and expensive.

3. Use adjustable LEDs to balance mixed lighting
Continuous light fixtures with adjustable Kelvin temperatures like the Limelite Mosaic Bi-Colour LED Panel are ideal for balancing mixed lighting, almost eliminating the need to gel the lights. They can also be battery operated, so they are a great complement for outdoor shooting.

4. Harness and control sunlight when shooting outdoors
Place diffusion material between the sun and the subject when shooting outdoors to prevent harsh highlights and use a reflector to eliminate shadows, just as you would in still photography.

5. Control lighting direction with barn doors
This is especially important with LEDs, which tend to spill the light. By using barn doors (or creating your own with cardboard and gaffer’s tape), you can direct the light and, ultimately, the viewer’s eye, which automatically goes to what is highlighted.

For more information on these topics, check out Angel’s courses on Lynda.com, Video for Photographers: Filmmaking on Location and Video for Photographers: Filmmaking Essentials; follow him on Twitter @EA_Photo; and visit his website, www.eduardoangel.com.

article.article_title: Picture Story: Childhood Malnutrition in Afghanistan
article.meta_description: Daniel Berehulak’s overcame several challenges to produce a story that helped him win Freelance Photographer of the Year honors at the 2014 Pictures of the Year International competition.
article.article_text_abstract: Daniel Berehulak’s first assignment as a freelancer for The New York Times was fraught with challenges, but he still managed to produce a story that helped him win Freelance Photographer of the Year honors at the 2014 Pictures of the Year International competition.
article.article_image_credit: © Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
article.article_image_caption: Because of local customs and security concerns, Daniel Berehulak struggled to capture intimate moments between mothers and children for a story about childhood malnutrition in Afghanistan. In this photo, a mother seeks treatment for her 8-month-old son at a hospital in Lashkar Gah.
article.article_text:
Daniel Berehulak’s photo story about a sudden epidemic of severe childhood malnutrition in Afghanistan is difficult viewing. The distended bellies and prematurely aged faces of distraught children conjure the tragic images of African famines of the 1980s, and force viewers to wonder: How could this possibly happen?

The New York Times reporter Rod Nordland was exploring the reasons last fall when International Picture Editor David Furst sent Berehulak, a freelancer, to Kabul on a two-month assignment to cover various stories for the paper. Berehulak recently won Freelance/Agency Photographer of the Year honors at POYi, partly on the strength of the malnutrition story that he ended up working on with Nordland.

“I’ve been following [Berehulak’s work] for a long time,” says Furst, explaining why he sent Berehulak. “He has a unique and brilliant eye, and experience covering that part of the world.”

Berehulak had been a staff photographer at Getty Images for eight years, and has rotated in and out of Afghanistan since 2009. He landed in Kabul for The Times last September, right after leaving Getty to freelance. Upon arrival, his first order of business was to sit down with Times editors and reporters to talk about the stories in progress.

The malnutrition story, says Furst, “had the potential to get a lot of attention. It was a priority [and] I talked to Daniel about the need to spend extra time on it.”

Berehulak began accompanying Nordland to hospitals and clinics to talk to doctors and aid workers. With a driver and translator, they visited treatment facilities in Kabul, and Lashkar Gah, the capital of Helmand Province.

Berehulak’s challenges were many, beginning with safety. “Lashkar Gah is a sketchy area,” he says. Bost Hostpital in Lashkar Gah, where children are treated for malnutrition, also serves as a military field hospital. Those brought in for treatment for gunshots and other war wounds “are possibly Taliban,” Berehulak says. Kidnapping was a risk, “if you spent too much time in one place.”

They had to limit visits to Bost Hospital to just two or three, each for a short period of time. “Word gets around” that journalists are there, Berehulak says. He and Nordland checked in with Times editors in the morning and evening, and traveled with a GPS tracker so the newspaper’s security personnel could track their whereabouts at all times.

“One afternoon, we were outside to get an exterior frame of the hospital,” Berehulak says, “and after about five minutes, the translator said, ‘OK, that’s it. We’re out of here.’”

Another challenge was building trust with NGO personnel. They’re suspicious because they’ve had encounters with some insensitive journalists, Berehulak explains. “So they want to know who you are, where you’re from, what you’re doing, what your intentions are. They don’t want their work conveyed in a bad light.”

NGO staff also hovered to make sure that Berehulak got permission to photograph patients. “We weren’t able to work completely freely,” he says. But he doesn’t blame the NGOs. They’re trying to protect Afghans, especially women. “Even if they consented [to be photographed], it was mentioned to us that if someone saw their identity, they could be killed,” Berehulak explains.

He had to let a lot of good photographs go for want of permission to shoot. And women who agreed to be photographed with their children automatically covered their faces, which made intimate photographs particularly elusive.

“It was frustrating not to be able to show candid moments,” he says. “I really wanted to capture the connection between the mothers and children.”

And then there were esthetic challenges. He was shooting in hospitals and clinics, where available lighting was poor, there wasn’t much visual variety from one room to the next and where a lot of medical equipment makes for cluttered backgrounds.

Berehulak says the many challenges forced him to work all the more to get good photographs. He notes that photographers are drawn to Afghanistan “because it’s a visually striking country. The rugged faces of the people, and the beautiful colors stand out in stark contrast to the grim realities of living there.”

The colors certainly worked in Berehulak’s favor. The lead image shows a mother in a dark-blue burka against a dark-green wall, holding her 8-month-old son Samiullah, who was suffering from an advanced form of malnutrition called marasmus. The child is in distress; the colors and the mother’s head-to-toe covering add a sense of foreboding.

“We were interviewing another family,” Berehulak recounts, “when I turned around and saw [Samiullah and his mother] and I thought: Whoa! To see a young child that has the face of an adult is deeply disturbing. I immediately reacted: That is really desperate, and really awful.”

Berehulak had permission to photograph in the room; he looked at the mother and she assented to a picture by standing up, covering her face and patiently waiting for Berehulak to take the picture.

“For me, that is the picture from this take,” says Furst. Not all photographers would have seen that image before it was shot, but Berehulak “is able to go in and see those pictures.”

Another image, “equally as haunting,” Berehulak says, shows four malnourished children on three beds in the intensive-care unit of Bost Hospital. Their mothers sit on the beds with them, hiding their faces from the camera.

“I had to work really hard to layer the image, to show three or four critically ill children lying in close proximity,” he says, explaining that he wanted to convey the scope of the crisis.

“To get them all in one frame, I worked that room from different angles,” he says. “You’re limited to what you can [depict] in a hospital. It’s all about, literally, millimeters, positioning yourself so you get everyone framed to show the magnitude” of the problem.

Berehulak says he would have liked to be able to go to the villages where families of malnourished children came from, “and paint a picture of [the environment] and the issues they were having.” That may have provided a clearer understanding of how extensive the malnutrition situation is, and the reasons for it, Berehulak surmises. But for safety reasons, he says, going to remote villages to photograph “wasn’t possible at all.”

Despite the limitations and frustrations, Berehulak “filed an exceptional set of pictures,” Furst says. The work “called people’s attention to the problem. It got people to look. It’s hard to cut through the noise, and he did. That’s a testament to his sensitive eye.”

The New York Times has posted a gallery of the images (http://nyti.ms/1e21Jth). The portfolio that won Berehulak Freelance/Agency Photographer of the Year honors is on the POYi website (http://bit.ly/1jRUiJM).

article.article_title: Fearful Symmetry: Aerial Photos Shed a New Light on Suburban Development
article.meta_description: In a new book, Christoph Gielen uses aerial photography to consider the sustainability and environmental impact of suburbanization and low-density development.
article.meta_keywords: Christoph Gielen, aerial photography, suburban photography, Ciphers
article.article_text_abstract: In a new book, Christoph Gielen uses aerial photography to consider the sustainability and environmental impact of suburbanization and low-density development.
article.article_image_caption: "Untitled VI," a photograph made in Arizona by Christoph Gielen. Click on the Photo Gallery link below to see more images.
article.article_text:
Christoph Gielen’s new book, Ciphers, tackles questions of land use and sustainable growth from an uncommon perspective: the air. Photographed from helicopters, suburban developments in the American West are transformed into alien topography; the familiar trappings of residential life (houses, yards, streets and highways) become jigsaws of geometric abstraction. An infinite collection of hexagons, loops and ovals, Gielen’s images are reminiscent of crop circles, wondrous in their scale and meticulous design yet foreboding and possessed of a fearful symmetry.

“My goal with Ciphers is to examine the broader ramifications of building trends well beyond North American borders, and to bring about an understanding of growth machines that systematically generate ever more car-dependent, low-density suburbanization,” Gielen explains. At a time when unprecedented growth is happening in emerging nations, he hopes that this work will contribute to conversations about development that may help other countries avoid the mistakes America has already made.

An artist and environmental advocate, Gielen has used photography as a means of communicating ideas pertaining to development and land use for a number of years. Although he was familiar with the aerial photography of artists like Michael Light, David Maisel and Edward Burtynsky, it was an experience much closer to the ground that turned Gielen’s ambitions skyward. In 2003, his interest in urban planning led him to document the controlled demolition of a public housing project in Scotland. He was camped out on the roof of a neighboring high-rise, waiting for the detonation, when he realized how striking the landscape was from this new vantage point. “[It was] a pivotal moment, which made me realize that in order to provide a larger perspective—quite literally—on how we currently live, I would have to get up above,” Gielen says.

Inspired, the German-born artist decided that, as an epicenter of car-centric growth and its attendant sprawl, Southern California would be his focus. With financing a major concern, Gielen’s process on Ciphers involved doing as much work as possible before he got up in the air. He combed through public records on foreclosure statistics, wildfire occurrences and income distribution to identify potential locations. He then did additional research using geological maps and satellite imagery, looking for locations that would be compelling from the air, whether because of extravagant architecture, cookie-cutter uniformity or layout quirks only visible from above. He was also limited to renting out blocks of time with a flight instructor and shooting photos out of a single-engine, light-utility helicopter with its door removed.

Aerial photography brings with it a range of unique conditions: the vibrations of the aircraft, the velocity of the wind and, for an artist working in a purely analogue format as Gielen was, the challenge of changing film rolls while hanging onto the outside of a moving helicopter. “It took several aerial missions to realize an optimum, workable shutter speed, given that I couldn’t work with a stabilizing gyro,” he says, because it would make moving the camera difficult and “prohibit pointing the camera down vertically.”

Perhaps the biggest challenge was that Gielen depended on the pilot to get him the shots he wanted. Before long, Gielen concluded it was worth the added expense to work with pilots who had experience in the film industry; those pilots had a much better understanding of the altitudes and angles Gielen was looking for, and also kept the aircraft steady while shielding him from the wind.

In the early going, Gielen was able to use his income from working at another photographer’s studio to finance the project. But when he began working independently in 2008, the need for alternative funding became pressing, especially as he began to work with larger and more expensive helicopters and crews. During “countless coffee-fueled days” at the Foundation Center, a grant research center in New York City, he sought out funding from disparate sources whose interests matched his own. Gielen’s approach was to cast a wide net, in fields including photography, visual arts, land preservation and education, and to take anything he could get, no matter how modest. A German citizen, Gielen also actively looked for grants in the European Union.

On a purely esthetic level, Ciphers is an arresting, mesmerizing piece of art, but it’s the inclusion of several thought-provoking essays that gives the work another dimension. For Gielen, his images are a means to an end, and as such are best served by an interdisciplinary approach. From architects, urban planners and climate-change activists, to cultural philosophers and self-described futurist Geoff Manaugh, Gielen brings together a heavyweight collection of thinkers to contextualize his aerial hieroglyphs.

While Ciphers has been well received by architects, Gielen hopes that the book’s publication in the U.S. will bring greater engagement with a broader audience. He believes that seeking out new interdisciplinary collaborations and drawing connections between his work and current events in the U.S.—like post-Hurricane Sandy rebuilding—will help. “The primary audience for this project comes from the fields of architecture, land preservation, art and photography. But of course I’d also like to reach out to a more varied audience, such as educators, students, academics specializing in urban development and policy, journalists and writers, city planners, and anyone interested in society’s role in land use and its effects on the environment.”

article.article_title: Annie Marie Musselman on Photographing a Wolf Sanctuary in Washington State
article.meta_description: With funding from a Getty Images grant, the photographer created a new body of work that helped Wolf Haven International update its visual communications.
article.meta_keywords: Annie marie Musselman, Wolf Haven, wolf sanctuary, wolf photography, photographs of wolves
article.article_text_abstract: With funding from a Getty Images grant, the photographer created a new body of work that helped Wolf Haven International update its visual communications.
article.article_image_caption: Jesse and Shiloh walking in the sun, 2012, Wolf Haven. Click on the Photo Gallery link below to see more images.
article.article_text:
Few wild animals have captured the human imagination quite like the wolf. They show up in our fables and our novels, they are the ancestors of man’s best friend and they are among the most researched animals in the world. Yet Annie Marie Musselman’s new project about Wolf Haven International, a wolf sanctuary in Washington State, manages to show wolves in a new light. 

Musselman created the work in collaboration with Wolf Haven after receiving a Getty Images Grant for Good, which provided her and a designer with funding to perform “a full media restoration” for the sanctuary. (The grant program has since been rebranded as Getty Images Creative Grants.)

In her images, Musselman quietly captures an intimate communion of these wolves and the woods of the Pacific Northwest. In one photograph, a wolf stands, almost politely, near a hole he has scraped in the damp earth, ears perked, eyes doleful. In another, a white wolf approaches cautiously, caught mid-stride in the long lush green grass. We see sunlight streaming through the trees, setting wolves’ fur aglow as they bask in the warmth. Taken as a whole, there is a serenity to these images that is rarely associated with the wolf.

“I strive to show these wolves as if I had happened upon them in the forest, to portray them as wild but also gentle, beautiful and loving creatures, unlike the way they are often portrayed in films and in the media as bloodthirsty hunters and killers,” Musselman explains. “I wanted to light them and make them stand out in nature.”

Photographing animals has long been a passion for the Seattle-based photographer—her first personal project, “Finding Trust,” is a series of images made at Sarvey Wildlife Rehabilitation Center, a hospital for wild creatures near Seattle. That project began seven years ago, when Musselman, reeling from the loss of her mother, started volunteering at Sarvey (a book of the work is out this month from Kehrer Verlag). While working with and photographing the injured and sick animals, she felt a connection to the wild creatures in her care. During a time of great personal tragedy (her father passed away a few years later), Musselman credits her experiences at Sarvey as part of a healing process and the impetus for an entirely new artistic direction.

“I slowly developed this hyper-real connection to animals. I think that came from lots of exposure to the wild ones,” Musselman says. “They aren’t quite as easy [to get close to] as domestic, so it made me try harder for some reason. I wanted their approval—sounds crazy but I just felt an all encompassing love for them.”

That love led her to join organizations like the Blue Earth Alliance, a nonprofit that supports photographic projects relating to environmental conservation. When Musselman began to formulate a concrete plan for a project about animal sanctuaries around the world, Blue Earth provided her with the services of a grant writer who helped her create a proposal. The project, “For the Innocent,” focuses on the plight of so-called “keystone species,” whose presence within an ecosystem is key to the well-being of other species. In 2009, she photographed orangutans in Borneo with funding from Mother Jones and Newsweek. She returned to the U.S. energized by what she had seen and bent on getting back to Asia as soon as possible. 

Serendipitously, a fellow photographer tipped Musselman off to the Getty Images Grants for Good program over drinks the night before submissions were due. By the next day she had tweaked her grant proposal. She won the Getty grant in 2010 and set up a trip to an Indonesian wildlife sanctuary, only to find out her new pregnancy made traveling to a malarial region risky. Having already purchased tickets for herself and an assistant, Musselman had no choice but to swallow the lost airfare and start looking for something closer to home. 

Wolf Haven International is a sanctuary set on 82 acres of prairie, wetlands and woodland in western Washington State. Once Musselman did some research on the 30-year-old nonprofit, she knew it was the right place for her work—she just had to convince them.

“Most sanctuaries are very private and protected; it’s very difficult to get them to believe that what you are doing can help them,” the photographer explains. But Musselman and Wolf Haven Executive Director Diane Gallegos had a rapport from the beginning, and once she saw how dedicated Musselman was and realized the benefits the photography and design could offer, she was sold.

Starting in the winter of 2011, every Tuesday and Thursday for 18 months, Musselman traveled to Wolf Haven to shoot. She wanted to make the wolves “look magnificent” and quickly realized just how challenging that would be. The 50-odd animals were paired off in large enclosures and had varying reactions to the photographer. Some were friendly and eagerly let Musselman pet them through the chain-link fence, others were afraid and reclusive; a few were openly hostile. The fence kept her safe, but it also added another obstacle to framing her shots. 

Musselman primarily used a Canon EOS 5D Mark II, which allowed her to work in low light and shoot video. However, a lot of her favorite images were shot with a Mamiya 7, and she regrets that lighting conditions often made it impractical for her to shoot film: It was difficult to know how the light was interacting with the fence at different angles without the instant feedback of digital. Maneuverability was also a concern when it came to choosing equipment. “I used a Qflash, which simulates the look of a studio setup but is much smaller, with a portable battery pack that I can swing around my arm or [hang] on the tripod holding the light, perfect and compact. Then I used two [radio] slaves, so everything is battery powered and portable,” Musselman says.

Musselman’s bond with the wolves was matched by the affinity she found with the women and men who make Wolf Haven work. She compares the atmosphere to that of a family, and once she was “in,” they did everything they could to make her work the best it could be—even if that meant allowing her to stay late and let herself out. 

During the summer she would enjoy long evenings with the ravens and the trees, but even during the winter she would put in five or six hours in the cold and wet, hoping to shoot something good. “I was looking for that expression of gentleness, peace and calm that they showed so much, with a little splash of fancy lighting,” she laughs, “if I could get it!”

Annie Marie Musselman Photo Gallery

article.article_title: Anatomy of Successful Grant Applications: The Alicia Patterson Foundation Fellowship
article.meta_description: Photographer April Saul and the writer-photographer team of Susan Stellin and Graham MacIndoe explain how they won $40,000 Alicia Patterson fellowships to pursue their in-depth projects.
article.article_text_abstract: Photographer April Saul and the writer-photographer team of Susan Stellin and Graham MacIndoe explain how they won $40,000 Alicia Patterson fellowships.
article.article_image_caption: Fatoumata, The Bronx, 2012, from Graham MacIndoe and Susan Stellin's "UnAmericans" project, about people caught up in deportation proceedings.
article.article_text:
The Alicia Patterson Foundation (APF) has been providing six-month and one-year fellowships to support independent journalism for decades. But the fellowships can be difficult for photographers to win, says Philadelphia Inquirer photographer April Saul, who managed to win one of 11 fellowships awarded this year. Photographer Graham MacIndoe also won a joint fellowship with writer Susan Stellin. 

Saul explains that the application process favors writers because proposals have to be about 2,000 words long, and the foundation likes to support hard-hitting investigative projects. Fellows are expected to deliver articles for publication in the foundation’s quarterly publication, APF Reporter. And the competition is stiff because the full-year fellowships provide $40,000 for the year ($20,000 for six months). 

Only about a dozen photographers have won APF Fellowships over the last decade, including Andrea Bruce (2011), Shiho Fukada (2010), Alessandra Sanguinetti (2010), Brenda Ann Kenneally (2008), Tomas van Houtryve (2008) and Jon Lowenstein (2008).

“It’s a journalism fellowship, not an arts grant,” says Stellin, who emphasizes the importance of researching past winners and their topics before applying, and the importance of understanding APF’s mission: to “provide support for journalists engaged in rigorous, probing, spirited, independent and skeptical work that will benefit the public.”  

Fellowships awarded this year went to journalists exploring criminal and social justice, healthcare and environmental issues. Stellin and MacIndoe applied for their project called “The UnAmericans: Detained, Deported and Divided,” about people—including legal U.S. residents and asylum seekers—caught up in aggressive deportation proceedings.

“The [proposals] that really stand out are the ones that have a sense of urgency about them,” says Margaret Engel, executive director of the foundation. “Graham and Susan opened judges’ eyes to injustices going on daily in this country” because of immigration enforcement policies. “Families are being shattered in a random way. They presented a persuasive case and statistics to show this is a problem that isn’t going away and needs some attention.”

Saul’s project, called “Camden, NJ: No Place to Grow Up,” is about the social impact of poverty and violence in a failing city. Saul says she had applied for an APF fellowship without success at least four times previously for another long-term project called “American Family.” The project is about several families Saul has been documenting since the 1980s.

Other photographers have documented American cities in decline, Engel says, but Saul has an exceptional eye. “Her photographic talent, her writing talent, her commitment to project and [her] ability to be six levels deep pushed her right to the top.”

The questions Saul always got when selling her stories to journalists who are writers—and APF Fellowship jurors—were, “‘Why this story? Why now?’ They were always looking for justification for what I was doing. The ‘American Family’ project defied those conventions.”

Last year, while attending an NPPA workshop, Saul sought some advice from photojournalist Louie Palu, who has won The Aftermath Project, Pulitzer Center on Crisis Reporting and Alexia Foundation grants. “He said, ‘If you’re not getting a grant for a project you’re suggesting, just suggest a different project.’”

It wasn’t what Saul wanted to hear, but she took the advice. Not only did the Camden project fit the Fellowship’s criteria better than her family project, but Saul had been working on it since 2011. Unlike some other grant and fellowship providers, APF favors projects in progress, because they want to see evidence of the applicant’s commitment.

MacIndoe says, “You could tell from the judges’ [questions during the interview] that it was important that we had put in a serious amount of time and money—we had done a lot of leg work first.”


Gambino "Showtime" Crespo, a young boxer, attends a daylong boxing tournament to promote peace in Camden, New Jersey. From April Saul's "Camden, NJ: No Place to Grow Up" project. Photo © April Saul


In her application, Saul mentioned that she already had numerous contacts in Camden, and that she’d won major awards for her work to date, including two Casey Medals for Meritorious Journalism, awarded by the Journalism Center on Children & Families. She also mentioned that she lives about five miles away from Camden. “I’m not parachuting in” to report a story from a long distance, she explains. “I think it would be easier [for jurors] to feel secure giving me a grant.”

Those points strengthened Saul’s application, but she’s convinced that showing jurors her ability to write made a critical difference. “I’m unusual among photographers in my ability to write well. I was an English major,” she says. In addition to including a portfolio of images, she submitted clips of stories about Camden that she had written for the Philadelphia Inquirer.

She also wrote a clear, compelling proposal that grabbed the jurors’ attention from the start. “It is hard to imagine a more dangerous place to grow up than Camden, NJ—the poorest, most violent city in America,” her proposal began. She then laid out some alarming statistics about poverty, unemployment, education, healthcare and crime in Camden, and gave a succinct explanation for the city’s troubles.

“For a half-century,” Saul wrote, “Camden has suffered tremendous loss of industry and corrupt politicians, including several mayors who were sent to prison. After race riots in the late 1960s, thousands of residents fled to the suburbs. What remains is a troubled shell of a city, with a thriving drug trade …”

Saul’s work in Camden to date has focused primarily on the stories of individuals caught up in the violence. Her proposal—and the portfolio of images she submitted with it—put a human face on her project. For instance, she described the plight of one particular subject, a young boy whose life changed when he got caught in drug war crossfire and lost his eyesight as a result.

But Saul was able to explain Camden’s broad social, economic and political conditions with authority because she did research about the city in preparation for her application. That research led her to information about issues she wasn’t aware of—the connections between an asthma epidemic and air pollution, and family instability and dropout rates, for instance—and provided her with ideas for expanding her project.

“I am not applying for this fellowship to pursue a new idea, but to deepen my work in a community close to my home and heart—and where I already have numerous contacts,” she wrote in her application. She went on to discuss “four approximate areas” she intended to report on with words and pictures: Hunger/Health Care, Poverty/Education, Violence/Trauma and Mentors.

“The [foundation] wants four quarterly articles for their magazine, and that’s why my proposal is divided into four parts,” Saul explains.

MacIndoe says that from his perspective, APF jurors “are trying to support people who are doing work on a topic they’re passionate about.” And a key to his and Stellin’s success, he adds, was the practice they got applying for grants. “You refine your application, and after three or four attempts you realize the first [application] wasn’t that good. This time it was really tight, really compelling,” he says.

He and Stellin also believe writers and photographers collaborating on a single proposal have an advantage, because media outlets are interested in combining text and images on different platforms—and the APF wants applicants to distribute their work as broadly as possible. “We didn’t propose a traditional project. We proposed a project for different platforms and outlets,” Stellin says.

The application process also included an interview. “I thought I blew it,” Saul says. Other applicants came with “facts in their laps, and sweeping reports on institutions and government agencies.” When jurors asked her to tell them about recent legislation that might impact people in Camden, she told them she’s not a policy “wonk.”

“The whole thing for me is to help people understand each other better,” Saul explains. She anticipated being asked what was missing from coverage about Camden, given that it has received a lot of national media attention. Saul used social media to crowd-source answers to that question before her interview.

A number of people responded that Camden was being demonized, and coverage enforced stereotypes about poverty and crime. To Saul’s surprise, jurors asked who besides Inquirer readers might care about the plight of Camden. Saul told them the city was already getting national media attention, then explained that she was trying to get beyond usual media stereotypes about cities like Camden and the people who live there.

“There are so many people leading ordinary lives, and people trying to improve the place,” she says she told jurors. She adds, “I’m interested in providing a window for how other people live.”

Saul begins a yearlong sabbatical from the Inquirer in June to work full-time on her Camden project. MacIndoe and Stellin have split their fellowship grant, and will each spend six months working on their “UnAmericans” project.

article.article_title: End Frame: Mentors of the 2014 PDN's 30
article.meta_description: Some of the photographers chosen for this year's PDN's 30 talk about the people who have been mentored them during their careers.
article.article_text_abstract: Some of the photographers chosen for this year's PDN's 30 talk about the people who have been mentored them during their careers.
article.article_image_credit: Clockwise from top left: © Kevin Arnold; © Victoria Will; © Grant Cornett; © Arnold Newman/Getty Images
article.article_image_caption: Photos by some of the mentors for the 2014 PDN's 30. Clockwise from top left: A personal image by commercial photographer Kevin Arnold; a tintype portrait of actor Anne Hathaway by Victoria Will; a Grant Cornett image from TIME's 2013 Food Issue; a 1944 portrait of painter Georgia O'Keeffe and photographer Alfred Stieglitz taken by Arnold Newman in New York City.
article.article_text:
No photographer is an island, to borrow a phrase. Careers have always been built as much on relationships with mentors (and peers) as they’ve been built on talent. Traditionally, the path to a career as a photographer was through apprenticeship: assisting for several years at one or two studios. Many photographers continue to take that path, but with access to information and resources online, photographers are less bound to old ways of learning their craft. But even so, photography is driven by vision, which is difficult to learn from YouTube tutorials. The lifeblood of photography is (and always will be) interaction among people, and direct one-on-one sharing of insight and knowledge. Mentors are invaluable for their advice, encouragement, and constructive criticism.

PDN’s 30 photographers tell us stories every year about the differences mentors have made in their careers. Here we list some of the 2014 PDN’s 30 and their mentors, along with stories from a few photographers about the difference their mentors have made to them.

Jeff Brown: High-school journalism teacher Pete Leblanc, college teacher Jody Fisher; “the love and encouragement of Sarah Wilmer, Erik Madigan Heck and Jackson Melamed have been invaluable.”

Fabio Bucciarelli: Philip Blenkinsop, Mimmo Candito.

Camilla de Maffei: Antoine D’Agata.

Bryan Derballa: Victor J. Blue.

Bobby Doherty: “I probably learned the most from Grant Cornett. He is in control of everything. Technically and stylistically he knows what he wants and knows exactly how to achieve it. I had assisted photographers who barely knew how to use their cameras ... I admired the way that Grant took full responsibility for every detail of his shoot.”

Grant Harder: “One of the people I used to assist was Kevin Arnold. When I need a little advice, I know I can give him a call. He has helped me out with everything from quoting on commercial jobs to recommending a backpack for a heli-skiing assignment.”

Theron Humphrey: “There is this fellow I met on the road, Michael O’Neal. He left a solid creative position at Apple to pursue photography because he couldn’t see waking up every morning and not taking photos, not sharing with the world what he loved. He’s this brilliant reminder that even a solid and steady paycheck won’t fill our souls.”

Kyle Johnson: Daniel Shea, Jake Stangel.

Zun Lee: Roy DeCarava, David Alan Harvey.

Phil Moore: Jerome Delay, Roberto Schmidt.

Greer Muldowney: Henry Horenstein.

Benjamin Rasmussen: Jake Stangel.

Carla Richmond: John Durant, Ethan Pines, Dana Smith, David Zaitz.

Jenny Riffle: Seth Thompson “has been a mentor in his commitment to his art. He takes his work very seriously and has always treated my work the same”; Jock Sturges “is very
generous and a great teacher. He makes sure that I am always learning while assisting him.”

Bryan Schutmaat: Peter Brown.

Marcus Smith: Gary Land, Parrish Lewis.

Ralph Smith: “When I was 17 years old, I managed to get an internship with Arnold Newman. He was in his early 80s at the time but still went to work five days a week. He loved what he did. Having the opportunity to be around  him was incredible.

“After college I moved to New York City [and] started working exclusively for still-life photographer Levi Brown. [Over five years] I got to see his business grow and evolve, it was an incredible learning experience.”

Ilona Szwarc: Joel Meyerowitz.

Josh Wool: Frank Ockenfels III, Joshua Black Wilkins and Victoria Will.
