article.article_title: How I Got That Shot: Close-Ups of Beauty Products in Action
article.meta_description: Arthur Belebeau produced striking compositions in his macro shots of lipstick, nail polish and more.
article.meta_keywords: Arthur Belebeau
article.article_text_abstract: Arthur Belebeau produced striking compositions in his macro shots of lipstick, nail polish and more.
article.article_image_caption: Arthur Belebeau gets his "signature, poppy lighting" by mixing hard lights with softer, more flattering lights.
article.article_text:
Client: Glamour
 Photo Director: Suzanne Donaldson 
Beauty Editor: Michaela Buratti

Fashion and beauty photographer Arthur Belebeau likes to create “clean, graphic and dynamic images.” “When I look through the camera I always try to find the most graphic way to do it, either by filling up the frame or leaving negative space,” he says.

For a Glamour magazine story about favorite beauty products for nails, lips, eyes and hair, he wanted to shoot tight close-ups of the models, which meant the compositions couldn’t be overly complicated, but he also needed to show the products in use. Belebeau says, “The hardest part was to create something graphic and poppy, and use all the tools and props that they gave me.”

He wanted to keep the lighting fairly consistent for all four images, but made adjustments for each subject. For his tight shot of fingernails, Belebeau, who is based in New York City and shoots for clients like Saks Fifth Avenue, Dior Beauty, Dasani and L’Oréal Paris, decided to shoot macro shots, with his camera on a tripod about five inches from the hand model’s fingertips, rather than shooting wider and cropping the image to get the composition he wanted. “For the quality of the image, I try not to crop,” the photographer notes.

Logistics
Belebeau photographed the story at New York City’s Sun Studios in a shooting space with a white cyclorama. Along with Belebeau and his assistants, Michaela Buratti, beauty editor at Glamour, was on the set with the models, stylists and a manicurist. The hand model rested her arm on a beauty table to keep it from moving, Belebeau recalls. “If she moved two inches, she was out of the frame.”

Before any shoot, Belebeau typically sketches out ideas for each composition. Once he’s begun working, he’ll experiment: “Then I try for an accident.” In sketching the nail polish image, he wanted the hand model’s fingers to be crossed. “I started with just the fingers, and then I started to add one element to it at a time—the product, the dripping.” The nail image was the last shot of the day. “I remember I had to shoot about 400 frames until something started happening in the image,” he says. An assistant put too much nail polish on the applicator, and it dripped. Belebeau recalls that at the moment it happened, Buratti, who was watching on a monitor, screamed. “I thought: That’s what I’m looking for,” Belebeau says. He had the assistant duplicate the drip ten to 15 more times, letting it fall just short of the end of the model’s finger so her French manicure wouldn’t have to be redone. After several more shots, he recalls, “We all went and had a drink.”

Lighting
Belebeau planned to use the same basic setup for all four shots. He photographed his subjects about eight feet from the cyc wall, which he lit using strobes with umbrellas placed on light trees—“basically c-stands with lights pounding on the background,” Belebeau explains.

To get what he calls his “signature, poppy lighting,” Belebeau combines soft lights, either diffused or bounced off of white foam core, which flatter the skin, and hard lights, “so it looks poppy,” he says.   

On all the shots, he used Profoto lights on 2400 watt-second packs. His diffused light was a large softbox that was usually behind him. “It was the same lighting throughout the day but I had to adapt the angles,” he says. “Because I was so close to the subject with my camera, sometimes I would create a shadow with my head or my camera.”

To add contrast to the image of shiny nail polish, he also used a single bare head that was placed three to four feet from his subject. On larger beauty shots, he notes, “I’ll use more than one hard light. I’ll put one behind the model, for example, to add highlights to her hair.”


Another image from Belebeau's Glamour shoot. © Arthur Belebeau

Camera
Belebeau shot with a Canon EOS 5D Mark III tethered to two monitors: one for the digital tech, and one for the beauty editor. He photographed the fingernails with a macro f/2.8 100mm lens. “It eats up a lot of your light so you have to open your lens maybe a half-stop or a stop,” he says. To catch the motion of the drip, he shot at 1/160 of a second.

When he was shooting the lips, he experimented with macro extension tubes that allowed him to try different lenses while focusing closely on the model’s mouth. He took the image that ran in the magazine on a 50mm lens with a macro extension tube.

Post-Production
Belebeau has worked with Denise Ierardi at 451 Imaging Ltd. in New York City on almost all his assignments for the past ten years. “When you work with someone so long, communication is easy,” he says. “She knows what the client is looking for, and what kind of direction we’re aiming for.” Because the retouching on the images was limited to “color and a few small things,” Belebeau says, he first sent Glamour’s editors his selection of five to six favorite takes for each of the four photos, then had Ierardi clean up and color correct the images they chose to run.

Belebeau adds, “I loved it because they picked my first choices.” The four images were published last year in a four-page layout in Glamour.

article.article_title: Antoine D'Agata: Photographing Life at Society's Margins
article.meta_description: Antibodies offers the most complete picture to date of the controversial, visionary photographer’s work.
article.meta_keywords: Antoine D'Agata, photographer interivew, Antibodies
article.article_text_abstract: Antibodies offers the most complete picture to date of the controversial, visionary photographer’s work.
article.article_image_caption: "Nuevo Laredo," 1990. Click on the Photo Gallery link below to see more images.
article.article_text:
From Antoine D’Agata’s perspective, life is most intense when lived in close proximity to death. For this reason he’s chosen to make most of his photographic and film work at the margins of society: in the street, among sex workers, drug addicts, and the impoverished in cities from Nuevo Laredo, Mexico, to Phnom Penh, Cambodia, and Sao Paulo and Salvador Da Bahia, Brazil.

“These spaces where sex, pleasure, pain, fear come close and contaminate each other, this is exactly the type of territory I’m looking for,” D’Agata says.

His black-and-white and color images primarily depict intense sexual encounters, heavy drug use, and physical and emotional pain. Through his long exposures and use of motion blur, his subjects often appear ecstatic, demonic, possessed. Many of his images are raw and explicit, full of naked bodies that tangle and merge.

D’Agata does not simply pass through this “night world” he depicts; he lives in it for long periods, he told PDN in February during a wide-ranging interview about his work. He states openly that he is a drug addict and that he has relationships that are “physical, emotional, sexual, whatever, with most of the people I photograph.” In this night world, people take risks with drugs, promiscuous sex, self-mutilation or other violent acts, to wrest some control and vitality from a marginal existence, D’Agata says. “Because they have nothing, their only choice is to be alive and to feel and to exist in very basic and instinctive ways.” This self-inflicted “violence of the night,” as D’Agata calls it, arises from the systemic, “more economic, institutional” violence that marginalizes people, often from birth. Even before he became a photographer, D’Agata made the choice to live among the disenfranchised, a choice that is both personal and political.

“From the very beginning, from well before I started photography, I always went to a very specific place where I felt I had to go, because I felt this was my duty as a citizen to be there and to understand and to share and be a part of it,” D’Agata says, noting that he spent more than a decade living a “street life.”

He turned to photography not because he wanted to raise awareness about the lives of sex workers or others at the fringes of society, but because he felt life was lived most intensely among them. Photography gave him a reason to be there and enough money that he could continue traveling. “My point in the end is not to show the viewer or to remind them that that [marginal] life exists. My point is to be alive,” D’Agata says. “This is my first aim, this is what I’ve been doing for many years, just to be as alive as possible.” D’Agata says he’s had no permanent home for nearly a decade.

Convincing his subjects to allow him to make these photographs comes down to trust, which he builds over time. He repeatedly returns to specific places where he’s built “long friendships,” and participates fully in the world he depicts. “Sometimes I spend weeks [there] before taking pictures,” he says. “Life always comes first.”

Drugs also help form connections with his subjects. “When you are part of this scene, photography just doesn’t matter anymore, it’s just a detail. If you trust somebody enough to [risk going] to jail for many years,” he says, alluding to the penalty for illegal drug use, “photography doesn’t mean anything.”

People will often test you in some way, he says, by asking you to take a risk, to see if you “are willing to be as desperate and daring” as they are. “If you are ready to lose everything, people will give you everything, and people will take you much further than you want to go, and you will take people further.”

D’Agata has been labeled a voyeur and pornographer by some, and much worse by others. And yet the intensity with which he pursues life, and the lengths he goes to in order to be a part of the world he depicts, draws the respect of many photographers.

“The questions that he poses are: How deeply do you engage and can you engage, and for whom are you engaging?” says fellow Magnum photographer Susan Meiselas. “I think those are really important, ongoing questions that every [photographer] answers in their own way.”

He has been widely recognized and celebrated for his work. (He is equally dismissive of criticism and praise, saying both “make you weak in some ways.”) In 2001 he won the Niépce Prize for young photographers in France. He’s published several books and has exhibited his work widely in Europe. (While he’s spoken and worked in the United States, his photos have yet to be exhibited here.) In 2004 he became a Magnum nominee, and was voted a full member in 2008. The Cambodian Room: Situations with Antoine D’Agata, a documentary about him, was released in 2009. D’Agata has also released several films, and another documentary is in the works.

His retrospective book, Anticorps, won the Rencontres d’Arles 2013 Author Book Award; this month, Prestel will release the English translation, Antibodies, which includes work from his year as a photojournalism student up through 2012.

Born in Marseille, France, in 1961, D’Agata had no aspirations to be a photographer or an artist as a youth. Approaching 30, he was “torn down, tired, broken by years and years of street life,” he says. Living in New York City and working in a sweatshop, he was urged by people close to him to study at the International Center of Photography. “I was just trying to survive, mentally, emotionally, physically,” he recalls. Joan Liftin, then the director of the ICP photojournalism program, accepted him as “some kind of experiment,” he says, “because I had so much [life] experience, and most young photographers don’t.” Liftin, however, recalls that D’Agata’s “intelligence [had] shown through” in his application essay.

That photography even occurred to him as a possibility was thanks to his friend Raphael, a photographer who was dying of AIDS when the two traveled to Mexico. Throughout the trip D’Agata noticed his friend photographing constantly. “It was shocking in a way,” he says. “You know you are going to die and you keep spending hours and days pushing on the button. I think I realized, maybe in an unconscious way, that photography was a good way to hang onto life, to be more alive.”

It’s often noted that at ICP D’Agata studied with Nan Goldin and Larry Clark, two artists known for their intimate, sometimes shocking images of their friends. However Liftin, who remains friends with D’Agata, recalls that his cityscapes and landscapes were “particularly strong,” and that his work made a marked improvement during his second semester.

Morten Andersen, who studied with D’Agata at ICP during the 1990-91 year and has seen the photographer work, recalls a trip they made to Mexico during a school break. They ended up in Boy’s Town, a commercial district of bars and brothels in Nuevo Laredo, and D’Agata’s photographs shifted. “He found his subject and way of working on that trip,” Andersen recalls.

“To me all these matters of esthetics, color, blur, techniques, of course I have to take it into consideration, but I don’t really care,” D’Agata says. He says that for years he would walk around with black-and-white and color film and shoot both, not “as a function of considering the subject,” but because he wanted “linguistic breaks, which mixing both of them in the same story would create.” He’s shifted between camera formats for the same reason, he says. D’Agata wants to emphasize the individual images, “to respect the singleness of each image, of each moment.” For this reason, he’s also shifted photographic styles.

“Every time I feel like I’m getting closed or I’m [becoming] a prisoner of my own habits, I break,” he explains. “I try to break again and again all types of things which could close me down, and to stay free from this.”

In Antibodies, D’Agata’s sequence shifts between his “night world” photographs, which include the images he made in Mexico as an ICP student, and images of conflict. We see photos of soldiers, barrier walls, destroyed structures, and street fighting he took in Israel, Palestine and the West Bank; of crumbling buildings in Marseille and Alexandria, Egypt, and destroyed homes in Bosnia; of the city of Oswiecim, Poland, and nearby Auschwitz concentration camp; of migrants in Sangatte, France; of mobile homes in North Dakota; of empty, makeshift beds in Phnom Penh, or of small prison cells in Tripoli, Libya. There are close-up headshots of people in Georgia, Montenegro, New York City and Siem Reap, Cambodia.

In his book, D’Agata often presents these photographs of sociological, political and economic issues as typologies. The images, which D’Agata has made on assignment, as grant-supported personal work and while working on Magnum group projects, seem like polar opposites of the instinctive, extreme images for which he is most known.

“What might strike people looking at the work is that it’s kind of schizophrenic,” D’Agata says of these “two visions” in his photography. What connects them, he says, is his interest in depicting the violence of the world with a visual language that is true to his own experience. “Photographically I try to invent a point of view which reflects my own position,” he explains. “If I photograph war and I’m scared, I try to give a sense of this fear. If I’m bored in some situation, I try to shoot boredom.”

In the book and his retrospective exhibition at Le Bal gallery in Paris, D’Agata says, “You can see I’m always trying to confront these two very different languages.” Though the photographic esthetics differ, they depict “sides of the same violence,” he says, “which is the violence of the world.” The political underpinnings of D’Agata’s life and work are “never spoken about,” he says, but in considering these two different bodies of work together, his political stance becomes clearer.

The violence that exists on the margins is “the world I’ve been living in for 30 years now,” he says. “And I don’t think it’s right, this violence, but it exists … it’s a violence which is part of me, and I photograph it in the most extreme way, and for years I’ve been trying to find ways to be more and more inside [it].” In recent work D’Agata has put himself in the frame, making himself a subject. “This is as far as I can go in this violence of the world,” he says.

The book includes a series of stream-of-consciousness texts D’Agata wrote. They range from explicit accounts of drug use and intoxication, relationships and sex, to nuanced delineations of his personal philosophy. In one text he lays out a dystopian vision in which the person of means is “robbed of his existence, he merely complies with a vast scheme of indoctrination and lives behind walls, under the surveillance of cameras, hires guards, buys weapons, protects himself against all dangers visible and invisible, dispersed but omnipresent, familiar and unknown.” This, he says, is the antithesis of the vibrancy of life at the margins.

“I find more beauty and more courage and more strength and more intensity in these specific worlds, but people who have this life, they don’t choose it,” he explains. “I’m in a very complex situation because I am there by choice. I have this experience and I can be in and out and I survive … just moving keeps me alive. And they have no choice and they die like flies, and so in real life, outside of the pictures, I do my best to pick them up.”

“I know he cares about people,” says Andersen. “If I didn’t know him at all, I’m not sure what I would think [of his work].” He adds, “I’m not sure if I like it or not, but it has a strong impact on me … You don’t forget these pictures.”

Photography both enables and complicates D’Agata’s life. Occasional assignments, and print and book sales give him the financial freedom to keep moving. Yet putting the Antibodies book and exhibition together required him to spend nearly a year in Paris, which “pulls me down and weakens me again,” he says. “And it’s been hard since to go back” to life on the margins.

D’Agata describes his personal life as “a mess.” His four children “know what’s happening, but we don’t speak about it. They don’t want any insight, and I don’t want to share this with them.”     

Yet photography has given D’Agata “freedom and strength,” he says. “For many years I was like a sponge, I kept absorbing something which I could not digest.” He adds, “Photography is the only art you cannot create from inside your head or inside your studio, you have to be in the world, you have to be part of it and you have to act in it, and you have to be responsible for this position. Photography has forced me again and again and again to push myself out there and be responsible for every single move, every single act. It gave me everything.”

article.article_title: Frames Per Second: Lessons Learned About Breaking Into Video
article.meta_description: Former PDN’s 30 photographers share the most valuable lessons they’ve learned about shooting video.
article.article_text_abstract: Former PDN’s 30 photographers share the most valuable lessons they’ve learned about shooting video.
article.article_image_caption: A still from a recent photo-and-video assignment Jenn Ackerman and Time Gruber did for the U.S. Army.
article.article_text:
Some of the emerging photographers chosen for PDN’s 30 issues in the last five years have been experimenting with video almost as long as they’ve been taking pictures. Many who entered professional photography around the time that digital SLRs gained HD video capabilities see moving and still images as equally important tools for their visual storytelling. But to land assignments as a director or a cinematographer, most had to acquire the skills, experience and vision that came from producing their own video projects from start to finish.

“No books or tutorials can match the simple act of doing and learning from your mistakes along the way,” says photojournalist Jenn Ackerman who, with her partner, Tim Gruber, made their first video as part of a documentary project on mental health issues in prisons; they are now being asked to bid on jobs requiring only video. Kyle Alexander, who has directed videos for many of his still clients, including O’Neill, says, “Technical things you can learn about the craft of filmmaking from a book or videos, but being a good director is more about your personality, I think.” Directing demands a passion for your subject, the ability to work with talent and crew, and “extreme patience,” he says, adding, “everything takes forever on a set.”

Learn by Doing
Advertising and editorial photographer Tobias Hutzler’s first forays into video were small, self-funded projects he made as an undergraduate. “The constraint of a very limited budget was a fantastic challenge,” he says. “I learned to improvise, condense, focus, and work creatively with very limited production and technical setups—a very similar approach to a still shoot.” The experience helped him hone his style. “Rather than getting caught up in gear and technical aspects, at the beginning I needed to learn about myself, [and] listen to what I have to say.”

Nick Hall: “Jump in, make massive mistakes and enjoy the epic learning curve.”

Kyle Alexander: “Write a small script or treatment, do all the parts you can: gaff, sound, shoot, wardrobe and edit. It might be awful but you will learn something.”

Find the Right Partners
“Coming from photography, directing was a new thing,” says fashion photographer Bon Duke, who used DSLRs to shoot his own videos, then showed his work to a production house, which hired him to shoot with their teams. “I have to really give it to my producers and especially my cinematographers for really believing in me when I needed help,” he says. They “showed me things I needed to understand or learn.”

Tobias Hutzler says that posting videos not only helped him find clients, it also introduced him to some of his collaborators. “By publishing work you gain recognition, and people want to work with you.” He worked with the production house B2Pro in New York City to make his video “Balance,” which was picked up by TIME and went viral.  

Be Prepared
Bon Duke says one of the most important lessons he’s learned is the value of planning and storyboarding before shooting. He considers his sketchbook as essential as any gear he brings to a set.  

Nick Hall: “I think the most important thing to learn, once you have some experience under your belt, is that pre-production is everything. If you have locked down the moving parts as much as possible prior to being on set with actors, talent and crew waiting, then there can be space for creativity.”

Know What You Need: Gear
Photographers we interviewed for this article have used a wide range of cameras on assignments. Among them: ARRI Alexa, Blackmagic Pocket Cinema Camera, Canon EOS 5D Mark III, Canon EOS 7D, GoPro cameras, Nikon D4, Nikon D600, RED cameras.

Photojournalist Jared Moossy, who has worked as a cinematographer for CNN, Al Jazeera, HBO and Bank of America, says, “I use a variety of cameras from the Canon DSLRs to the C series to GoPros to … the Alexa and RED cameras.” He adds, “Whether it’s run-and-gun documentary work or commercial work, each one has its advantages or disadvantages.”

Jenn Ackerman: “A lot of our projects are … documentary in nature so the [Canon EOS] C100 is also a great fit for the way we work, which often means being quick and nimble.”

Besides cameras, what other gear have photographers found valuable?

Nick Hall: “For smaller productions, my 1m glider has been indispensable. No matter where you are, you can put the camera on the glider and get a mini-dolly shot.”
Jenn Ackerman: “Audio equipment including the lavalieres and shotgun mics.”

Whether photographers rent or own their biggest pieces of equipment depends on the types of jobs they shoot.

Tobias Hutzler: “I rent almost all of the gear for productions. I travel a lot for shoots within the U.S. or to Europe and Asia, and shipping would simply be too difficult. Renting also gives me the freedom to experiment, to use lights and setups I haven’t worked with before.”

Jared Moossy: “I tend to rent my gear as a lot of [technology] is changing so quickly.”

Jenn Ackerman: “We have always bought our equipment because we are often working on long-term personal projects that require that we have access to the same gear for long periods of time. “

Kyle Alexander: “I own a basic kit: C-stands, apple boxes, sandbags, tripod, and sound gear and mics. It’s just nice to have all you need at the drop of a hat to go shoot.”

Know What You Need: Budget and Crew
Photographers we interviewed have worked with crews ranging in size from two to 20. The bigger the budget, the more help you have on the set.

“What I’m seeing now is an unfortunate equation where clients want their cameraman to be an all-in-one because of budgets, and the work is suffering,” says Jared Moossy. “If you start spreading yourself too thin, then you can’t fully concentrate on your job.”

Bon Duke: “Make sure the concept you have, or the idea that the client has, is actually realistic within the budget. In the end, you don’t want to shoot yourself in the foot with an amazing concept that cannot be pulled off because of budget restraints.”

Jared Moossy: “I sometimes run the audio myself, though I prefer there be someone to run that gauntlet … I think it is also really key to have an editor, because they are separate from the emotional ties of the project and can make the necessary and ruthless cutting choices … Plus, editing has its own set of skills and if you want high-quality work, you have to take the right steps.”

Tobias Hutzler - BALANCE from Tobias Hutzler on Vimeo.



Janie Taylor For Chloe By Bon Duke from Bon Duke on Vimeo.

article.article_title: Picture Story: Adventures in Patagonia
article.meta_description: A three-week assignment in Argentina to tell the story of a sustainable sheep ranching project tests photographer Nick Hall’s versatility, problem solving skills and good humor.
article.meta_keywords: Nick Hall, Nature Conservancy, Patagonia, Argentina
article.article_text_abstract: A three-week assignment in Argentina to tell the story of a sustainable sheep ranching project tests photographer Nick Hall’s versatility, problem solving skills and good humor.
article.article_image_caption: Nick Hall spent hours crawling in the dirt to get the perfect shot of a lamb bolting upon release inside a corral. This image became the opener of the story that ran in Nature Conservancy magazine. Click on the Photo Gallery link below to see more images.
article.article_text:
When Nick Hall got a three-week assignment to shoot a story for Nature Conservancy magazine about a project to restore sheep grazing grasslands in Patagonia, in southern Argentina, he figured the biggest challenge would be making pictures of sheep that weren’t, well, boring. “Everyone knows what a sheep looks like,” he says.

Little did he realize how difficult it would be. He had envisioned majestic landscapes, but found grasslands flat to the horizon, like the ocean. The wind blew relentlessly, bending Hall’s light stands and grinding away at morale. And the sheep were not the docile animals Hall remembered from the UK, where he grew up. In Patagonia, he couldn’t get closer than a couple of hundred feet to any grazing sheep.

“We tried all kinds of different things: herding; remote camera traps, which didn’t work very well; long lenses—all kinds of things I was never very happy with,” says Hall, who was chosen as a PDN’s 30 in 2011.

But he delivered anyway. “I knew there would be awesome visual opportunities and Nick would do a great job, which of course he did,” says Melissa Ryan, director of photography for Nature Conservancy magazine. In remote locales, she says, “There are often logistical challenges that require patience and good humor because it doesn’t always work out the way you planned. His amazing skill, humor and good attitude is worth millions to me.”

The story, called “Reviving Patagonia,” appeared on the cover of the September/October 2013 issue of Nature Conservancy. The Nature Conservancy (TNC) has undertaken the grasslands restoration project in partnership with the outdoor clothing brand Patagonia, Inc. and Ovis XXI, a local agricultural NGO. TNC and Ovis XXI are introducing new land management practices to sheep ranchers, with the goal of reversing damage to the grasslands. Patagonia, Inc. is providing seed money and a market for the sustainably raised wool.

Hall’s assignment brief called for landscapes, portraits, wildlife, livestock and reportage. “I feel like it’s a small sector of photographers who can do all of those things in an exceptional way. And Nick does it,” Ryan says. She also asked him to shoot video for a series of behind-the-scenes vignettes for Nature Conservancy’s iPad edition, but the still photography was Hall’s priority.

Ryan has hired Hall to photograph several previous stories. Besides his skills as a photographer, she notes, he is knowledgeable about environmental and conservation issues “from the grassroots to the policy level.” Moreover, Ryan says, Hall manages to get on well with researchers, policy experts and other TNC partners who sometimes consider photographers a nuisance.

Ryan provided Hall with a long list of possible portrait subjects and ranches where he might photograph sheep, wildlife and landscapes. “Melissa does a huge amount of leg work in advance, so it becomes a cherry-picking exercise for me, to pick the most beautiful places and characters,” Hall says.

He flew to Patagonia with his assistant, Oliver Ludlow, in December 2012. They rented a truck, and drove from ranch to ranch with program managers from both TNC and Ovis XXI. “It was quite a lot of driving, but it wasn’t difficult to get around,” Hall says.  

It was summer in Patagonia, and because of its extreme southern latitude, Hall arose by 4:15 every morning to catch the early morning light, and worked until 9 or 10 every night. A chill wind, he says, “blew all day, every day.” By the third or fourth day, “your soul feels like a beaten, tattered flag. It takes it out of you.”

He decided to shoot portraits outside, to connect his subjects to the landscape they were all working to save. And because the story was promoting a TNC project, Hall wanted the portraits more stylized than he might normally shoot on an editorial assignment. So he brought “a lean lighting kit,” including a Profoto umbrella, four Profoto heads, several medium and small softboxes, two power packs, stands and batteries. (He shot stills and video with a Nikon D4 camera; his assistant shot video with a Canon EOS 5D Mark II.)

The stands were lightweight, and turned out to be no match for the wind. “They started to bend, so Oliver had to anchor them down to prevent them from breaking,” Hall says.

Because the sheep were so elusive, Hall found it impossible to get the hero shot he imagined: a wide-angle close-up of sheep grazing toward the camera on fresh green grass, against an epic sky. About the best he was able to do out on the grasslands were some pictures of cute lambs huddling out of the wind among tufts of grass after they had become separated from their mothers. He also got some majestic shots of a herd of wild horses that were curious enough to let him approach.

“I made up for what I didn’t get on the grasslands in unexpected ways with the farmers,” he says. “I made good pictures of ranchers tending to their sheep, sending them to market and shearing them. I was also able to set up location lights, and do quirky portraits in barns.”

One of those portraits, showing two proud ranchers in a barn with a freshly shorn sheep, became the cover image. Outside the barn, where those same ranchers were tagging and castrating lambs, Hall saw an opportunity for an image he hadn’t anticipated.

“The lambs were jumping very high in the air upon release, so I tried to capture a shot of a lamb in mid-air,” he says. He worked at it for several hours, lying all the while on the ground of an outdoor corral. “I finally got the image, and I got very intimate with more than a few sheep droppings,” Hall recounts.

The wide-angle image, showing a lamb soaring across the corral, was a favorite of Ryan’s, and became the lead image of the story. More images from the project are displayed on Hall’s website. And as this issue of PDN was going to press, another story that Hall shot last summer in Mongolia appeared in the April/March 2014 issue of Nature Conservancy.

article.article_title: Client Meeting: Popular Science Looks to The Future
article.meta_description: The magazine’s redesign favors more portraiture and conceptual photography, making its futuristic subjects more relatable to readers.
article.article_text_abstract: The magazine’s redesign favors more portraiture and conceptual photography, making its futuristic subjects more relatable to readers.
article.article_image_credit: © Popular Science/Photo by Travis Rathbone; Prop Styling by Wendy Schelah for Halley Resources; Grooming by Valissa Yoe
article.article_image_caption: Olympic skier Ted Ligety, photographed by Travis Rathbone for the opening spread of a cover story.
article.article_text:
In its 142 years of publishing, the publishers and editors of Popular Science magazine have shown a fearlessness in changing the brand’s visual identity that’s somewhat akin to strapping on a jetpack. Since debuting in 1872, Pop Sci, now owned by Bonnier Corporation, has scrapped its logo 24 times; its overall look, more. A willingness to modernize itself seems to be part of Popular Science’s DNA—the magazine’s main beat is the future, after all, and its goal is to explain how breakthroughs in science and technology might alter the lives of its mass readership.

For the first large-scale refresh of the 1.3-million circulation title in eight years, newly tapped Editor-in-Chief Cliff Ransom worked with Design Director Todd Detwiler and Photo Editor Thomas Payne to unify the magazine’s visual approach, beginning with the February 2014 issue. The magazine’s design had become somewhat fractured (the use of multiple logos, for instance) and the general feeling was that the disarray wasn’t serving the content well. The first step was a logo change. Detwiler hired type designers Gail Anderson and Joe Newton of Anderson Newton Design, well known for their “retro tendencies,” Detwiler says, to come up with a logo and branding that would nod gently to the magazine’s mid-century, flying-car heyday but push it forward into the future of tech.

The visual changes get more interesting from there. The most noticeable change: the cover. Nearly all of Popular Science’s covers in recent years have been illustrated: cyber soldiers, rolling robots, levitating trains. “The illustrated covers were always something shiny and hard, something that looked like it was real but didn’t really exist. They were an intangible look at the future,” says Detwiler. “But the amount of money being spent [on] them was blowing our budget.” The solution: Hire a photographer to shoot every cover.

In fact, Popular Science is now assigning more photography throughout the book.

“When I got here two years ago, we were shooting maybe 50 percent of the magazine from issue to issue; now we’re shooting almost 85 percent,” says Payne, adding that the rest is a combination of stock photography, manufacturer-supplied images and illustrations. The result of having more photographs commissioned specifically for Popular Science is a more cohesive look and feel. “The more you shoot of the magazine, the better it will look because you control what you can and cannot do,” says Detwiler.

The rise of photography at Pop Sci can be traced to the magazine’s evolving editorial direction. In a quest for new subscribers, there is an emphasis on relatability—how an upcoming development in science (or a current one) might affect the reader. That means more portraits and more personality profiles. The first cover of the redesigned February issue shows Olympic gold medalist skier Ted Ligety, shot by New York City-based photographer Travis Rathbone in an homage to Leonardo da Vinci’s Vitruvian Man. The story is called “Engineering the Ideal Olympian,” and covers the technologies used to give U.S. athletes an edge on their global competitors. Rathbone photographed Ligety in a ski suit that has a shark-skin-like coating and precision-placed zippers to reduce drag. It’s the same suit Ligety would go into competition with, and be seen wearing by millions of fans tuning in to watch the Winter Olympic Games. The article explains a bit of the scientific backstory behind it.

The March cover story focuses on a broader issue: the “science of sleep.” After kicking around far-out ideas, some inspired by Philip K. Dick novels, some including a live sheep, the magazine’s editors came to the conclusion that the cover would be a man in bed, yawning, holding a glowing tablet—speaking to a modern, gadget-addled lifestyle that’s not entirely conducive to sleep. It’s a topic most Pop Sci readers have first-hand knowledge of, and didn’t call for a futuristic illustration.

Rathbone, who also shot the March cover, says that when Detwiler and Payne talked over the concept with him before the shoot, “the big point that they impressed upon me is the idea that we’re reflecting what’s happening right now. They’re trying to put a little bit more ‘popular’ into Popular Science.”

He added that the pair chose to go for a moody shot with dark tonalities—a rarity for a consumer magazine. “I think it was a bold choice, and will pop out on the newsstand,” he says.

Though Rathbone shot two covers back to back, Payne says that he would definitely consider other cover photographers. “We have a great back-and-forth, and I like the consistency, but we’re open to others shooting it.”

Beyond the cover, a revised front of book will feature more prominent photography as well. The NOW section, which focuses on new developments in gadgets and tech, generally features a half-dozen product shots per month; the rest are pick-up images, using studio product photography provided by a manufacturer. Every product that’s assigned to be photographed will generally be shot by a photographer based in New York City, where Pop Sci’s editorial offices are located, so that Payne or one of the magazine’s creative representatives can be on hand. “If it’s a lawnmower or a lightbulb, we’ll do something cool with it,” says Payne. The rotating cast of photographers he’s used for the front of book since before the redesign has included Sam Kaplan, Jonathon Kambouris, Claire Benoist and Brian Klutch. “Everyone brings their creative mix to it. No one photographer shoots the entire front of book every month,” says Payne. “I’m always looking to work new talent into the mix, too.”

Flipping forward, a new section called NEXT covers ideas and innovations. Whereas the NOW section shots are more literal, NEXT’s are more conceptual: a February story on concussions featured a Sam Kaplan shot of watermelons colliding. The section also covers personalities. A Q & A in the February issue featured Dave Lange of FedEx, who’s in charge of handling the logistics of shipping anything that requires a chartered plane: whales, pandas, enormous emergency famine relief shipments, 80,000 sea turtle eggs, the Titanic’s hull. Lange works in Nashville, and the visual concept of a NEXT Q & A is that the subject should be shot in his or her workspace. Looking for someone based in the South who could do a “Martin Schoeller-style close-up, almost,” Payne searched the online photographer directory Wonderful Machine and came across the work of Jacob Slaton, a portrait photographer in Little Rock, Arkansas. Slaton drove several hours to Nashville for the shoot. He photographed Lange in his office wearing a pressed dress shirt, coffee cup in hand, sitting in front of a map of the world. There’s a Walter Mitty sensibility to the picture, which contrasts Lange’s banal office world to the weird, adventurous problems he works on solving day to day. It’s a striking portrait, and funny. “The best photographers are able to see in an instant the personality of someone and extract it,” Detwiler says.   

The secondary message of that shot: The breakthroughs Popular Science covers can happen anywhere, so if you’re a photographer located outside New York City, Los Angeles and the other big photo markets, Payne may come searching for you. “I’m looking to find great photographers everywhere—Atlanta, Tennessee, North Dakota,” says Payne. “More and more, we’re finding that there are great photographers in smaller markets that, for our needs, work out great.”

How does Payne look for photographers around the country? Wonderful Machine is a go-to, as is PhotoServe, he says. “There might be a great photographer that’s not on them, but I’ve had good luck so far,” he says. Another way he finds photographers is through old-fashioned printed promos mailed to his office. “It doesn’t matter if it’s just one striking image or several, I keep a huge stack of them in my office and periodically flip through them. I’m more inclined to keep them if they’re not from New York City.” He adds, “And I meet with as many new names as I can in-house.”

The photography in Pop Sci’s feature well remains a mix of more conceptual themes (a story on dark matter featured a photograph of a sphere in fog, for example) and more literal ones (a story on face detection opened with surveillance camera images stitched together). But there will be at least one major difference in the magazine moving forward: “We’ll always have the promise of the cover pay off inside,” says Detwiler. Previously, the illustrated cover might have been the only time the image was seen, and the cover concept might not even have been a feature, Detwiler explains. To demonstrate how the magazine has changed, Detwiler points to the February Olympics feature. Rathbone’s da Vinci-style cover image of Ligety is followed up inside with a story opener that’s a splashy spread from the same shoot: a profile portrait of the skier tucked for downhill battle. The typography is muted; the photograph shines.

Clearly the creative team has more control since the redesign. But they have not been given carte blanche yet. Because Popular Science is the biggest brand at Bonnier, “We can’t just do anything we want. Everything we do is calculated,” says Detwiler. “But if we stay within our framework, we’ve definitely got the ability to cool it up,” adds Payne.

Photographers, fire up your jetpacks.

Spotlight: The Photography of Modern Farmer

article.article_title: Frozen in Time: Powder Magazine's First Foray Into Branded Content
article.meta_description: Photography and video come together in a digital multimedia feature that tells the story of a ski expedition sponsored by The North Face.
article.article_text_abstract: Photography and video come together in a digital multimedia feature that tells the story of a ski expedition sponsored by The North Face.
article.article_image_caption: Skier Ian McIntosh, Kahiltna Glacier, Denali National Park, Alaska. McIntosh pitched the ski expedition to Denali to The North Face, and suggested Adam Clark as the photographer. Click on the Photo Gallery link below to see more from "Frozen in Time."
article.article_text:
When outdoor clothing and equipment brand The North Face wanted a way to promote a ski expedition they sponsored to Mount Hunter in Alaska’s Denali National Park & Preserve, they turned to Powder Magazine to produce a branded, editorial-style multimedia feature that combined photography, video and text into an interactive experience.

The digital feature, titled “Frozen in Time,” was released by Powder in December 2013. The story follows professional skiers Ian McIntosh, Angel Collinson and Johnny Collinson as they spend a couple of weeks in April 2013 skiing previously untouched lines near the Denali base camp from which mountaineers access the highest peaks in North America.

The multimedia “flipbook,” as Powder calls it, features Adam Clark’s photographs, video by Sherpas Cinema and text by Powder editor John Stifter, as well as maps, journal entries from the athletes and other design elements. The piece also allows readers to see and shop for The North Face products that were used during the expedition.

Each year The North Face funds roughly a dozen expeditions for their sponsored athletes, and the photography and video created during those expeditions provides the bulk of the content the brand uses in its advertising, marketing and communications, says Aaron Carpenter, The North Face’s vice president of global marketing.

The flipbook about the Denali ski expedition that Powder proposed appealed to The North Face because it used new technology, and combined great photography, video and storytelling while seamlessly featuring their products. “That’s the ultimate, if we can combine a great story along with the product,” Carpenter says.

That the flipbook was a Powder production sponsored by The North Face, rather than a North Face production released by the brand, made a difference as well. The distinction may sound subtle, but as Carpenter notes, working with media partners like Powder changes how potential readers view a story. When readers turn to Powder or other magazines, “they’re really in the mindset of, ‘I want a story and I want to go deep on it,’” Carpenter says, whereas if The North Face releases photo and video via their own social channels, “it actually doesn’t reach that many people” despite their large audience, which includes more than three million followers on Facebook.

Once their agreement with The North Face was in place, Powder treated the creation of the flipbook “basically like another magazine” they were producing, says Powder editor John Stifter. The magazine’s staff, which includes longtime Director of Photography David Reddick, created and edited all of the material, including Clark’s photographs and video clips provided by Sherpas Cinema; designed the 51 slides that went into the flipbook; then handed the production over to Kindmags, a British company that produces digital magazines and other media. About a month later, Powder published “Frozen in Time.”

It’s the first time Powder has produced a multimedia flipbook, though they previously created one static flipbook “as a way to feature photography” outside of the space limitations of print, Stifter says. (Other magazines operating under Powder’s parent company, GrindMedia, have also created digital magazines or other features in this style, which gave the Powder team some knowledge of the process.)

As readers click through the pages of the flipbook, which they can view on a computer, tablet or smartphone, Clark’s action images, portraits and detail shots are the entry points into each part of the story.

A veteran of the ski industry who sold his first images to Powder in the late 1990s, Clark is on retainer with The North Face, and is also a senior photographer for Powder. Often the athletes will pitch expedition ideas to The North Face and the brand will decide on the photographer, but in this case McIntosh recommended Clark—the two had traveled to Denali together before and had “scoped out some of the lines that we were shooting and skiing,” Clark says.

The expeditions are great to work on, Clark explains, because The North Face “[tries] to give you as much time as possible to get as much done as possible,” and they also “pay well” because they “realize it’s a lot of time and it’s dangerous.”

The difficulty of being a ski photographer often comes from long hikes with heavy backpacks, but on this trip the cold presented the greatest challenge. Clark says it was in the neighborhood of -40 degrees the first night. It was also challenging “to keep that creativity alive but also to be safe and secure.”

The crew was working with guide Fred Collins, and Clark asked him questions about where to go and where not to go. But, he says, it was ultimately on him to decide “if I’m going to take two more steps forward to get that perfect angle … It’s all about having experience in the mountains and hopefully making a good decision.”

Coordinating with the cinematographers was also important, Clark says. He’s often after wide-angle, tight shots of the skiers, but has to be careful to stay out of the frame of the video cameras.

Clark went on the expedition with a shot list from The North Face, but also documented the trip as if it were an editorial assignment, something the brand appreciates. “They want more than just the hero stuff, they want all the details of these athletes’ lives,” Clark explains. Winter camping gave him a chance to make lifestyle images and portraits as he lived with the athletes in tents for a couple of weeks. “I love that aspect of it,” he says. The long days of the arctic spring also meant golden hour stretched to two or three hours. By the end of the trip they were shooting sunset skiing at 10 PM.

The Powder staff was “careful” in designing and programming the flipbook, wary that readers might be put off by heavy-handed branding, a caution The North Face appreciated. “We were trying to be as careful as possible with those ‘buy now’ links and our North Face coverage,” says Stifter, adding that the brand “was not asking [us] to be over the top in their branding, they wanted it to be subtle as well.”

A branded feature like this, Carpenter says, is “really good at reaching our most involved consumers. We call them hardcore achievers: people who really are getting outdoors and pushing their personal limits … [This type of project is] really effective with a smaller group of really influential people and loyal people.”

“It’s exceeded my expectations in terms of views,” Stifter tells PDN, noting that at press time in late December, the flipbook had “been viewed just shy of 300,000 times, and the time spent analytic is 4 minutes and 28 seconds, so people are flipping through it which is really awesome.”

Clark says he’s received “a ton of great feedback from all different parts of the outdoor industry,” from athletes to people working on the marketing side of the business.

article.article_title: Portraits That Tell Stories: Jocelyn Lee's "Women & Girls"
article.meta_description: The fine-art photographer talks about her long-term series in which she photographs women of all ages.
article.article_text_abstract: The fine-art photographer talks about her long-term series in which she photographs women of all ages.
article.article_image_caption: "Girl in Sunroom," 2011, from Jocelyn Lee's series "Women & Girls."
article.article_text:
Jocelyn Lee shoots primarily portraits, taking a conceptual approach that strives to elevate them to fine art. Her goal is to communicate ideas not only about her subjects, but about the world in which they live.    

Lee, a Yale University graduate who taught at Princeton University for ten years, lives in New York and Maine. Over the course of almost 30 years, she has established a name for herself primarily by photographing women and girls, exhibiting portraits that challenge the norms of female beauty at Pace/MacGill Gallery in New York City, Rose Gallery in Santa Monica, California, and Flatland Gallery in Amsterdam.  

Her agenda isn’t heavy handed, but throughout her career Lee has sought to expand and explore conventional definitions of female beauty. “We are all imperfect in profound and complicated ways,” says Lee. “Women have a particularly difficult time with aging because youth and perceived notions of beauty are prioritized in our culture and in being so demand the complete obfuscation of a giant population of women.”   

Inspired by the casual, girl-watching photographs of Garry Winogrand in his 1975 series “Women Are Beautiful,” which she says she greatly admires, Lee has spent her career photographing her friends and family as well as paid models, exploring all body types and ages and stages of life. Her portraits, often nude or semi-nude, include very pregnant young women, nursing mothers, babies, little girls, budding adolescents, tattooed and pierced teens, middle-aged women, older women, women with the wrinkles of age and the scars of surgery, even her own mother as she lay dying.  

“The concept behind this body of work is to expand the notion of female beauty and to add new images to our cultural image bank of the female body,” Lee explains. “I’m also interested in the psychological portrait. These pictures are as much about the internal lives of these women as [they are] about the external body.”   

So while Winogrand took a street photographer’s approach to stealing glimpses of young women, Lee takes a portrait photographer’s more deliberate approach to her subjects, selecting indoor and outdoor environments to pose them in and photographing them with a Mamiya RB67 film camera. She scans her negatives and makes pigment prints, typically about 24 x 20 inches.   

“Although Lee is interested in photographing specific people at different stages of life, each portrait also provides a broader opportunity to reflect on our shared humanity,” notes the website of the Smithsonian’s National Portrait Gallery where Lee was featured in the 2008 to 2009 “Portraiture Now: Feature Photography” exhibition with Katy Grannan, Ryan McGinley, Steve Pyke, Martin Schoeller and Alec Soth.   

In 2011, some of Lee’s portraits were published along with a selection of landscapes as Nowhere But Here (Steidl). In 2013, she received a New York Foundation for the Arts grant to help with the publication of a much larger selection to be called Women & Girls.   

Where Winogrand’s photographs embodied the male gaze and all the flirting heterosexual tension that it implies, Lee is after something quite different.    

“I want these portraits to convey love,” she says. “I want them to convey tenderness and compassion. I want to make pictures that feel that they were made, at least in part, by someone who loves the body that sits before them.”   

While the immediate subject of Lee’s “Women & Girls” portrait series is the female body, the subtext is aging. Because she has photographed some women repeatedly for almost three decades, her photographs portray girls becoming women and women becoming elderly.   

“It is about the individual in time,” Lee says, “short time, the moments it takes to make a single portrait, and long time, over years or a lifespan.”   

And what she has learned from this long-term portrait project is that photography has a narrative all its own.    

“The default of being a photographer,” says Lee, “is that if you take photographs all your life, you end up photographing your life.”

article.article_title: Native Son: Joe Leavenworth Searches for His Roots
article.meta_description: In his first monograph, the photographers explores the very personal subject of his own adoption and upbringing.
article.article_text_abstract: In his first monograph, the photographers explores the very personal subject of his own adoption and upbringing.
article.article_image_caption: "Untitled," 2011, from Joe Leavenworth's first monograph, Native Son, a project about his search for connections to the American South. Click on the Photo Gallery link below to see more images.
article.article_text:
Photographs are inextricably connected to memory, and our memories are, in many ways, the sum of our lives. We grew up looking through photo albums at the people our parents were before they became our parents, and at images of ourselves from before we can even remember. We keep photos of events from long ago, showing people we have not thought of in years.

Native Son, the first book by photographer Joe Leavenworth, is a quietly compelling work that operates at the intersection of memory and identity. All of the photographs were taken in the American South—specifically in Georgia—and represent the artist’s attempt to explore and connect with the place where he was born. If that sounds fairly conventional, here is the catch: Leavenworth has no memory of growing up in the South, because after his birth in Decatur, Georgia, in 1985, he was adopted and raised by a family in small-town New England. In fact, he made his first trip back to the state of Georgia to begin working on Native Son.

Leavenworth’s parents were open about the fact that he was adopted, but as a child he had little desire to investigate his roots. He grew up with the knowledge that his birth mother had left a lengthy letter for him, but it wasn’t until he was an adult that Leavenworth wanted to read it.

“I decided to read the letter and that propelled me forward to begin unraveling the mysterious nature of my own beginnings,” he says. “She talked about Georgia and her family and how I came to be and my father … it had a profound impact on me, and that was why I needed to get down there and see this place.”

When Leavenworth made his first trip to Decatur in 2009, he was a young photographer. He soon realized that he was in over his head. His shyness made it difficult for him to approach strangers and, lacking any real plan for what he wanted to shoot, he achieved little. It took more than a year for Leavenworth to return to Georgia, but he was far more productive when he did. In the interim, he read voraciously about the state, studying its official and vernacular histories, taking note of places he might want to investigate.

When he finally headed south again it was with a colleague who was working on a separate photo project. This time Leavenworth gave himself a solid two weeks to shoot, and arrived with places to stay, people to network with and a clear idea of the areas he wanted to photograph.

Leavenworth returned to New York City excited about his work, but so broke that he couldn’t afford to develop the film for six months. In retrospect, he says, the dead time between creating the work and actually seeing it allowed him to “reflect and imagine my photographs as I’d remembered creating them, or the context of their creation. I found this process insightful … a little inclusion of a fictive element.”

In the book we see dilapidated clapboard homes and churches; a man glaring from his truck window; a rope hanging from a tree; a girl on a swing; a young African-American woman looking into the camera defiantly. Leavenworth does not shy away from ideas of race and class, but also refuses to make “any sort of grand statement,” as he puts it. At the same time, his personal search imbues what could be viewed as straight documentary images with a tension that elevates the collection into something more than the sum of its parts.

In this way Leavenworth’s outsider-ness is instrumental to the work’s success, because Native Son is a story of exploration and discovery. He is not trying to uncover some “truth” about the American South, but instead to make images that feel true to what he saw. “I am a collector, collecting evidence of my own lived experience. Nothing special,” he insists. “But I’m hungry, and I am obsessed with looking and questioning … and I want to share my discoveries.” He also wanted to make images that reflect some of what he felt when he returned “home” to a place where he never lived, a place to which he nonetheless holds a connection.

While Leavenworth continues to travel to Georgia and search for this elusive connection, he has not yet attempted to find his mother. “It’s something I have begun to think more seriously about,” he says. “But I don’t know yet, we’ll see.”

Leavenworth met his book’s publisher, Margo Dooney of VUU, at the NY Art Book Fair this past September. At the time, he was not actively looking for a publisher, and had already begun to research self-publishing options, determined to put the book out on his own if necessary. In working on his first book, Leavenworth’s biggest adjustment was balancing his own perfectionism and VUU’s tight publishing schedule.

Native Son is almost devoid of text, until near the end of the book where there is a scanned handwritten note: the last page of the lengthy letter that Leavenworth’s biological mother left him. Although it is brief, it grounds the photos and brings some context to the work. For the artist, it was not an easy decision to add any text, let alone use his mother’s letter. But when his publisher asked for an artist statement, Leavenworth struggled to write something he was happy with, then thought of using the letter.

“I felt it belonged, but was a little skeptical due to the very personal aspect. It also remains slightly mysterious because she hasn’t addressed me by name … it may be confusing, but I didn’t want to qualify the letter in a statement,” Leavenworth explains. He says, “I’ve wanted to see this work in a physical book more as photographs only—no text—because it digs into that aura of mystique which one takes away from the photographs themselves … But the letter is the reason I am in Georgia.”

article.article_title: Portraits That Tell Stories: Joe Pugliese’s Photos of Veterans and Their Families
article.meta_description: For a Texas Monthly assignment, the Los Angeles-based shooter photographed soldiers returning home from Afghanistan.
article.meta_keywords: Joe Pugliese, Texas Monthly, soldiers, photos
article.article_text_abstract: For a Texas Monthly assignment, the Los Angeles-based shooter photographed soldiers returning home from Afghanistan.
article.article_image_caption: Sergeant First Class Sheila White, 42, holds her daughter Nema, 5, after returning from service in Afghanistan. Click on the Photo Gallery link below to see more images.
article.article_text:
Los Angeles portrait shooter Joe Pugliese has photographed a who’s who of celebrities, from Oprah Winfrey to Justin Bieber, and newsmakers such as Associate Justice of the Supreme Court Sonia Sotomayor and the late Apple CEO Steve Jobs. His portraits of glamorous actors regularly appear in The Hollywood Reporter, and he has photographed many of the world’s most powerful business executives for clients like Money.   

But Pugliese has also made portraits of injured American combat veterans, so it was not a stretch for Texas Monthly to commission him to photograph Texas soldiers returning from Afghanistan.

Texas Monthly Director of Photography Leslie Baldwin says it was Pugliese’s “Operation Mend” portraits of injured GIs that attracted the magazine’s attention.   

“Joe’s experience and interest in working with veterans was a plus to us,” says Baldwin. “We needed someone who was sensitive to the situation and wouldn’t buckle under pressure.”   

There was pressure during the shoot at El Paso’s Fort Bliss because, while the creative team—Pugliese, two assistants, Baldwin and Texas Monthly Creative Director T.J. Tucker—had permission to photograph the returning soldiers, the veterans had just completed a lengthy plane ride, hadn’t seen their families in months and had no idea they would be asked to pose for pictures.   

“Talk about a nail biter!” says Baldwin. “Joe was the ultimate pro and made it all come together beautifully.”   

The cover of Texas Monthly’s July 2013 Coming Home issue, and the 12-page photo essay inside the magazine, featured portraits of a dozen soldiers and their families returning to Fort Bliss after a nine-month deployment. Pugliese’s photo essay combined classic black-and-white documentary photos of the returning veterans with color portraits of the soldiers and their families posed against white seamless.   

Pugliese shot the black-and-white images with a 35mm digital SLR while the 48-member unit was arriving and being processed. The color portraits were taken with a medium-format Hasselblad on a small, makeshift set moments after the soldiers were reunited with their loved ones.   

The original idea had been to photograph returning veterans all over Texas, both on their bases and in their homes, but it was decided that would be too costly and time-consuming. So Pugliese was under the gun to shoot the whole story at Fort Bliss.   

“We had no more than five minutes per family,” he says. “The whole shoot was under an hour.”

Families that volunteered simply posed, many horsing around and mugging for the camera, in front of the white scrim Pugliese used to decontextualize and de-militarize the portraits.   

“I wanted to take the politics out of it. I wanted to make it human,” he says of the set. “They had been gone for a long time. This was a reunion.”   

Pugliese shot tethered to a laptop so Texas Monthly creatives could preview the images quickly. He says working so fast and so close could have been a disaster, but he loved how the shoot turned out.    

“For what it was, it was a fantastic project, my favorite project of the year,” says Pugliese. “I loved the simplicity and the honesty.”   

The spontaneity of the shoot meant that Pugliese “had no idea what these pictures would look like.”

“Would they be emotional? Stoic? Serious? You just have to pay attention and see what your subjects give you,” he says.    

For Pugliese, the take-away from the project was “direct less, pay attention, let things happen.”   

“The learning process never stops,” he says. “The photographs get better and better the less I try to control the situation.”

Baldwin says Pugliese’s photo essay for the Coming Home issue is “one of my favorite pieces we’ve done in the ten years I’ve been at Texas Monthly.”   

“There’s an elegance to Joe’s portraits,” Baldwin continues, “beautiful lighting and great sense of color. The emotions and expressions in his portraits always seem genuine, not forced. We thought his approach would be perfect for our photo essay.”

Portraits That Tell Stories: Andrew McConnell’s Photographs of Refugees by Night

article.article_title: Portraits That Tell Stories: Andrew McConnell’s Photographs of Refugees by Night
article.meta_description: The Irish photojournalist used portraiture to raise awareness about people displaced by war and now living in major cities around the world.
article.article_text_abstract: The Irish photojournalist used portraiture to raise awareness about people displaced by war and now living in major cities around the world.
article.article_image_caption: Syrian refugees Ihsan and Sammia, pictured on a rooftop in Al Mafraq, Jordan. They crossed the border into Jordan three days earlier after fleeing the increasing violence in Syria.
article.article_text:
Irish photographer Andrew McConnell began his career as a photojournalist in Belfast, Northern Ireland, but since 2003 he has lived in Asia, Africa and now Beirut, Lebanon, pursuing long-term projects about stories that are often overlooked, untold or underreported.

In 2011 McConnell won a pair of World Press Photo awards, one for a photograph of a woman practicing the cello in the Democratic Republic of Congo and the other for a photo essay titled “The Last Colony” about Sahrawi refugees in the Western Sahara. The Sahrawi people have suffered one of the world’s most protracted refugee crises, having been condemned to refugee camps in 1975 when Morocco invaded the Western Sahara.

McConnell’s Sahrawi story, which consisted of haunting portraits taken at night in the desert, led to an even more ambitious series: “Hidden Lives: The Untold Story of Urban Refugees,” portraits of refugee families in eight cities around the world taken by available light.  

“I would never have imagined undertaking a portrait-driven story. Most of my work is reportage,” says McConnell. “But when I went to the Sahrawi refugee camps I saw a lot of people I knew nothing about and the world knows nothing about, and I just felt reportage would not convey how forgotten these people are.”

McConnell’s Saharan nocturnes came to the attention of the International Rescue Committee (IRC), which approached Panos Pictures, the London-based photo agency that represents McConnell, about commissioning a series of portraits to publicize the plight of urban refugees around the world. The IRC secured a grant from the European Commission’s Humanitarian Aid and Civil Protection group that enabled McConnell to photograph Somali refugees in Kenya, Syrian refugees in Jordan, Congolese refugees in Burundi, Burmese refugees in Malaysia and refugees from the earthquake in Haiti, as well as refugees from many other nations now living in Bangkok, London and New York City. McConnell made all the portraits at night.  

“Shooting at night works because it gets a sense of how hidden, how unseen they are,” explains McConnell. “These people are almost like ghosts in the cities. And on another level, it speaks to the long night these people are living through.”  

McConnell photographed with a Canon EOS 5D Mark III which he says, “works magic in low light.” He supplemented the ambient city lights with one to three flash guns.  



Human rights lawyer Parvez Aslam Choudhry and his wife, Neelam Shazia, from Lahore, Pakistan, photographed in Bangkok. Parvez was forced to flee Pakistan with his family after receiving death threats due to his work defending Christians charged under the country's blasphemy laws. © Andrew McConnell/Panos

The portraits, some 40 in all, were exhibited in 2013 at St. Pancras International train station in London and at The Cathedral of Saint John the Divine in New York City. “Hidden Lives” also has its own website, www.hidden-lives.org.uk, that combines the portraits with testimonies from the individual refugees and photographs of their living spaces and identity papers.  

“With reportage, a lot of times the people are just subject matter,” says McConnell of his decision to use portraiture in a social documentary project. “We wanted to elevate them as individuals and treat them with respect.”  

The IRC’s goal with the “Hidden Lives” portraits is to challenge the stereotype that all refugees live in tent cities run by host countries and international aid agencies.  

“For most people, the word ‘refugee’ conjures images of endless rows of white tents spread out over a dusty plain,” states the IRC website. “But this does not give an accurate picture of what life is like for millions of refugees in the twenty-first century. According to the United Nations Refugee Agency, today more than half of the world’s refugees live in the slums of some of the world’s biggest cities, such as Bangkok in Thailand, Amman in Jordan and Nairobi in Kenya.” 

“These people are everywhere,” says McConnell. “It’s not just a third-world problem. This can happen to anyone.”

article.article_title: Kingston Sessions: Exploring Jamaica's Music, Art and Street Culture
article.meta_description: Through his collaboration with a writer and art director, photographer Alexander Richter found an audience for a personal project about the Caribbean city.
article.meta_keywords: Kingston, Jamaica, Photography, Alexander Richter
article.article_text_abstract: Through his collaboration with a writer and art director, photographer Alexander Richter found an audience for a personal project about the Caribbean city.
article.article_image_caption: The interior of Rockers International, a legendary record store opened by the late musician Augustus Pablo on what is locally known as "Beat Street." Click on the Photo Gallery link below to see more images.
article.article_text:
One of the major benefits of the democratization of publishing in recent years is the autonomy it offers photographers who want to find audiences for their personal work. Now, photographers not only challenge themselves creatively with their self-assigned projects, they often also test their abilities as publishers and collaborators.

For Alexander Richter, who works primarily as an editorial and commercial photographer in New York City for clients like Atlantic Records, Nike, Rolling Stone, Mass Appeal and XXL, traveling to Kingston, Jamaica, to produce a body of work was about challenging himself to go abroad with no backing and create photo stories through force of determination and his ability to persuade subjects to participate. It was also an opportunity to collaborate with a writer and art director to publish and find an audience for the work.

Richter’s interest in exploring life and culture in Kingston grew from his longtime appreciation for reggae and dancehall music, two art forms for which the city is famous. Through Tumblr, Richter had connected with writer Sean Stewart, who was born and raised in Kingston. After they decided to collaborate on what they envisioned as a print and digital project, they traveled to Kingston in August 2012 to work for seven days.

They created roughly two stories per day, Richter says. “The goal was to cover music, explore art and sport culture, as well as some of the nefarious elements that exist … The idea was to show modern Kingston, its beauty and its underbelly, so once we landed it was nonstop—search, shoot and drive, day and night, to find the story.”

Richter and Stewart had local help from a friend of Stewart’s, who made introductions for them, but as on all the best journeys, one connection led to another. A shoot with popular dancehall artist Tommy Lee led to an introduction to a fashion designer, who then introduced them to a tattoo artist. Other stories include a snapshot of Kingston gun culture, and profiles of a prominent local music promoter, a boxing legend and an Australian abstract sculptor who runs a gallery in a former Red Stripe beer factory.

Approaching people and convincing them to participate depended heavily on the personalities of the photographer and writer. Richter brought business cards with some of his portraits of well-known musicians printed on them, but otherwise they relied on “the energy that we presented [subjects] with at that moment,” Richter says. “So it was kind of run and gun.”

Once he had permission to photograph, however, Richter’s experience shooting editorial portraits helped him connect with his subjects. “I think the main thing that allowed me to do the work was just personality and the ability to have a very genuine interaction with whomever it was,” Richter says. “If you’re able to interact and create a natural connection there, and they can tell that you’re feeling that moment, they tend to relax and have a connection with you that’s a bit more authentic.”

On their first night in Kingston, Richter defined the visual style he’d use for the project almost by default. Out at 2 AM documenting the prostitutes who work Ripon Road, he decided not to use a flash to limit the attention he was already drawing to himself and Stewart. He liked the look of the ambient light, and decided to shoot without flash throughout the project. An interior shot of a man holding a pistol, for instance, was lit using a Blackberry, Richter says. His photographs include documentary-style images, posed portraits, and details that pay special attention to atmosphere and place.

Early on in his career, he says, he was gear-oriented, but work like he did in Jamaica has helped him develop a natural-light esthetic that he’s carried into his day-to-day work. “I can move people around and find places to make stuff happen that I think is interesting, but that doesn’t anchor me to outlets or battery packs,” he says.

When they returned from Kingston, Richter and Stewart connected via Instagram with Anthony Harrison, a designer in Portland, Oregon, who agreed to collaborate with them to publish the work digitally and in print. Richter and his collaborators dubbed the project “Sevens Clash,” a reference to a seminal roots reggae album by the group Culture, and built a brand around the work. While the ultimate goal was a print piece, which they created and released in December 2013 as a limited-edition zine, the digital component of “Sevens Clash” was essential to helping them find an audience.

By publishing their stories as digital features throughout 2013, and sharing them on social media sites like Instagram and Facebook, Richter, Stewart, and Harrison built a following that resulted in features on WIRED’s Raw File blog and the now-defunct Tumblr Storyboard, among other media outlets. The work also led to commercial assignments for Richter for a major brand and creative firm. (Richter asked we keep the clients’ names quiet.) And when they published their zine, which included eight of their features, they sold out the limited edition of 100 quickly, with some of those copies purchased by fellow photographers Richter admires.

“It was inspirational to see that the work resonated with people,” Richter says. “I already have a few other things that I’m ready to move forward with, because in the end I know I can do it independently.”
