Alexander Richter Photo Gallery

article.article_title: Emma Summerton's Fashionable Portraiture
article.meta_description: Whether she’s shooting a portrait or a fashion spread, it all comes down to creating a concept, and then letting the subject shine.
article.meta_keywords: Emma Summerton, fashion photography, portrait photography
article.article_text_abstract: Whether she’s shooting a portrait or a fashion spread, it all comes down to creating a concept, and then letting the subject shine.
article.article_image_caption: For the cover story in the Art Issue of W, Emma Summerton photographed actor George Clooney in a suit designed by artist Yayoi Kusama in an environment that was built to match. Click on the Photo Gallery link below to see more images.
article.article_text:
Celebrities are the new models. To sell copies, fashion magazines regularly feature the celebrity of the moment, modeling the clothes of the moment. For fashion photographers, the challenge is to create photo stories that present the celebrities in unexpected ways, while making sure they remain recognizable to readers and fans. 
For photographer Emma Summerton, who moves seamlessly between shooting fashion and celebrity portraiture for publications such as i-D, Purple, Vogue and W, and commercial clients like Burberry, Miu Miu and Yves Saint Laurent, her approach is the same: All her work is based on creating an intriguing concept using an environment or location, and then letting her subjects inhabit it in ways that feel comfortable. “For me, it’s more about getting the mood and the space right, and then collaboratively running with it once the shoot starts.”

The difference, she says, is that photographing models is easier. “When you work with girls like Gemma Ward or Lily Donaldson, who have been in training camp with photographers like Steven Meisel for many years, it’s incredible,” she explains. “You give them a personality to take on in the shot, and they just do it.” Moreover, they see themselves as part of a team. “They are interested in the hair, the makeup, the clothes,” Summerton says. “They don’t leave everything up to the photographer.”

Busy celebrities, however, play a less active role in the process of creating a great image. “They are pressed for time,” explains Summerton, who has photographed George Clooney, Michelle Dockery, Nicole Kidman and Katy Perry. “They want to get the shot done, so they can move on to the next thing.”

She frequently finds that the best images come at the end of a shoot, when everyone else feels like the workday is done. On a 2012 job for W photographing actors Nicole Kidman and Clive Owen, she recalls, publicists were rushing them through shots. The story was called “An Affair to Remember,” a nod to the film the two actors were promoting, Hemingway and Gellhorn, and to the ladylike 1950s clothes of the season in which Kidman was posing. As they were wrapping the shoot at the Beverly Wilshire hotel in Los Angeles, Summerton noticed Kidman looking in the mirror, and asked her to take one final shot. “I took about five frames, and one of those ended up being my favorite photograph,” Summerton says.  

Summerton has years of experience both with fashion models and performers, thanks to a career that started out as a happy accident, and has grown to include commissions from commercial brands, fashion magazines and celebrities like Katy Perry, who hired Summerton to bring her distinctive, graphic concepts to the promotional campaign for the singer’s single “Teenage Dream.” 

Summerton says she never guessed she would shoot commercial and editorial work when she was a student at the National Art School in Sydney during the early 1990s. Then, while out for coffee with her musician boyfriend, she met a professional photographer who was looking for an assistant. Summerton offered her services, even though her experience was limited to working in the school darkroom. “It was eye-opening,” she laughs. “I realized I had almost no technical skills.”

For the next six years, she devoted herself to learning the craft by assisting fashion and lifestyle photographers in Australia. During that time, she discovered Vogue Italia. “It was a revelation for me,” she says. “I said to myself, ‘Oh my god, there’s fashion photography that can actually be put on a wall.’” 

In 1998, she moved to London. “I wanted to leave Sydney before I got too comfortable there.” Rather than work for another professional photographer, she got a job as a studio assistant for Fiona Banner, a British installation artist who was shortlisted for the prestigious Turner Prize in 2002. 

Much of her time in Banner’s studio was spent on printmaking and drawing, but she never stopped taking photographs. Along with capturing shots of Banner’s text-based installations, she also took the artist’s portrait for press releases. Banner didn’t influence Summerton’s personal work, but working for the artist taught her how to nurture her visions. “I got to see how someone could transform an idea into a work of art,” she explains. It’s something she aspires to do in her photography. 

Through friends of friends, Summerton met Stacey Mark, then photo director for Nylon, who began assigning her freelance fashion pieces for the front of the magazine, and later portraits of musicians like The Raveonettes and The Kills. Around the same time, she was working on a personal project that would inform her later esthetic, and it led to a big break in fashion.

The project involved self-portraits she took with a Polaroid camera. “My mother was a dressmaker, and in school, she would make me dresses to wear to dances based on drawings I made,” she says. Back then, costumes were an access point to unleash Summerton’s imagination. In her “Polaroid experiments,” as she calls them, costumes again became a vehicle for her to express her inner life.  

The most successful of the portraits involved a pair of Terry de Havilland shoes she purchased in a boutique in London. When Summerton went back to buy another pair, she found that the shop where she had purchased them was gone. “I found de Havilland’s contact information via Google, and sent him some of the Polaroids I had taken with his shoes,” she says. She hoped he would let her borrow a few more pairs. He was so impressed, however, that he offered her a job taking the photographs for the brand’s next look book. 

That job led to more work in the fashion industry, and soon she was shooting a spread for Dazed & Confused featuring designer Stefano Pilati’s first collection for Yves Saint Laurent. He saw the work, and bought prints of the whole story. “That really opened up doors in the fashion industry,” she says. 

Today, it would be hard to find a fashion publication Summerton has not shot for. Her lush, graphically sophisticated images are easy to spot. “Emma is a great colorist with a magical eye,” says Mia Adorante, associate to the fashion and style director at W. Explains Summerton, “I don’t like white spaces.” She cites director Stanley Kubrick and cinematographer Edward Linden as inspirations. “If you freeze frame any of their films, the resulting images look like oil paintings.” Her esthetic also reflects her personal taste. “My apartment is stuffed full of vintage cabaret, lace curtains, pictures from all over the world,” she says. “I love things even more if they’re falling apart.”

She also loves the look of analogue film. Although she shoots with digital equipment—she switches between cameras a lot, but cites the Leica S-System as one she recently tried—she often imitates the color effects of her early Polaroid work. “My assistant and I keep a really detailed catalogue of all of the lighting we’ve ever done—from daylight shoots to studio sets,” she explains. This allows Summerton to go back and recreate the same effects in disparate conditions.

Her images always evoke a sense of place. Summerton typically creates an entire environment from scratch, or collaborates with the editorial team who has a location in mind. “She loves to research and puts her all into her work,” says W’s Adorante.

For a cover story on George Clooney for W’s Art Issue, released in December 2013, Summerton was told that Clooney would be wearing a black-and-white polka dot suit designed by the Japanese artist Yayoi Kusama. After brainstorming with the magazine’s design director, Johan Svensson, and photography director, Caroline Wolff, Summerton asked Kusama to design a matching backdrop to go with the images. Thomas Thurnauer, a set designer, created a table and chair covered in dots to fill out the composition. The resulting work is equal parts surrealist and retro pop—Clooney’s face practically jumps out of the textured surfaces of the images.  

Although Summerton primarily shoots for fashion clients, she hasn’t ruled out the possibility of showing her work in an exhibition, marking a return to what first drew her to fashion photography when she was a young assistant. “Right now, I’m just letting go, and going along for the ride,” she says.

article.article_title: End Frame: Michael Lewis on Lucas Samaras
article.meta_description: The portrait photographer talks about the role artifice plays in making images.
article.meta_keywords: Michael Lewis photographer, Lucas Samaras photographer
article.article_text_abstract: The portrait photographer talks about the role artifice plays in making images.
article.article_image_credit: © Lucas Samaras/Courtesy of Lucas Samaras and Pace Gallery
article.article_image_caption: “Sitting 20 x 24 (14A),” October 31, 1980, by Lucas Samaras.
article.article_text:
Portrait photographer Michael Lewis, one of six photographers we interviewed for “How Great Portraits Are Made," says he has long been fascinated by Lucas Samaras’s Polaroids, particularly the way the artist calls attention to the subjectivity and artifice of his hallucinatory images. Working in 8 x 10- or 20 x 24-inch Polaroids, Samaras often puts himself in his frames. He also shows the light stands and gels he used to produce the otherworldly colors in his images, revealing his tools and tricks to the viewer. Lewis discovered the work when he was in college, studying color photography. To Lewis, Samaras’s work seemed to say, “We’re using fake lighting. Why do we have to pretend that it’s real?” 
Having photographed politicians, musicians, entrepreneurs, writers and artists, as well as many well-known movie and TV actors, Lewis is keenly aware of how much artifice goes into portraits of celebrities. When he photographs so-called “real people,” he says, he usually photographs them in their own homes or workplaces, and they wear their own clothes. When photographing Hollywood personalities, however, “You’re quite often photographing them in a place they’ve never been that doesn’t mean anything to them. They come in dressed one way, they’re shot another way,” he says. “None of it’s real.”

Lewis says he dabbled only briefly with colored lights; even when he’s using lights to alter the space in which he photographs portrait subjects, he wants his lighting and use of color to be “grounded in reality.” Such attention to realism is “the antithesis of what I like about Samaras,” he admits. Still, he admires how Samaras references the process by which he makes his photos, which question the illusion that a photo is a window onto reality. Says Lewis, “That was something that was liberating to me.”

article.article_title: From Assistant to Photographer: Pascal Shirley’s Professional Transition
article.meta_description: The Los Angeles-based photographer developed his style by shooting friends on road trips and outdoor adventures, and used personal connections and social media to start landing assignments.
article.article_text_abstract: The Los Angeles-based photographer developed his style by shooting friends on road trips and outdoor adventures, and used personal connections and social media to start landing assignments.
article.article_image_caption: Advertisers hire Pascal Shirley to bring the carefree feel of his personal work to their campaigns. The talent he recruited for this Fresco Towels shoot last fall included several of the photographer's friends. Click on the Photo Gallery link below to see more images.
article.article_text:
Pascal Shirley likes to photograph his 20-something friends on road trips and outdoor adventures, just enjoying each other’s company. It’s personal work with the genuine, carefree feel that many brand managers are looking for. But Shirley’s challenge, when he was trying to launch his career, was harnessing his documentary style for commercial application, and getting his work noticed.
It took time, patience, mentoring and a measure of luck. Shirley struggled to attract commercial clients for nearly two years, shooting weddings for friends (and friends of friends) to stay afloat. His career started taking off about a year ago with local assignments through personal connections. Around the same time, he signed with I Heart Reps in Los Angeles, which has helped Shirley build momentum and land his first national advertising jobs.

After studying photography at the California College of the Arts, Shirley moved to Los Angeles in 2007. “My plan was to assist as much as possible. I came from a fine-art background, and I didn’t have much technical training,” he says.

He assisted regularly for Jeff Lipsky and Craig Cameron Olsen. Olsen turned into a good friend and mentor. “We hang out and talk photography and look at each other’s portfolios. He has taught me a lot about the business from his own experiences,” Shirley says.

He also assisted many out-of-town photographers on fashion, celebrity and lifestyle shoots, including Patrick Fraser, Nadav Kander, Nicolas Moore and Patric Shaw, among others. But his intention had always been to shoot for his own clients someday, and in his spare time, he was practicing his craft.

Shirley had tried fashion test shoots. “There was this pressure in LA to do test shoots with agencies and models. It didn’t really click with me, so I went back to shooting personal work of my friends,” he says.

By the end of 2010, he was “getting a little tired of assisting” so he cut back to free up more time for personal work. At the urging of Olsen, he also started putting more effort into self-promotion.

“Craig got on Instagram right when it started, and he was like, ‘You ought to check this out.’ I thought: Ugh, more social media? And Craig was like, ‘You gotta get on this.’

“I became more social on the networking side, which I wasn’t doing much, but it’s very important,” Shirley says. In addition to getting on Instagram, he also started a Tumblr blog. He posted pictures from his road trips with friends, “and followers started coming along. It’s not like I have tons of followers, but people started taking notice.”

One was freelance photo editor Katie Dunn. “I found [on Tumblr] tons of his images that were perfect for different stories that I was pulling images for,” she says, explaining that she was looking for images that felt more authentic than stock photography.

It was through Dunn that Shirley began licensing images to Cosmopolitan, GQ and other magazines. Those licensing deals led to some editorial assignments. Shirley also started to get assignments with some West Coast advertising clients through connections with friends he was photographing. Those clients included Coldsmoke apparel, Fresco Towels and Garrett Leight California Optical.

Meanwhile, Shirley had been casting about for a rep. He compiled a list of reps in Los Angeles, and sent an e-mail inquiry to I Heart Reps. Owner Dara Siegel invited him for a meeting, and agreed to represent him on a trial basis.

“I loved his work. I liked him as a person and he had experience assisting, so he knew how it all worked,” Siegel says. “If someone’s really talented, and I see the spark of what [it] takes to be a commercial photographer, I’ll coach them.”

She encouraged Shirley to shoot constantly, while working on his lighting and production values. “Every week I send her new pictures,” Shirley says. “She expects that, and I’ve been pretty good about it.”

The goal was to create images in which brand managers could imagine their products. To that end, Siegel helped Shirley come up with advertising concepts for test shoots, and encouraged him to give his friends more direction when he photographed them.

For instance, after he recently lost a bid for a Reebok campaign, Shirley gathered some friends to shoot the campaign as if he’d won it, just for practice. The brief was “three girls hanging out in Venice Beach for the day, having fun with a carefree kind of feel,” Shirley explains.

Siegel also worked with Shirley on his social media presence, helping him edit his Tumblr and Instagram feed to emphasize images with advertising potential.

“We’re finding that for one out of every five jobs, the art director is finding the photographer through social media,” Siegel says. “We’re making sure he’s ‘friending’ the right people, responding, liking their photos and commenting” on their posts.

In early 2013, Shirley got an assignment to shoot an outdoor campaign for a Canadian department store called Mark’s. The job came to him through a MacLaren McCann art director Shirley had met while assisting Lipsky. The art director “kept in touch with me and followed my Tumblr,” Shirley says.

Around that time, Shirley quit taking assisting jobs. “As much as you might want that few hundred dollars [for an assisting job], you’ve got to cut yourself off from it totally so people don’t look at you as an assistant any more.”

Siegel has been setting up meetings with ad agency art directors on national accounts, so Shirley has been making the rounds with his portfolio in New York City and San Francisco, in addition to promoting himself on social media. He’s also working on a self-published book that he’ll give to prospective clients.

“People want tangible objects,” he says.

And he’s trying to arrange an exhibition for a personal project he recently shot in Iceland, featuring attractive friends cavorting about the beautiful landscape. “Everything is digital now, and I’ve been noticing that people want to see prints,” Shirley says.

His advice for assistants trying to transition is to make time to shoot personal work. “It is easy to get caught up [in] assisting too much because it gets comfortable,” he says. He also advises aspiring photographers to take advantage of opportunities to show their work in pop-up shows and other local venues to get attention and work from local clients, and then build business from there.

article.article_title: Michael Lewis on How Great Portraits Are Made
article.meta_description: The Los Angeles-based photographers shares the lessons he's learned about assuming how his famous subjects want to be photographed.
article.article_text_abstract: The Los Angeles-based photographers shares the lessons he's learned about assuming how his famous subjects want to be photographed.
article.article_image_caption: Before photographing the sketch comedy team Key & Peele for The New York Times, Michael Lewis asked them for their ideas, and shared a lesson he had learned about planning portrait concepts when Anthony Kiedis of the Red Hot Chili Peppers rejected his idea and took control of a shoot.
article.article_text:
Before Michael Lewis photographed the stars of Key & Peele, a sketch comedy show on Comedy Central, he first asked for their thoughts about how they wanted to be photographed. Photographers sometimes come up with a “gag,” says Lewis, who was on assignment for The New York Times, but he told Keegan-Michael Key and Jordan Peele, “I don’t think I should be telling you what’s funny. You’re the comedians.”  
Lewis says, “They were very surprised that I was offering this chance to collaborate.” He told them about a shoot he did 14 years ago when musician Anthony Kiedis taught him a lesson about imposing his own ideas about a subject.

Lewis’s career shooting celebrities had just taken off when he landed an assignment to photograph the Red Hot Chili Peppers. “I had really elaborate ideas. I’d brought a lot of props.” He planned to photograph the band in the courtyard of the Los Angeles apartment building where he lived at the time. Then the band’s lead singer and songwriter, Anthony Kiedis, arrived. “Kiedis took one look at the kiddie pool, and the toy fishing line, and he said, ‘We’re not doing that,’ and he just starts moving all the props out of the way.”

In hindsight, Lewis says, his concepts for the shoot were based on an outmoded idea of the band that dated back to when he first listened to them, when they were building their reputation as a goofy funk/punk band. Lewis had set up his props and lights indoors, but Kiedis proposed moving outdoors to the front of the apartment building. He grabbed a garden hose and started having a water fight. Then Kiedis stuck the hose down his pants. Rick Rubin, who had produced some of the band’s records, liked the photo that Lewis took so much he asked the photographer for a print.  

Lewis says that when he studied fine-art photography, he was encouraged to express himself in his photos. In creating editorial portraits, he wants to create “a Michael Lewis image,” but has other goals as well. “A lot of portrait photographers forget that at the end of the day it’s a portrait of someone else, not of them,” he says. “They put so much of themselves in, they treat their subjects like props.”

It surprises Lewis that celebrity publicists are more concerned with logistics or making sure the shoot doesn’t take too much of their clients’ time than they are with the content of the image, or making sure the photographer gets a good photo. Lewis, who got his MFA at San Francisco Art Institute, says his experience during class critiques is helpful when talking to reluctant publicists. “If you can verbally articulate the visual language to someone, they’ll step back and say, ‘OK, now that makes sense,’” he explains. If they’re not convinced, he listens. “Then I’ll reword my original idea using their own words to bring us to a common understanding. I’m always open to suggestions and ideas, but if I am confident that my original idea is going to make a great portrait, I can shift a bit to accommodate their concerns, so that they don’t kill the entire setup.”

On set, Lewis seizes opportunities to talk with subjects themselves. “I’ll walk up like I’m going up to check the light. I’ll have an exchange with the subject that no one else hears.” He might talk to them about their work, or a common interest he’s researched. Says Lewis, “It creates a micro moment that only you and the subject have, and I’ve found the subject is more open to direction.”


Another photo from Lewis's shoot with Key and Peele. © Michael Lewis

article.article_title: How I Got That Shot: Lighting a Garden at Night
article.meta_description: Jason Madara created dramatic nighttime shots of a sculpture garden in an ad campaign for oriental rugs.
article.article_text_abstract: Jason Madara created dramatic nighttime shots of a sculpture garden in an ad campaign for oriental rugs.
article.article_image_credit: © ABC Carpet & Home/Photo by Jason Madara
article.article_image_caption: One of eight ads Jason Madara shot for ABC Carpet & Home. The photographer was inspired by the color palette of Dutch landscape paintings.
article.article_text:
Client: ABC Carpet & Home

 Art Director: Angela Gruszka

A brilliantly colored silk carpet is spread beneath a canopy of trees at night. A path, illuminated by unseen light, leads into the distance. This fairy tale image is one of eight ads in the campaign for ABC Carpet & Home, the luxury home design and carpet store in Manhattan. Jason Madara photographed eight handmade, one-of-a-kind carpets over the course of two nights on the manicured grounds of the LongHouse Reserve, a sculpture garden in East Hampton, New York. Working under a moonless sky from 7 PM until 4 AM, Madara had to provide all the illumination in the garden. “I basically approached it like it was in the studio,” he recalls. 

Madara, who is based in San Francisco, says he and Angela Gruszka, the art director for ABC Carpet & Home’s advertising, spent about two months brainstorming the campaign. For a previous campaign, Madara had photographed carpets in empty rooms. Each wall was painted a different hue, highlighting the colors of a carpet’s design. For the new campaign, they wanted something different, but equally dramatic. They decided to take the carpets into nature. “Considering last year was inside, outside made sense,” the photographer says. 

When he is conceiving images, Madara typically creates mood boards to show his ideas to clients. For the newest ABC Carpet & Home campaign, he took inspiration from Dutch landscape paintings in which the rich colors of forests and pastures are enhanced by afternoon sunlight breaking through clouds. 

In composing the shots, “it was a delicate balance,” Madara says. “The rugs are the heroes but you couldn’t showcase the beauty of the rugs without the environment,” he explains. “As far as the lighting, we knew it had to be dramatic and strong, making a strong statement.” 

Logistics
Says Madara, “Shooting in the dead of night brings its own challenges. Lots of work lights, bug spray and generators fix that problem.” The locations for each of the eight shoots were chosen during a scout around the LongHouse Reserve. He and his crew would first set up work lights so they could see what they were doing. Then the digital tech set up the computer and monitor, while Madara’s assistants set up lights and power packs. Handlers put each rug into position. Then Madara captured separate images of the foreground and background for each scene, as well as plates of certain areas. When all the exposures were done, the crew packed up the gear and walked to the next location for the next ad. Each ad took about two hours to set up and shoot. Madara recalls, “We didn’t stop from 7 at night until 4 in the morning, we just powered through it.”

Lighting
Whether he’s shooting an interior, an exterior or a portrait, Madara’s lighting plan begins with one light, then he adds more lights in succession. In each shot of the ABC Carpet & Home campaign, he took an approach similar to what he would do when creating a portrait, he says. “I start with the background and how I want it to look, always separating it from the key light on the foreground, occasionally letting the background light bleed into the foreground for overall mood and [ambience], then add the key light to the subject, normally with a gridded beauty dish or a seven-inch grid spot that’s focused directly on the subject.” Before lighting the rug, he first worked on lighting the background to set the mood. In each shot, he used between six and eight Profoto lights, each with 5-, 10- or 20-degree grids. 

“Grids make a bold statement and I thought the whole environment should be specular and contrasty,” he says. The hard lights are unforgiving, he notes, because moving any light by an inch changes the look, but he likes their effect. He notes, “I always travel with softboxes and umbrellas but never end up using them.”

In the shot with the garden path in the background, he began by lighting the tree at camera left, then added grids pointing toward the bushes next to it. Tucked outside the frame, he placed another light on a stand about 15 feet high pointing down through the trees, like moonlight. Another light with a grid was placed out of the frame at camera left to illuminate flowers and branches. At the furthest visible point of the path leading into the distance, he had an assistant place a 10-degree grid about three feet above the ground. “It helped open up the path,” leading the viewer’s eye into the distance and giving the image more depth.

He lit the rug using a silver beauty dish with a grid at camera right, pointing down on the middle of the rug, creating slight fall off at the edges. “We did test shots of the background first, then started doing test shots with all the strobes on to see how everything looked together.” Next, Madara says, “We did a few exposures of everything on, then separate plates with only particular lights on, to then put them all together in post later.”


Another ad from the campaign. © ABC Carpet & Home/Photo by Jason Madara

Camera 
Madara used a Hasselblad H4X with a Phase One IQ260 back. “We knew we wanted big files with a lot of latitude to eventually make giant prints for the store,” he says. For lenses, he used a 50mm and an 80mm. 

He bracketed each shot to make sure he provided his retoucher with enough variations in light and contrast. With no ambient light in the scene, “all bracketing was done through ISO brackets, leaving the aperture and shutter speed the same,” at f/11 for a quarter of a second, he says. He also bracketed some shots by turning the power on the packs up or down.

Post-Production
Rebecca Bausher, a retoucher in San Francisco, has collaborated with Madara on all of his projects over the past four years. “She’s really involved in the concept process,” and had seen the paintings he had referenced when planning the ABC Carpet shoot, Madara says. When he provides bracketed shots to Bausher, “I make notes on the RAW image of where I want the shadows and highlights to be.”

During the post-production phase, the backgrounds were scarcely retouched. Attention was paid to accurately reproducing the colors in the carpet. Once Gruszka approved each composite, Madara provided the client with two files—an RGB file for use on the Web, and a CMYK for print ads and in-store displays. 

As Madara notes, dark, contrasty shots are more challenging to reproduce accurately when printed on paper. In converting the RGB files to CMYK, the contrast was “pulled back a little,” he says, “because we had to be wary of how they would print.”

The ads have appeared in Wallpaper*, Whitewall and other style magazines, and the campaign itself has been featured on design blogs. Says Madara, “It turned out exactly as we had planned.”

article.article_title: Meiko Takechi Arquillos on How Great Portraits Are Made
article.meta_description: The Los Angeles-based photographer shares her tips for photographing kids.
article.meta_keywords: Meiko Takechi Arquillos, portrait photography, portraiture, kid photography
article.article_text_abstract: The Los Angeles-based photographer shares her tips for photographing kids.
article.article_image_caption: The Guardian's picture editor didn't want a typical cute kid portrait, "and I was so grateful," says Meiko Takechi Arquillos. To prepare for the shoot, she thought of scenarios that would have appealed to her as a kid.
article.article_text:
Meiko Takechi Arquillos says that no matter whom she’s photographing, “there is a story to be told,” and she sees it as her job to find that story, and translate it into a portrait that viewers immediately relate to. 
“I originally started out taking pictures of kids because it was easy for me to connect with them,” she says. “I love playful and authentic sensibilities in images. What I usually do is really make myself seem very goofy—I don’t need to try very hard either—and that lets people’s guard down.”

Last summer, editors at The Guardian Weekend assigned her to shoot a cover for a nostalgic story about summertime food you ate as a kid. Arquillos cast a boy named Charlie for the project. She had previously worked with him on a shoot for Real Simple magazine.

“He is not your usual happy, smiley kid,” Arquillos says. “He has a lot of character. While he is super cute, he also has an attitude. I love that about him.”

She explains that she’s not interested in shooting “normal, cute kid pictures” because they’re not authentic: Kids have more personality and complexity than such images suggest.

Guardian Picture Editor Kate Edwards didn’t want another cute kid photo for the story, either, “and I was so grateful,” Arquillos says.

Arquillos was looking for something viewers would find familiar and unexpected at the same time, so she thought about scenarios that might have appealed to her as a kid. One idea she came up with was to show Charlie with not just one colorful Popsicle, but a bunch of them all at once, melting down his chin and arms. 

“It is important to have some conversations to get to know the subject first,” Arquillos says. “It is my way to figure out how far I can stretch it. In this case, I probably said something like, ‘So Charlie! Do you like Popsicles? You do? How would you like it if I gave you eight more?!’ Then I wait and see his reaction.”

Charlie wasn’t happy, and the cover photo she shot shows it.  

“You look at it and go, ‘Why [not]? Is he sneaking these Popsicles before his parents find out?’ It always makes you stop and think about the story behind it when you see something unexpected,” she says.

In preparation for all of her shoots, Arquillos comes up with a lot of ideas, but doesn’t wed herself to any of them. “You have to be malleable,” she says. “Often something unexpected strikes during a shoot.” She also avoids doing too much research on her subjects, for fear that it could drive away serendipity on set.

After tweaking the lighting and composition, Arquillos says, “I snap away like crazy as I talk to the subject. Sometimes real stuff comes out when a subject starts to get tired, but I have to be careful not to exhaust them.”

article.article_title: What's Your Niche: Mineral Photography
article.meta_description: Jeff Scovil explains his technique for shooting minerals as well as how he's built his client base.
article.article_text_abstract: Jeff Scovil explains his technique for shooting minerals as well as how he's built his client base.
article.article_image_caption: An amethyst (purple quartz) from the Stan Esbenshade collection. On the far side of the glass plate, Jeff Scovil hung a black background, and placed a 30-degree spot grid over the light behind a scrim to create the natural halo.
article.article_text:
Photographer Jeff Scovil of Phoenix travels 230 days per year around the U.S. and Europe to photograph crystal specimens for mineral dealers, private collectors, museums, scientists and publishers. He’s the author of Photographing Minerals, Fossils, and Lapidary Materials (Mountain Press Publishing Co, 1996), and is a long-time contributor to The Mineralogical Record and Rocks & Minerals magazines.  

PDN: How did you get started shooting minerals and crystals?
Jeff Scovil: I started collecting crystals when I was about 8 years old. In college I was an anthropology and archaeology major. I did a lot of research into forensic photography, and applied it to archaeology. Then I applied what I learned to shooting minerals. That was in 1975. I started doing it professionally in 1990.

PDN: What’s appealing to you about photographing minerals and crystals?
JS: They’re beautiful: the color, the luster, the transparency of them and the variety of forms. Photographing minerals is a matter of total control. And that’s me: a little bit of a control freak, a little [obsessive compulsive]. It gives me an outlet to finely manipulate the subject and the lighting. There’s an incredible amount of detail to recognize and bring out. 

PDN: So how do you go about it?
JS: The setup is done on a raised sheet of non-glare glass. That helps cut down reflections, I don’t have to worry about shadows and the glass allows me to light from any direction. I use a variety of [colored] backgrounds [and] a softbox positioned above the piece I’m photographing. I have another light under the table to illuminate the background, and a third light that I call a kicker, which sits on the glass, positioned any way I need it.

Crystals have numerous faces, and you have to define the shape, [so] you have to get different amounts of reflection from each face to distinguish them from each other. You also have to be able to see through the reflection of each face to the inside of the crystal. Each face has micro topographic features [i.e., imperfections] and you have to bring those out, too. There’s the rub. So I have 3.5 x 5-inch cards that I carefully position around the crystal, to reflect light off of the faces.

PDN: What does the kicker light do?
JS: When you’re photographing something highly reflective, you really have to use diffuse lights, or you get burned-out highlights. So I have the softbox light, but when you use a diffuse light source, you start losing dimensionality, transparency [and] saturation of color. It starts to look dead. The kicker light puts the life back in. It is aimed at the specimen, which is surrounded by the reflector cards. 

PDN: Besides lighting, what are the other challenges?
JS: Propping up the specimens is a challenge. Sometimes they’re heavy, or just top heavy. My greatest nightmare is breaking a specimen. I’ve only destroyed two specimens. The first time, it was a $100 specimen that fell off the glass. The second time, the specimen was worth a couple of hundred dollars. When I was putting it back in the box, it started to crumble.

Now I carry liability insurance of $1 million, which costs $500 a year.

PDN: How do you promote yourself?
JS: I’ve been in it so long that it’s all word of mouth. But I’ve been putting an ad in The Mineralogical Record for the past year. I want to make sure I’m still out there, in people’s faces, and a friend of mine says I need to be branded with a classy reputation. 

PDN: How did you establish your reputation?
JS: Before I started doing this as a profession, my philosophy was publish, publish, publish. I became a regular contributor to several [mineralogical] magazines. I only required that every picture published had my [credit] so you were always seeing my name. 

PDN: How did you transition from hobbyist to professional?
JS: I would attend mineral shows, going from dealer to dealer with a portfolio, asking the dealers if they wanted me to take pictures of specimens. My first road trip was when the publisher of Rocks & Minerals wanted pictures of some minerals from China. A collector in California had some of the minerals. So I shot those, and the road trips kept building from there. 

PDN: How do you arrange jobs for a road trip?
JS: Sometimes it revolves around a show. I keep a list of [dealers and collectors] who want me to shoot for them, as well as a list of people I’ve shot for in the past, and when I have trip coming up, I call them.

PDN: How do you travel?
JS: I drive to a lot of places because I have a truck full of equipment. 

PDN: What gear do you carry?
JS: I’ve got a table that folds up, a couple of sheets of glass, backgrounds, diffuser material, reflector cards in a variety of sizes up to 8 x 10 [inches], natural density filters in case things are too bright, blocks, putty, clips, glass cleaner, light stands, a tripod, a magic arm, a portable Manfrotto boom. I carry about six cases of equipment—for shooting something so small, it’s a lot of crap, but you have to have a lot of control. I’m a fussy maximalist.

PDN: What camera and lenses do you use?
JS: For years, I shot film, first with a Pentax, then the Canon F-1 system. I would light specimens as best as I could, bracket a little bit, then pray. Digital is a godsend. I use a Nikon D2Xs, mostly with a 60mm macro lens, but also a 105mm macro. I shoot tethered and I can tweak the lights until [I’m] really happy. 

PDN: Why do clients want the pictures? How do they use them?
JS: Dealers use pictures for publicity. Museums use them for publicity and education. For collectors, it boils down to ego. They know it’s likely they’ll have my photos of their minerals published in magazines with their name on it. I have two collectors who pay me a bonus if I get them a cover of a magazine.

PDN:  What are your rates?
JS: At first I was charging peanuts to get my foot in the door. Now I charge [dealers and collectors] $1,000 a day plus expenses. I average 20 pieces in a day. The magazines are a different story: They’re cash poor. They pay $40 a shot.

PDN: Why do you continue to license pictures at that price?
JS: It’s publicity [i.e., self-promotion]. In an average year, I publish 1,300 photographs in books, magazines, posters, calendars—things like that. Textbook publishers will pay based on page size, with a minimum price of $180. 

PDN: What advice do you have for photographers who are interested in this niche?
JS: Start studying minerals and mineralogy and mineral collecting. As you’re doing that, find a collector in the neighborhood [who] you can mooch minerals from to start learning [how to shoot]. There’s the website www.mindat.org, where you can get information about any mineral. It also has a forum where people share pictures of minerals.

article.article_title: John Harrington on How Great Portraits Are Made
article.meta_description: The Washington, DC-based photographer talks about how he works with subjects who aren't used to being in front of the camera.
article.meta_keywords: John Harrington, portrait photography, portraiture
article.article_text_abstract: The Washington, DC-based photographer talks about how he works with subjects who aren't used to being in front of the camera.
article.article_image_caption: John Harrington uses conversation to determine how a subject should be photographed as well as loosen them up. For this image, he "primed the pump" by telling the EzGov Inc. co-founders how excited he was about the shoot's concept.
article.article_text:
In the course of his career, Washington, DC-based John Harrington has photographed a wide range of subjects, from actors and musicians to business moguls and presidents. However, he’s often tasked with photographing people who are not used to being in front of the camera, which presents its own set of challenges. “People naturally stiffen up, and all of their preconceived opinions about their appearance come to the fore,” Harrington explains. “I try to break through that.”

In order to do this, he talks to his subjects first—without his camera—to find out what they do for a living so he knows how to photograph them. Then he’ll slowly walk them over to where the lights are set up and ease them into the shoot. If he feels they are tensing up at any point, he’ll again put down his camera and engage them some more, asking about their family or a subject matter that will help elicit a reaction or emotion.

Harrington began his career as a photojournalist, and notes that many portraiture assignments require the same kind of on-the-fly problem solving. When they’re not sure what the shooting environment will be like, his team always packs three cases of lighting equipment. The ideal situation, he says, is when the client wants to brainstorm ideas before the shoot.

One of his all-time favorite examples of collaborating with a client was when he photographed Bryan Mundy and Ed Trimble of EzGov Inc. The goal of the image was to “demonstrate how the client’s company helps to get through all of the red tape in Washington so citizens can engage governments,” Harrington explains. A concept that came up in their meeting was wrapping one of the co-founders in red tape—literally—while the other co-founder cuts him free. Harrington adds, “The idea was to do this with the U.S. Capitol building—an easy symbol of the government—in the background.” Harrington made some initial portraits of the two men indoors, all the while talking up the concept for the red tape. By the time they got to the location, he says he had “primed the pump” so the subjects were excited to participate in the shoot.

Many iconic places throughout Washington, DC, have served as backdrops for Harrington’s portraits, helping to communicate ideas as well as provide a setting for the image. Years ago, when he photographed the city’s then Mayor-elect Anthony A. Williams, he wanted the image to take place on the banks of the Potomac River—so much so that he was willing to spend 15 minutes of his hour-long shoot getting Williams to the location. At the time, back in early 1999, Washington, DC, was on the brink of financial ruin. The image of Williams “was about revitalizing the city, and water represents that,” Harrington explains.

These on-location shoots can be difficult to accomplish because many spots in Washington, DC, require photographers have a permit. Yet Harrington notes that when he mentions this to potential clients it often helps him land the gig—mostly, because other photographers bidding on the job failed to mention the need for a permit so he seems more prepared. Once he’s on set, Harrington says, “demonstrating responsible confidence is important” as long as it’s not perceived as arrogance. He adds, “Clients will quickly replace an arrogant photographer with one who’s easy to work with, and can execute a vision through a garnering of respect.”



Harrington's 1999 portrait of then Mayor-elect for Washington, DC, Anthony A. Williams. © John Harrington.

article.article_title: Emily Shur on How Great Portraits Are Made
article.meta_description: The photographer talks about building trust with her subject in order to get the portrait she hopes to capture.
article.meta_keywords: Emily Shur, portraiture, portrait photography
article.article_text_abstract: The photographer talks about building trust with her subject in order to get the portrait she hopes to capture.
article.article_image_caption: "I think a big part of being a portrait photographer is the ability to carve out the opportunity for yourself, to build the trust, to even get the change to take the picture you want to take," says Emily Shur. Her conversation with embattled former cyclist Lance Armstrong about how she wanted to photograph him put the potentially defensive subject at ease.
article.article_text:
It’s rare, says Emily Shur, to speak on the phone with a subject before a shoot. But there she was in her hotel room in Aspen, Colorado, last November, explaining to former professional cyclist Lance Armstrong what she envisioned for their ESPN The Magazine shoot later in the day. The conversation was a delicate one. Armstrong, the vilified one-time king of cycling whose career and reputation were sullied by a doping scandal, was likely to be a wary subject. A misplaced word, Shur thought, and “he wouldn’t have trusted me and would’ve given me, like, ten minutes.”

She says, “I think a big part of being a portrait photographer is the ability to carve out the opportunity for yourself, to build the trust, to even get the chance to take the picture you want to take.” She tried to convey to Armstrong that she wasn’t there to judge or put one over on him. “I really did want him to like the pictures, and I hope he did,” she says.

Shur read the interview with Armstrong that would appear in the magazine, and felt that it was balanced and forthcoming. She told Armstrong that she wanted a “simple, honest picture of just him,” and that she’d like to do something outside, since they were in Aspen. In the interview, Armstrong spoke about the isolation he was feeling in life, in the world of cycling and with his charity, so Shur envisioned an image of “him alone in this vast natural setting.” ESPN The Magazine photo editor Nancy Weisman liked the idea and gave Shur the freedom to do “what I thought was best.” Armstrong was on board.

The vibe during the shoot was relaxed and friendly, Shur says, “but when it came time to take the pictures I was definitely trying to keep in mind everything we talked about, everything I wanted to do.” She felt comfortable directing Armstrong, and as they walked in an area where he goes for runs, he suggested a location near a river that might work. “We came to the river and I saw this rock and this patch of sun, and I asked if he would sit there,” she recalls. “I felt like he understood what the picture looked like,” Shur says. “He understood where I was going with it.” That photo ran in the magazine as a double-page opener, and at the top of the full interview that was published on ESPN.com. Other images of him walking on a trail and crossing a bridge also ran in the magazine, along with a tight shot of Armstrong in his home.

Shur chose not to light the outdoor photos. “Part of doing this is sensing the vibe of the situation,” she says. Because she chose not to set up and test lights with an assistant, she says, it felt like a “walk in the woods.”

The magazine had called Shur the day before Thanksgiving and asked if she would travel over the holiday weekend for the assignment. While she was reluctant, the opportunity to photograph Armstrong at an interesting point in his life for a client she likes proved worth it. “It’s such a perfect example of why I don’t like to turn down work,” Shur says. “You just never know. You could have an experience that reaffirms your faith in photography.”



Another photo from Shur's shoot with Lance Armstrong. © Emily Shur

article.article_title: Nadav Kander on How Great Portraits Are Made
article.meta_description: Collaboration, intuition and authenticity are all important to the London-based photographer's portraiture.
article.meta_keywords: Nadav Kander, portrait photography, portraiture
article.article_text_abstract: Collaboration, intuition and authenticity are all important to the London-based photographer's portraiture.
article.article_image_caption: Nadav Kander collaborated with Michael Shannon on a series of portraits for Port. To set the mood for the shoot, Kander showed the actor some of his other portrait work, and let Shannon choose the music.
article.article_text:
Before he photographed actor Michael Shannon for a cover story in the men’s style magazine Port, photographer Nadav Kander first met with the publication’s co-founder and senior editor, Matt Willey, to discuss the portraits. They spoke about getting a variety of emotions from Shannon, who is often portrayed in a way that reflects the tough or haunted characters he has played in films like Take Shelter and Man of Steel, and the TV series Boardwalk Empire. Kander notes, “He’s always known as this sort of aggressive actor so [we aimed for a range], from aggression to a real softness.” Yet the photographer is quick to add that he never really knows how a shoot is going to go until the subject is on set. He prefers to let things happen intuitively.

To prepare for the Shannon shoot, Kander, who is based in London, studied images of the actor. “Always my homework is in the face more than in the writing about the person,” he says. “I’m not that interested in Wikipedia and column inches about a person. I’m much more into how they look, which often I feel is more accurate to who a person is than what they’ve done in life.”

Looking at photos of his subjects also helps Kander discern the type of lighting to use. On set he tweaks the lights as he goes, often not remembering exactly what he changed. For the Shannon shoot, Kander can only recall that the strobe lighting was “flat because he has a very craggy and arresting face, so I lit him quite open and just let it be.”

What’s fresher in his mind was the atmosphere on set. He and Shannon very much collaborated on the images, with the Method actor losing himself in the work. As is his habit, Kander talked to Shannon before they began but never while he was shooting. Music was an important part of the process: They listened to the indie rock band Pavement and jazz guitarist Grant Green. “Actually the cover picture is [Shannon] snapping his fingers to the music that he had put on and sort of going off in his own head.”

In front of a camera, “Actors are very particular as a genre to photograph because they so understand an entertaining image—they so understand atmosphere, they so understand that there is an otherness to a picture, to a film, to a stage play,” Kander explains. “It’s not just what the words on your lips [are] or the look on your face, but there’s an atmosphere created and that sits apart from you.”

The magazine dedicated eight pages to the article, so the photographer had to make a variety of images that required several wardrobe changes. Kander says he often worries that in fashion shoots, an actor will feel more like a model than a portrait subject. He and Willey both agreed to keep the styling to a minimum, and worked with stylist and Port Fashion Director David St. John-James who, Kander says, “has a very light touch and you feel things are not overly done.”

Kander always strives to make portraits that feel authentic to the subject—whether they represent the person accurately or reflect the mood on set that day. For the Shannon shoot, the goal was to portray the actor in a way that felt real and not too fashion-y while avoiding clichéd representations of him. The photographer notes, “In the months after that shoot I saw so many pictures of him snarling at the camera and looking terrifying, and I was really pleased we didn’t go there.”

article.article_title: Donna DeCesare on Photographing Central America’s Long Cycle of Violence
article.meta_description: The photojournalist has spent her career documenting gangs and urban violence, two legacies of Central America’s civil wars of the 1980s.
article.meta_keywords: Donna DeCesare
article.article_text_abstract: The photojournalist has spent her career documenting gangs and urban violence, two legacies of Central America’s civil wars of the 1980s.
article.article_image_caption: Donna DeCesare won trust and access by building relationships with her subjects over months and years. This teenage couple, photographed in Los Angeles in 1993, keeps binoculars handy to make sure the streets are clear of police or enemy gang members before taking their baby for a walk. Click on the Photo Gallery link below to see more images.
article.article_text:
Donna DeCesare says in her 2013 book, Unsettled/Desasiego, that she moved to El Salvador in late 1987 “to witness and report on war, with all the earnest idealism and naïveté of youth.” Ever since, she has been exploring causes, effects, and possible solutions to a troubling legacy of Central America’s civil wars: gangs and urban violence.

DeCesare still believes in the power of journalism to bring about change by sounding alarms of injustice. But what if things are complicated and intractable, and the story long outlasts the media’s attention span? DeCesare’s response has been to find creative ways to engage directly with audiences that care the most: her subjects, their families and communities, and others trying to help.

She has worked with NGOs trying to help people escape gangs. She teaches workshops and sometimes coaches subjects individually to help them connect with others, gain self-confidence and see alternatives for themselves. She has created a website, www.destinyschildren.org, to tell stories about youth caught up in gang life and their efforts to escape, and to provide resources to others who want to get out.

DeCesare has also worked with academics and public officials to explore the social and psychological causes of gang attachment and violence. Her goal is to combat stereotypes about gang members and help change draconian public policies that have (inadvertently) strengthened gangs. All the while, DeCesare has walked a fine line between journalism and advocacy.

“You have to bring your own critical thinking and perspective to the issue … but I also feel that it’s important to develop human relationships,” she says. “I don’t see that as contradictory. I think you can be detached, but in the sense that spiritual traditions talk about: that you feel empathy and compassion, and that you try do whatever you can without getting overly involved. Our role [as journalists] is to be witnesses. It’s not to be social workers.”

DeCesare’s book traces the arc of her career in three parts, beginning with her coverage of the brutality of the civil wars of El Salvador and Guatemala during the 1980s. Her images show mostly women and children bearing up amidst the chaos and death around them.

“I saw myself as telling the story so people in the United States would care,” she says of the motivation behind her early work. The U.S. was propping up right-wing oligarchies that were terrorizing peasants to maintain a political and economic status quo in the region. Death squads murdered with impunity those suspected of sympathizing with rebels. Boys were kidnapped and forced into the army.

But DeCesare soon realized that things weren’t black and white. Violence begat retaliation, and victims became victimizers. “I started to feel that if we really care about changing things, it’s not just about blaming [people], but it’s also about understanding the human psyche and the human heart and what makes people behave in the way that they do, and how do we get people to change.”

Her encounter before the end of the war in El Salvador (in the early 1990s) with a young man named Franklin Torres led to her coverage of gangs in Los Angeles. Torres’s mother had fled with him to the U.S. city when he was 11. Unschooled in American culture and unable to speak English, he was ostracized and bullied, and ended up joining a gang for comfort and protection. He was eventually deported to El Salvador, after serving time for drug crimes.

“It struck me as ironic that someone who fled war as a refugee to find safe haven became involved in another kind of violence. That’s what I decided I wanted to find out,” DeCesare explains.

Gang culture was entrenched in Los Angeles long before Central American war refugees arrived there. DeCesare found that gangs “filled a void” for marginalized Latin Americans who, like Torres, had limited economic prospects and troubled lives.

As drug trafficking and the proliferation of guns made the gangs more violent, U.S. authorities cracked down by deporting gang members who were originally from Central America. DeCesare followed them with her camera back to El Salvador and Guatemala, where authorities dealt with them brutally.

“Young people … who desperately want a chance to correct the past and build a different life find themselves isolated, vulnerable and invisible,” DeCesare writes in her book. Most deportees had to remain with the gangs for the same reason they had joined in the first place: physical and emotional protection. Attempts to suppress violence, in other words, were just breeding ever more virulent forms of it.

Having built close relationships with many gang members, DeCesare was interested in how to break the cycle of violence in their lives. She asserts that most media coverage about gangs emphasizes the frightening manifestations: tattoos, sinister-looking men and harsh prison life. Those images show truth, but incomplete truth.

“You don’t get a sense that they have families, they have mothers, they have kids. They grew up in situations where they had to make terrible choices at a young age. It’s very complicated,” DeCesare says. In the popular view, “The gang is evil incarnate, and every child with any kind of relationships to it must be tainted and must be [irredeemable], and that’s just wrong,” she says. “People change, and the circumstances that led them [to gang life] can change.”

DeCesare followed a number of subjects, hoping to show how they extricated themselves and found new lives and identities. And she had already decided that she could—and should—do more to help her subjects while she was photographing in a red light district in El Salvador. “I didn’t want to take pictures and then leave,” she says. “I thought the most effective way to [help] was to help them get out of [prostitution] if they wanted to.”

Her opportunity came when an NGO that was offering a literacy program in El Salvador asked DeCesare for help reaching the prostitutes. “I started to realize that I could be a teacher at the same time [as being a journalist],” she says.

She continues, “[Journalism isn’t] just [about] going in aggressively and exposing things. It’s also about developing bonds of concern and compassion, and one’s own behavior can model a way of being in the world that can have an impact on that subject as well.”

DeCesare started teaching her subjects photography, so they could tell their own stories. She also gave her subjects a measure of control over how and when she photographed them, and how she identified them.

“When you’re victimized, one of the things you lose is a sense that you have control over anything. You feel powerless,” she says. “Making it collaborative makes it feel less invasive. It gives [subjects] the sense that they are the protagonist, and that they are directly reaching out to tell their story.”

DeCesare also withheld her images of gang members for several years before publishing them. She explains that she didn’t want her subjects condemned forever by photographs that showed one isolated time in their lives. “I wanted to see how people change over time, the way a documentary filmmaker would.”

She found a few success stories. One of her subjects managed to escape gang life and establish a career as an artist in Europe, for instance. DeCesare says it is essential to tell those stories, but her book ends with a palpable sense of disappointment.

“Too many of the youths I met while making this book are now memorialized by RIP tattoos,” she writes in the epilogue. On her most recent trip to Central America, in 2011, she found a pervasive climate of fear and danger for everyone, “especially for those who have left gangs.”

And yet, she says in our interview, “I remain hopeful.” A tenuous truce between rival gangs has held, just barely. Officials in the region—and at influential international organizations such as the World Bank—now see Central America’s gang problem as a public health issue, not just a criminal justice issue. That has opened up the possibility of promising new political approaches to dealing with gangs.

“Things are terrible, but I think we’re sort of at a turning point where things could get better,” DeCesare says. “But it will take the effort of all concerned, working hard on many fronts.”

article.article_title: Jeffery Salter on How Great Portraits Are Made
article.meta_description: The photographer talks about the importance of engaging his subjects, and showing enthusiasm on set.
article.article_text_abstract: The photographer talks about the importance of engaging his subjects, and showing enthusiasm on set.
article.article_image_caption: Jeffery Salter says that he likes to talk quietly to subjects to explain what the photo is about. Before photographing basketball player Dwyane Wade and his sons for the cover of Ebony, published after George Zimmerman was acquitted of the murder of Trayvon Martin,  Salter told the two boys, “You’re here for the young man who can’t be here.”
article.article_text:
Trained as a photojournalist, Jeffery Salter doesn’t give his portrait subjects much direction. Instead, he views a portrait as a collaboration, and believes his role as the photographer is to engage his subjects. “I like to set the stage and wait for things to happen.”

He continues, “You can set the tone by being low key or high key, but the most important thing is to have enthusiasm. I think when people see you have focus and enthusiasm on the set, they respond accordingly. ‘He’s here, he’s interested. I’m going to respond accordingly.’”

For the September 2013 cover of Ebony, Salter was assigned to photograph Dwyane Wade, a shooting and point guard with the Miami Heat, and his two sons. The headline on the cover read “We Are Trayvon,” and it was published after a jury found George Zimmerman not guilty of the February 2012 murder of Trayvon Martin, an unarmed 17-year-old African-American man.

On set with Salter, Wade and his two sons each wore a gray hooded sweatshirt, which Martin was wearing the night he was killed. Salter says he wanted the portrait “to go beyond the symbol and make a more human connection” between the viewers and the boys he was photographing. “It was important the image be more than a simple, flat, two-dimensional document. It needed to convey the gravity of the situation.”

To engage Wade’s sons, Salter gave them access to Pandora and let them choose the music when they arrived. “That set the scene that they could just be themselves,” Salter says.

Salter, whose clients include Inc., O, The Oprah Magazine, Sports Illustrated and The New York Times, says that whenever he photographs subjects who aren’t used to being in front of the camera, he explains what he wants the photo to say. “I tell them, ‘I’m going to be here for a little while in your life and a lot of people are going to see the picture. I want you to relax and think about why you’re here.’”

When Wade and his sons were in front of the camera, he told them, “‘You’re here for the young man who can’t be here.’ When I said that, I didn’t shout it. I walked up and I whispered it.”

After that, Salter simply watched for cues. “I have to find the moment and just say, ‘Do that again,’ or ‘Hold that.’”

Before these moments of quiet observation, however, Salter spends hours on location scouting and setup. When shooting in an office or other location, Salter usually alerts the PR people that he’ll be arriving about four hours early to look around. His goal is to find a location that helps him deliver a storytelling portrait.

He adds, “I’m not afraid to change a location if I see something while walking the subject to the set. I ask questions, such as ‘Where do you go to relax?’ or ‘Did you drive your Harley to the office today?’”
Once he’s set up for the shoot and has the subject in front of the camera, he turns his attention to communicating his ideas for the photo.

“I show them where I’m going,” he says. “I don’t hide anything.”

article.article_title: Mira Mexico: Louie Palu's Conceptual Project About the War on Drugs
article.meta_description: The veteran conflict photojournalist's self-published newspaper takes a hard look at Mexico’s drug war—and how the media covers it.
article.meta_keywords: Louie Palu, Mira Mexico, War on Drugs, Mexico's Drug War
article.article_text_abstract: The veteran conflict photojournalist's self-published newspaper takes a hard look at Mexico’s drug war—and how the media covers it.
article.article_image_caption: Luis Avila Archulata, 40, is a former gang member who spent his whole life in Arizona. Archulata was jailed multiple times in the U.S. and finally deported to Mexico, where he now lives. He was recruited into gangs and first exposed to drugs in the U.S. Click on the Photo Gallery link below to see more images.
article.article_text:
Photographer Louie Palu’s Mira Mexico, a 15 x 12-inch “conceptual newspaper” on the Mexican Drug War, forces its audience not only to confront the grisly violence of the conflict, but also to wrestle with ideas of censorship and modes of representation. “Something I like doing is blurring the lines between journalism and art,” Palu says of the project, a departure from his years of work as a photojournalist covering conflict for major media organizations. “At this stage of my career I’m not afraid to challenge myself. I’m not afraid to look in the mirror and face my own criticism.”

The son of Italian immigrants living in Toronto, Palu grew up in a neighborhood where the power of the criminal underworld was an open secret. Organized crime was a subject that he had long wanted to explore photographically, but thought doing it in his own neighborhood would get him “knocked off, probably,” he says. After five years working on and off in Afghanistan, Palu was looking for his next move. He applied for and won a fellowship from the New American Foundation, a Washington DC-based think tank. That grant enabled Palu to take the first of what would become several trips to Mexico over a two-year span.

“I started doing some research. I looked at how people were covering the [Mexican Drug War] and then I just [went] down [to Mexico] and started covering violence,” Palu explains. “But [my work] became something more than just understanding the violence. It was about understanding how the violence happened and what were the mitigating factors that let that violence happen.”

He worked along the U.S.-Mexico border, wading through the bottomless depravity of America’s often forgotten drug war, eventually securing funding from the Pulitzer Center on Crisis Reporting. The years Palu spent covering the Afghan war proved invaluable as he soon saw the many parallels between the conflict he had just left, a world away in Central Asia, and this one, right on North America’s doorstep. The pervasive corruption, the absence of social infrastructure, the erosion of the rule of law, the prisoners, the refugees, the dead bodies—all these things dominated the day in Mexico, but to his mind, the true scale of this conflict was going unseen in the West, particularly in the United States and Canada.

Palu believes the bloodbath raging in Mexico is far more relevant to the interests of the United States than the conflicts in Syria or Afghanistan. “What’s going on in Mexico is much bigger than what people really understand,” Palu insists. “There are sections of Mexico that are not in the control of the government, and I’m not talking a corner—I’m talking about large swaths of territory.”

To Palu’s eyes, Western media was largely ignoring the reign of terror in Mexico while conflicts in the Middle East dominated front-page news. That observation led him to think about how to approach the realities of the war and media coverage conceptually. “With this work, what came to mind most was how the war was being documented, talked about and represented with pictures in the media,” Palu says. “It became a project about questioning what we see, what we don’t see and who are the gatekeepers that control this.”

Creating visibility was at the forefront of Palu’s mind when, eschewing a more traditional approach, he partnered with three different media entities to release his work in January 2013. Canada’s The Globe and Mail; Foreign Policy in the United States; and Mexico’s online news magazine Animal Politico all simultaneously published individually tailored photos and writing from Palu in their respective corners of NAFTA. For Palu, the idea was to maximize the discussion, to put Mexico’s trauma in front of as many eyes as he could and keep it there.

The broadsheet Mira Mexico project, produced in collaboration with the New America Foundation, was another way of expanding that dialogue. Most conflict photographers have experiences of their work being cropped or edited in a way they don’t agree with, or used in a context other than they intended. By printing and publishing Mira Mexico himself, Palu decided what would be included. The newspaper has been distributed at university events, museums and galleries, and limited quantities will be available online through the photo bookstore photo-eye.

On one side of the paper are unflinching images from the drug war’s blood-soaked trenches: bodies lying in the short grass, wrists bound, pockets pulled out like rabbit’s ears. A needle dangles from a junkie’s hand as he bends to his task next to the Tijuana River. The rubber-gloved hands of U.S. Border Patrol agents stacking bricks of seized contraband in Laredo, Texas. But turn the paper another way and that story disappears, replaced by images of “another Mexico,” where orderly new factories churn out exportable goods in a Free Trade Zone. Children play in the waters of the Rio Grande, laborers carry their harvested produce to market and a mayor-elect beams at her ecstatic supporters celebrating a victory at the polls.

While Palu’s newspaper allows readers to decide which side of Mexico they view and encourages them to think about the selection of images, Mira Mexico shows there is little distance between everyday life in Mexico and the pestilence of drugs and death. The Mexico of the hard-working peasant, the hopeful migrant, the youth at play in the slum is the same Mexico occupied by stone-faced gangsters, the sick and destitute, and the corpses of the condemned, given over to rigor mortis and left twisting in the sun. The maladies of poverty, corruption and inequality hover behind it all, the drug war the most prominent symptom. In one photograph a man with a U.S. passport waits to cross the border into the United States with his bicycle. In the background of this would-be innocuous example of open borders and cultural exchange—somewhat out of focus—a drug dog stands, tongue lolling. There is just one Mexico. Either you choose to see it all, or you don’t.

article.article_title: What's Your Niche: Funeral Photography
article.meta_description: Mark Thackeray, who mostly shoots weddings and commercial work, talks about marketing himself as a funeral photographer.
article.meta_keywords: Mark Thackeray, funeral photography
article.article_text_abstract: Mark Thackeray, who mostly shoots weddings and commercial work, talks about marketing himself as a funeral photographer.
article.article_image_caption: Supported by her surviving grandmother, a girl attends the viewing of her deceased grandmother, January 2013.
article.article_text:
Salt Lake City photographer Mark Thackeray shoots mostly weddings and commercial assignments. But a little more than three years ago, after documenting his grandparents’ funerals at his mother’s request, he started marketing himself as a funeral photographer, too.  

PDN: What’s appealing to you about funeral photography?
Mark Thackeray: I like how new it is. It’s in its infancy stage. I also like it because there’s a huge range of emotions. I love capturing that, and the interactions between people. That’s why I’m drawn more to this than commercial work: This is so real and so personal.

PDN: How many funerals have you documented?
MT: Twenty-five or so.

PDN: How do you market yourself?
MT: Primarily by word of mouth, and I contact people I’ve worked with in the past to generate more referrals. I’ve also approached some funeral homes to get them to include my services in some of their package options.

It’s a new market, and a lot of people haven’t thought of it before. I use albums and DVDs to show people what it’s going to be like, and I explain that a funeral is an opportunity to relive old memories, and create more memories. It takes a series of meetings before the event, where I’ll outline my approach, and make sure everyone is on board.

PDN: What is your approach?
MT: I have a journalistic approach. I like to capture things as they unfold.

PDN: What concerns do potential clients have?
MT: The [idea] of someone being right up in their face while they’re viewing their loved one in the casket scares people. But once you show them, and they understand the reality, people start to open up.

PDN: Walk us through a typical job. What’s the procedure?
MT: Doing your homework is the biggest thing, and that involves communicating clearly with the family. Make sure you understand what they want. Some people don’t want to be in the pictures, they just want all the detail shots, and the displays.

I make sure I have the schedule dialed in. I’ll show up at the viewing 20 or 30 minutes early to suss out the lighting conditions, and figure out what I’m going to do. I get shots of all the details of the displays—the cards and flowers—before people arrive. Once people arrive [I get] the interaction between the people and those displays. That’s also a great time for any family photos that you’ve arranged prior to the event.

Then I’ll spend an hour or two capturing the candids, and the faces of the people coming in. That’s another thing I’ll try to discuss with the client before I come to the event: I’ll tell a family to please let everyone know I’m going to be there taking pictures. And if there are people they want me to photograph besides the family members, I’ll ask one or two family members to point those people out to me.

The next day, at the service, I’ll [again] take pictures before everyone arrives. Then I’ll make sure I get pictures of the pallbearers and the hearse. I like to get pictures of them bringing the casket in, and bringing it to the graveside. And I just follow the event as it goes—the talks and tributes that different people give. I’ll ask the family during the event if there’s anything we hadn’t thought of beforehand. I like to let them know that within reason, I’ll do whatever they want.

PDN: What are some dos and dont’s?
MT: The dos include longer lenses to maintain distance, stay in the background as much as possible so I don’t have any influence on what people are doing. In terms of interacting, it’s a conservative approach. I don’t instigate many conversations with people.

PDN: Can you give us a sense of where, how far back you are, compared to a wedding job?
MT: I’d say I’m almost twice as far back as I would be at a wedding. I’ll never be closer to the casket than anyone else. And I’ll try to camouflage myself behind a display of flowers.

PDN: What’s the rule about taking photographs of people who are openly grieving?
MT: A lot of people are afraid of that. I like to tell them beforehand there probably will be pictures of them where they look vulnerable. A lot of people see the value in [those pictures]: That was a trying time, and I’m glad that image shows what I was going through. But some people don’t feel comfortable with it, or with having other people see it.

PDN: What about taking pictures of the deceased? Any rules about that?
MT: That’s a big one. I specifically ask them before the event: How comfortable do you feel about pictures of your loved ones in the casket? I’ll show them some examples, and say it’s a personal choice.

PDN: What gear do you use?
MT: I shoot primarily with a Canon EOS 5D Mark II body and I only shoot with prime lenses so if I want to frame something differently, I have to move. That keeps me on my feet. Also, they’re faster lenses. I have a 24mm, a 50mm, an 85mm and a 135mm lens.

In terms of light, I don’t like to bring much except my 580EX II Speedlite. I usually keep it on camera. I don’t want to be a distraction, and I want to keep it as simple as possible.

PDN: What do you deliver to the client?
MT: Most of the options I offer include an album. I put photos into an online gallery so my clients can share them with family and friends, and pick out pictures for albums. It takes seven to ten days to design an album draft.

PDN: How do you charge clients?
MT: The hours of coverage are the biggest component. Albums are a big part, too, and then digital rights [so clients can] make prints on their own.

PDN: What is your fee?
MT: It depends on the number of hours they opt for, but it’s usually $300 to $500 per hour.

PDN: What advice would you give a photographer who approached you about getting into this niche?
MT: Be conservative in your approach. Realize the importance of the situation, and how vulnerable people are. If you can acknowledge those things and empathize, people will be open to the idea of your being there, and capturing it.

It’s such a new thing, and people still aren’t sure about it quite yet. There’s definitely a lot of selling that needs to go on beforehand to get people on board.

See more of Thackeray’s memorial service photography at http://everlongtribute.com/.
