As a self-described visual anthropologist, Laurel Golio is enthralled by how people identify and present themselves, how they navigate the world and how they fit into various subcultures. Emiliano Granado has seen over the past four years of working together that Golio is a “real human” who has “been making significant work. Instead of trying to make work that will get her jobs, she’s been working on a project that changes young people’s lives,” he says. Golio began her “We Are the Youth” project to raise the visibility of queer youth in America. “She’s one of the best people I know,” Granado says.

Like many successful people, Gage Thompson didn’t wait for work to come to him—he sought it out. Along with taking his own photos of the skateboarding culture in Utah, he’s also a trusted first assistant. When he approached Mike Tittel, a lifestyle and sports photographer, about working as his assistant, Thompson sent him not only a resume, but also a time when he would call to follow-up. Tittel was so impressed by Thompson’s professionalism that he hired him. On a recent shoot with Tittel, Thompson took it upon himself to learn a lot of unfamiliar equipment so that he would be ready for every shot. But Thompson is not all work. “We have a lot of fun on set,” Tittel says. “He has a great sense of humor.”

Michael Clarke, who has about ten years of experience in the photo industry, started working as first assistant for Damian Strohmeyer back in 2008 while also working with staff photographers at Sports Illustrated. Sahara Coleman’s love for photography was ignited as a child, and in high school she began experimenting with such alternative processing techniques as lith printing, and Sabattier and solarizing effects. Today, she’s shooting weddings, portraits and working with The House Studios as a freelance production assistant. Coleman hopes to eventually art direct in the commercial world, but she still likes returning to the older ways of taking photos. “Once in a while I take out my Hasselblad 501c and shoot some 120,” Coleman says. “It’s good for the soul.”

article.article_title: PDN's All-Star Assistants: Don Razniewski
article.meta_description: This New York City-based photo assistant is one the 2014 PDN’s All-Star Assistants.
article.meta_keywords: new York City photo assistant
article.article_text_abstract: This New York City-based photo assistant is one the 2014 PDN’s All-Star Assistants.
article.article_text:
Type of Assistant: Digital Tech, First Assistant, Full-Time/Studio Assistant & Video Assistant  

Location: New York City

Best Skills: Administration/studio management; color calibration and color profiling; daylight shooting; digital capture and software; light metering; managing other assistants; photo archiving/image editing/image delivery; post-production software/retouching; still cameras: 35mm, digital backs, large format and medium format; still lighting: continuous/tungsten/HMI/Lowel/Kino Flo and strobes/flash systems; video editing; video lighting; website design and management

Has Assisted: Jorg Badura

“Honestly, I am not sure my words will do justice to my first assistant, Don Razniewski,” says adventure photographer Jorg Badura. Razniewski, who’s been working with Badura over the past six years, is particularly praised for his ability to roll with the punches. Badura recalls that on a recent shoot, when they needed to familiarize themselves with new cameras overnight, Razniewski was perfectly proficient with them by the next morning. Having saved the day many times, he gets the job done under any condition, “even with a broken toe,” Badura says. “And did I mention that he isn’t afraid of heights and he doesn’t get seasick?”

article.article_title: Photo Innovation: Canon's Dual Pixel CMOS AF Offers Quick Live View and Video Autofocus
article.meta_description: Canon introduces an autofocus system that utilizes two separate photo diodes for each pixel.
article.meta_keywords: Canon EOS 70D, Canon Dual Pixel CMOS AF, camera autofocus
article.article_text_abstract: Canon introduces an autofocus system that utilizes two separate photo diodes for each pixel.
article.article_image_caption: The Canon EOS 70D, which uses the company's new Dual Pixel CMOS AF system.
article.article_text:
Canon’s new Dual Pixel CMOS AF system may be one of the biggest advancements in digital-camera technology we’ve seen in quite a while. Introduced in 2013 with the launch of the Canon EOS 70D digital SLR, this innovative autofocus process—which utilizes a unique approach to implement phase-detection AF—is a major development for solving autofocus issues that arise when a dedicated phase-detection sensor is unavailable and the camera is forced to use the slower contrast-detection AF. This occurs in a DSLR’s live view and movie capture mode, when the mirror must be flipped up.

At the same time, Dual Pixel CMOS AF has strong implications for further improvements in mirrorless cameras, which, like live view and movie capture, depend on sensor-based contrast-detection AF. Canon’s Dual Pixel CMOS AF can also be effective when a hybrid autofocus system is used, where a camera dedicates only a limited number of pixels to phase-detection AF to be used in combination with contrast-detection AF.

While hybrid systems have improved autofocus speed, this approach is still lacking, with lenses hunting or pulling in and out of focus before locking on a subject. This occurs because cameras still depend largely on contrast-detection AF. As the name “contrast-detection AF” implies, a certain amount of contrast between adjacent pixels is needed before focus can be achieved, which is particularly difficult in low light.

With its Dual Pixel CMOS AF, Canon takes a unique approach by creating two separate photo diodes for each pixel, covering about 80 percent of the sensor vertically and horizontally. Hiroshi Miyanari, a Canon staff engineer and one of the technology’s developers, explained in a white paper that each set of photo diodes perform both phase difference AF and imaging functions by capturing two parallax images at the same time: “With Dual Pixel CMOS AF, signals from these two images are used to carry out phase-difference detection AF.” In addition, he noted that, “by combining two photo diodes, the image signal can be output as one pixel,” with no negative effect on image quality. Because the two processes are combined, he pointed out, Canon was able to expand the dual functionality to “all pixels” (albeit with 80 percent coverage).

Thanks to its broad coverage of phase detection across the sensor, Dual Pixel CMOS AF is designed to bring faster and more accurate autofocus to DSLRs in live view and smoother autofocus tracking when shooting video. Additionally, the technology promises better performance in low light, since the autofocus is not dependent on the amount of contrast available in a scene. Read our review of the Canon EOS 70D at www.pdnonline.com/cameras.

article.article_title: Photo Innovation: 3-D Printing to Build Your Own Photo Gadgets
article.meta_description: Now it's easier than ever to turn an idea for a camera accessory into an actual product, thanks to 3-D printing.
article.meta_keywords: 3-D printing, photo gadgets, Pinhole camera
article.article_text_abstract: Now it's easier than ever to turn an idea for a camera accessory into an actual product, thanks to 3-D printing.
article.article_image_caption: Pinhole, a 3-D printed pinhole camera by Clint O'Connor, is one example of the photo accessories and gear that have been created using 3-D printing technology.
article.article_text:
Imagine that one morning, while enjoying your daily latte, you come up with an absolutely brilliant idea for a new camera accessory. So, how do you go from concept to reality? In the past, you would have had to work with a machine shop to create a prototype, then talk to manufacturers about having an injection mold made for your first production run.

What if instead you could sit down at your computer for a few hours of design work, and have the prototype in your hands the very same day? That is the promise of what is known as 3-D printing. With a machine about the size of a 1990s-era laser printer, you can use your computer and basic 3-D modeling software to “print” out items in the same way that you would use a word processing program and a printer to create your neighborhood newsletter. Sounds too good to be true, right? But this technology has already been used to make camera mounts and even a camera.

The process of 3-D printing goes something like this: The printer takes a material, often ABS plastic filament, and melts it. Then, a tiny movable nozzle squirts out the melted plastic as though it were ink from an inkjet printer. Instead of just laying down a single layer of ink, however, the 3-D printer retraces its steps, laying down layer after layer of material on a platform, building items up one very thin layer at a time. For almost three decades, automobile and airplane manufacturers have used 3-D printing technology for prototyping parts and designs. The printers they used were giant industrial machines with a price tag of around a million dollars. While the use of these machines is still growing across a wide range of industries, the real explosion in 3-D printing has been in small-scale production and manufacturing.

For around $1,300 you can get a build-it-yourself kit online to make your own 3-D printer or spend $2,200 on a turnkey unit such as the Replicator 2 from MakerBot.com. In the past you would have had to purchase 3-D CAD (computer-aided design) software, such as AutoCAD or SolidWorks, before you could make use of your new printer. These programs are both quite expensive and rather complicated to use. With the advent of free 3-D software such as Google SketchUp, however, the cost and the learning curve have been greatly reduced.

While it is still a young technology with worlds of evolution ahead of it, 3-D printing has already started to work its way into the photography industry. Sites like Thingiverse.com provide files you can print to produce everything from basic lens adapters and GoPro mounts, to more complicated creations like a rail system for a digital SLR film rig with motorized focus-zoom ring control. Some exciting and innovative projects have been produced with 3-D printing technology as well. A French student recently designed and printed an entire film SLR camera, the OpenReflex. A pinhole camera dubbed the Flyer is another piece of photographic equipment created with 3-D printer technology. The Flyer began as a Kickstarter project, and it was so popular that it reached its goal of $1,200 in ten hours, going on to raise an additional $12,000.

The bottom line is this: 3-D printing is changing the ways in which inventors are able to design, prototype, manufacture and ultimately sell their products. It has also greatly leveled the playing field, allowing smaller companies to more effectively compete in the marketplace. So, the idea that the next great photographic accessory could come from your morning coffee daydream session may not be quite as far-fetched as it seems.

article.article_title: A Photo Book That Mixes Poetry and Vintage Street Photography
article.meta_description: For her compelling new book, Elisabeth Tonnard combined images from a historic photo archive with various translations of the opening lines of Dante’s The Inferno.
article.meta_keywords: Elisabeth Tonnard, In This Dark Wood, Dante, The Inferno, vintage street photography
article.article_text_abstract: For her compelling new book, Elisabeth Tonnard combined images from a historic photo archive with various translations of the opening lines of Dante’s The Inferno.
article.article_image_caption: In her book, Elisabeth Tonnard paired each of the photographs with one of 90 different translations of the opening lines of Dante’s The Inferno. The translation that accompanies the image on the opposite page reads: “Halfway on the path our life is/I found I was in a dark woods;/For I had lost my direction.” The translation that accompanies the above image reads: “About the middle of life’s onward way,/I found myself within a darksome dell,/Because from the true path I went astray.” Tonnard says she feels as if “each person [in the images] is saying those lines and saying something about their situation in life, and it sounds very unique. But because they are all saying the same thing, it’s not very unique at all.”
article.article_text:
Elisabeth Tonnard describes her book In This Dark Wood as a “modern gothic.” In it, 90 different black-and-white portraits are paired with 90 different English translations of the opening lines of Dante’s The Inferno. “Midway along the journey of our life/I woke to find myself in a dark wood,/for I had wandered off from the straight path,” reads one of the translations, by Mark Musa.

Part of the macabre beauty of In This Dark Wood lies in subtleties like the items clutched and ferried by these would-be lost souls. Crumpled paper bags and hastily wrapped packages abound, as if they are refugees sent into this gray limbo, bearing their last effects in hand. Or the words on an oft-glimpsed movie marquee that swims in the gloomy background of many images. Soon, you begin to notice the words suspended in the air—petrified, terror, hell, doomed—only amplify the dread that builds alongside each translation of Dante’s foreboding introduction. All the while, though we know their way is lost, the subjects set forth grimly, one after the other, alone.

Tonnard sourced all of the images from the Fox Movie Flash collection, a massive archive of mid-twentieth century street photography. Held by the Visual Studies Workshop, a nonprofit photographic arts center in Rochester, New York, the archive consists of millions of negatives donated to the institution by Joseph N. Selle. Selle owned the long-defunct Fox Movie Flash, a company that employed teams of street photographers who prowled downtown San Francisco from the 1940s to the 1960s. Selle and his team made snapshots of tourists and pedestrians in the hopes of selling them the portraits. A high-volume business model meant that they took far more pictures than they ever sold, leaving a vast archive of images that had never been printed or seen.

In This Dark Wood is not, technically, a new book. A prolific self-publisher, Tonnard released the first edition in 2008 and continued printing copies in small batches over the intervening years. In 2012, she and J&L Books publisher Jason Fulford reached an agreement to print a trade edition. Fulford first met Tonnard and saw the self-published edition in 2010, when he was lecturing at the Visual Studies Workshop in Rochester. “The book really surprised me—such a simple concept and understated presentation, but with a result that is very moving and emotional,” Fulford says in an e-mail to PDN.

Working with a publisher has been a new experience for Tonnard, who has more than 30 self-published works. She acknowledges feeling as though she has surrendered some ownership of the work, but the prospect of wider distribution excites her.

“I felt like I have reached the audience I can reach with my publications, they have seen this book, they know about it. So this is a good thing. I’ll close the open edition that I had and give somebody else the chance to bring it to a larger audience,” Tonnard explains.

Tonnard first encountered Selle’s treasure trove during her time in Rochester as an MFA student in 2006. Combing through what was merely a fraction of the negatives, Tonnard lit upon ideas for two different artist’s books. The first became 2007’s Two of Us, a meditation on “the double,” making liberal use of photographs from the archive and a Baudelaire poem. The second idea became In This Dark Wood.

“In that collection of 18,000 scanned images I had, there was one roll of about 1,500 images which was shot completely at night. There was a contrast in that roll, there were more people walking alone than in the daytime rolls. I also noticed that the people looked as if they were in another place; lost in thought, alienated from their surroundings,” Tonnard says. “There were all sorts of people in that book [of images], but they all share this expression on their face.”

Tonnard can no longer remember exactly how she began to associate these images with The Inferno, but recalls having “a very beautiful, very old” copy of the poem in her studio at the time. Her experience working on this book seems to mirror the experience of reading it: she found herself surprised by the synergy the text and photographs developed as the work progressed.

“It’s as if each person [in the images] is saying those lines and saying something about their situation in life, and it sounds very unique. But because they are all saying the same thing, it’s not very unique at all,” Tonnard muses.

The conceit seems simple on its face, but each perusal of In This Dark Wood reveals another layer of meaning. The candid night photography is imbued with new pathos from Dante’s poetry, with each solitary pedestrian pressed into service in an epic tragedy. The result is a remarkably malleable work that is both repetitive and ever-changing.

article.article_title: Photo Innovation: The Lumenator Is a Continuous LED Light and Flash Diffuser in One
article.meta_description: This device lets you use an LED light and flash at the same time, which can help when shooting stills and video.
article.meta_keywords: Lumenator, LED light, flash diffuser
article.article_text_abstract: This device lets you use an LED light and flash at the same time, which can help when shooting stills and video.
article.article_image_caption: With more photographers switching between lighting systems as they shoot both video and stills, Drew Strickland created the Lumenator as a way to let photographers use their electronic flash and an LED light at the same time.
article.article_text:
Videography requires a continuous lighting source rather than the strobes used for still photography. LED (light-emitting diode) lighting has become increasingly popular for video work in recent years due to the advent of affordable high-output LEDs. They are significantly more efficient than their halogen and incandescent forerunners, and give users a longer run time for a given battery size. In addition, LEDs offer a multitude of output colors, meaning that true daylight-balanced fill lighting is easily possible without any filtering. Because of these advantages, LEDs from companies like Litepanels and Fotodiox have become commonplace on everything from a wedding photographer’s digital SLR to a broadcast TV on-location rig.

There are, however, drawbacks to using continuous LED lighting for still images. Not the least of them is that it takes a giant LED light panel to equal the lumens output produced by even a very small Speedlight. This leaves many working pros with no choice but to switch back and forth between two lighting systems, both fighting for the single hotshoe on their DSLR. Drew Strickland, founder of ColorRight and inventor of the popular FlashRight diffusers, says he wondered to himself: “Why isn’t there one small, simple unit that lets you use your electronic flash with an LED at the same time?”

Strickland set out to develop one. His newest product, the Lumenator, is a combination flash bounce diffuser and LED light panel. It can attach to any Speedlight flash with Velcro. It is just slightly over half of an inch thick and weighs in at just over one pound, including its battery pack. It uses a patent pending technology that ColorRight is calling LEDNatural, which was designed to provide very diffused light with minimal power loss. The Lumenator can be used as a standard, if slightly bulky, bounce diffuser for electronic flash, but it also offers the ability to light stills or videos with daylight-balanced LED light. The Lumenator has an output of over 3,000 lumens, which is approximately equivalent to the output of a 300-watt bulb. Power options include both a 2,800 mAh battery pack and an AC adapter for studio work.

Having designed and released a number of ColorRight products, Strickland is well versed in the traditional product development and production process. But for the Lumenator, he chose to go in a different direction and use indiegogo, a crowd-funding website. “Crowd funding has been a really cool experience for us because it provides instant feedback on our product offering,” he says. “Thanks to a lot of new technologies, like 3-D printing, we have been able to make improvements and refinements to products on the fly, before we commit to the final design. The participatory element of crowd funding cannot be overlooked. I think involving your customers in designing, and in financing, your dream of a product produces much better results for everyone involved.”

ColorRight has taken advantage of an innovative idea (a lighting option for both photos and video), using a new technology (high output LEDs and new diffusion) and used production methods that were not available even a mere five years ago (3-D printing and crowd funding). Says Strickland, “There seems to be a sense of ownership that takes place when you go the crowd-funding route. I think we owe a lot of our success with the Lumenator campaign to this feeling of ownership and participation.”

article.article_title: How National Geographic Creative Pitches Its Photographers for Ad Jobs
article.meta_description: The agency is doing more than just licensing stock images; it’s also creating ads and pitching the unique expertise of the photographers it represents to commercial clients.
article.meta_keywords: National Geographic Creative, professional photography
article.article_text_abstract: The agency is doing more than just licensing stock images; it’s also creating ads and pitching the unique expertise of the photographers it represents to commercial clients.
article.article_image_caption: Michael S. Yamashita shot this image in Bangkok for an HSBC Bank campaign that National Geographic Creative produced. Click on the Photo Gallery link below to see more images.
article.article_text:
National Geographic is beloved by photographers because it supports long-form storytelling, often dedicating multiple pages to the photo essays that run in every issue. But the organization is doing more for photographers than just hiring them to produce images for the monthly magazine. National Geographic Creative, an agency that operates separately from the publication, is pitching the unique skills and expertise of many National Geographic photographers to help them land assignments in the commercial world.

National Geographic Creative has had many iterations over the years. At one time it was simply a photo archive where third parties could license National Geographic imagery. It has since grown to include an agency that represents nearly 60 percent of the photographers who shoot for the various National Geographic publications, and a creative studio that creates custom advertising for National Geographic as well as other brands, including Disney, HSBC Bank, Nokia and Volkswagen.

When pitching its photographers for commercial assignments, National Geographic Creative tries to present “a 360-view of who these photographers are and what they can bring to the table for clients,” explains Alice Keating, vice president of sales and marketing at Nat Geo Creative. Keating and her team see their photographers as more than just people who shoot photos—they are also experts, spokespeople and more.

When commercial clients hire a National Geographic photographer, “we know that [they] expect more than just great pictures,” explains National Geographic Society Senior Vice President Maura Mulvihill. “They expect problem solving, expertise, and an ability to handle all different kinds of personalities and situations.”

An obvious expertise that Nat Geo Creative photographers bring to any assignment is a depth of knowledge about locations around the world. The agency benefits from having a network of over 70 photographers who not only share information about off-the-radar places but also have valuable contacts on the ground, including fixers who can help facilitate a shoot. A recent campaign for HSBC Bank required photos from little-known spots in 27 different locations. The images were captured for the campaign by a team of Nat Geo Creative shooters, including Jodi Cobb, Annie Griffiths and Joel Sartore, and used for print ads, online ads, out-of-home displays, on-site promotions and more. JWT New York, HSBC Bank’s ad agency, turned to Nat Geo Creative not only to hire talent but also to produce the campaign.

Another skill that Nat Geo Creative can pitch is the technical know-how its photographers have gained from decades of experience shooting for the magazine. Disney originally reached out to Nat Geo Creative because it needed photographers in specific locations to shoot panoramic views to use as decor on its cruise ships. Three Nat Geo Creative photographers shot the assignment, including Stephen Alvarez. Disney reached out to Nat Geo Creative again when it needed iconic, panoramic images of seven major cities across the globe to display on the 72-inch screens that encircle the lounge on its new Disney Fantasy cruise ship. The images needed to be shot in a particular way so they could later be animated by a CGI (computer-generated imagery) team. Disney was so pleased with the shots of Paris that Alvarez made for the initial assignment, that it hired him to shoot all seven cities.

“They were really very technically specific images because things had to stitch into the [screens] the right way,” explains Alvarez. After discussing both the logistics and technical requirements with Disney and its CGI team, Alvarez shot the entire seven-week assignment.

Alvarez says his experience scouting locations and making travel images helped him on the Disney job. “What I think [Disney] enjoyed was that I was ‘fire and forget,’ because they could give me the criteria and then send me out and not have to worry about it because I know how to get on rooftops in cities, I’ve been doing it my entire career,” he says about the assignment.  

Alvarez has been shooting for National Geographic magazine since 1995. He has done a few commercial assignments over the years, but never big, international campaigns until Nat Geo Creative started pitching him for jobs. While the Disney Cruise Line work may seem like a natural fit given his past experience shooting caves, cultures and cityscapes for National Geographic, his partnership with Nokia is a little less on the nose.

Initially, the company wanted Alvarez to shoot the American Southwest using the Nokia Lumia 1020 smartphone for a gatefold ad that would appear in the October issue of National Geographic. But the assignment evolved to include him being the subject of a video about the campaign, which was shot by fellow Nat Geo Creative photographer John Burcham.

Because Alvarez is interested in technology and has been shooting with cell-phone cameras for years, he also became a Nokia digital imaging brand ambassador (for example, he just returned from speaking at a launch event for the phone in Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates). Alvarez explains, “Those things are based all around my ability to not only make photographs but then to talk about the things I’m using and why they’re important,” He adds, “I’m actually really excited about these phones because they do astound me.”

Nat Geo Creative has been able to successfully translate many of its photographers’ passions into paying gigs. For example, when The Richards Group came up with a campaign for its client AVG that involved a tiger, it contacted Nat Geo Creative. “They wanted an authority on tigers and how to deal with tigers, and someone who was familiar with working with them and also able to direct the shoot,” Keating explains. “So they hired Steve Winter. He was the perfect candidate for this job: he was a tiger expert, he was an authority in the field and respected in the field, and knew how to work with the animals in a way that was respectful to them.” The resulting online video, which involved an actor being protected from a real tiger by a cage built with toothpicks, has gotten over four million views.

Keating says of the talent Nat Geo Creative represents, “These photographers have been here for a very long time and they are skilled in what they’re doing. They’ve cultivated an entire career very organically and are experts in certain areas.” This expertise goes beyond just shooting stills and videos about a subject matter and includes being able to speak and/or write about it so they can “demonstrate” their expertise. “It’s a way for them to build their brand around their expertise,” Keating adds.

The agency has spread the word about the photographic, marketing and custom advertising services it offers in a number of different ways. They’ve done promotional and social media campaigns, but Keating says, “It’s also a lot about personal relationships so we’re pounding the pavement, and we’re reaching out, and we’re talking with people.” She adds, “We have very close relationships with art buyers and art director and creatives.”

The recent trend in advertising toward branded print and motion experiences has benefitted Nat Geo Creative tremendously. “What’s happening in the advertising industry is that people don’t want to just buy an advertising page in the magazine or a three-minute TV spot,” Mulvihill explains. Instead, they want unique content that doesn’t scream “advertising.” Mulvihill adds, “I think photographers who have spent their lives building passions for what they do, like photojournalists, are uniquely positioned to take advantage of this trend in advertising.”

Alvarez notes, “I think that Nat Geo Creative is in a good place because they have all this storytelling expertise they can bring to a project.” Plus, he says. “The income’s great, the storytelling is interesting … and what I do for the commercial clients I have is very much like what I do for the magazine. I bring a big storytelling set to a problem, but Nat Geo Creative sells all these things—photography, motion, talent—together under one roof.”

article.article_title: Photo Innovation: Mixed Media Exhibitions That Create Powerful Photographic Experiences
article.meta_description: Nick Appelbaum of the exhibition design firm Ralph Appelbaum Associates talks about photo exhibition trends.
article.article_text_abstract: Nick Appelbaum of the exhibition design firm Ralph Appelbaum Associates talks about photo exhibition trends.
article.article_image_caption: The Smithsonian's Arctic Studies Center at the Anchorage Museum in Anchorage, Alaska, is an RAA-designed exhibition where visitors can zoom in on high-resolution photos and see Alaskan Native artifacts in detail.
article.article_text:
For today’s museums and other cultural institutions, luring viewers away from their screens and into exhibition spaces is more challenging than ever. Exhibitions that are interactive are “critical” to engaging modern audiences, according to Nick Appelbaum, a partner at the multinational exhibition design firm Ralph Appelbaum Associates (RAA). “There’s an almost innate expectation, particularly amongst young people, that any environment will feature some sort of tactile, interactive experience.” Appelbaum says his firm’s clients are also considering how to speak to people outside of the museum walls.

RAA has offices in five countries, and the company has completed more than 500 commissions over the course of 35 years for clients that range from the American Museum of Natural History and the William J. Clinton Presidential Library to the Smithsonian and London Transport Museum.

Often in their work, RAA utilizes photography “as a complement to everything else that we can do, and usually as something that we can combine with other mediums to try and create something different and unique for the visitor in a physical space,” Appelbaum says.

“There is increasingly a desire to mix media to create powerful experiences,” he adds. RAA has a media department that produces films, interactive experiences and photography, and RAA also commission new photographic work “quite often,” Appelbaum says. Even in cases where historical photography exists, “museums often want to feel current so there is a desire for new photography to be taken and to be included in exhibitions,” Appelbaum explains. “There’s a desire to connect the past and present.”

For the Smithsonian’s Arctic Studies Center, a cultural center completed in 2010 at the Anchorage Museum in Alaska, RAA used high-resolution digital photography to give viewers an opportunity to interact with Alaskan Native artifacts in a way they wouldn’t be able to if they were simply examining the objects behind glass. Using a touchscreen, visitors, says Appelbaum, can “zoom in and look at the details [of the artifacts] and look at the texture in a way that they could otherwise never do.”

For a project currently in the works, a library for former Russian President Boris Yeltsin, RAA will fill a large wall with an iconic photograph of Yeltsin atop a tank in front of the Russian White House in 1991, during a coup attempt. By combining the photograph with a scenographic installation that recreates what surrounded Yeltsin, RAA aims to “build a feeling of being there on the day,” Appelbaum says.

One photography-related technological tool that audiences respond to, Appelbaum says, is “2.5-D,” an animation technique that makes two-dimensional photographs appear three-dimensional. The technique is particularly useful when working with historical photography. “We’re always experimenting with ways to take historical photography and to try to make it as alive as possible, and I think digital techniques help get us much further than we otherwise can go with zoom effects and just a simple display,” Appelbaum says.

Despite the prominence of interactivity and digital technology in modern exhibitions, Appelbaum laments the number of exhibitions that use “technology for technology’s sake.”

“You can throw a lot of money at technology, but before you do that, it’s probably worth asking yourself why, and it’s probably worth considering whether the learning goals of the museum are being met due to the application of interactivity or technology in the museum.”

Increasingly clients are reaching outside their walls to engage audiences, looking to create exhibitions in public spaces or other trafficked areas. “The idea is that we can learn anywhere,” Appelbaum says. Parks, schools, hospitals and public spaces are examples. “If you take that attitude and apply it to the wider world you can see that the application of what happens in a museum, that social learning experience, is very powerful, and so we find ourselves working in increasingly new environments.”

And it’s often museums and other institutions that are looking to step outside their own walls, be that into a public space or onto the Web, where sites that complement exhibitions have become the norm. Says Appelbaum, “They feel as though by having a bigger role in the communities in which they exist, or even an online presence, they can reach more visitors.”

article.meta_keywords: Google Glass, photo innovation, Richard Koci Hernandez
article.article_text_abstract: Photographer Richard Koci Hernandez talks about why he's impressed with Google Glass, and how he's been using the wearable camera in his work and classroom.
article.article_image_caption: A self-portrait taken with Google Glass by street photographer, writer and educator Richard Koci Hernandez.
article.article_text:
Ask Richard Koci Hernandez what recent innovations in photography impress him and he doesn’t hesitate. “Google Glass,” he says. “It’s the closest you get to the idea of the eye as a camera.” He predicts that “putting cameras and video within our point of view is only going to proliferate,” despite the fears of many critics, because of the creative possibilities and practical applications.

At press time, Google Glass was not available to the masses, but Google made several thousand pairs of the Internet-connected glasses available for purchase (for $1,500) to winners of a contest earlier this year. Entrants were asked to describe how they would use Google Glass. Hernandez, an award-winning journalist-turned-professor, street photographer, blogger, and tireless explorer of new media trends and technology, was among the winners.

Google Glass is eyewear that positions a tiny screen close to the eye, enabling users to search the Web, send and receive e-mail, navigate with GPS, and take photos and video using voice commands. “When I first got them, I thought the photo and video [functions] would be secondary” to the other functions, Hernandez says.

He began wearing his Google Glass everywhere he went—on the street, to meetings, in cafes—and quickly found the Web surfing and e-mailing functions to be limited and disappointing. But the quality of the 5-megapixel camera “was way better than I thought it would be,” he says.

Google Glass has drawn plenty of criticism over fears that users will be walking around in public, taking pictures surreptitiously of strangers for who-knows-what purposes. The potential for privacy invasion seems obvious and unnerving.

Hernandez dismisses the fears as “knee-jerk” reactions that aren’t grounded in actual experience with the product. It’s impossible to take pictures surreptitiously with Google Glass, he argues. You have to give either a voice command to take a picture, or lift your hand to click the shutter. (Hernandez always does it manually.) Google Glass also lights up in camera mode, and it makes an audible sound when the shutter is triggered.

“Google has made it so obvious you’re [photographing], that it’s hard to hide [it],” he says. “I can be more surreptitious with an iPhone than with Google Glass.”

He continues, “Can it be creepy? Yeah. So I have my etiquette.” Walking into a room, he explains, he wears his Google Glass on his forehead “so when I engage them people can see.”

And yet almost nobody has noticed him wearing his Google Glass—or at least, hasn’t let on—in all the months he’s worn them. Hernandez surmises people are conditioned by culture not to notice. “We don’t look [each other] in the eye. We don’t look people in the face. Sunglasses”—an accessory that’s as much for hiding our eyes as for shading them from bright light—“are a mainstay of our culture,” he says.

It may be that people aren’t yet conditioned by uncomfortable experience to notice Google Glass. Whatever the reason, though, it is to the advantage of street photographers. “I’m taking pictures all the time—with no ill intent, just practicing the art of street photography—because people don’t look me in the eye,” Hernandez says.

He sees practical applications beyond street photography, too. Google Glass makes shooting and sharing photographs easier. “They’re right there on my eye. I can see something, instantaneously shoot it and, more quickly than [with a] phone, share it to a network.”

Google Glass is connected to Google Hangouts, where users can broadcast a live video feed. “I could imagine [a person using Google Glass at] a breaking news scene, or a photographer showing people what they’re shooting. For example, I have to teach students how to take evocative portraits. There are a lot of words out there about that, but few instances of photographers in the field, showing you how they work.

“So I could put on Google Glass, hit record and show students from my perspective how I’m working. They could hear and see me interact with the subject,” he says. Although Hernandez has yet to broadcast while he’s teaching, he has posted instructional videos on a website for his classes at University of California, Berkeley, where he is assistant professor of new media.

“My next to-do is showing myself with a mobile phone, [using] Google Glass as a recording device to show what I look for” as a street photographer, he says.

Google Glass may or may not turn out to be the tool of creepy intrusion that many people fear, but Hernandez is far more excited about what he sees as a powerful and revolutionary innovation for photography.

article.article_title: Picture Story: Life Under Austerity in Appalachia
article.meta_description: With an assignment from MSNBC.com to explore how the economy is affecting Kentuckians, Peter van Agtmael had to work around the locals’ mistrust of national media.
article.meta_keywords: Peter van Agtmael, Appalachia, Harlan County, economic downturn photos
article.article_text_abstract: With an assignment from MSNBC.com to explore how the economy is affecting Kentuckians, Peter van Agtmael had to work around the locals’ mistrust of national media.
article.article_image_caption: Kids in Lynch, Kentucky, wait as their parents rehearse a community theater production based on local lore passed down through the generations.
article.article_text:
In Eastern Kentucky, the once-thriving coal industry that provided secure jobs in the region is dying, and unemployment has risen to 18 percent. Government spending cuts on social programs has only added to the local hardship.

Editors at MSNBC.com wanted to see how the changing economic circumstances are affecting the lives of average people, so they sent reporter Suzy Khimm and photographer Peter van Agtmael to find out. Van Agtmael’s contemplative take appeared on MSNBC’s website in mid-October in a 29-image photo essay called “Life Under Austerity.”

MSNBC gave van Agtmael a six-day assignment that he describes as “pretty open.” He spent about half the time trying to photograph the people and places Khimm mentioned in her story. The rest of the time he wandered around in search of images that captured the feeling of the place.

Van Agtmael has been photographing small towns across the U.S. as part of a personal project for the past two years. He never photographed in Eastern Kentucky, but says he was intrigued by the assignment because he had found the area “mysterious and beautiful” on the occasions that he has driven through it. He was also aware of the stereotypes of Appalachia perpetuated by some media, and says, “I wanted to see [the region] for myself.”

MSNBC Director of Photography Amy Pereira was also sensitive to past media coverage in the region, which many locals view as shallow and exploitative. “I didn’t want [our story] to be a cliché of American poverty. I wanted it to have subtlety, nuance and a great deal of humanity,” she says. “Peter has a keen understanding of the subjects he works with. I felt he would give a nuanced impression of the place.”

MSNBC, which has been struggling to shore up its audience, is experimenting with more in-depth coverage of big issues such as the environment, immigration and social justice. The company is re-launching its website, and Pereira says, “We’re approaching photography in the old-school way.” She explains, “You can’t go into a community, spend two days and expect anything with sophistication. It’s not fair to the subjects, and it’s not fair to the photographers.”

Van Agtmael says he approached the story in his usual way: by wandering around to see “what soaks into my bloodstream, what I’m dreaming about and what seems important when I’m brushing my teeth.”

The feeling he got about Harlan, Kentucky, “was this town being slowly, economically strangled because it essentially relied on one industry that is now dying. There are abandoned stores, for sale signs, dollar stores, signs for government assistance—signs of economic hardship, but not outright poverty.”

Van Agtmael captured that feeling with a variety of images, including several quiet photographs shot at dusk of mostly empty streets with run-down storefronts for last-ditch businesses, such as a check-cashing establishment and a real estate broker advertising federally subsidized apartments.

He photographed some of the people he encountered from a middle distance, rather than close up, partly because they were so wary of him. “Every attempt I made to get inside people’s homes fell flat,” he says. “They felt exploited by the mainstream media. It’s also a conservative area, and they were worried about a partisan take by MSNBC. They had no reason to trust me beyond my word. That only goes so far.”

Shooting subjects from a distance, he showed them going about their daily lives in the context of the surroundings beyond their own houses. There’s a palpable sense of economic malaise over which individuals have little control.

In one image, for instance, some residents of Harlan try to sell some household possessions out of the back of their 20-year-old sedan along a state highway. In another image, a man helps his son change into a football uniform in the parking lot behind a school, a scene that might play out anywhere. But here, the run-down school and its unkempt surroundings suggest a community that is barely hanging on. Van Agtmael says one of his favorite images is a picture of two boys—one asleep, the other looking painfully bored—in the bleachers of an old school gymnasium in Lynch, Kentucky. The caption explains they are waiting as their parents rehearse with a community theater for a play based on local stories that have been passed down through the generations. The image can be read as a metaphor for the region’s cultural dissolution and doubtful future.

Van Agtmael’s subjects look like struggling working class people anywhere. He purposely avoided Appalachian stereotypes. They might have been easy to find by driving into the hollows (aka the hollers), he says, but the fortunes of people in the towns and cities are more closely tied to the coal industry. And van Agtmael adds, “I was sensitive to this notion of exploitation.”

He says he passed up a chance to photograph a Pentecostal church service with snake handlers, and instead photographed a more traditional church service to convey a sense of the religious spirit. “I was far more interested personally and visually in the snake wrangling thing. I know that kind of image has become so representative of Appalachia, [but] it’s in fact a small part of [religious life] there. So I thought, what the hell, I’ll err on the side of going to the more conventional church.”

Van Agtmael was unable to gain entry to any of the local mines because of federal safety regulations. So he ended up photographing exhibits at both the Kentucky Coal Mining Museum and the Portal 31 underground coal mine tour in Harlan County, Kentucky. The exhibits are idealized representations of the past that border on the surreal, and convey local pride. But in van Agtmael’s images, there’s a whiff of sadness in the bygone glory.

The project drew criticism when it first appeared as just a photo gallery during the soft launch of MSNBC’s redesigned website in mid-October. (The story written by Khimm was posted two weeks later.) Roger May, a Raleigh, North Carolina-based photographer who photographs and writes about Appalachia, tweeted: “Just more of the same — @pvanagtmael’s disappointing & uninteresting images of #Appalachia.”

In a return tweet, Van Agtmael asked May to be more specific. They ended up talking on the phone, and afterwards May retracted his criticism of van Agtmael’s work. May later tells PDN, “I had a knee-jerk reaction … [the story] called up the ghosts of other fly-by, drop-in journalists” who have come to Appalachia to photograph “poor people living in trailers.

“Peter didn’t do that. I reduced his work. I was frustrated by the fact that [the MSNBC photo gallery] didn’t include a single name of any person he photographed. It grated my nerves that a region and people that have been portrayed so poorly were given no identity, and no voice.”

John Edwin Mason, a professor at the University of Virginia who writes a blog about photography, tweeted, “Editors, either give a photographer enough time to do the story right or hire an equally good photographer who already knows it. #Appalachia.”In a phone interview with PDN, Mason emphasizes the he was not accusing van Agtmael of “dealing in stereotypes.” But the story as Mason first saw it on MSNBC “didn’t give the depth and nuance that I think the story deserves.” He adds, “Editors should have commissioned any one of the half dozen photographers I can name off the top of my head who work in Appalachia and know it deeply and could have done a better job.”

Van Agtmael tells PDN, “I’m not saying [my story] is a decisive representation. It’s mine, and I hope it’s honest and fair.” He adds,  “Do you have to be from a region to photograph it effectively? The history of photography decisively proves that no, you do not.”

Pereira, of MSNBC, says, “I feel like I did give [van Agtmael] a fair amount of time … I think he did [the story] in a way that will give insight to audiences [outside Kentucky]. And I would hope people in the community will look and feel that their story was told accurately.”

article.article_title: Photo Innovation: Sedition Selling Fine-Art Photos for the Screen
article.meta_description: Learn more about a service that sells licenses for digital copies of photographs that are meant to be displayed on screens only.
article.article_text_abstract: Learn more about a service that sells licenses for digital copies of photographs that are meant to be displayed on screens only.
article.article_image_caption: Wim Wender's "Lounge Painting 1" is available to s[edition] members as a digital limited edition for $8, but it can only be displayed, not printed.
article.article_text:
British art star Damien Hirst has sold some of his iconic spot paintings for more than a million dollars. But London-based Sedition sells Hirst’s spot art for just $21. What collectors get for $21 is not a one-of-a-kind painting but a “digital limited edition,” a high-resolution digital file limited to 10,000 copies and capable of being displayed on any electronic screen from a smartphone to a flat-screen TV.

The obvious question digital art that exists only on screens raises is whether file art is really fine art or just a likeness of art, a reproduction or a virtual representation of a physical object. But Sedition Director Rory Blain points out that people once asked the same question about photography. Is it art?

“It’s a very logical extension of an art world tradition,” replies Rory Blain. “It’s the modern-day equivalent of the art world multiple, like photographs and prints.”

Sedition was the brainchild of Rory Blain’s art dealer brother Harry Blain, formerly of Haunch of Venison, now a partner in the art gallery Blain|Southern. Harry Blain first toyed with the idea of marketing affordable screen-based copies of expensive fine art in the early 1990s, but it was not until 2011, when screen resolution and bandwidth had improved enough to enable the online delivery of high-quality digital imagery, that Blain teamed up with Robert L. Norton, then director of Saatchi Online, to launch Sedition.

Initially, Sedition marketed digital representations of existing artworks, but most of the works for sale on its website now were created exclusively for Sedition.   

Rory Blain says that while several online art portals use the Internet to market digital art, usually the output is in physical form, so Sedition has no direct competitors in the marketing of digital images that “turn screens into art.”

Sedition collectors, who range from traditional fine-art collectors to art lovers who cannot afford the original art they flock to see in galleries and museums, are actually buying access to a computer code and the right to stream the encoded digital information on as many screens as they like. The hi-res digital images and videos are not downloaded directly but are stored in collector “vaults” on the Sedition server.

Collectors receive a certificate of authenticity and the digital images are protected by digital watermarks on the Sedition website and by a security code attached to individual pixels, a technology the company is in the process of patenting.

In just two years, Sedition has signed up some 60,000 members, who can buy access to the PNG and MP4 files s[edition] uses. The members can then display the images, but not print them. Prices range from a mere $8 for Wim Wenders’s “Lounge Painting 1,” a photograph of a hotel lobby in Gila Bend, Arizona, to $1,600 for Michael Elmgreen and Ingar Dragset’s video of a day in the life of their “Prada Marfa” installation in Marfa, Texas, made from hundreds of still photographs of the faux Prada boutique in the high desert.

“Generally our collectors gravitate more to moving images than still images,” says Rory Blain.

The only edition that has sold out so far is Ryoji Ikeda’s “A Single Number That Has 124,761,600 Digits,” a video in which numbers flash by in a blur. All 300 sold at $8. Idris Khan’s “After Twombly … One Evening” is a stop-frame animation of photos made as he wrote a poem on a chalkboard and the series is sold in an edition of 1,000 for $29. The artists receive a 50 percent commission on each sale.

As flat-screen televisions become more affordable, Sedition foresees collectors exhibiting their art on multiple screens displayed like sculpture and paintings in their homes. The company also issues public display licenses to enable museums and corporations to display Sedition artworks. Collectors can sell or trade digital works once an edition is sold out, though they must do so through the Sedition website.

“It really is most helpful to just think of it as another form of art,” says Rory Blain. “Anything you can use art for, you can use this for.”

article.article_title: How to Land Photography Assistant Jobs
article.meta_description: Professional photographers share how they hire assistants, and what makes an assistant get rehired.
article.meta_keywords: photography assistant jobs, photo assistant, photography assistant
article.article_text_abstract: Professional photographers share how they hire assistants, and what makes an assistant get rehired.
article.article_image_caption: A photo by Brandon Magnus-Ledesma, a 2013 PDN's All-Star Assistant nominated by photographer Donald Miralle.
article.article_text:
When photographers responded to our call for nominations for PDN’s All-Star Assistants, they sent in their stories of times when their assistants, digital techs or second shooters went the extra mile to make sure a shoot went smoothly—despite bad weather, a broken-down car, the first shooter too sick with the flu to handle all the shots of the bride and groom. They also described the qualities they believe are essential for every assistant to have—and what they look for when considering applicants who want assisting jobs. Though every photographer and studio has different needs, the same talents were mentioned again and again as being essential if an assistant is to succeed and grow on the job.

Getting Noticed
When hiring assistants, where do photographers look for qualified applicants? Most photographers PDN spoke to say they ask other photographers. “I find them from word of mouth or recommendations by colleagues,” says photographer Sheena Leazenby.

When building your network of referrals, it can be helpful to meet and talk to other assistants. Says Matthew Jordan Smith, “I like having a personal recommendation from someone I trust. That recommendation usually comes from another assistant.”

But it’s hard to get referrals when you have little experience, so how do photo assistants get started? Contacting photographers directly can pay off, especially if you can demonstrate that you are familiar with the work that the photographer does.

Donald Miralle says one of his best assistants contacted him after seeing one of his photos in a textbook. Mark Mahaney says he’s hired photographers who e-mailed him. Mike Tittel got a cover letter from a prospective assistant with a link to his personal website, and a note promising to follow up with phone call. “I was impressed by his professionalism,” Tittel recalls, “so we set up a coffee meeting and he has been working with my regularly since.”

Some photographers, like Ted Horowitz, say they check the ASMP list of assistants, especially when they’re looking for local help on a location shoot.

Photo students who want to assist should use their school time wisely. Lou Jones, for example, says he has found assistants through “photo school teacher recommendations.” He has also hired “standouts who start as interns.” Monte Isom hired an assistant who “was one of my first and best interns.” Stephanie Hickerty notes, “I did find my most recent [assistant] from an interview that was required for her class at the Institute of Art. I'm very happy that she chose me to interview!”

The Qualities That Land the Job
So what skills do photographers look for in assistants? That varies according to the needs of the photography business, which may demand different lighting or technical skills, either on location or in the studio. But being an assistant requires long hours and lots of work, so to land a job, you have to demonstrate that you have worked hard and been flexible when facing a challenge.

“Work ethic” and “professionalism” were the two factors mentioned most by photographers describing what they look for when interviewing assistants. “Initiative: Everything else grows from there,” says Anthony Nex. “Dependability and timeliness go without saying,” according to Stephanie Hickerty.   

Many photographers say that the qualities of character and personality are just as important as technical skills. “Photography can be taught to anybody but the ability to put your ego aside and get along with others is something you have or you don't,” says Matthew Jordan Smith. “Anyone can learn the technical material,” Jackie McCool says. “Not everyone can learn how to be diplomatic, discrete, kind, patient and never offended.” Stephanie Hickerty needs someone with an artistic eye and technical skills to serve as second photographer, but notes, “For the most part, camera skills can be taught … which is why they weren't at the top of my list. Being able to put the client at ease immediately and instill a sense of trust is key to making the day flow smoothly.”

“A willingness to learn about all aspects of the business,” impresses TJ Houston. Cheryl Maeder says of her old assistant, “What is most important is that she is willing to learn every day and always wants to learn new skills.”  

The Plane’s Delayed: Who Do You Want to Sit in the Airport With?
When asked the biggest challenge his assistants have to face on the job, John Fulton says, to “sit in a car for eight hours straight with a stranger (me).” Shoots don’t just involve taking pictures, and photographers hire—and re-hire—the assistants who were still tolerable to be around at the end of a 20-hour day.

Among the skills Richard Kelly says he needs in an assistant are, “mechanical skills, a sense of humor, an overwhelming sense of professionalism, great karma especially for parking, the ability to pack well, have long interesting conversations during waits at the airport, a drivers license, communication skills.”

The Qualities That Lead to Success
Photographers want assistants who will represent their business well. For some, that means assistants who have a personal stake in the photos.

Monte Isom, “On every shoot if the assistants/techs are thinking about what they would do if it were their set, they can start to predict what the photographer needs. Also it prepares them on someone else's time and dime for when they are the photographer.”

Says Scott Kelby, “I think you have to be a serious photographer to understand what another serious photographer needs, because being a successful assistant isn't about moving equipment. It's about being able to produce a shoot, spec and troubleshoot the equipment, coordinate with models and generally be a jack of all trades on the set.”  

Mark Mahaney says, “I'm constantly asking my assistants what their opinions are about images I make while I'm making them. I don't always listen to their advice, but it's invaluable for me to have their input or to keep their eye out for something I might be missing while I'm actively shooting and crunched for time.”

article.article_title: Social Study: Yael Ben-Zion's Series on 'Mixed' Marriages
article.meta_description: In a new book and exhibition, the photographer uses intimate images to deliver a nuanced portrait of intermarried couples and their families.
article.meta_keywords: Yael Ben-Zion, Intermarried, mixed marriages
article.article_text_abstract: In a new book and exhibition, the photographer uses intimate images to deliver a nuanced portrait of intermarried couples and their families.
article.article_image_caption: "Family" from Yael Ben-Zion's new book and exhibition, Intermarried. Click on the Photo Gallery link below to see more images.
article.article_text:
Intermarried is Yael Ben-Zion’s new photo book exploring the personal, cultural and political implications of “mixed” marriages. Published by Kehrer Verlag in Europe last fall and available in U.S. bookstores this spring, the book is a combination of photography, expository writing and excerpts of interviews with her subjects. Intermarried succeeds in large part because of the intimacy that Ben-Zion cultivates throughout the work. These couples’ homes, their children and their personal spaces provide a quietly powerful backdrop to their stories. This is domesticity politicized, and Ben-Zion’s careful hand steers around clichés to challenge our assumptions and expectations.

Four years in the making, Intermarried was inspired by an Israeli media campaign decrying the “loss” of Jews to intermarriage. As an Israeli-American woman who married a non-Jewish person, Ben-Zion was offended by the short-lived ad, and it triggered an impulse to seek insights into why people choose partners outside of their “immediate social group.” She started by posting on a message board for parents who live in Washington Heights, her New York City neighborhood, seeking couples who self-defined as “intermarried.” (This month Ben-Zion is exhibiting the work in the community in which it was made, at La Galeria at Boricua College in Washington Heights.)

From the beginning, Ben-Zion knew that she wanted to do more than just take pictures of intermarried couples. She wanted to know their stories—the whys and hows of their lives together. “I would go to these people and we would talk for a long time before I even took out my camera. I didn’t record [audio interviews], I told them that later on I would send them a questionnaire and they could fill out whatever they were comfortable with,” she says.

Despite what she thought was encouraging initial progress, Ben-Zion began to feel that the images she was taking were lacking. More often than not the photograph was of a couple that “either did or did not have the same skin color” seated on a couch. Frustrated, she went back to some of her previous work, trying to ascertain what was missing. Her 2011 monograph titled 5683 MILES AWAY, an allusion to the distance between her current home, New York City, and the city of Tel Aviv, looks at everyday life in Israel. Ben-Zion made that book with almost unlimited access to people she already knew very well, and that connection was evident. In order to make Intermarried, Ben-Zion realized, she would have to collaborate more closely with her subjects.

“I like to work at the space between [candid and posed]. As I used a medium-format camera and lighting equipment, my subjects were aware of my presence. However, we spent enough time together and they were open enough to enable me to capture intimate moments,” Ben-Zion elaborates. “Moreover, even in the more constructed images—images that were conceived in collaboration between us based on an experience they went through—the images themselves were not strictly posed. Although my subjects were ‘acting’ for the camera, it was in reference to something they experienced or that was dear to them, and I think this comes through in the images.”

These intimate settings and attendant conversations form the heart of Intermarried and force us to see its subjects as individuals and families, not “examples.” But the book’s essays, written by Yale University law professor Amy Chua and art critic Maurice Berger, address the broader issue of cross-cultural coupling, and bring an analytical edge to what is, on its face, a very personal work.

Ben-Zion is actually a former student of Chua’s, and was struck by a memorable lecture in which Chua contended that the level of intermarriage was one indicator of social and economic mobility within a country. Given their relationship and Chua’s own experience with mixed marriage—she is Chinese-American and her husband is Jewish—she was a natural fit for the project.

And while Ben-Zion didn’t know Berger personally, she knew and admired his work, which often deals with race and culture.  She approached him with her concept and a slide show of images from the book, and Berger agreed to contribute his writing.

With the essays serving as contextual bookends, Ben-Zion structured the book with a loose narrative arc in mind. The discussion moves from marriage to the couples’ children and their upbringings, to challenges the couples face and then on to solutions or “ways that people deal,” as Ben-Zion puts it. It ends with the author’s own essay, a poignant account of her friendship with a woman named Beatrice Rippy. They met in 2007 when Ben-Zion was a student at the International Center of Photography in New York City, and working on a project about elderly New Yorkers. By then widowed, Rippy had entered into an interracial marriage in the 1950s, when anti-miscegenation laws were commonplace in the United States. When Ben-Zion started working on Intermarried, Rippy agreed to participate. Sadly, she passed away only weeks later, before they were able to work together, but Ben-Zion dedicated the book to her and cites Rippy as “a great source of inspiration.”

That closing essay is another example of Ben-Zion’s ability to take the controversial subject matter and imbue it with humanity and emotional resonance. Instead of a polemic, she gives us a nuanced reflection on interracial and interfaith relationships.

“Most people have some kind of opinion or preconception about this issue and I wanted to try and have the viewer question their preconceptions,” she says. “I wanted to open a dialogue about these issues that are both very personal and very political.”

article.article_title: Personal Work That Lands Assignments: Dustin Cohen’s Made in Brooklyn Project
article.meta_description: Dustin Cohen and his agent explain how the photographer has been using the project to attract advertising assignment work.
article.meta_keywords: Dustin Cohen, Made in Brooklyn videos
article.article_text_abstract: Dustin Cohen and his agent explain how the photographer has been using the project to attract advertising assignment work.
article.article_image_caption: Frank Catalfumo of F&C Shoes was the subject of Dustin Cohen's video "The Shoemaker." Click on the Photo Gallery link below to see more still images from the project and watch the videos at the end of this article.
article.article_text:
In early 2012, photographer Dustin Cohen posted a short video about a Brooklyn, New York-based violinmaker who is known for his exquisite craftsmanship and elite clientele. To Cohen’s surprise, the video went viral after Gizmodo, Gothamist, The Huffington Post and other sites picked it up.

“I just kind of sat there and watched it spread around,” he says. “And Tricia”—that’s Tricia Scott, his rep—“said, ‘Don’t just sit there. You have to harness it and make the most of it.’”

They started making lists of advertising clients who might be interested, and sending e-mails and personal notes. Cohen also rushed to post two follow-up videos—one about a watchmaker, another about a jeweler—and called his project “Made in Brooklyn.”

The project has ended up shifting the balance of his assignments, from mostly editorial portraiture, to a mix of editorial and advertising work for a wide range of clients seeking both still and video productions for the Web and TV. He says the proportion of his income from advertising work is now 40 percent and rising. Budgets for the commercial jobs have ranged from $20,000 to $250,000, according to Scott.

Whole Foods Market was one of the first ad clients to hire him. For one of their publications, they asked Cohen to photograph an urban farmer, a brewing supply shop and other subjects. Macy’s hired him for two projects, one for an internal campaign about diversity, and another about the company’s charity initiatives.

He shot a 60-second spot about a multi-generation family with diabetes, to run during a program on Current TV sponsored by Roche pharmaceuticals.

“That was as sweet as it gets,” Cohen says. “They told me, ‘We want you to do exactly as you do [the videos for] the “Made in Brooklyn” project, with the Roche logo at the end.’ I didn’t have to show any of their products.”

At press time, Cohen was preparing to shoot a 90-second video for Bose about one its products. Bose had called Scott, and told her they wanted Cohen to shoot a video for them in the style of his most recent “Made in Brooklyn” video about a shoemaker. “There was no triple bid. They said, ‘We just want him, and if we can make the budget work, it’s yours,’” Scott says.

Meanwhile, Cohen has another nearly finished branding video for Stella Artois beer, about an engineer who makes one-of-a-kind musical instruments. The documentary-style video, which will be ten to 15 minutes in length, features an instrument that the engineer designed to construct Stella Artois chalices.

Scott says the “Made In Brooklyn” project appeals to clients because it resonates with the current popularity of products that are handmade by artisans. And Cohen’s stories “have a great human element” because he’s genuinely interested in why people do the things they do, Scott explains. “In advertising, it’s all about the story.”

Cohen didn’t start the project to attract advertising work, though. His primary motivation, he says, was his love of documentary work, and his desire to stretch beyond portraiture by shooting more complete stories.

“I pitched ideas to magazines,” he says. But they weren’t biting. “So I created this project for myself.”

It began in late 2011, when American Way magazine hired him to photograph the Brooklyn violinmaker for a profile. “I showed up at his studio, and I was blown away by how amazing it looked. There were wood chips flying everywhere,” Cohen recounts.

After he finished shooting the portraits, he asked American Way about shooting a video. “They let me run with it,” he says.

Cohen went back with an assistant. He shot a video interview using two cameras, and then hung around the violinmaker’s studio to shoot B-roll. He called on an editor friend, Michael Hurley, to help edit the piece.

Cohen posted the video on his own website, then started working on the videos about the watchmaker and the jeweler. Hurley helped with the shooting and editing for both videos, which Cohen completed within a few months of the first video.

Cohen says he keeps “an epic notebook of potential stories.” He finds ideas by searching the Internet, reading local newspapers, and e-mailing and calling friends and acquaintances. “I go meet people, see their spaces and hear their stories,” he says. “It’s just legwork, really.”

He came across his most recent subject, one of the last shoemakers in the Bensonhurst neighborhood of Brooklyn, through an article in the New York Post. Cohen ended up doing a story that was not so much about the craft of making and repairing shoes, but a character study “of a 91-year-old man you could just sit and listen to for hours,” he explains.

He has since finished other videos, but hasn’t posted them. Cohen says he and Scott have stepped back to figure out how the “Made in Brooklyn” project should evolve. Scott says one impetus for re-thinking it is that a number of photographers are now doing similar projects. But more importantly, Scott says, “Dustin has to take his personal work to the next level to get to the next level of clients.”

Cohen is pushing himself to the next level in two ways. First, with each new commercial assignment he gets, he’s boosting the production values of his work by adding elements: more experienced crew, more equipment and lighting, and better locations, for example. “It’s one thing to shoot a violinmaker by myself with the gear I have in my camera bag, and another thing to direct a documentary with a crew,” he says. “I want to do bigger and better projects.”

The second way Cohen is pushing himself is by trying his hand at writing and directing fictional screenplays, with actors. “It’s the next level of directing,” Scott says. The stories “would be more concept-based, so they can translate into the commercial world.”

But Cohen emphasizes it is still not the lure of commercial work that is driving his personal work. It is instead his desire to tell stories, and do it on his own terms. With the personal projects, he says, “You’re the boss. You set the parameters, and execute your own personal vision, and it doesn’t get any better than that.”
